HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Little Changed in a Shortened Session

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Bond prices showed little change yesterday in a short trading session as the blizzard in the Northeast prevented many traders and investors from getting to work.
"Not only do you not have a lot of the traders in, a lot of the customers based in New York are out, too," said James Kenney, head trader at Prudential Securities in New York. 
 The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond remained steady at 6.04 percent. The two-year note's yield was also unchanged at 5.18 percent.
Because of the snowstorm, the Public Securities Association recommended that bond trading close at noon.
And the Treasury delayed its weekly auction of $28 billion of three- and six-month bills until today.
About $9.7 billion in Treasury securities traded through most of the major bond brokers yesterday, according to Govpx Inc., a bond pricing service, down sharply from a daily average of about $69 billion during the last three months.
Municipal bonds were little changed ahead of a spate of new sales expected to take place this week, traders said. Mortgage bonds also showed little movement amid concern that interest rates were poised to fall further and pare the bonds' returns.
The blizzard kept Federal employees in the Washington area home on the first day after President Clinton signed a bill to end a 21-day partial shutdown of the Government.
The President and Congressional Republicans have been at odds over a plan to balance the Federal budget in seven years. Some traders and investors said prospects for a deficit-reduction accord were receding.
"A budget deal is going to be more difficult than some people are currently thinking," said William Westgate, a vice president at HSBC Securities in London. "This is going to be a long, drawn-out fight between two sides who don't want to reach a compromise."
A balanced budget could drive bond prices higher and interest rates lower because the supply of Treasury securities would dwindle as the Government sold less debt.
Companies postponed borrowing yesterday because of the blizzard. Still, borrowers are lining up in what is shaping up as a busy month for corporate bond sales, with $2 billion in debt sales expected this week.
This week's borrowers will join the Procter & Gamble Company, Eli Lilly & Company and other companies that have already taken advantage of low interest rates to sell more than $2.5 billion of bonds so far this year.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, is expected today to sell $500 million in 10-year notes.
Time Warner Inc. will borrow the most this week. The company is expected to raise as much as $750 million in the corporate bond market, according to MCM Corporate Watch, which tracks sales of fixed income and other securities. Time Warner carries a below-investment-grade Ba1 rating by Moody's Investors Service and a BBB- investment-grade rating by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: A Less Harmful Budget

 BODY:
The budget proposal released by the White House over the weekend answers critics who have harshly, though accurately, accused President Clinton of stalling on his promise to deliver a plan that would balance the budget in seven years using Congressional scorekeeping.
Mr. Clinton tried valiantly to protect spending on the poor and education and other public investments. But his plan is littered with time bombs that make its protections partly illusory. There was no way to adopt the Republican budget target and yet preserve the progressive economic agenda that he had used to win the White House. 
 In this latest budget plan, Mr. Clinton would wipe out $60 billion from corporate subsidies. He would also cut taxes by $87 billion, which is less than half the Republicans' target but still $87 billion too high in a plan that aims to reduce the deficit.
Nevertheless, the lower tax cut allowed him to propose trimming Medicare, Medicaid and other programs for the needy by about half of what the Republican-led Congress passed. He preserves food stamps and Medicaid as Federal entitlements. On balance, these trade-offs make a powerful case for preferring Mr. Clinton's plan.
Even so, part of the advantage is illusory. The President would pile up cuts in non-military discretionary spending in the last two years of the plan. By 2002, spending on everything from protecting the environment to patrolling the border might be cut by 30 percent or more.
The plight of discretionary programs is even worse than these numbers indicate. Mr. Clinton says his tax cut -- for families with children and for some educational expenses -- would be temporary unless the economy grows more quickly than Congressional scorekeepers expect. Political reality will probably dictate that the cut, once enacted, will not be withdrawn. If so, Congress would, under existing budget rules, be required to make even deeper cuts in discretionary and entitlement programs after 2002 than the President has so far outlined. Cuts that large would mean that Mr. Clinton would have to abandon any vestige of his original agenda for investing in infrastructure, research, education and job training.
He could have preserved more of these plans by jettisoning tax cuts entirely, but that would be politically hazardous as the G.O.P. waves the promise of even bigger cuts in front of nearly every non-poor voter.
Nor does the Clinton plan take on some powerful constituencies. It does not go after subsidies to wealthy farmers. It sets low Medicare premiums for wealthy retirees. As hard as the White House tried to protect the poor, its plan envisions a budget that would cut foods stamps by hundreds of dollars a year per family and throw many disabled children off cash assistance programs.
Yet each of these flaws is magnified in the Republican plan, even taking into account agreements yesterday to whittle down proposed cuts in Medicare, Medicaid and programs for the poor. They cynically keep the costs of their tax cuts on capital gains and retirement accounts modest during the seven-year life of the budget plan, but allow them to explode soon thereafter, committing Congress to huge cuts in spending even after the seven years have elapsed.
Further, the Republican plan not only cuts off many disabled children from cash assistance, but also reduces cash allowances for most of the children who remain in the program. It cuts off food stamps and other aid to some legal immigrants even after they become citizens. Compared with the Republicans', Mr. Clinton's budget occupies the higher ground; but compared with the needs of the poor and the economy, it comes up very short.

HEADLINE: Facing the Storm

 BODY:
New York disappeared under the Blizzard of '96, only to emerge as a new city. Roadways were as bare as the tundra, and like the tundra they were crisscrossed by hunters who trudged their way up- and downtown in search of their offices, groceries or a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
The underground city, however, was doing business. At times like this New York's subway system, often the subject of more unfavorable comment than Vlad the Impaler, reveals itself as a miracle. Non-New-Yorkers might also find it miraculous that above ground, strangers jumped in to help liberate stuck cars, that restaurants gave out free food to stranded travelers or that bus passengers urged their driver to wait an extra few minutes for a straggling family to make its way to the stop. 
 But city residents know that New Yorkers are almost always subject to these kindly impulses. The problem is getting their attention, and nothing focuses the municipal mind like a couple of feet of newly fallen snow.
These days are an Event, a Milestone -- like the legendary Blizzards of 1888 and 1947, exclamation points in history. Chronic competitors rooted for a record-breaker. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani assured the population that Staten Island and the Bronx had already gone over 1947's record 26.4-inch marker. Could Central Park be far behind?
The novelty of the vehicle-free streets, the cross-country skiers in the parks and the ice floes in the Hudson almost obscured the disruption the event caused. Normal life in the tri-state area came to a dead halt. The blizzard closed schools, shut down all the area airports and brought economic havoc to a city that was for all practical purposes cut off from the outside world.
New York and New Jersey declared states of emergency. Roofs collapsed under the weight of the snow. Emergency vehicles were stranded in drifts, and normal vehicular traffic was banned altogether from New York City. Bus service was suspended, along with much of the suburban train service.
Even the Post Office canceled deliveries, a cause for dismay for all those who have long taken that "neither-rain-nor-snow" slogan literally. Mayor Giuliani, who may have tempted the fates by slashing this year's snow-removal budget, put 1,663 plows on around-the-clock duty.
At times like these the citizenry may be more eager to see a snowplow than a politician. Still, and perhaps for reasons of reassurance, ancient custom dictates that politicians of rank be visibly on the move. While Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey drove a snowplow and helped evacuate a trailer camp, New York's Governor was unhappily trapped in Albany, where, irony of ironies, there was not enough snow to warrant even a personal inspection. But Mayor Giuliani, wearing what appeared to be a new Christmas sweater, roamed the boroughs tirelessly, rallying sanitation workers and setting a tone of efficient concern. New York would take this storm seriously, but not be cowed by it.
Advice abounded. Stay dry. Wear layers. Clear out fire hydrants. Shovel in small scoops, without lifting above your shoulder. Stay off sloped roofs. Keep your hat on outdoors. Refrain from driving snowmobiles on the highway.
Most New Yorkers, wisely, opted to keep smiling and enjoy the show. They knew it was only a matter of time before the miracle of nature became a grimy sea of sidewalk obstruction, and the spirit of shared experience faded into carping about unplowed side streets and unshoveled walks. They reveled for a moment at the cusp of a natural disaster, when its images are still vivid and its costs are yet to be tallied.

HEADLINE: The Legacy of Francois Mitterrand

 BODY:
Francois Mitterrand, who died yesterday at age 79, was, with Charles de Gaulle, one of the two dominant French political leaders of the postwar era. Though Mr. Mitterrand served longer than de Gaulle as President -- longer, in fact, than anyone in the history of France's five republics -- his legacy was more ambiguous.
Mr. Mitterrand strengthened France's alliance with Germany, the core of the European Union. He also improved relations with the United States, ended the Gaullist chill toward Israel and even earned the personal respect of his frequent adversary Margaret Thatcher, a woman he once described as having "the lips of Marilyn Monroe and the eyes of Caligula." 
 It was Mr. Mitterrand who began the long moratorium on French nuclear testing that his successor, Jacques Chirac, recklessly abandoned last year. At home, Mr. Mitterrand abolished the death penalty and added the final touches to France's cherished system of social benefits, another achievement his successor has tried to reverse.
Leading an alliance of Socialists and Communists to victory in 1981, Mr. Mitterrand brought the long-marginalized French left a greater combination of executive and legislative power than it had ever known in modern times. But within two years, Mr. Mitterrand pragmatically sacrificed his left-wing platform to the demands of an increasingly integrated European market.
Market necessity dictated most of the policy changes. But an unwise commitment to a European currency union led to punishingly high interest rates that translated into chronic double-digit unemployment. Mr. Mitterrand's Socialists paid heavily at the polls and twice the Socialist President was forced to share power with right-wing legislative majorities. Last year Mr. Chirac, running on a platform of economic populism, captured the presidency for the right as well.
Mr. Mitterrand was a master political tactician with few immutable principles. Not only his Socialist beliefs were lightly held. Even his record of resistance in World War II was ambiguous. In the early 1940's he worked uncomfortably closely with the Vichy regime and maintained lifelong friendships with some of Vichy's more odious figures.
Throughout his presidential term, Mr. Mitterrand refused to offer France's apologies for Vichy's wartime roundups of Jews, most of whom ended up in Nazi death camps. Extending that overdue apology was one of Mr. Chirac's first and most admirable gestures.
On other issues, however, President Mitterrand's record was more positive, and when he left office he could boast that France's economic foundations were stronger and its alliances firmer.

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Grip

BYLINE: By Timothy A. Canova; Timothy A. Canova, who teaches at the University of Miami School of Law, specializes in banking and finance.

DATELINE: CORAL GABLES, Fla.

 BODY:
The word is that President Clinton may reappoint Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve when his term expires this spring. The chairman's support of the Mexican bailout and his support for increasing the debt limit to avoid government default has helped the White House at crucial moments.
But while Mr. Greenspan may have prevented the financial house of cards from collapsing, his overall handling of monetary policy has harmed the economy. For much of the last year, the weight of indicators has shown both a sluggish economy and negligible inflation of 2.6 percent. But the Fed has reacted with a tardy gradualism. 
 Last summer and again in December, the Fed lowered short-term interest rates by a paltry one-quarter of a percentage point. Each time, Wall Street bulls pushed stock prices higher, then immediately craved another tiny fix. Optimists may hope that a vibrant stock market will lead the economy out of the doldrums, but there is a danger that the market is actually a lagging indicator and that weak earnings could burst the bubble.
Fed economists are aware of this possibility. Some believe that interest rates should not be lowered too much or too quickly for fear of encouraging the bubble to expand even more. But the reverse may be more likely: corporate earnings could fall too far to sustain the current stock prices, unless the Fed lowers interest rates significantly and quickly.
If the economy then takes a dive, we are sure to hear a drumbeat of voices blaming the Federal deficit. Mr. Greenspan, it would seem, is prepared for this scenario. In November 1995 he warned: "If, for some unforeseen reason, the political process fails, and [a balanced budget] agreement is not reached, it would signal that the United States is not capable of putting its fiscal house in order, with serious, adverse consequences for financial markets and economic growth."
The political establishment can be expected to react to any bad economic news with renewed demands for more fiscal austerity since the consensus for a balanced budget wrongly assumes that high deficits are the sole cause of today's high interest rates.
But contrary to that view and Mr. Greenspan's assertions, the nation has been keeping its fiscal house in order, with the deficits declining over the past three years. The 1992 budget deficit of $290 billion was 4.9 percent of the gross domestic product; the 1995 fiscal year deficit of $164 billion is only 2.3 percent.
But this decline did not stop the Fed from raising interest rates six times in 1994. Real interest rates (adjusted for inflation) began to rise dramatically in the early 1980's (from less than 1 percent to about 5 percent on long-term government securities), not because of the deficits but because of the Fed's reliance on high interest rates as the sole anti-inflation policy.
But persistently high real rates have retarded investment and slowed economic growth. As a consequence, governments are now burdened by much larger "passive deficits" as they collect less in tax revenues and spend more on jobless compensation and enormous interest costs on their debts. By increasing debt service costs of the private sector as well as of Federal, state and local governments by hundreds of billions of dollars a year, higher interest rates constitute the most important and most hidden of the so-called unfunded Federal mandates.
With economic storm clouds on the horizon, the Administration may be wary of creating an open rift with the Fed. But without a change, the Administration will remain dependent on the dubious crisis management skills of Mr. Greenspan.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Death for Chinese Children

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Thousands of Chinese children die in orphanages every year from deliberate medical neglect and starvation. This is policy, part of Beijing's technique of controlling the increased number of children abandoned by parents who either could not feed them or feared the regime would cut the rations for the whole family for the crime of having more than one or two children.
This report, detailed by Human Rights Watch, is of course sad. But do we still have the right to mourn? 
 America, people and leadership, has known for decades that every Chinese Communist regime used forced abortion and starvation to control population growth, slave labor as an intricately planned part of its economic program, and torture and prison as fundamental instruments of political power.
The American response, bottom line: Shut up, or the Chinese may forbid us to enrich them with trade that might one day turn a little profit for American businessmen.
So be thankful that the nasty comedy of the Government shutdown, plus the blizzard, so far have saved us from hearing the Administration or top leaders of either party run on mourning the abandoned children.
The U.S. Government and Western society in general have sold for theoretical trade profit the right to mourn the orphans. They didn't get much more for the deal than Chinese political slaps in the American face and military provocations.
The U.S., and its allies, have betrayed not only orphans and women forced to abort but the principles and safety of our democratic society.
So be it. But those Americans who have the right given by consistent protest against Beijing's horrors to mourn for the orphans can serve them best by speaking up again.
The issue is simple. How long will Americans tolerate the wealth they created under freedom to be used to give dictatorship the strength it needs to destroy freedom wherever its writ extends?
This problem confronted America much of this century. More often than not, the decision was to permit American wealth to bolster dictatorships. But their very nature drove them to use their power, reinforced by American trade, to create a military threat that led to war. See Germany, Italy, Japan and Iraq.
In the China trade, profits go mostly to China. It sells the U.S. eight times more than it buys. Since wages are so low in China, and in labor camps nonexistent, this will mean loss of jobs to America.
And, predictably, most of China's profits go to its armed forces and the huge police force that enables the Communists to stay in power.
In memory of the orphans, please note: Their death is more refutation of the myth, spread by Western apologists, that human rights progress will follow economic progress.
Like all dictatorships, Beijing uses increased economic power for increased police power. The more powerful the police state, the better it hides its atrocities behind barbed wire and coerced denials.
After corporate America decided that profits were worth the risk of building up China, President Clinton decided it was worth breaking his own word to submit. He scrapped his executive order pledging to use trade tariffs to persuade the Chinese Communists to ease, however slightly, the repression of their own people and the occupied Tibetans.
This did soil Mr. Clinton's honor, naturally, but it turned out to carry no penalty here on earth. Republican Presidential candidates, except Patrick Buchanan, trot behind the China lobby. And our allies, as great as Germany and small as Israel, are also busy at the Communist trough.
Yet those Americans who care are not powerless. Republican and Democratic politicians who never surrendered faith in freedom or disgust with tyranny can make murdered orphans, forced abortion, religious oppression and slave labor an issue at the Presidential conventions. They can demand tariff penalties for these instruments of Beijing's governance.
Other Americans can make them an issue at stockholders' meetings, in churches and synagogues; remember South Africa. We can boycott Chinese imports and investments in companies that feed at the trough, uncaring of the blood therein.
That can be our flower, for the graves of the orphans.

HEADLINE: Let New Jerseyans Spend to Bolster Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Time Bomb in Governor Whitman's Tax Cut" (Op-Ed, Jan. 3): Neil Upmeyer says the New Jersey economy is weak and concludes that higher taxes and higher levels of government expenditures are needed to correct it. This Keynesian remedy does not work on the state level, and even neo-Keynesian economists doubt if it works on the national level. 
 It makes little sense to cite the weak economic condition of the state economy and the labor market in particular. Why does an unemployment rate that is higher than the national level mean that taxpayers should not be entitled to retain a higher percent of their earnings? If anything, the burdensome tax structure and excessive regulations have contributed to the weak economy.
It is almost always possible to find some value in services proposed for cuts. But that is not the proper economic comparison. Rather, it is more valid to compare the goods and services that consumers may be able to purchase of their own choosing with those that are imposed upon them by bureaucrats who rely on the taxing powers of government to finance their own initiatives and pet programs.
 
PATRICK A. GAUGHAN
Dir., N.Y.-N.J. Economic Research
Center, Fairleigh Dickinson U.
Madison, N.J., Jan. 5, 1996

HEADLINE: New Balloon Technology Stars In a World Race With No Trophy

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
WITH the morning sun gleaming from its aluminized plastic skin, a 150-foot-high balloon piloted by a lone American rose above South Dakota yesterday to begin a race in which three teams will try to be the first balloonists to circle the globe nonstop.
Cheers rose from a crowd as the huge balloon, the Solo Challenger, climbed smoothly away from the Stratobowl, a natural rock formation near Rapid City that offers protection from the wind on three sides. At the controls for the perilous trip, which is expected to last at least two weeks, was Steve Fossett, a 51-year-old commodities broker, yachtsman and champion balloonist. 
 No balloonist has ever succeeded in circling the earth nonstop, and Mr. Fossett is the first to attempt the trip without a crew. Two competing teams of balloonists, one British and one Dutch, expect to launch next week. Both groups believe they can make much better time than Mr. Fossett because they will fly at higher altitudes, where the speed of the jet stream is greater. The speed of the jet stream can be as great as 200 miles an hour, but a balloon riding the wind is subject to no aerodynamic buffeting and the crew feels no sensation of speed except by observing the craft's rapid progress over land or sea.
The Solo Challenger, with its unpressurized pilot capsule, quickly ascended more than 6,000 feet and entered a wind system expected to carry it over Nebraska, Iowa, Missouri, Illinois, Kentucky and South Carolina, reaching the Atlantic coast tomorrow, said a spokesman, Timothy E. Kemper, assistant vice president of Loyola University of Chicago. Meteorologists forecast that after crossing the Atlantic Ocean Mr. Fossett would make landfall over Portugal and subsequently fly across Spain, the Mediterranean and North Africa.
"New York's blizzard won't affect Steve at all," Mr. Kemper said. "He'll be flying at between 16,000 and 18,000 feet by the time he reaches the coast, and even if he should drift toward the storm he can easily get above it."
Because the Solo Challenger has a metalized skin, it will be visible from the ground for most of its trip.
The informal race, which has neither an organizer nor a prize, pits experienced long-distance balloonists and some new technical innovations against each other in a grueling and dangerous ordeal.
Each of the three balloons is setting out from a different country, Morocco, the Netherlands and the United States. Whoever (if anyone) first circumnavigates the globe will win the honor of an entry in the record books for achieving the last great goal of lighter-than-air flight.
The race will take place amid persistent fears that the armed forces of several nations over which the balloons may drift may open fire on the aeronauts, or at least force them down. Last September an international hydrogen-balloon race that started in Switzerland ended when two American balloonists were shot down and killed by a Belarus military helicopter.
Although all the crews in the forthcoming race have sought assurances of safe passage from the 100 or so countries over which they may fly, several governments have not responded. A particular concern had been Iraq, but Erin Porter, speaking for the British team, said yesterday that the Iraqi Government had granted permission to the balloonists to fly over the country. However, balloonists have also expressed concern about Afghanistan, Libya and North Korea, among other countries.
"The real risk for all of us is not equipment failure," Mr. Fossett said shortly before his departure. "It is the military risk. Getting clearance from government leaders -- even prime ministers -- is one thing. Getting the word down to military officers commanding border posts or fighters is quite another."
In some respects, Mr. Fossett's balloon is the most primitive of the three in the race. Accommodating only one person, its tiny capsule is too low for Mr. Fossett to stand fully. Because the capsule is not pressurized, he will have to breathe oxygen from a mask throughout most of the two-week trip, much of which will be at an altitude of about 20,000 feet. He will subsist on military field rations and 15 gallons of water. While some elaborately equipped balloons have plumbing and pressurized toilets, Mr. Fossett has only a bucket, which will be emptied through a hatch.
Mr. Fossett takes pride in having launched his project on a shoestring. The cost of his balloon and related expenses, he said yesterday, is $300,000, all paid by Mr. Fossett himself. The competing British and Dutch teams spent $5 million to $7 million, Mr. Fossett estimated, both financed by advertising sponsors. Neither the British nor the Dutch team has disclosed the cost of its balloon.
But the Solo Challenger, built by the British designer Don Cameron, has some innovations that may help it. Among its instruments is a newly devised automatic pilot that senses altitude, and fires up the propane burners to keep the balloon from descending when temperatures drop at night. This will permit Mr. Fossett to sleep for short periods.
The Solo Challenger is also equipped with a reflective Mylar tent extending over the top of the balloon. The tent is held up by a small helium balloon instead of a tent pole, and a solar-powered fan circulates cool air between the tent and the top of the balloon to prevent overheating during daylight hours.
Shortly after Mr. Fossett's launching yesterday his competitors sent him telegrams of congratulation.
The British balloon, called the Virgin Global Challenger, is to be flown by Richard Branson, chairman of Virgin Atlantic Airways; Per Lindstrand, chairman of Lindstrand Balloons Ltd. of Oswestry, England, and an Irish balloonist, Rory McCarthy. Mr. Branson and Mr. Lindstrand, who have set several ballooning records, were the first pilots of hot-air balloons to cross both the Atlantic Ocean, in 1987, and the Pacific, in 1991.
Mr. Lindstrand said that because of unfavorable weather patterns over England he and his colleagues had decided to launch their Virgin Global Challenger from a military airfield at Marrakech, Morocco.
To move the big crew capsule, balloon and accessories, the British group chartered a Beluga transport plane -- a modified Airbus 300 similar to the Pregnant Guppy aircraft used by NASA to transport large rocket components. The flight to Morocco is scheduled for Friday, and Mr. Lindstrand said the balloon launching would probably take place a day or so later.
Mr. Branson, chairman of the multifaceted Virgin Group, which includes Virgin Atlantic Airways, believes that his competitor, Mr. Fossett, faces grave risks.
"Because his capsule is not pressurized," Mr. Branson said in an interview, "Steve will have to stay at around 20,000 feet, which is usually well below the core of the jet stream. That could slow him down a lot. We will be at 30,000 to 35,000 feet, where our chances of riding the high-speed jet stream are much better.
"Steve is incredibly brave, and if anyone should beat us, I'd rather it was he."
The Dutch team, led by Henk Brink, recently tested the inflation of its Unicef Flyer balloon at Cape Kennedy in NASA's huge Vehicle Assembly Building, where space shuttles are prepared for flight. Mr. Brink, who intends to launch his balloon from Nijmegen, the Netherlands, is a helicopter instructor and veteran balloonist. In 1986, he, his wife, Evelien, and William Hageman, a Dutch fighter pilot, became the first European balloonists to cross the Atlantic; so precise was their navigation that they landed within a few miles of Mr. Brink's home in the Netherlands.
Although balloons must travel in the same direction as the wind that carries them along, a pilot can navigate to some extent by changing altitude to seek wind headed in the desired direction. Even a small change in altitude can result in a large change in direction.
The Unicef Flyer flight suffered a setback on Dec. 26 when its third crew member, Wouter Bakker, resigned from the flight crew "for personal reasons." Days before the expected launching this week, Mr. Brink said in an interview that he had advertised for a replacement, stipulating that the third crew member should be an airline captain. "We're down to three candidates," Mr. Brink said on Friday, "and all of them are completely familiar with our navigation and communication equipment. For the launch and landing, I will do the piloting."
All three teams are flying Rozier balloons -- a type that has achieved many long-distance records in recent years. A modern Rozier is kept aloft by helium gas, but to add extra lift, the balloon is compartmentalized and the lower part can be filled with hot air from a gas burner. This enables the balloon to maintain altitude at night, when cold air and the lack of sunlight cools the helium and lessens its lifting power.
Since the first manned balloon flight in 1783 by Jean Francois Pilatre de Rozier and the Marquis Francois Laurent d'Arlandes in a Montgolfier hot-air balloon, many balloonists have attempted round-the-world flights, but all have failed, and some have died trying. Five unsuccessful attempts were made by a single team led by Larry Newman of Scottsdale, Ariz., in his Earthwinds balloon before Mr. Newman abandoned his efforts one year ago.
The Rozier balloon is named after its inventor, who was forced to use inflammable hydrogen in his 18th-century version, since a century was to pass before the discovery of nonflammable helium. Rozier was killed in 1785 while trying to cross the English Channel; his hydrogen-and-hot-air hybrid balloon caught fire and crashed.
From that time until 1960, balloonists relied almost exclusively on hydrogen or helium for lift, since hot-air burners were regarded as too dangerous.

HEADLINE: Trump Moves to Put Taj Mahal in His Company

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
In a sign that his financial recovery is gathering speed, Donald J. Trump moved yesterday to fold his Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City into his publicly traded casino company.
Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts, his publicly traded company, is doing well enough that Mr. Trump expects to attract new investors. He plans to raise $59 million in equity above the costs of transferring ownership of the Taj. 
 Trump Hotels is offering to buy 1.35 million class A shares of the Taj Mahal Holding Corporation for $30 in cash or in Trump Hotels stock. That values those shares, which equal half of the Taj equity, at $40.5 million.
For his own half, Mr. Trump is to receive additional stock in Trump Hotels. Alan C. Marcus, a Trump spokesman, said that "to my knowledge" Mr. Trump would not get any cash out of the deal. Trump Hotels expects to issue $140 million in new stock to make the offer to shareholders and to raise cash. In addition, to replace the existing Taj bonds, $750 million of new debt will be sold by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Mr. Marcus said. That would value the Taj at about $890 million.
Because Mr. Trump owns about 40 percent of Trump Hotels, and half of the Taj, the deal announced yesterday could slightly increase his stake in the publicly traded company. Mr. Marcus said he did not believe Mr. Trump's share would exceed 44 percent when the deal was completed, which he said should be in April.
Trump Hotels closed yesterday unchanged at $21.75. The 10 million publicly traded shares have risen 55 percent since they came to market last June at $14.
The deal announced yesterday is conditional on the stock's remaining at $20 or higher.
In many ways Mr. Trump's turnaround has mirrored the fortunes of the Taj, which opened in April 1990. The Taj cost more than $1 billion to build, but it failed to generate enough cash to make interest payments on its original $675 million of junk bond debt issued by Merrill Lynch. Mr. Trump's stake in the Taj was halved in his negotiations with bondholders and other creditors whom he could not repay as promised.
The Taj was a crucial factor in Mr. Trump's 1990 financial crisis, during which one of his lawyers, Thomas Cerabino, testified that Mr. Trump was just one day away from uncontrolled bankruptcy unless casino regulators approved a deal with creditors. In 1991 Mr. Trump prepared a document showing that he had $44.7 million in personal bills coming due and only $1.6 million in projected income.
Mr. Trump avoided financial collapse through a series of deals he and Stephen Bollenbach, then his finance chief, negotiated with creditors who were owed more than $3 billion. Last fall, Mr. Trump, in a speech, claimed he owed $8.8 billion.
The deals with creditors won approval from the New Jersey Casino Control Commission even though it found that he did not meet the requirement in state law that he prove he was financially stable. The commission held that since creditors were negotiating with Mr. Trump he might eventually regain financial stability.
Since 1990 Mr. Trump has been forced to relinquish most of his Manhattan properties, including the Plaza Hotel. But by focusing on his three Atlantic City casinos he has managed to slowly rebuild his financial position.
Mr. Trump also hired Dennis Gomes, a respected casino executive, to run the Taj. But last fall Mr. Trump and Mr. Gomes came to a parting of the ways.
Last year, the Taj won $506.1 million from players, up 9.7 percent from 1994's winnings of $461.5 million, or just about the same percentage increase as all 12 Atlantic City casinos.
But in December, the amount the Taj won from players declined 8.9 percent, to $38.9 million compared with a year ago, largely because the casino lacked the high-rollers that were brought in a year earlier by Mr. Gomes and his team.
Last month builders in Florida launched the Trump Princess, a 290-foot riverboat that is to open to gamblers near Gary, Ind., in April. The Indiana operation, owned by Trump Hotels, expects to draw gamblers from nearby Chicago.
 The article omitted the current findings of New Jersey casino regulators regarding Mr. Trump. They have found that he is now financially stable.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 13, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in some editions of Business Day on Tuesday about Donald J. Trump's latest casino plans misidentified the period in which, Mr. Trump asserted, he owed $8.8 billion. It was 1991; the assertion was made last fall.
The article also misstated Mr. Trump's ownership interest in his Manhattan properties. Mr. Trump retains control of some his Manhattan properties, retains a minority interest without control in others and has invested in additional properties.

HEADLINE: Francois Mitterrand Dies at 79; Champion of a Unified Europe

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Francois Mitterrand, who revived France's Socialist Party into a modern political force and whose election as President ended decades of Gaullist rule, died this morning in his official residence here of prostate cancer. He was 79.
"It is a great figure who has left us, and I salute him with emotion and with respect," said President Jacques Chirac, a conservative Gaullist and longtime political adversary of Mr. Mitterrand, who succeeded him last May. 
 Mr. Mitterrand will be buried after a private funeral Thursday morning in Jarnac, the southwestern French village where he was born. A public Mass will be celebrated for him at the same time at Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris. Friends said Mr. Mitterrand did not want a state funeral, but Mr. Chirac declared Thursday a day of national mourning and ordered flags to be flown at half-staff.
As President, Mr. Mitterrand embraced the cause of European unity as his intended legacy. He evidently sought in this crusade propitiation for the political sins of his youth. For most of his political career, Mr. Mitterrand kept hidden his service in the wartime collaborationist rule of Marshal Philippe Petain in Vichy, emphasizing instead his work with the Resistance, which he joined only at the end of 1943.
It was only in the twilight of his life, after one of his most notorious former associates -- a Vichy police officer -- was accused of deporting thousands of French Jews to German camps, that Mr. Mitterrand allowed a biographer to disclose the details of his own time as a Vichy bureaucrat.
He dedicated his 14-year presidency, the longest since the Fifth Republic was established in 1958, to building a more united Europe on the foundation of close Franco-German relations.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl, his closest ally, led the first of many tributes by European leaders today. "Europe has lost a great statesman in Francois Mitterrand," he said. "I am mourning a good friend."
Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, now Lady Thatcher, said that while their political views were very different, she liked and respected Mr. Mitterrand. "Over his many years as President, and by his bearing and his culture, he seemed to symbolize for the rest of the world something of the essential France," she said.
In the United States, former President George Bush said he would remember Mr. Mitterrand "for his love of France, his pride, his extraordinary sweep of history and the fact that he put value as we did on the strength of the relationship" between France and the United States.
Though weakened by his illness, Mr. Mitterrand had spent the Christmas holidays in Aswan, in southern Egypt, with his wife, Danielle, and the former President's daughter from outside the marriage, Mazarine Pingeot.
They, the Mitterrands' two sons, Mr. Mitterrand's brother Robert and other relatives were with him when he died at 8:30 A.M. today in his official apartment near the Ecole Militaire on the Left Bank, according to his doctor, Jean-Pierre Tarot.
Mr. Mitterrand's election to the first of two terms in 1981 crowned his singlehanded revival of the French Socialist Party, which he had headed for more than a decade.
The first Socialist to lead his country since Leon Blum in the 1930's, Mr. Mitterrand was elected President on his third try, having lost to De Gaulle in 1965 and Valery Giscard d'Estaing in 1974, both by narrow margins.
In 1981, he solidly defeated Mr. Giscard d'Estaing, partly through support in the runoff of the French Communist Party, whose opposition to Mr. Mitterrand in the first round of the election led to their worst showing at the polls in 45 years.
Mr. Mitterrand's election represented the biggest shift in French politics since the end of World War II. Mr. Mitterrand was the first non-Gaullist to occupy Elysee Palace in the brief history of France's Fifth Republic, and tens of thousands of Parisians celebrated his victory far into the night, marching along the Boulevard Beaumarchais singing the "Marseillaise" and holding a rally at the Bastille.
But if Mr. Mitterrand's election elated his supporters, it produced apprehension in Washington, London and Bonn, where fears arose that the new Socialist President would allow the Communists too strong a voice in a leftist French coalition. But Mr. Mitterrand managed to marginalize the Communist influence and the party returned to the opposition in 1984 and were never again the force they once were.
In his first months in office, Mr. Mitterrand and the new National Assembly, in which the Socialists and leftist parties had a majority, nationalized banks and major industries, raised the French minimum wage, and increased government spending.
But these efforts failed to halt unemployment and rising inflation and French voters began to have second thoughts about the Socialist's policies. When control of the National Assembly was returned to the rightist parties in 1986, Mr. Mitterrand tried to work with a Prime Minister from the opposition, Mr. Chirac. This attempt at "cohabitation," as Mr. Mitterrand called it, ended as enough of a success that Mr. Mitterrand was re-elected President two years later.
Pragmatic centrism rather than doctrinaire socialism characterized much of Mr. Mitterrand's 14-year tenure.
He considered among his greatest accomplishments the abolition of the death penalty in the first year of his presidency and a policy of steady decentralization, which gradually returned authority to the regions, which had been ruled tightly from Paris since before the French Revolution.
Mr. Mitterrand's presidency was also marked by grand public works that changed the face of Paris, including a gigantic square-edged modern arch at the city's western portals, a modern opera house at the Bastille, and a vast new National Library built on the eastern side at the end of his second term.
But of all of his legacies to the city, he was proudest of the revitalization of the Museum of the Louvre, a project capped by the construction of a new entrance under a frame-and-glass pyramid designed by I. M. Pei and placed in the palace's western courtyard.
 
Political Smorgasbord
Disciple of Voltaire In a United Europe
Mr. Mitterrand was a complex figure who had been a conservative lawyer from the Cognac region of western France.
A disciple of traditional French literature and thought, Mr. Mitterrand possessed a skill with words. "I observe -- and I write," he said in one of his dozen books. "I like the written word. Language, philology, grammar. I believe that real literature is born from the exact correspondence of word and thing."
Mr. Mitterrand said his greatest intellectual hero was Voltaire, the essence of French wit, intelligence and republican spirit. For him France's greatest villain was Charles de Talleyrand, who directed French foreign policy for kings, revolutionaries, and Napoleon Bonaparte alike. "He sold out France -- to everybody," was Mr. Mitterrand's withering judgment.
Mr. Mitterrand said he believed that close cooperation between France and Germany was the keystone of European unity, and the Socialist French leader established close ties with Helmut Kohl after he became Chancellor of West Germany in 1982.
Their relationship came under strain with the collapse of the Berlin Wall in late 1989 when Mr. Kohl pressed ahead, too vigorously for Mr. Mitterrand's taste, toward Bonn's goal of reunification in 1990. Keeping Germany committed to a more closely integrated Europe, a goal that coincided with Mr. Kohl's vision, became the centerpiece of Mr. Mitterrand's strategy to preserve French influence despite Germany's greater economic strength.
After German reunification, Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl were the two principal architects of the treaty signed in the Dutch city of Maastricht in late 1991 that created the European Union out of the European Community, itself an expansion of the old Common Market. The tie between the two leaders remained unbroken, and they remained close friends.
Mr. Mitterrand's efforts to restore France's stature in world affairs reflected the fact that the French had never fully adjusted to the breakup of the French empire that followed World War II.
Echoing De Gaulle, Mr. Mitterrand insisted that France was still a great power, with a vast sphere of influence in its former colonial domains in Africa and other Francophone countries around the world. He supported the independent nuclear deterrent De Gaulle established, carrying out even more atomic weapons tests -- 86 -- than the General had permitted.
Also like De Gaulle, Mr. Mitterrand had no fear of telling off the United States when he thought it was wrong. In this he was often encouraged by his wife, the former Danielle Gouze, whom he married in 1944 and who was active in political causes of her own.
One of Mrs. Mitterrand's interests was Cuba, which she visited often and whose leader, Fidel Castro, she befriended. She persuaded her husband to invite Mr. Castro to Paris for a visit in early 1995, an occasion Mr. Mitterrand used to describe the continuing American embargo of Cuba as "stupid."
One of the high points of French-American cooperation in the Mitterrand era came in 1991 when France sent troops to join the American-led coalition that drove Iraq out of Kuwait during the Persian Gulf war.
France also sent thousands of troops to serve with the United Nations force in the Balkans and Mr. Mitterrand himself made a dramatic and daring visit to Sarajevo in June 1992 that opened the way for an international airlift to the Bosnian capital.
 
Early Years
From Vichy To the Resistance
Francois Maurice Marie Mitterrand was born on Oct. 26, 1916, in the town of Jarnac, near Cognac, the brandy-distilling center, one of eight children of Joseph Mitterrand and Yvonne Lorrain. His father was an employee of the Paris-Orleans railroad company who later went on to become a businessman and an executive of Marcel Dassault's group of aviation companies, a mainstay of the French defense industry.
Strongly influenced by his Roman Catholic upbringing, Mr. Mitterrand attended the College Saint-Paul in Angouleme, a religious school not far from his home in Jarnac, before moving to Paris to study law and political science.
Much of his political activity between the time he arrived in Paris as a student in 1934 and the time he emerged as a member of the Resistance to Nazi occupation in 1943 were until recently shrouded in mystery.
But later in life, as if wanting to set the record straight before his death, he collaborated with a writer named Pierre Pean on "A French Youth: Francois Mitterrand 1934-1947."
The book, published in 1994, was a revelation. The young Mr. Mitterrand, it turned out, had not been a socialist dreamer but an ultraconservative French nationalist who joined a paramilitary group, the League of National Volunteers.
After the League of National Volunteers was banned by the government authorities, the young Mr. Mitterrand flirted with other ultranationalist paramilitary groups, Mr. Pean wrote, but did not join them.
Sent to the front as an army sergeant after the war broke out in 1939, Mr. Mitterrand was wounded by a shell explosion in June 1940 and taken to a prison camp near the city of Kassel, Germany, from which he escaped at the end of 1941.
With France under Nazi occupation, Mr. Mitterrand initially sought to help the collaborationist Government of Marshal Petain in Vichy. He worked initially as a minor official of its commissariat for repatriated prisoners of war.
Mr. Pean wrote that he found no evidence that Mr. Mitterrand had had anything to do with the anti-Semitic measures taken by the Vichy government, and Mr. Mitterrand told the author, "I didn't think about the anti-Semitism" when he was employed by Vichy.
Toward the end of his life, Mr. Mitterrand told Elie Wiesel, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and a Holocaust survivor, in a book the two of them published in April of 1995, "Memoirs in Two Voices," that seeing French Jews forced to wear a yellow star was one of the things that turned him against the Vichy Government.
After the war, he became friendly with the former Secretary General of the Vichy police, Rene Bousquet, who was responsible for the deportation of thousands of French Jews to Germany's death camps. Mr. Bousquet was charged with treason but acquitted in 1949. Mr. Mitterrand told Mr. Wiesel that he met Mr. Bousquet then and continued to see him until 1986, when he again came under investigation for committing war crimes.
Mr. Bousquet was charged anew in 1991 for ordering the deportation of more than 2,000 French Jews in 1942. He was assassinated by Christian Didier, a writer whom the police described as "deranged," in June 1993, before he came to trial.
 
Changing Sides
A Political Game Of Musical Chairs
It was not until after receiving "La Francisque," Vichy's highest civilian medal, for his work with the former prisoners of war, that Mr. Mitterrand became disabused, in 1943, of the notion that a collaborationist government could preserve French independence.
He switched his loyalties and offered his services to the anti-Nazi Resistance movement, journeying to London and then to Algiers in December 1943 for a meeting with General De Gaulle, who asked him to forge a single former prisoners' organization from those of the Resistance, the Communists and the one he had run for Vichy.
After the liberation of Paris in August 1944, he served as secretary general of the Organization of Prisoners of War, War Victims and Refugees in De Gaulle's first postwar provisional government. He then established a newspaper and began a political career that would not be tied to the fortunes of the General.
"After the war, a man of my age didn't know where to go," he said later. "I did not feel like a man of the right, because I disagreed with certain points, especially on social justice. I was tempted by socialism, but not by the parties that represented it."
He won election to the new National Assembly in 1946 as a member of a center-left party from the Nievre constituency, a largely hilly department in central France. He held this Assembly seat until 1958, when De Gaulle formed the Fifth Republic.
It was a time when governments rose and fell frequently, and Mr. Mitterrand maneuvered into a variety of cabinet posts under a succession of prime ministers. In 1954 and 1955, he held the key post of Minister of the Interior in the Cabinet of Pierre Mendes-France, and in 1956 and 1957, he held the Justice portfolio under Guy Mollet.
After the foundation of the Fifth Republic, Mr. Mitterrand formed a center-left opposition to De Gaulle and he was soon recognized as the principal political threat to Gaullism. Mr. Mitterrand ran unsuccessfully against De Gaulle in 1965 as the candidate of the left, uniting the socialists and the Communists. By winning 32 percent of the vote on the first round, Mr. Mitterrand forced De Gaulle into a runoff, which De Gaulle won narrowly.
But it was not until 1971 that Mr. Mitterrand took over as leader of the Socialist Party, which had won barely 5 percent of the vote in the previous elections. He reorganized the party and forged tactical alliances with the Communists to increase its appeal to French voters.
He ran for President again in 1974 and lost by a narrow margin to Mr. Giscard d'Estaing. But seven years later, in a major upset, he defeated him with 51.76 percent of the vote.
 
At Elysee
Fear and Trembling By the Bourgeoisie
Mr. Mitterrand was elected to his first term by voters who had warmed to his words about solidarity and human generosity and to the socialist agenda, including economic growth, the creation of jobs, and the redistribution of wealth. His social policies ranged from reducing the price of false teeth to providing greater protection for tenants.
But as President, he seemed initially to be more dogmatic. His Socialist-Communist coalition set about nationalizing banks and big industries and frightening France's moneyed classes so badly that many of them sold their luxury apartments in Paris and sought refuge abroad for families and fortunes.
But the measures failed to achieve economic gains and they weakened the franc. Many wage earners saw their purchasing power decline. Unemployment rose. Before long, public opinion polls were indicating that Mr. Mitterrand's policies, including his austerity measures, had become highly unpopular.
Four decades in the hurly-burly of French politics had taught Mr. Mitterrand flexibility and brought him a reputation as a pragmatist. After the economy deteriorated, he changed policies.
By 1984, the French Communist Party broke with Mr. Mitterrand, and in early 1986, the Socialists lost control of the National Assembly. Mr. Chirac, the head of the neo-Gaullist Rally for the Republic, became Prime Minister.
For the remainder of Mr. Mitterrand's first term as President, he shared power uneasily with Mr. Chirac, who retained the Prime Minister's post until 1988, when he unsuccessfully challenged Mr. Mitterrand for the presidency. The dual arrangement -- known as "cohabitation" -- added to the blurring of distinctions between the left and the right in French politics.
By the end of his first term, Mr. Mitterrand and the Socialist Party had substantially softened their economic views. They were no longer pledged to nationalizing major industries. In other economic spheres, their economic doctrine contained only small differences from the free-market liberalism of Mr. Chirac.
During the re-election campaign, it was Mr. Mitterrand who presented himself successfully as the soul of caution and legitimacy. By the time he was re-elected President, his popularity had rebounded, and his personal following was far larger than that of his party.
Despite that success, Mr. Mitterrand was dogged by many other problems. They included the growth of the far-right in French politics and a considerable degree of disorientation, within the French populace, that stemmed from the end of the cold war.
In March 1993, the Socialists were trounced in parliamentary elections by a conservative coalition, and from then until the end of his second term in May 1995, Mr. Mitterrand was again forced to co-habit with an opposition Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur.
In September 1992, Mr. Mitterrand had undergone surgery for prostate cancer and seemed to recover well. But after a second operation in July 1994, followed by chemotherapy, he began to look pale and drawn.
To the end, Mr. Mitterrand maintained his habit of speaking in long sentences peppered with references reflecting his traditional education in Latin and Greek.
For all his erudition, Mr. Mitterrand's personal style was simple. After taking office as President, and thereby becoming master of Elysee Palace on the Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honore, he continued to live relatively modestly in his home on the Rue de Bievre on the Left Bank.
He is survived by his wife; their sons, Jean-Christophe, a consultant, and Gilbert, a law professor and socialist politician in Aquitaine, and a daughter from outside the marriage, Mazarine Pingeot, a student at the Ecole Normale Superieure. He is also survived by two brothers and four sisters.

HEADLINE: Ford Says More Buyers Behind On Automobile Loan Payments

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The number of Americans who are behind on their car payments is rising, a senior executive at the Ford Motor Company said tonight.
Edsel B. Ford 2d, the president and chief operating officer of the Ford Motor Credit Company, said that the car finance unit had recently noticed a 10 percent increase in the number of its delinquent accounts, which include car loans and leases. The finance company declares a debt to be delinquent if a payment is 30 or more days overdue. 
 Mr. Ford minimized the implications of the rising delinquencies for the Ford Motor Company. "We ought to worry about it, because it's a concern, but we ought not to go into a panic about it," he said.
Many banks and consumer loan companies have experienced higher levels of delinquencies in recent months. Mr. Ford, a great grandson of Henry Ford, said that about half the increase at his company reflected current economic conditions, notably the high level of consumer indebtedness, and half reflected his company's recent move to lend more money to customers with riskier credit histories.
Mr. Ford declined to give precise figures on delinquencies at Ford but said that, in general, the company seldom has more than one-half of 1 percent of its accounts that are 90 or more days overdue. He spoke to reporters after giving a speech tonight at the Automotive News World Congress here, a trade conference.
In other comments, Mr. Ford dismissed recent reports that his family, the largest shareholder in Ford, was unhappy with its chairman, Alexander Trotman, over the company's stagnant stock price and high product-development costs.
Some auto industry analysts and executives at other car companies have expressed worries recently that cars are becoming too expensive for too many American families to afford. Last week, Mr. Trotman dismissed the question of affordability, but Mr. Ford said tonight that "from any point of view, the market has become very price-sensitive."
And today, Ross Roberts, a Ford vice president and general manager of the Ford division, said the company was planning to introduce a new round of price incentives to spur sales. He declined to say whether the incentives would be offered to buyers of the new Taurus and Sable models, which have been selling slower than expected.

HEADLINE: Second Thoughts on India;
Enron Project on Track, but Policy Doubts Remain

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Jan. 8

 BODY:
When the Government of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao began dismantling India's socialist economic system and replacing it with free-market policies in 1991, the country's image in corporate board rooms around the world underwent a striking transformation.
As recently as last summer, corporate leaders like Michael D. Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company, were adding their voices to the chorus of Western executives who have described a new India -- with at least 130 million middle-class consumers among its 930 million people -- as the world's most promising market. 
 But recent events have caused a sobering reassessment.
"India seems to have a knack for shooting itself in the foot," said Claude Smadja, an economist who follows the country for the World Economic Forum, based in Geneva. At a conference last month in New Delhi, Mr. Smadja joined other participants in urging the Rao Government to push the changes forward after a year in which little new was done to overhaul an economy still poised uneasily between a socialist past and a free-enterprise future.
"It's time to stop talking about 'India's huge potential' and to start realizing it," Mr. Smadja said.
On Monday, India went part of the way toward meeting concerns about the economic changes when the state government of Maharashtra agreed to revive the largest single foreign investment ever made here, a power plant south of Bombay that is to be built by an American consortium led by the Enron Corporation of Houston. The cancellation of the project in August, after Enron and its partners had spent $300 million, sent warning signals around the world about the uncertainties of doing business here.
But to many who worry about India's economic policies, getting the Enron project back on track was only a start. While the country has avoided a protracted legal battle by Enron to recover its losses from Maharashtra, the lessons that seem likely from the affair will hardly be positive.
As the cost of getting the cancellation reversed, for example, Enron and its partners in the Dabhol Power Company, the Indian subsidiary that is to build the plant, were forced to reconfigure the project to cut $300 million from the original price tag of $2.8 billion. Some fear that the step could set a precedent for other state governments that want signed contracts revised.
Also, the Enron controversy is only one issue dogging India's economy. While the revival of the power plant was being negotiated in Bombay, Finance Minister Manmohan P. Singh, who has been the chief architect of the free-market changes, conceded that the Government had run out of steam in its eagerness to make India competitive with its fast-developing Asian neighbors. Nor can Mr. Singh, or anyone else, say with any confidence when the process of change will start rolling again.
Starting almost a year ago, Mr. Rao, who has feared a backlash against the changes in a general election to be held in April, signaled that there would be no big new steps toward overhauling the economic system until after the voting. Nonetheless, opinion polls in recent months have suggested that the ruling Congress Party could lose the election to opposition groups that have ambiguous attitudes about the changes, including Hindu nationalists and leftists who have threatened to restrict foreign investment and to defer other moves.
At meetings around the country, Mr. Singh has sounded a valedictory note. "The reforms do not depend on one man," he has said. And he has urged skeptics to look beyond the election to what he calls an unstoppable process. "There has been a sea change in the minds of Indians in the past four years," he said recently. "I think foreign investors know that there is a new India in the making."
Like Mr. Rao, Mr. Singh, a former governor of India's central bank, was a late convert to market economics. But on his first day as Finance Minister in June 1991, he told Mr. Rao that India could only avert default on $90 billion in foreign debt by opening the economy. Since then, the two men have pushed through changes that have allowed foreign companies to own up to 100 percent of a business in India, slashed maximum import duties from 300 percent to 50 percent and cut corporate taxes to levels comparable to those of other Asian countries.
Other key changes have rolled back a system of licensing under which New Delhi made vital decisions for virtually every business on the size of work forces, the scale of investments and the type and volume of products. Industries that were Government monopolies, like power generation, have been opened to competition; in the airline industry, a small group of private carriers has already taken 40 percent of domestic passenger traffic from the Government-owned Indian Airlines. Insurance, a state-owned industry with labor unions wary of job losses, is one of the few big industries still closed to foreigners.
Mr. Singh also offers an economic score card that he says reflects the benefits India has already gained from the changes: a 1994 growth rate of 6.2 percent, up from 1.5 percent in 1991; gains in industrial production of 10 percent annually, up from near-stagnation levels, and lower inflation and Government deficits. And $3 billion in foreign equity investments in the last two years has doubled all the foreign investments in India between 1947 and 1991.
But many Indians say the halt in the free-market changes has come as the most difficult part, dismantling some of the most stubborn parts of the socialist legacy, still lies ahead.
"When is the Government going to put its foot down and say, 'This cannot go on'?" said an exasperated Abhaykumar N. Firodia, chairman of Bajaj Tempo Ltd., a producer of commercial vehicles that lost 21 of 25 working days at a plant in Madhya Pradesh state in November because a state electrical utility -- part of a national network of Government-owned power companies -- could not generate enough electricity to run the plant.
In fact, the Enron project was intended to kick-start a Government program for drawing private investment to meet India's estimated need to triple power production by 2007.
Before today's official revival of the project, it had been mothballed for five months, at a loss to Enron and its partners that they estimate at $250,000 a day. After weeks of internal wrangling, the state government in Maharashtra settled for terms not much different than Enron offered last fall, after the project was canceled. In the meantime, the two Hindu nationalist parties that form the state government used the issue as a political football, telling voters that Enron and other American companies looking at Indian markets needed to be "taught a lesson" about not exploiting India.
India's chronic power problems are but one of the difficulties that make it a museum for outdated economic practices. The country's best-selling car is the Hindustan Ambassador, produced in a Government-owned plant in Calcutta. But the car is a barely updated version of Britain's 1951 Morris Oxford. And only eight million people have telephones, while at least 20 million others wait for connections.
And because of an uncontrolled birth rate that has nearly tripled the population since 1947, proportionately as many people -- 350 million, by Government estimates -- live in poverty as when British rule ended.
Despite all this, many powerful groups are allied to the opposition political parties in their effort to slow down the changes. Armies of officials in government offices, banks, ports, airports and railway stations maintain a tangled bureaucratic system that makes even the former Soviet Union look efficient. And powerful labor unions have flexed their muscles to insure that more than 240 state-owned industries, nearly half of them big loss-makers for years, escape privatization.
Some examples are almost farcical: The Hindustan Fertilizer Corporation, owned by the Government, has employed 1,550 people at a technically flawed plant that opened at a cost of $1.2 billion near Calcutta in 1979. But it has yet to produce a pound of fertilizer or anything else marketable.
Many foreign companies that came into India in the rush after 1991 have also begun to learn that things taken for granted in other countries are absent in India. Even Mr. Singh, the Finance Minister, has acknowledged the "appalling state" of the country's economic infrastructure. Cargos sit on docksides for weeks for lack of rail cars, ports are antiquated and roads are a nightmare.
While these factors have been enough to deter some foreign companies, others are bullish on India. Last week, the Ford Motor Company became the latest of scores of American corporations to place its bet, announcing a tentative agreement on a joint venture with an Indian vehicle maker, Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd., to build a car plant in Madras. Eventually, the two companies see an investment of up to $700 million and production of up to 100,000 vehicles a year.
In choosing Madras, the capital of Tamil Nadu state in southern India, Ford settled on a site that illustrated many of India's strengths and drawbacks. The Tamil Nadu government, led by a former movie star, Jayalalitha Jayaram, is widely considered one of India's most corrupt, and has been accused by opponents of using violence, including acid-throwing, against those who cross it. But Madras also has a surplus of engineers and other professionals, and is the hub of an auto parts industry that began before World War II.
"We have made a strategic decision, and it is simple: to be in India," said John Parker, a Ford executive who will be managing director of the venture, which is expected to start production in 1998. Ford joins other foreign auto makers, including General Motors, Honda Motor of Japan, Fiat of Italy and Daewoo of South Korea, that have announced plans to build vehicles here to compete for a fast-growing car market.

HEADLINE: Japan Coalition Names Candidate Likely to Become Premier

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The governing coalition today selected Ryutaro Hashimoto as its candidate for Prime Minister, virtually assuring that he will be chosen by Parliament on Thursday to head the Japanese Government.
Mr. Hashimoto, the Trade Minister and president of the Liberal Democratic Party, Japan's dominant political party, would succeed Tomiichi Murayama, who announced his resignation on Friday. 
 The three parties in the governing coalition have almost no policy positions in common, but they have agreed on a vague platform that is supposed to guide Mr. Hashimoto's administration.
The platform calls for "the realignment and reduction" of American military bases in Okinawa, and seeks "visible results within a year" in reducing the burden of the bases on the people of Okinawa.
Despite urging from the Socialists, however, the platform does not make any specific commitment to curtailing the bases, which Mr. Hashimoto tends to support. The platform expresses support for the Japan-United States security treaty, which is the underpinning of the bases.
The security treaty and the bases have been sharply criticized within Japan in the last few months, particularly since the rape of a 12-year-old Okinawan girl, for which three American servicemen have been charged, focused attention on the hostility that many Okinawans feel for the bases.
The coalition refused to include a reference in the platform to Mr. Murayama's apology in August for Japanese aggression in World War II. The result may be to raise anxieties elsewhere in Asia about whether Mr. Murayama's speech, the most direct apology any Japanese leader has ever given for brutality during World War II, really represents Japan's thinking.
Instead, the platform struck a compromise by leaving out any reference to Japanese aggression during the war, and instead including an ambiguous phrase about "learning the lessons of the past."
Tonight, Mr. Hashimoto shook hands with the leaders of the other two parties in the coalition -- Mr. Murayama and Masayoshi Takemura of the New Party Sakigake -- and pledged to do his best if elected Prime Minister.
"I'm very grateful for this," Mr. Hashimoto told reporters. "I'll do my best to build trust among the parties in the coalition."
Mr. Hashimoto said that the economy was slowly improving, a point that the coalition has emphasized in rejecting calls for new general elections.
"I don't think we need new elections before the fall," Koichi Kato, the secretary general of Liberal Democratic Party, said tonight.
New elections do not have to be held for another 18 months. But many people have been angered by the prospect of the Prime Minister's office being turned over to the leader of another party without consulting the voters.
The leadership of the New Frontier Party, the main opposition group, tried a new strategy today to demand immediate new elections. The party leadership tried to get all of its 170 members of Parliament -- one-third of the total -- to resign en masse to dramatize its protest against the change in prime ministers without an election.

 The strategy failed. One faction in the New Frontier Party, led by former Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata, resisted the idea and it was dropped at least for now.
The failure of the effort underscores the cracks in the opposition and represents a defeat for Ichiro Ozawa, the president of the New Frontier Party. Mr. Ozawa, who will be the main candidate running against Mr. Hashimoto when the Parliament selects a new Prime Minister on Thursday, had to settle for new demands that the Parliament be dissolved and new elections called.
The governing coalition responded by repeating its accusations that the New Frontier Party is a front for a religious organization, Soka Gakkai. A Buddhist group, Soka Gakkai supports the New Frontier but is regarded by many Japanese as a cult.
