HEADLINE: As the N.A.A.C.P. Regroups, Many Blacks Doubt its Relevance

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5

 BODY:
As the host of a call-in show on New Orleans's major black radio station, Bill Rouselle knows what people in this city's African-American community have on their minds.
Daily, Mr. Rouselle hears their views on education, politics, relations with the police and a variety of other issues. But, one subject almost never comes up: the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. 
 "It's not a relevant organization to most of those people," he said.
Rocked by scandal and mired in debt, the N.A.A.C.P. board has revamped its leadership in the past year and pledged to restore the organization to prominence. It elected Myrlie Evers-Williams, the widow of the slain civil rights worker Medgar Evers, as its new chairwoman, and it replaced Benjamin F. Chavis Jr. with Representative Kweisi Mfume, a Maryland Democrat, as executive director.
But as the new hierarchy takes over the 86-year-old civil rights organization and tries to revitalize it, it must confront the sobering fact that many blacks have questions about the N.A.A.C.P.'s purpose in today's world and its relation to their daily lives. Indeed, interviews with more than a score of black people in this city, which once served as a kind of staging area for civil rights volunteers who worked in tough areas like the Mississippi Delta, found that when people consider the N.A.A.C.P. at all, it often is in the past tense.
Ronnie Burns, 44, owner of Quick Courier Services, the largest black-owned courier company in Louisiana, said: "When I think about the N.A.A.C.P., what I think about is the struggle that a lot of African-Americans have gone through and the sacrifices they made so that people like myself are able to own a business, run a business and compete in corporate America."
Asked what he thought of the group's new leadership, Mr. Burns said, "The new leader? Is it still Ben Chavis?"
Like Mr. Burns, many interviewed have not closely followed the internal struggles that have wracked the organization since disclosures in 1994 that Mr. Chavis had committed the organization's money to forestall a sexual-harassment and sex-discrimination suit by a former employee. In part, the lack of knowledge of the organization reflects a natural inattention of people busy with their daily lives. In part, it reflected a sense of alienation resulting from the group's recent travails.
"I know they had a scandal going on sometime last year with some lady that Chavis had employed," said Herbert Gilson, 44, a plumber with the local housing authority. "After that, I just deleted them out of my mind."
For some, particularly the young and the poor for whom the organization often says it speaks, the lack of familiarity with the N.A.A.C.P. was jarring.
"I've never heard of them," said Lucinda Carter, a 20-year-old mother on welfare.
Asked about the group's new leaders, Melvin Scott, 47, a construction worker looked perplexed and thought for a moment. Nearby, one of his buddies, who would not give his name, tried to help out. "It's a lady," the friend said in a stage whisper. "Husband got shot in Mississippi. I'm trying to give you a hint."
Even among some familiar with the organization there seemed to be questions about the need to be a part of it.
"Not yet, not yet," David Thomas, 17, a freshman at Southern University's New Orleans Campus, when asked if he was a member. "I've always been able to deal with my life. I think I can provide for myself. I may join later on in my life, but not right now. I've got college right now."
To be sure, among many blacks active in business and politics, the selection of Mr. Mfume as president and chief executive, drew praise. As the former chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, he is viewed as someone who would bring to the organization a measure of political acumen they say has been sorely missing in recent years.
"If he calls he's going to get a response," said Mayor Marc H. Morial, 38, of New Orleans, whose father Ernest Morial was president of the local N.A.A.C.P. branch in the 1960's and a New Orleans mayor in the '80s. "If he calls, people are going to know he's not calling with some foolishness -- that it's something that's going to have a sense of political sophistication."
As president of Louisiana's largest black-owned bank, Alden McDonald, has worked in the past with Mr. Mfume who, when the Democrats were in control, served on the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee.
"He's been very helpful to the minority banking industry, minority contractors, all the minority professional groups," Mr. McDonald said. "He's been supportive without asking for anything. That means he's made a lot of friends in the entire country who are ready to support him. He's not even going to need a letter to get our financial contributions."
But even among strong supporters of Ms. Evers-Williams and Mr. Mfume, there was little consensus of what the N.A.A.C.P. should -- or could -- do. Doubts about the organization's role seemed particularly acute given the large number of blacks who have been elected to office -- particularly in the South -- since the 1970's.
"I think that, in the past, the N.A.A.C.P. was so important in the South, particularly in the pre-black electoral era," Mr. Morial said. "But to a great extent in the electoral era -- and I can only speak from the perspective of this city -- the advent of African-Americans serving in elected positions, plus our increasing ability to influence elected leaders, has probably created a necessity to question the relevance of the organization."
Sheila Williams, 33, current president of the New Orleans branch said she feels the organization needs to hone its purpose to a few issues or programs, like housing or employment discrimination, and carry them off well, rather than trying to take on every issue that relates to blacks, and handling them all ineffectively.
"I think nationally, we have to set an agenda, a very targeted agenda," she said. "You can pick any issue today and it would monopolize the whole time for a branch and the national office to mobilize their forces. I think in the past, we have just tried to be everything to everybody."
In interviews, person after person expressed an unease that, without the stark and tangible racism embodied in legalized segregation, the black community was fracturing. To them, a national organization like the N.A.A.C.P. is needed to unify blacks, but unifying them around what remained an open question.
"The N.A.A.C.P.'s purpose has to change at this point," said Matt Suarez, 57, who worked in Mississippi in the 1960's as a volunteer for the Congress of Racial Equality, and now operates a day care center. "We as a people are becoming fragmented; splitting, dividing into a lot of different little groups. People like to say it's the haves and have nots, but it's not that simple. We're separating and splitting among ourselves in terms of politics, philosophies, economics, regions, all sorts of influences that didn't have as much importance in our lives during the civil rights movement."
Mr. Suarez added: "More and more the pressures of American life, American society, American politics are dividing us. The N.A.A.C.P.'s role has to be to find those avenues that will reunite us as a people."

HEADLINE: Flat Tax, Once Obscure Idea, Is Set to Enter Campaign Debate

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The idea of discarding the elaborate Federal tax system in favor of a simple flat tax is about to go from an obscure academic discussion among economists to a full-throated debating issue in the Presidential campaign.
The release later this week of a study on how to simplify the tax system, sponsored formally if not wholeheartedly by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and Speaker Newt Gingrich, will almost certainly add momentum to the debate and thrust the flat tax into Republican policy discussions. 
 In the last few weeks, Steve Forbes has offered the most vivid demonstration of the issue's appeal. He has used the flat tax effectively as one of his weapons in the self-financed advertising blitz that has propelled him from a novelty candidate to someone who is getting enough attention to warrant consistent attacks from his rivals.
The basic idea of a flat tax is to jettison the sliding scale of tax rates and make all taxpayers pay the same percentage of their income. At the same time, almost all deductions would be eliminated so wealthy people could not reduce their taxes by festooning their returns with deductions available only to the rich. About 75 percent of tax returns do not claim any special deductions.
Edmund G. Brown Jr., a Democrat and a former governor of California, campaigned for President advocating a flat tax in 1992 but was unable to gain any traction with it in his party. This time around, the issue will be featured on the Republican side, becoming all but unavoidable for any Republican Presidential hopeful, said Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster.
"It's got tremendous appeal," Mr. Luntz said in an interview. "It goes to some basic issues -- Americans' effort to simplify their lives as well as the increasing resentment of government that many feel."
The major Republican candidates have spoken positively, if ambiguously, in favor of some form of a flat tax. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas is expected to issue soon his own version of a proposal, which is likely to preserve deductions for charitable donations and home-mortgage interest.
Yet some surveys show that while the flat tax has wide appeal, that support may prove to be shallow because of the inevitable trade-offs: a flat tax large enough to replace the current system could carry a high rate -- 21 percent or more, according to some estimates -- and might mean the end of the home-mortgage and charity deductions. The vigorous debate over how high the rate would have to be is linked to equally contentious arguments over how deeply the Federal budget could be cut to accommodate less revenue.
Although there is the inevitable discord among economic studies, many say a flat tax would be a boon to the rich and cause most middle-class taxpayers to pay more.
Mr. Forbes's proposal, which is similar to one introduced in Congress by Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, is the only one currently on the table in the Republican campaign. It has these basic elements:
*The tax rate would be set at 17 percent for everyone.
*Couples filing jointly would be able to exempt the first $26,000 of income -- $13,000 for individuals -- and $5,000 per child. Thus, a family of four would not pay taxes on the first $36,000 of income.
*Virtually all other deductions would be eliminated, including those for home-mortgage interest, charitable contributions, and state and local taxes.
*Businesses would no longer be able to deduct the cost of fringe benefits.
The appeal, both opponents and supporters agree, is twofold.
First, a flat tax is simple. Now, even professional tax preparers struggle to figure out the complexities of the tax code. Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, who campaigned on a flat tax before he dropped out of the Republican Presidential race last year, said that he had always drawn the greatest response during appearances when he had pulled out of his pocket a postcard-size facsimile of what a tax return would look like under a flat tax.
Second, the simplicity suggests fairness to voters because it promises the elimination of the loopholes typically available to filers who can hire accountants and tax consultants. It could also mean the shrinking of the unbeloved Internal Revenue Service.
"It has enormous appeal," Mr. Forbes said in an interview. "It would bring simplicity and honesty to the tax code, and people believe that the current complexity means that a lot of people are getting away with something."
Mr. Forbes has nothing bad to say about the flat tax. The elimination for charitable deductions would not cripple charities, he says, because "Americans do not have to be bribed by the tax code to give." People will not object to allowing wealthy individuals to avoid paying taxes on income from interest and stocks, he contends, because they would understand that the income would be taxed at the corporate level.
But the political vulnerabilities of that argument were evident when Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican candidate who has styled himself a populist, told an audience in Manchester, N.H., on Sunday that Mr. Forbes's proposals would benefit the rich. Mr. Buchanan said he would keep an exemption for mortgages while taxing unearned income.
Mr. Luntz, the Republican pollster, said his surveys showed that more than a fourth of the electorate strongly favored the concept of a flat tax and that nearly half liked it but had less enthusiasm.
Yet Democratic strategists argue that once the fine print is attached to any proposal, voters will be wary. One White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the flat tax issue was analogous to the health care issue for the White House. President Clinton's plan to overhaul health care started out as a winning idea in 1993 but eventually collapsed under the weight of its complexity.
"Everybody agrees there's a need for change, that what we have now is flawed," the official said. "But when you start presenting the details, you find it's easy for opponents to beat up on you."
The official said the Democrats would be eager to run against such a specific tax proposal.
That reasoning is seemingly shared, at least in part, by Mr. Dole, the apparent front-runner in the Republican race. Initially, his sponsorship of the Republican tax study was a handy way for Mr. Dole to put off questions on tax policy.
But recently, as the publication of that study approaches, Mr. Dole's supporters have persuaded the study panel to keep its recommendations vague and not recommend a specify flat tax rate.
The idea of a flat tax has several powerful institutional opponents, like the nation's bankers, insurance agents and real estate companies, all of whom rely on the mortgage deduction to keep Americans buying homes. Those lobbies are influential both in Washington and in all the nation's 435 Congressional districts, each of which has at least one bank, realtor and insurance agent.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Allow Limits on Indecent RAdio and TV Shows

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today rejected a constitutional challenge to a Federal law that bans indecent programming on radio and broadcast television during the day and in prime-time evening hours.
The Court took the action without comment, leaving intact a sharply divided Federal appeals court ruling that upheld the 1992 law last June. The debate over Federal regulation of indecent and sexually explicit speech is certain to continue, however, both within and outside the Court. 
 Congress is considering curbs against transmitting obscene and indecent material over computer networks, and the Justices themselves recently agreed to review a separate Federal law intended to curb access to indecent programming on certain cable television channels. Also awaiting action by the Justices is a challenge to the Federal Communications Commission's approach to imposing fines on broadcasters for indecent programming.
In light of the continued ferment over the issue of indecency, the Justices' quick action today in refusing to hear the challenge to Section 16a of the Public Telecommunications Act of 1992, limiting indecent programming to late-night and pre-dawn hours, was somewhat surprising.
The Clinton Administration, while defending the constitutionality of the law, urged the Court to defer action until after it decides the cable television case, set for argument on Feb. 21. The Court's decision in the cable case, Denver Area Consortium v. F.C.C., No. 95-124, "could affect the analysis and disposition of this case," the Administration's brief in the new case told the Court.
The F.C.C. defines indecency as "language that depicts or describes, in terms patently offensive as measured by contemporary community standards for the broadcast medium, sexual or excretory activities or organs." In 1978, in a ruling commonly known as the "seven dirty words" case, the Court upheld the commission's authority to regulate indecency. But as the constant flow of new legal challenges makes clear, that decision left many questions.
The question presented by the case today was the constitutional adequacy of the late-night "safe harbor" that the 1992 law provided to broadcasters of indecent material. In 1988 Congress directed the F.C.C. to ban indecent programming 24 hours a day, but the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit struck that law down on the ground that the First Amendment required there to be some time of day when broadcasters could offer indecent programming to a willing adult audience.
Congress then enacted the 1992 law, which permits indecent broadcasts from midnight to 6 A.M. for commercial stations and 10 P.M. to 6 A.M. for public radio and television stations that go off the air at or before midnight. In 1993, a panel of the appellate court declared the new law unconstitutional as well.
That panel was made up of the court's three most liberal members, Judges Harry T. Edwards, Patricia M. Wald and Abner J. Mikva, who later resigned to become the White House counsel. The full appellate court quickly vacated the panel's opinion and upheld the law by a vote of 7 to 4, on the ground that the law served the Government's interest in "supporting parental supervision of what children see and hear on the public airwaves."
Two coalitions of broadcasters filed Supreme Court appeals from that ruling. One appeal, Pacifica Foundation v. F.C.C., No. 95-509, was filed by a group of noncommercial broadcasters and by literary figures, including the poet Allen Ginsberg. Their brief said that the result of the ruling would be to limit the American adult audience "to watching and hearing only programming fit for children."
Another group, including the commercial networks and civil liberties groups, argued that the indecency standard was unconstitutionally vague and that the law intruded into families' varying approaches on child rearing. That appeal was Action for Children's Television, No. 95-520.
There were also these actions today at the Court, the only major institution of Government open in the snowbound capital:
 
Condom Distribution
The Court, also without comment, turned down an appeal by a group of religious conservatives from a ruling that upheld a program of distributing condoms to junior and senior high school students in a Massachusetts public school district.
Parents of four students challenged the program, which was put in place by the Falmouth, Mass., school board in 1992. Under the program, students may receive condoms from a school nurse without charge or from bathroom vending machines for 75 cents. The parents argued that while no student was required to participate, the availability of the condoms violated the constitutional right of parents to guide their children's upbringing.
In a ruling last July rejecting that challenge, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court stressed the voluntary nature of the program. "The plaintiff parents are free to instruct their children not to participate," the state court said. The case was Curtis v. School Committee of Falmouth, No. 95-617.
 
Speech Restriction
The Court refused to hear an appeal by Katherine Ann Power, the former fugitive who turned herself in 23 years after participating as an antiwar protester in a fatal bank robbery.
Facing a potential life sentence, Ms. Power pleaded guilty in Massachusetts state court in 1993 to armed robbery and manslaughter and received a sentence of 8 to 12 years in prison, followed by 20 years of probation. In the case today, Power v. Mass., No. 95-277, she was challenging a condition the trial judge placed on her probation, a prohibition against receiving any direct or indirect "profit or benefit" from telling her story, including her life as a fugitive.
The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court last year upheld that order as a reasonable condition of probation, rejecting the argument that it amounted to an unconstitutional prior restraint on speech.
 
Citizenship
The Justices turned down a challenge to a provision of Federal immigration law that draws a distinction between two groups of illegitimate children born abroad to one parent who was a United States citizen and one who was not.
If the citizen-parent was the mother, the child is deemed under the law, the Nationality Act of 1940, to have acquired United States citizenship at birth. But if the citizen-parent was the father, the child has the right to citizenship only if paternity has been established by the child's 21st birthday.
The law was challenged as a violation of the constitutional guarantee of equal protection by a Philippines-born woman whose father was an American member of the armed forces. She did not learn her father's identity until she was in her mid-30's, at which point she traced him and obtained genetic testing results that proved he was her father. But because she had passed her 21st birthday, the woman, Luzvisaminda Ablang, was not entitled to claim automatic citizenship.
Judge Irving Hill of Federal District Court in Los Angeles declared the law unconstitutional in 1993, in a decision that was overturned last year by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco.
The appellate court said that despite the current availability of reliable genetic testing, the rationale for the 1940 law was still valid. "We cannot say that Congress's desire to promote early ties to this country and to those relatives who are citizens of this country is not a rational basis for the requirements," the court said. The appeal was Ablang v. Reno, No. 95-505.
 
No Smoking
The Court refused to hear a constitutional challenge to a regulation in North Miami, Fla., that bars the hiring of smokers for any city job. Under the regulation, no one can be hired without signing a statement that he or she has not smoked or used tobacco products in the preceding 12 months.
The regulation was challenged by the American Civil Liberties Union on behalf of a woman who passed the city's employment examination and was invited to apply for a job as a clerk-typist. But when she said she could not sign the no-smoking statement, the interview ended and she was not called back.
The city's stated rationale for the policy, which does not apply to workers already on the payroll when it was adopted in 1990, was an economic one: the city said smokers had costlier health problems and required the taxpayers to spend more for the medical coverage of municipal workers who smoke.
A state appeals court in Florida declared the policy unconstitutional as a violation of the right to privacy guaranteed by the Florida Constitution. The Florida Supreme Court overturned that ruling last year, finding no violation of any state or Federal constitutional right.
The woman, Arlene Kurtz, challenged the policy as a violation of constitutional due process. She said the state court's decision would permit governments to "open up virtually every aspect of a person's private life to intrusive governmental regulation in the supposed interest of cost-cutting." The case was Kurtz v. North Miami, No. 95-545.

HEADLINE: Lockheed to Acquire Loral In a Deal Worth $10 Billion

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8

 BODY:
In a startling move that accelerates the consolidation of military contractors and is likely to lead to more layoffs, the Lockheed Martin Corporation announced today that it planned to acquire most of the Loral Corporation in a complex deal that is valued at more than $10 billion.
The announcement came as a surprise, in large part because Lockheed Martin was itself a result of a merger, in 1994, and it is still struggling to digest that combination. But the announcement underscored pressure from the markets -- and from the Pentagon -- for military contractors to grow larger and more efficient through consolidation to survive at a time of declining military procurement budgets. 
 Just last week the Northrop Grumman Corporation said it was acquiring the military electronics businesses of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for the equivalent of $3.6 billion. Loral had been a losing bidder in that deal.
Analysts also said they expected the merger to result in several thousand layoffs, at least some of them in the New York area, where Loral, a big electronics company, has its headquarters and the two companies employ about 10,000 people.
Loral's shareholders will benefit, because they will receive the equivalent of about $45.50 per share for each share they own. Loral's stock jumped $8.25 today, to $44.50. Lockheed Martin stock rose $2.875, to $80.25.
The deal will create two new entities that will be huge competitors in their businesses. Lockheed Martin will absorb the highly regarded military electronics business of Loral. It will emerge as by far the country's largest maker of military hardware, with annual revenues of about $30 billion.
The company will produce everything from the F-16 and F-22 jet fighters to missiles, commercial and military rocket launchers and electronic defense systems for the Navy.
In addition, the deal will result in the creation of a new company, to be called the Loral Space and Communications Corporation. This company will be involved in the growing civilian business of satellite telecommunications for individuals and businesses, particularly in Southeast Asia and other regions.
Up until now, this business has been regarded as a promising but untested new way to expand the telecommunications market. Today's announcement, and especially the fact that Loral's respected chairman, Bernard L. Schwartz, will be leading the new company, will bring new focus on this emerging industry, analysts said. In fact, Mr. Schwartz indicated that the company was already preparing some acquisitions to increase its presence in the business.
Under the terms of the transaction, shareholders in Loral will receive $38 in cash for each share, plus one share in the new company. Lockheed Martin will then purchase a 20 percent stake in Loral Space and Communications for $344 million. That gives the new shares an estimated value of $7.50 each, which makes the transaction worth roughly $45.50 per share for Loral shareholders.
Lockheed Martin will thus pay roughly $7 billion in cash for Loral's shares and will assume an additional $2.1 billion of Loral's debt. The new space company will have a value of about $1 billion, which brings the total value of the acquisition and spinoff to about $10.1 billion.
The deal is also interesting for what it does for Mr. Schwartz, who recently turned 70. Analysts said they expected this wealthy entrepreneur, who built Loral over the last two decades from a modest company to a behemoth in its business, to stay active in the new space business.
"The nice thing about this is that it's not just a finale," said Lior Bregman, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. "The company has a new start. Schwartz is not just taking his money and going to Florida. It's very exciting."
Analysts also said the combination would force other military contractors to hasten any planned mergers and to make the remaining American companies even more competitive in selling military hardware overseas.
"Bernard Schwartz and Norm Augustine have been the two visionaries in this industry, and that makes this an important transaction," said Jon B. Kutler, the president of Quarterdeck Investment Partners, an investment bank that specializes in the military industry. Norman R. Augustine, the former Under Secretary of the Army in the Defense Department, is now the president and chief executive of Lockheed Martin.
One clear benefit of the acquisition is that it will produce a fortune for Mr. Schwartz, who earned $6.24 million in compensation last year. He owns stock that is now worth about $160 million.
In a press conference today, the heads of the companies were at pains to stress that the number of layoffs would be relatively modest and that, over time, the employment rolls of the combined company, more than 200,000, would grow. But they did acknowledge that some layoffs were inevitable.
Mr. Bregman estimated that perhaps 4 percent of the combined staff of the companies would be cut. That would amount to about 8,000 people.
"Ours is an industry that has to change," said Mr. Augustine, who added that the business of military contracting was going through "Darwinian times."
While there is likely to be a review by the Justice Department of whether the creation of such a huge company would be anti-competitive, analysts said they did not expect the Government to block the deal, which was put together in secret over four months. The top executives have already discussed the transaction with the Pentagon.
The new Lockheed Martin will receive about $17 billion a year of its $30 billion in revenues from defense electronics. About 60 percent of its revenues will come from military contracts, and the remainder from civilian businesses.
The deal will also make it an even more formidable competitor to foreign military contractors, particularly the big European companies. Mr. Augustine said that Lockheed Martin currently received about 17 percent of its revenues from overseas, and that that figure was likely to grow in the future.
A number of factors brought the two sides together, among them the pressure by the Pentagon to consolidate as well as the low interest rates available because of the weak economy.
Lockheed Martin will borrow about $10 billion to complete the transaction, and its executives stressed that taking on so much debt -- it will have a total of $12.5 billion after the deal -- was made far easier by the fact that interest rates are at their lowest levels in years.

HEADLINE: Snow Slows, Doesn't Stop, Stock Markets

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The East Coast blizzard of '96, one of the biggest storms of the century, caused major disruptions at financial markets yesterday, but some exchanges managed to open for limited trading. Trading today is expected to be practically normal.
Stocks were traded only between 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. on the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market. "We didn't make any money today," said Edward L. Goldberg, an executive vice president of Merrill Lynch. "But over all we functioned fine." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 16.25 points, to 5,197.68, and the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index lost ground.
Bond volume was also restricted after the Public Securities Association recommended that trading end at noon. As a result, only about $9.7 billion worth of Treasuries changed hands, compared with the recent daily average of $69 billion. In that market, "It was essentially like the Brooklyn Bridge during the day: empty," said William K. Joseph, senior vice president of Smith Barney.
Bonds ended little changed in light trading, with the yield of the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond steady at 6.04 percent. There was no regular auction of Treasury bills because of the partial shutdown of the Federal Government.
There was also no commodities trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the Commodity Exchange, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange did not open trading in many of its index products until the leading stock exchanges began to trade. And the dollar was little changed, rising to 105.30 Japanese yen from 105.27.
The exchanges and brokerage firms in New York said that their work forces and customer business were at about one-third the normal levels.
That was reflected in yesterday's turnover on the Big Board, which totaled 130.4 million shares, the lightest since the Thanksgiving period. Volume was 437.1 million shares Friday, while the 1995 average daily volume was about 350 million shares.
"The stock market didn't get much of a chance to move a lot one way or another," said Hugh A. Johnson, senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation. "It's so quiet that the traders look like they are almost asleep."
Andrew Schwarz, a specialist on the American Stock Exchange, said: "The difference is the camaraderie that existed on the floor. Everyone was helping each other out. I told all those on my staff who made it in that I'd give them an extra day's pay."
The preparation for opening the markets yesterday in the midst of a snow emergency began on Sunday. The Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal Reserve Board, the big exchanges and the member firms were in contact throughout the day as the storm's intensity grew.
"We wanted to make sure that everyone was tied in to the loop," said Richard Lindsey, the S.E.C.'s director of market regulation. "Our preference is to have the markets open."
The most important participant among the marketplaces was the New York Stock Exchange. And Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of that exchange, had left New York Sunday morning for a meeting in Seoul with the Korean Stock Exchange, although he kept in touch by telephone.
Senior officials of the Big Board spent Sunday night at New York hotels and conducted their first meeting yesterday at 7:45 A.M. By 9:30 A.M., they determined that they would have a delayed opening, and about an hour later, they decided to start at 11 A.M.
"Our dollar cost in the loss of volume was far exceeded on the plus side by giving investors the opportunity to buy and sell stocks if they wanted to," said Robert Fagenson, a specialist on the exchange and a member of its board. "I determined to be here the earliest and leave the latest."
A personal tragedy struck at the New York Stock Exchange before the opening. William Weyer, a 55-year-old clerk who had worked there since he was 18, collapsed on the floor, apparently from a heart attack, at 9 A.M. He was pronounced dead on arrival at Beekman Downtown Hospital.
Among the market indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 1.75 points, to 618.46, and the Nasdaq composite fell 1.10 points, to 1032.37. Advancing issues exceeded decliners on the New York exchange by 1,261 to 904.
Military stocks were particularly strong. In the aerospace group, Boeing benefited from a report that it might soon win a $3 billion order for up to 60 planes, gaining 1 3/4, to 80 1/4. It was followed by Allied Signal, which advanced 3/8, to 49 1/8, and United Technologies, which increased 1 1/8, to 94 1/8.
And Loral surged 8 1/4, to 44 1/2, after Lockheed Martin offered to buy most of the company for $9.1 billion. Lockheed Martin soared 2 7/8, to 80 1/4, McDonnell Douglas increased 3 1/4, to 95 3/4, and Rockwell rose 1 3/4, to 54 3/4.
There was continuing weakness in some technology issues, though. Motorola declined 3/4, to 56 1/4; Micron dropped 1/2, to 38 5/8, and Sun Microsystems fell3/8, to 40 1/8.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 613 words

HEADLINE: A Less Harmful Budget

 BODY:
The budget proposal released by the White House over the weekend answers critics who have harshly, though accurately, accused President Clinton of stalling on his promise to deliver a plan that would balance the budget in seven years using Congressional scorekeeping.
Mr. Clinton tried valiantly to protect spending on the poor and education and other public investments. But his plan is littered with time bombs that make its protections partly illusory. There was no way to adopt the Republican budget target and yet preserve the progressive economic agenda that he had used to win the White House. 
 In this latest budget plan, Mr. Clinton would wipe out $60 billion from corporate subsidies. He would also cut taxes by $87 billion, which is less than half the Republicans' target but still $87 billion too high in a plan that aims to reduce the deficit.
Nevertheless, the lower tax cut allowed him to propose trimming Medicare, Medicaid and other programs for the needy by about half of what the Republican-led Congress passed. He preserves food stamps and Medicaid as Federal entitlements. On balance, these trade-offs make a powerful case for preferring Mr. Clinton's plan.
Even so, part of the advantage is illusory. The President would pile up cuts in non-military discretionary spending in the last two years of the plan. By 2002, spending on everything from protecting the environment to patrolling the border might be cut by 30 percent or more.
The plight of discretionary programs is even worse than these numbers indicate. Mr. Clinton says his tax cut -- for families with children and for some educational expenses -- would be temporary unless the economy grows more quickly than Congressional scorekeepers expect. Political reality will probably dictate that the cut, once enacted, will not be withdrawn. If so, Congress would, under existing budget rules, be required to make even deeper cuts in discretionary and entitlement programs after 2002 than the President has so far outlined. Cuts that large would mean that Mr. Clinton would have to abandon any vestige of his original agenda for investing in infrastructure, research, education and job training.
He could have preserved more of these plans by jettisoning tax cuts entirely, but that would be politically hazardous as the G.O.P. waves the promise of even bigger cuts in front of nearly every non-poor voter.
Nor does the Clinton plan take on some powerful constituencies. It does not go after subsidies to wealthy farmers. It sets low Medicare premiums for wealthy retirees. As hard as the White House tried to protect the poor, its plan envisions a budget that would cut foods stamps by hundreds of dollars a year per family and throw many disabled children off cash assistance programs.
Yet each of these flaws is magnified in the Republican plan, even taking into account agreements yesterday to whittle down proposed cuts in Medicare, Medicaid and programs for the poor. They cynically keep the costs of their tax cuts on capital gains and retirement accounts modest during the seven-year life of the budget plan, but allow them to explode soon thereafter, committing Congress to huge cuts in spending even after the seven years have elapsed.
Further, the Republican plan not only cuts off many disabled children from cash assistance, but also reduces cash allowances for most of the children who remain in the program. It cuts off food stamps and other aid to some legal immigrants even after they become citizens. Compared with the Republicans', Mr. Clinton's budget occupies the higher ground; but compared with the needs of the poor and the economy, it comes up very short.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Facing the Storm

 BODY:
New York disappeared under the Blizzard of '96, only to emerge as a new city. Roadways were as bare as the tundra, and like the tundra they were crisscrossed by hunters who trudged their way up- and downtown in search of their offices, groceries or a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
The underground city, however, was doing business. At times like this New York's subway system, often the subject of more unfavorable comment than Vlad the Impaler, reveals itself as a miracle. Non-New-Yorkers might also find it miraculous that above ground, strangers jumped in to help liberate stuck cars, that restaurants gave out free food to stranded travelers or that bus passengers urged their driver to wait an extra few minutes for a straggling family to make its way to the stop. 
 But city residents know that New Yorkers are almost always subject to these kindly impulses. The problem is getting their attention, and nothing focuses the municipal mind like a couple of feet of newly fallen snow.
These days are an Event, a Milestone -- like the legendary Blizzards of 1888 and 1947, exclamation points in history. Chronic competitors rooted for a record-breaker. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani assured the population that Staten Island and the Bronx had already gone over 1947's record 26.4-inch marker. Could Central Park be far behind?
The novelty of the vehicle-free streets, the cross-country skiers in the parks and the ice floes in the Hudson almost obscured the disruption the event caused. Normal life in the tri-state area came to a dead halt. The blizzard closed schools, shut down all the area airports and brought economic havoc to a city that was for all practical purposes cut off from the outside world.
New York and New Jersey declared states of emergency. Roofs collapsed under the weight of the snow. Emergency vehicles were stranded in drifts, and normal vehicular traffic was banned altogether from New York City. Bus service was suspended, along with much of the suburban train service.
Even the Post Office canceled deliveries, a cause for dismay for all those who have long taken that "neither-rain-nor-snow" slogan literally. Mayor Giuliani, who may have tempted the fates by slashing this year's snow-removal budget, put 1,663 plows on around-the-clock duty.
At times like these the citizenry may be more eager to see a snowplow than a politician. Still, and perhaps for reasons of reassurance, ancient custom dictates that politicians of rank be visibly on the move. While Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey drove a snowplow and helped evacuate a trailer camp, New York's Governor was unhappily trapped in Albany, where, irony of ironies, there was not enough snow to warrant even a personal inspection. But Mayor Giuliani, wearing what appeared to be a new Christmas sweater, roamed the boroughs tirelessly, rallying sanitation workers and setting a tone of efficient concern. New York would take this storm seriously, but not be cowed by it.
Advice abounded. Stay dry. Wear layers. Clear out fire hydrants. Shovel in small scoops, without lifting above your shoulder. Stay off sloped roofs. Keep your hat on outdoors. Refrain from driving snowmobiles on the highway.
Most New Yorkers, wisely, opted to keep smiling and enjoy the show. They knew it was only a matter of time before the miracle of nature became a grimy sea of sidewalk obstruction, and the spirit of shared experience faded into carping about unplowed side streets and unshoveled walks. They reveled for a moment at the cusp of a natural disaster, when its images are still vivid and its costs are yet to be tallied.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Legacy of Francois Mitterrand

 BODY:
Francois Mitterrand, who died yesterday at age 79, was, with Charles de Gaulle, one of the two dominant French political leaders of the postwar era. Though Mr. Mitterrand served longer than de Gaulle as President -- longer, in fact, than anyone in the history of France's five republics -- his legacy was more ambiguous.
Mr. Mitterrand strengthened France's alliance with Germany, the core of the European Union. He also improved relations with the United States, ended the Gaullist chill toward Israel and even earned the personal respect of his frequent adversary Margaret Thatcher, a woman he once described as having "the lips of Marilyn Monroe and the eyes of Caligula." 
 It was Mr. Mitterrand who began the long moratorium on French nuclear testing that his successor, Jacques Chirac, recklessly abandoned last year. At home, Mr. Mitterrand abolished the death penalty and added the final touches to France's cherished system of social benefits, another achievement his successor has tried to reverse.
Leading an alliance of Socialists and Communists to victory in 1981, Mr. Mitterrand brought the long-marginalized French left a greater combination of executive and legislative power than it had ever known in modern times. But within two years, Mr. Mitterrand pragmatically sacrificed his left-wing platform to the demands of an increasingly integrated European market.
Market necessity dictated most of the policy changes. But an unwise commitment to a European currency union led to punishingly high interest rates that translated into chronic double-digit unemployment. Mr. Mitterrand's Socialists paid heavily at the polls and twice the Socialist President was forced to share power with right-wing legislative majorities. Last year Mr. Chirac, running on a platform of economic populism, captured the presidency for the right as well.
Mr. Mitterrand was a master political tactician with few immutable principles. Not only his Socialist beliefs were lightly held. Even his record of resistance in World War II was ambiguous. In the early 1940's he worked uncomfortably closely with the Vichy regime and maintained lifelong friendships with some of Vichy's more odious figures.
Throughout his presidential term, Mr. Mitterrand refused to offer France's apologies for Vichy's wartime roundups of Jews, most of whom ended up in Nazi death camps. Extending that overdue apology was one of Mr. Chirac's first and most admirable gestures.
On other issues, however, President Mitterrand's record was more positive, and when he left office he could boast that France's economic foundations were stronger and its alliances firmer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Grip

BYLINE: By Timothy A. Canova; Timothy A. Canova, who teaches at the University of Miami School of Law, specializes in banking and finance.

DATELINE: CORAL GABLES, Fla.

 BODY:
The word is that President Clinton may reappoint Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve when his term expires this spring. The chairman's support of the Mexican bailout and his support for increasing the debt limit to avoid government default has helped the White House at crucial moments.
But while Mr. Greenspan may have prevented the financial house of cards from collapsing, his overall handling of monetary policy has harmed the economy. For much of the last year, the weight of indicators has shown both a sluggish economy and negligible inflation of 2.6 percent. But the Fed has reacted with a tardy gradualism. 
 Last summer and again in December, the Fed lowered short-term interest rates by a paltry one-quarter of a percentage point. Each time, Wall Street bulls pushed stock prices higher, then immediately craved another tiny fix. Optimists may hope that a vibrant stock market will lead the economy out of the doldrums, but there is a danger that the market is actually a lagging indicator and that weak earnings could burst the bubble.
Fed economists are aware of this possibility. Some believe that interest rates should not be lowered too much or too quickly for fear of encouraging the bubble to expand even more. But the reverse may be more likely: corporate earnings could fall too far to sustain the current stock prices, unless the Fed lowers interest rates significantly and quickly.
If the economy then takes a dive, we are sure to hear a drumbeat of voices blaming the Federal deficit. Mr. Greenspan, it would seem, is prepared for this scenario. In November 1995 he warned: "If, for some unforeseen reason, the political process fails, and [a balanced budget] agreement is not reached, it would signal that the United States is not capable of putting its fiscal house in order, with serious, adverse consequences for financial markets and economic growth."
The political establishment can be expected to react to any bad economic news with renewed demands for more fiscal austerity since the consensus for a balanced budget wrongly assumes that high deficits are the sole cause of today's high interest rates.
But contrary to that view and Mr. Greenspan's assertions, the nation has been keeping its fiscal house in order, with the deficits declining over the past three years. The 1992 budget deficit of $290 billion was 4.9 percent of the gross domestic product; the 1995 fiscal year deficit of $164 billion is only 2.3 percent.
But this decline did not stop the Fed from raising interest rates six times in 1994. Real interest rates (adjusted for inflation) began to rise dramatically in the early 1980's (from less than 1 percent to about 5 percent on long-term government securities), not because of the deficits but because of the Fed's reliance on high interest rates as the sole anti-inflation policy.
But persistently high real rates have retarded investment and slowed economic growth. As a consequence, governments are now burdened by much larger "passive deficits" as they collect less in tax revenues and spend more on jobless compensation and enormous interest costs on their debts. By increasing debt service costs of the private sector as well as of Federal, state and local governments by hundreds of billions of dollars a year, higher interest rates constitute the most important and most hidden of the so-called unfunded Federal mandates.
With economic storm clouds on the horizon, the Administration may be wary of creating an open rift with the Fed. But without a change, the Administration will remain dependent on the dubious crisis management skills of Mr. Greenspan.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Death for Chinese Children

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Thousands of Chinese children die in orphanages every year from deliberate medical neglect and starvation. This is policy, part of Beijing's technique of controlling the increased number of children abandoned by parents who either could not feed them or feared the regime would cut the rations for the whole family for the crime of having more than one or two children.
This report, detailed by Human Rights Watch, is of course sad. But do we still have the right to mourn? 
 America, people and leadership, has known for decades that every Chinese Communist regime used forced abortion and starvation to control population growth, slave labor as an intricately planned part of its economic program, and torture and prison as fundamental instruments of political power.
The American response, bottom line: Shut up, or the Chinese may forbid us to enrich them with trade that might one day turn a little profit for American businessmen.
So be thankful that the nasty comedy of the Government shutdown, plus the blizzard, so far have saved us from hearing the Administration or top leaders of either party run on mourning the abandoned children.
The U.S. Government and Western society in general have sold for theoretical trade profit the right to mourn the orphans. They didn't get much more for the deal than Chinese political slaps in the American face and military provocations.
The U.S., and its allies, have betrayed not only orphans and women forced to abort but the principles and safety of our democratic society.
So be it. But those Americans who have the right given by consistent protest against Beijing's horrors to mourn for the orphans can serve them best by speaking up again.
The issue is simple. How long will Americans tolerate the wealth they created under freedom to be used to give dictatorship the strength it needs to destroy freedom wherever its writ extends?
This problem confronted America much of this century. More often than not, the decision was to permit American wealth to bolster dictatorships. But their very nature drove them to use their power, reinforced by American trade, to create a military threat that led to war. See Germany, Italy, Japan and Iraq.
In the China trade, profits go mostly to China. It sells the U.S. eight times more than it buys. Since wages are so low in China, and in labor camps nonexistent, this will mean loss of jobs to America.
And, predictably, most of China's profits go to its armed forces and the huge police force that enables the Communists to stay in power.
In memory of the orphans, please note: Their death is more refutation of the myth, spread by Western apologists, that human rights progress will follow economic progress.
Like all dictatorships, Beijing uses increased economic power for increased police power. The more powerful the police state, the better it hides its atrocities behind barbed wire and coerced denials.
After corporate America decided that profits were worth the risk of building up China, President Clinton decided it was worth breaking his own word to submit. He scrapped his executive order pledging to use trade tariffs to persuade the Chinese Communists to ease, however slightly, the repression of their own people and the occupied Tibetans.
This did soil Mr. Clinton's honor, naturally, but it turned out to carry no penalty here on earth. Republican Presidential candidates, except Patrick Buchanan, trot behind the China lobby. And our allies, as great as Germany and small as Israel, are also busy at the Communist trough.
Yet those Americans who care are not powerless. Republican and Democratic politicians who never surrendered faith in freedom or disgust with tyranny can make murdered orphans, forced abortion, religious oppression and slave labor an issue at the Presidential conventions. They can demand tariff penalties for these instruments of Beijing's governance.
Other Americans can make them an issue at stockholders' meetings, in churches and synagogues; remember South Africa. We can boycott Chinese imports and investments in companies that feed at the trough, uncaring of the blood therein.
That can be our flower, for the graves of the orphans.

HEADLINE: Let New Jerseyans Spend to Bolster Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Time Bomb in Governor Whitman's Tax Cut" (Op-Ed, Jan. 3): Neil Upmeyer says the New Jersey economy is weak and concludes that higher taxes and higher levels of government expenditures are needed to correct it. This Keynesian remedy does not work on the state level, and even neo-Keynesian economists doubt if it works on the national level. 
 It makes little sense to cite the weak economic condition of the state economy and the labor market in particular. Why does an unemployment rate that is higher than the national level mean that taxpayers should not be entitled to retain a higher percent of their earnings? If anything, the burdensome tax structure and excessive regulations have contributed to the weak economy.
It is almost always possible to find some value in services proposed for cuts. But that is not the proper economic comparison. Rather, it is more valid to compare the goods and services that consumers may be able to purchase of their own choosing with those that are imposed upon them by bureaucrats who rely on the taxing powers of government to finance their own initiatives and pet programs.
 
PATRICK A. GAUGHAN
Dir., N.Y.-N.J. Economic Research
Center, Fairleigh Dickinson U.
Madison, N.J., Jan. 5, 1996

HEADLINE: New Balloon Technology Stars In a World Race With No Trophy

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
WITH the morning sun gleaming from its aluminized plastic skin, a 150-foot-high balloon piloted by a lone American rose above South Dakota yesterday to begin a race in which three teams will try to be the first balloonists to circle the globe nonstop.
Cheers rose from a crowd as the huge balloon, the Solo Challenger, climbed smoothly away from the Stratobowl, a natural rock formation near Rapid City that offers protection from the wind on three sides. At the controls for the perilous trip, which is expected to last at least two weeks, was Steve Fossett, a 51-year-old commodities broker, yachtsman and champion balloonist. 
 No balloonist has ever succeeded in circling the earth nonstop, and Mr. Fossett is the first to attempt the trip without a crew. Two competing teams of balloonists, one British and one Dutch, expect to launch next week. Both groups believe they can make much better time than Mr. Fossett because they will fly at higher altitudes, where the speed of the jet stream is greater. The speed of the jet stream can be as great as 200 miles an hour, but a balloon riding the wind is subject to no aerodynamic buffeting and the crew feels no sensation of speed except by observing the craft's rapid progress over land or sea.
The Solo Challenger, with its unpressurized pilot capsule, quickly ascended more than 6,000 feet and entered a wind system expected to carry it over Nebraska, Iowa, Missouri, Illinois, Kentucky and South Carolina, reaching the Atlantic coast tomorrow, said a spokesman, Timothy E. Kemper, assistant vice president of Loyola University of Chicago. Meteorologists forecast that after crossing the Atlantic Ocean Mr. Fossett would make landfall over Portugal and subsequently fly across Spain, the Mediterranean and North Africa.
"New York's blizzard won't affect Steve at all," Mr. Kemper said. "He'll be flying at between 16,000 and 18,000 feet by the time he reaches the coast, and even if he should drift toward the storm he can easily get above it."
Because the Solo Challenger has a metalized skin, it will be visible from the ground for most of its trip.
The informal race, which has neither an organizer nor a prize, pits experienced long-distance balloonists and some new technical innovations against each other in a grueling and dangerous ordeal.
Each of the three balloons is setting out from a different country, Morocco, the Netherlands and the United States. Whoever (if anyone) first circumnavigates the globe will win the honor of an entry in the record books for achieving the last great goal of lighter-than-air flight.
The race will take place amid persistent fears that the armed forces of several nations over which the balloons may drift may open fire on the aeronauts, or at least force them down. Last September an international hydrogen-balloon race that started in Switzerland ended when two American balloonists were shot down and killed by a Belarus military helicopter.
Although all the crews in the forthcoming race have sought assurances of safe passage from the 100 or so countries over which they may fly, several governments have not responded. A particular concern had been Iraq, but Erin Porter, speaking for the British team, said yesterday that the Iraqi Government had granted permission to the balloonists to fly over the country. However, balloonists have also expressed concern about Afghanistan, Libya and North Korea, among other countries.
"The real risk for all of us is not equipment failure," Mr. Fossett said shortly before his departure. "It is the military risk. Getting clearance from government leaders -- even prime ministers -- is one thing. Getting the word down to military officers commanding border posts or fighters is quite another."
In some respects, Mr. Fossett's balloon is the most primitive of the three in the race. Accommodating only one person, its tiny capsule is too low for Mr. Fossett to stand fully. Because the capsule is not pressurized, he will have to breathe oxygen from a mask throughout most of the two-week trip, much of which will be at an altitude of about 20,000 feet. He will subsist on military field rations and 15 gallons of water. While some elaborately equipped balloons have plumbing and pressurized toilets, Mr. Fossett has only a bucket, which will be emptied through a hatch.
Mr. Fossett takes pride in having launched his project on a shoestring. The cost of his balloon and related expenses, he said yesterday, is $300,000, all paid by Mr. Fossett himself. The competing British and Dutch teams spent $5 million to $7 million, Mr. Fossett estimated, both financed by advertising sponsors. Neither the British nor the Dutch team has disclosed the cost of its balloon.
But the Solo Challenger, built by the British designer Don Cameron, has some innovations that may help it. Among its instruments is a newly devised automatic pilot that senses altitude, and fires up the propane burners to keep the balloon from descending when temperatures drop at night. This will permit Mr. Fossett to sleep for short periods.
The Solo Challenger is also equipped with a reflective Mylar tent extending over the top of the balloon. The tent is held up by a small helium balloon instead of a tent pole, and a solar-powered fan circulates cool air between the tent and the top of the balloon to prevent overheating during daylight hours.
Shortly after Mr. Fossett's launching yesterday his competitors sent him telegrams of congratulation.
The British balloon, called the Virgin Global Challenger, is to be flown by Richard Branson, chairman of Virgin Atlantic Airways; Per Lindstrand, chairman of Lindstrand Balloons Ltd. of Oswestry, England, and an Irish balloonist, Rory McCarthy. Mr. Branson and Mr. Lindstrand, who have set several ballooning records, were the first pilots of hot-air balloons to cross both the Atlantic Ocean, in 1987, and the Pacific, in 1991.
Mr. Lindstrand said that because of unfavorable weather patterns over England he and his colleagues had decided to launch their Virgin Global Challenger from a military airfield at Marrakech, Morocco.
To move the big crew capsule, balloon and accessories, the British group chartered a Beluga transport plane -- a modified Airbus 300 similar to the Pregnant Guppy aircraft used by NASA to transport large rocket components. The flight to Morocco is scheduled for Friday, and Mr. Lindstrand said the balloon launching would probably take place a day or so later.
Mr. Branson, chairman of the multifaceted Virgin Group, which includes Virgin Atlantic Airways, believes that his competitor, Mr. Fossett, faces grave risks.
"Because his capsule is not pressurized," Mr. Branson said in an interview, "Steve will have to stay at around 20,000 feet, which is usually well below the core of the jet stream. That could slow him down a lot. We will be at 30,000 to 35,000 feet, where our chances of riding the high-speed jet stream are much better.
"Steve is incredibly brave, and if anyone should beat us, I'd rather it was he."
The Dutch team, led by Henk Brink, recently tested the inflation of its Unicef Flyer balloon at Cape Kennedy in NASA's huge Vehicle Assembly Building, where space shuttles are prepared for flight. Mr. Brink, who intends to launch his balloon from Nijmegen, the Netherlands, is a helicopter instructor and veteran balloonist. In 1986, he, his wife, Evelien, and William Hageman, a Dutch fighter pilot, became the first European balloonists to cross the Atlantic; so precise was their navigation that they landed within a few miles of Mr. Brink's home in the Netherlands.
Although balloons must travel in the same direction as the wind that carries them along, a pilot can navigate to some extent by changing altitude to seek wind headed in the desired direction. Even a small change in altitude can result in a large change in direction.
The Unicef Flyer flight suffered a setback on Dec. 26 when its third crew member, Wouter Bakker, resigned from the flight crew "for personal reasons." Days before the expected launching this week, Mr. Brink said in an interview that he had advertised for a replacement, stipulating that the third crew member should be an airline captain. "We're down to three candidates," Mr. Brink said on Friday, "and all of them are completely familiar with our navigation and communication equipment. For the launch and landing, I will do the piloting."
All three teams are flying Rozier balloons -- a type that has achieved many long-distance records in recent years. A modern Rozier is kept aloft by helium gas, but to add extra lift, the balloon is compartmentalized and the lower part can be filled with hot air from a gas burner. This enables the balloon to maintain altitude at night, when cold air and the lack of sunlight cools the helium and lessens its lifting power.
Since the first manned balloon flight in 1783 by Jean Francois Pilatre de Rozier and the Marquis Francois Laurent d'Arlandes in a Montgolfier hot-air balloon, many balloonists have attempted round-the-world flights, but all have failed, and some have died trying. Five unsuccessful attempts were made by a single team led by Larry Newman of Scottsdale, Ariz., in his Earthwinds balloon before Mr. Newman abandoned his efforts one year ago.
The Rozier balloon is named after its inventor, who was forced to use inflammable hydrogen in his 18th-century version, since a century was to pass before the discovery of nonflammable helium. Rozier was killed in 1785 while trying to cross the English Channel; his hydrogen-and-hot-air hybrid balloon caught fire and crashed.
From that time until 1960, balloonists relied almost exclusively on hydrogen or helium for lift, since hot-air burners were regarded as too dangerous.

HEADLINE: Trump Moves to Put Taj Mahal in His Company

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

 BODY:
In a sign that his financial recovery is gathering speed, Donald J. Trump moved yesterday to fold his Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City into his publicly traded casino company.
Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts, his publicly traded company, is doing well enough that Mr. Trump expects to attract new investors. He plans to raise $59 million in equity above the costs of transferring ownership of the Taj. 
 Trump Hotels is offering to buy 1.35 million class A shares of the Taj Mahal Holding Corporation for $30 in cash or in Trump Hotels stock. That values those shares, which equal half of the Taj equity, at $40.5 million.
For his own half, Mr. Trump is to receive additional stock in Trump Hotels. Alan C. Marcus, a Trump spokesman, said that "to my knowledge" Mr. Trump would not get any cash out of the deal. Trump Hotels expects to issue $140 million in new stock to make the offer to shareholders and to raise cash. In addition, to replace the existing Taj bonds, $750 million of new debt will be sold by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Mr. Marcus said. That would value the Taj at about $890 million.
Because Mr. Trump owns about 40 percent of Trump Hotels, and half of the Taj, the deal announced yesterday could slightly increase his stake in the publicly traded company. Mr. Marcus said he did not believe Mr. Trump's share would exceed 44 percent when the deal was completed, which he said should be in April.
Trump Hotels closed yesterday unchanged at $21.75. The 10 million publicly traded shares have risen 55 percent since they came to market last June at $14.
The deal announced yesterday is conditional on the stock's remaining at $20 or higher.
In many ways Mr. Trump's turnaround has mirrored the fortunes of the Taj, which opened in April 1990. The Taj cost more than $1 billion to build, but it failed to generate enough cash to make interest payments on its original $675 million of junk bond debt issued by Merrill Lynch. Mr. Trump's stake in the Taj was halved in his negotiations with bondholders and other creditors whom he could not repay as promised.
The Taj was a crucial factor in Mr. Trump's 1990 financial crisis, during which one of his lawyers, Thomas Cerabino, testified that Mr. Trump was just one day away from uncontrolled bankruptcy unless casino regulators approved a deal with creditors. In 1991 Mr. Trump prepared a document showing that he had $44.7 million in personal bills coming due and only $1.6 million in projected income.
Mr. Trump avoided financial collapse through a series of deals he and Stephen Bollenbach, then his finance chief, negotiated with creditors who were owed more than $3 billion. Last fall, Mr. Trump, in a speech, claimed he owed $8.8 billion.
The deals with creditors won approval from the New Jersey Casino Control Commission even though it found that he did not meet the requirement in state law that he prove he was financially stable. The commission held that since creditors were negotiating with Mr. Trump he might eventually regain financial stability.
Since 1990 Mr. Trump has been forced to relinquish most of his Manhattan properties, including the Plaza Hotel. But by focusing on his three Atlantic City casinos he has managed to slowly rebuild his financial position.
Mr. Trump also hired Dennis Gomes, a respected casino executive, to run the Taj. But last fall Mr. Trump and Mr. Gomes came to a parting of the ways.
Last year, the Taj won $506.1 million from players, up 9.7 percent from 1994's winnings of $461.5 million, or just about the same percentage increase as all 12 Atlantic City casinos.
But in December, the amount the Taj won from players declined 8.9 percent, to $38.9 million compared with a year ago, largely because the casino lacked the high-rollers that were brought in a year earlier by Mr. Gomes and his team.
Last month builders in Florida launched the Trump Princess, a 290-foot riverboat that is to open to gamblers near Gary, Ind., in April. The Indiana operation, owned by Trump Hotels, expects to draw gamblers from nearby Chicago.
 The article omitted the current findings of New Jersey casino regulators regarding Mr. Trump. They have found that he is now financially stable.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 13, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in some editions of Business Day on Tuesday about Donald J. Trump's latest casino plans misidentified the period in which, Mr. Trump asserted, he owed $8.8 billion. It was 1991; the assertion was made last fall.
The article also misstated Mr. Trump's ownership interest in his Manhattan properties. Mr. Trump retains control of some his Manhattan properties, retains a minority interest without control in others and has invested in additional properties.

HEADLINE: William Bloor, 86, Columbia University Treasurer

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
William Bloor, who arrived at Columbia University as a freshman in 1928 and retired in 1979 as its treasurer, overseeing a portfolio of $500 million in securities and real-estate investments, died on Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 86 and a longtime resident of the New York Athletic Club on Central Park South.
Mr. Bloor, who was born in Manhattan, graduated from the college in 1932 and joined the treasurer's office as a manager of buildings on Morningside Heights. He advanced to assistant treasurer in 1948 and became treasurer seven years later. 
 Mr. Bloor, who watched both investments and cash flow for Columbia, was in charge of the fifth largest university endowment portfolio in the country. In the 15 years since his retirement, the endowment has grown to $2.2 billion.
During his tenure, Columbia's neighborhood was deteriorating, and the university came under attack for its handling of its real-estate holdings in the area. Some community groups accused Columbia of seeking to drive the poor and minority tenants from buildings it bought for faculty housing.
One point of tension was the Bryn Mawr, a six-story single-room-occupancy building at the northeast corner of the campus that was a known haven for drug dealers and prostitutes. After quarreling in and out of the courts, Columbia and other neighborhood institutions took possession in 1965, and it was eventually torn down for a Barnard College dormitory.
In the 1960's, with economic and social conditions on the Upper West Side in decline, Mr. Bloor's office turned to investing outside New York City, including high-rise faculty housing just across the George Washington Bridge.
Mr. Bloor, who never married, is survived by a brother, James, of Hilton Head Island, S.C.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Hafez Answers Chris

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Sunday's column was about how Secretary of State Warren Christopher should address Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, when they meet in Damascus tomorrow. Here's what Mr. Assad would answer if he were speaking candidly:
Chris, it's good to see you again. I love it when you talk tough with me -- especially that line about how this is going to be your last visit to Damascus. Ha, ha, ha. You really crack me up sometimes. 
 Now you listen to me, Mr. Secretary of State: Do you take me for a fool? Do you think I just fell off a watermelon truck from Aleppo? We both know what keeps pulling you back here. I'm the moosehead you want to mount on your wall. I'm your ticket to a Nobel Peace Prize. Well, Chris, here I am. If you want me you'll have to come and get me, and it's going to take a few more trips.
Now Chris, you tell me I have to make a personal, emotional appeal to the Israeli public -- "a psychological breakthrough," you called it -- just like those bootlickers Sadat, Arafat and Hussein did. Chris, I'm not the President of Norway. If I were the kind of leader capable of personal, touching and emotional appeals, I never would have survived as ruler here for 27 years.
I've read my Machiavelli, Chris, and he taught that it is better to be feared than loved. Love is something people grant or withdraw according to their whims. But fear, Chris, is like a cold hand resting on your shoulder that you can't remove. Haven't you seen how my ministers tremble in our meetings? They are terrified of me. But you want me to persuade the Israelis to trust me? Trust -- that is such an American concept. Fear, Chris: ruling is about fear. You could use some of that yourself.
But Chris, it's not only my people who are afraid. I am too. I come from a minority in Syria -- the Alawite tribe. The Sunni Muslim majority here watches every move I make. They will pounce on me in a second if I go too far. I think about that constantly. Haven't you noticed that I never send Alawites to negotiate with you or Israel -- only Syrian Muslims and Christians? That's because I want them to be held responsible for any deal.
So let's be clear: I am ready to sign a peace treaty with the Israelis in order to get my Golan Heights back. I am ready to give them the security arrangements they need, provided that they give me the same. I am even ready to attend a signing ceremony with Shimon Peres. But I am not ready to embrace the Israelis or show them any warmth, and I am not ready to open the Syrian economy to their businessmen. You cannot force such a psychological breakthrough from the top. That can only emerge over time. I want peace, but without any ideological or human reconciliation with the Zionist state.
There is still plenty in it for Peres and his people. A peace treaty with me means an end to the state of war between Israel and its most dangerous enemy. It also means an end to the Arab-Israeli conflict, because if I do a deal with Israel, all the other Arabs, including Saudi Arabia, will fall into line. The Arab world comes with me. That is a big deal, Chris, and I will sell that deal to my own people in order to get back the Golan Heights, but don't ask me to sell it to the Israelis as well. To sell this deal to my own people I need to maintain a high level of fear. To sell this deal to the Israeli people, someone has to soothe their fears. That's not my thing. Peres is good at soothing fears. I'm good at generating them. Don't confuse our roles. I will deliver Syria; let Peres deliver Israel.
When the Israeli people see what's on the table -- peace with Syria and peace with the Arab world -- they will eventually come along. And Peres will come along too, because I will not only deliver him all of these strategic benefits, but I will get him re-elected as well. Maybe he'll even win like me -- with 99.6 percent of the vote! You know, Chris, after my last election one of my aides came to me and said: "Mr. President, you won 99.6 percent of the vote. It means only four-tenths of 1 percent of the Syrian people didn't vote for you. What more could you ask for?" And I said: "Their names." Ha, ha, ha.
So there you have it, Chris. I'm ready to do business with the Israelis -- but not therapy. I'm in no hurry, but it looks to me like you and Peres are, so you'll be back and your room at the Sheraton will be waiting.
