HEADLINE: About New York;
A Tepee Comes Down, and Hackles Are Raised

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
CHRIS RAMOS wants his tepee back on Rockaway Parkway. And his sweat lodge, too.
So what if the Canarsie man can go to Brighton Beach for a steam bath? He can't learn the ways of the Turtle Clan in Little Odessa. 
 Mr. Ramos is no holdover from Brooklyn's past, when Indian villages dotted its southern reaches. He was taken in by a broad-minded group of Mohawks who had built a small encampment on an unused strip of Parks Department land hugging the Belt Parkway. For weeks, he and his friends huddled inside the moist, meditative warmth of the sweat lodge as a medicine man taught them about Native American traditions.
Last Friday, he learned a really old lesson: the Government tore down the tepee and took back the land.
The Mohawks, who had ambitious, if unfinanced, plans to build a museum and cultural center on the land, said the Parks Department had reneged on its commitments after the parcel had been cleared of stolen cars, garbage and weeds. Parks Department officials lauded the volunteers for cleaning up the place but noted that the permit for the tepee and sweat lodge expired on the last day of December. Any plans to build anything on the site needed to go through the usual complicated process of permits, hearings and variances.
The Mohawks and their supporters feel slighted and unwanted after two months of sharing their culture -- actually a blend of different tribal traditions, since the sweat lodge and conical tepee are not part of the Mohawk way. Then again, this Brooklyn group is perhaps the only one to have elected a Jewish man, Morris Fischer, as a sub-chief.
"You don't have to be Native American to be down with the Native Americans," said Mr. Ramos, a 22-year-old unemployed painter. "The sweat lodge is actually very good for the skin, to tell you the truth. It cleanses the soul."
NOW he is searching his soul.
"Straight up, let me tell you, I'm a future Marine," he said. "Now I'm supposed to defend the same Government that takes people's rights away?"
The encampment went up in November, after the city granted the Native American Longhouse Society permission to erect a cultural exhibit for two months. Schoolchildren, neighbors from the housing projects across the street and long-time Canarsie residents soon made their curious way to the tepee by the Seaview Diner.
There were powwows where the locals got free food and native crafts, as well as smaller celebrations of Native American life, said Gia:iatah Crosstherivers, the group's medicine man, who said he was raised shuttling between Canarsie and Mohawk land in Canada.
"We brought them into our sweat, where they go through a cleansing process and bring them closer to Mother Earth," he said. "We educated them about the pine tree, the cedar tree and the red willow."
What the city taught them, he said, was the ways of the red tape. He did not have the right permits. The land belonged to the people of New York, even though the city had let it pretty much rot over the years.
He refused to take down his encampment, even though the permit for structures was good only for two months. After a few days of negotiations, Parks Department workers showed up with chain saws and removed the tepee and lodge.
"They took away my church," Mr. Crosstherivers said. "It was a General Custer type thing. That's the way I took it. Had I lived back then, they would have had no mercy on my people. Two hundred years ago, they would have killed everybody in sight."
Henry J. Stern, the Parks Commissioner, said he was ready to continue talking with members of the group about future plans as long as they showed community and financial support for their proposed museum. But he faulted them for not living up to their word.
"It undermines your feelings on how to deal with them if they're not responsible," he said. "You wish they would do something, but they must act responsibly."
MR. CROSSTHERIVERS dismisses such criticism as another insult in a long line of broken promises made by European colonists. And he is angry at what he says is the city's lack of concern for a burial ground in a wooded area near the lot. As proof, he said a parks worker once uncovered three skulls on the site.
Of course, this is Brooklyn.
"That was landfill when they built the Belt Parkway," Mr. Stern said. "It is thoroughly chewed up and excavated. They were more likely to be skulls from Bensonhurst or Bath Beach."
Whatever the case, Mr. Crosstherivers vowed to continue his quest in court and in the tradition of peace.
Mr. Ramos knows a few other traditions, too, like how to raise a ruckus.
"We could start some havoc over here, you know what I'm saying?" he said. "They're into peace. I'm into getting even."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Few Takers For Japanese Finance Post

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The job of running the world's second-largest economy is about to become vacant, and nobody seems to want it.
Ryutaro Hashimoto, who is expected to be named Japan's next Prime Minister on Thursday, is assembling his Cabinet. But he appears to be having a hard time finding a candidate for one of the most important posts: Finance Minister. 
 Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama's Cabinet will resign on Thursday, and the current Finance Minister, Masayoshi Takemura, has declined to be reappointed. Mr. Takemura's shoes are rather awkward ones to fill: He was chosen last year by Euromoney magazine as the world's worst finance minister for the year.
The field is wide open for replacement candidates, since a background in finance is not necessary. The minister relies heavily on the ministry's bureaucrats.
"Expertise or knowledge in finance should not be an absolute condition," Mr. Takemura told reporters recently. "It is very important to study the issues, but flexibility and a broad sense of politics is more important than expertise or specific knowledge."
Local news reports say that Mr. Hashimoto offered the job to Seiroku Kajiyama, a tough-minded, loose-talking leading member of the Liberal Democratic Party, which Mr. Hashimoto heads.
Mr. Kajiyama, who continues to be a strong candidate for the job, has a controversial past and no previous experience in finance. He is most remembered in the United States for remarks he made in 1990, when he was Justice Minister, that compared foreign prostitutes in Tokyo to American blacks who move into white neighborhoods and, in his words, "ruin the atmosphere."
Two years ago, there were reports in the Japanese press that he was under suspicion of having taken bribes, but no official action was taken against him.
Mr. Kajiyama is said to have responded tartly to Mr. Hashimoto's offer of the post. "Unless the person is willing to die for you, he won't be able to bear the job," he said, according to Asahi Shimbun, a leading daily.
Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, a former secretary general of the Liberal Democratic Party, is also a candidate for the post. But Mr. Kajiyama's gruff and firm manner may be exactly what Mr. Hashimoto wants in a Finance Minister.
"The next minister should be tactical and sophisticated," said Takao Toshikawa, publisher of the newsletter Tokyo Inside Line. "He wants somebody, a big shot, to make the Ministry of Finance's high-ranking officials become obedient."
The ministry, made up of the nation's most elite bureaucrats, is considered the most powerful institution in Japan. But the Finance Minister himself has always been a political appointee who sails in above the career officers and usually ends up having less influence than they do.
Still, for a politician, the post has usually been regarded as a highly coveted one, a prestigious and influential seat traditionally considered a passport to even better things. Mr. Hashimoto, for instance, was Finance Minister from 1989 to 1991.
But now Japan is mired in a mess of bad loans, and the next Finance Minister has a sticky mission ahead of him later this month: He must persuade the Parliament to dip into taxpayers' funds to pay for the cost of cleaning up some of the numerous bad housing loans. Whoever is chosen is sure to be savaged in Parliament by members of the other parties who are critical of the Government's bailout proposal.
"There is a Japanese saying: No one is willing to pick out the chestnut from the hot fire," said Toru Nakakita, a professor of economics at Toyo University. "This is going to be dynamite."
Moreover, other measures announced by the Finance Ministry last year may also come under fire. Plans for a sweeping overhaul of the ministry's management of the nation's banks have led to some calls for the supervisory function of the ministry to be split off and operated separately.
Some ministry officials fear that such a trend could bring wider demands to break up the ministry, which governs the financial markets, the banks, tax collection and the budget process.
"The new Finance Minister needs strong political clout and there are no volunteers," a senior Government official said. "This is a very difficult job at this stage."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Wariness About Federal Budget Produces Mixed Day for Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The uncertainty about the Federal budget continued to afflict the foreign exchange market yesterday, leaving the dollar mixed against major currencies as traders sought safety by nullifying their positions.
A report of an increase in unemployment in Germany and hints of lower interest rates there failed to have much effect on the dollar, leaving it unchanged against the mark. 
 The dollar changed little during the day against the Japanese yen, but finished with a slight loss, as traders apparently were unfazed by Japan's economic and political gyrations.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 104.65 yen, down from 105.30 late Monday. The dollar was worth 1.4395 marks in New York, unchanged from Monday.
Negotiations between President Clinton and Congressional Republicans were suspended yesterday afternoon after the two sides failed to reach agreement on a plan to balance the budget in seven years. Earlier, traders said they were hesitant to take strong positions in the currency markets as long as there was uncertainty about the talks.
 "This whole budget thing is at the forefront of everything; as the Republicans said, 'Today is the day,' " said David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, an investment advisory firm. "People are nervous. Nobody wants to be positioned either way in front of these meetings."
As the talks had dragged on this week after the end of the partial Government shutdown, the dollar appeared to be poised to make strong gains against the mark after two events in Germany.
First, the Government reported yesterday that unemployment surged in the final months of 1995 and that the trend was likely to continue into the new year.
Second, three officials of the German central bank said that interest rates could stand to be lowered again. The earliest drop, according to Johann Wilhelm Gaddum, a member of the central bank, could occur today with a change in the bank's securities repurchase rate.
When a country's interest rates drop, its debt assets become less attractive to investors, who as a result are less likely to buy the currency needed to acquire the assets.
But the dollar, despite rising temporarily yesterday, failed to close above its level of the day before against the mark.
Against the British pound, however, the dollar rose. The pound was quoted at $1.5487 yesterday, compared with $1.5520 on Monday.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Unemployment in Germany Rose to 9.9% in December

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Germany endured a barrage of negative economic news today -- in particular, that unemployment soared in December -- creating a sense of gloom that has not been seen since the country began to climb out of its worst postwar recession more than two years ago.
And if the conventional wisdom is true that as the German economy goes, so goes Europe, the reports mean that much of the Continent this year will see little growth, rising unemployment, depressed business and consumer activity, and a further falling behind the United States. 
 The federal Labor Office reported that unemployment in December posted the greatest one-month surge in years, rising to 9.9 percent for all of Germany from 9.3 percent in November.
More than 211,000 people lost their jobs, in part the result of seasonal layoffs of workers. But beyond that, high wages and an overvalued mark have made German exports less competitive, inducing companies to cut back work forces here and open plants abroad, according to Labor Office officials.
Factoring out seasonal shifts in joblessness, permanent unemployment increased by almost 70,000 in December.
So gloomy is the business environment that economists predicted that the country was certain to pass the psychological barrier of 10 percent unemployment early this year, and that more than four million people would soon be out of work.
Labor Minister Norbert Blum called the unemployment figures an "alarm signal of the highest urgency," and called on unions, corporations and Government officials to create programs to generate jobs.
A central bank official quickly said that such weak economic statistics could justify a lowering of lending rates later this week.
And Steven Englander, international economist at Smith Barney in Paris, said: "Germany is clearly very weak. I think this means that unemployment rates across Europe are going to remain very high and they are not going to come down any time this century."
Adding to the gloom, the Economics Ministry reported that manufacturing orders for western Germany fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in November, a harbinger of further weakness in the economy.
A survey of Germany's midsized companies found that 81 percent of them described the economic outlook for 1996 as "bad" or "poor."
And the highly regarded German Institute for Economic Research cut in half its forecast for 1996 national growth, to 1 percent from 2 percent, a rate that effectively means economic stagnation. A year ago, many economists were predicting growth this year of 3 percent.
Economists at the research institute said the moderate recovery from recession in 1994 and 1995 had been Germany's weakest postwar rebound.
So far, a full-blown recession is not being predicted either for Germany or Europe. That is mainly true in the latter case because some countries -- Italy and Spain, among them -- are not as weak as Germany, France, Switzerland or Belgium, and are expected to buoy the European economic region somewhat.
But the weak data mean that Europe's biggest problem -- persistently high levels of unemployment -- is not about to go away soon. There are now a total of 14 million unemployed, many of them with little prospect of finding anything but minimum-wage jobs.
And though generous social-welfare programs are now keeping the unemployed out of poverty, once such funds begin to dry up, European nations risk a kind of social problem not seen in decades -- structural poverty and the threat of social unrest.
Governments are also hard pressed to find solutions because they are under enormous pressure to reduce their budget deficits in order to qualify for participation in a common European currency, the first stage of which is to take effect in 1999.
Low growth means lower tax revenue and thus bigger budget deficits at a time when many are calling for relief from high tax burdens.
If there is hope among economists, it seems to be in the ability of Germany's central bank to take center stage and again cut interest rates to stimulate the economy.
Over the years the central bank, or Bundesbank, has rejected the idea of helping Europe as a whole by lowering interest rates, saying that its charter is to look out for Germany's economy and monetary stability. But now, conveniently, at a time when Europe needs economic stimulation, Germany appears to need it more, providing the bank with an acceptable rationale for helping the entire Continent.
While some economists have predicted another cut in the discount rate by March, others say that given the recent weak economic data, that could be moved forward.
Franz-Christoph Zeitler, a member of the Bundesbank's central council, said the bank might lower one short-term rate on Wednesday -- the securities-repurchase, or repo, rate. He said that the economic research institute's forecast had been too pessimistic and that 1996 national growth would be 2 percent.
But private economists remained grim. "So far, the labor market has not at all reflected the economic upswing of 1994, and there is little hope for this year, as well," said Holger Fahrinkrug, economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland here.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Drop On Impasse Over Budget

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The bond market fell sharply yesterday, posting its biggest decline in three weeks, after President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders broke off their negotiations on the Federal budget.
Investors are "truly scared of a problem in the budget process," said Fabio Savoldelli, who helps manage $68 billion of investments at the Chase Manhattan Private Bank in New York. "This really could have an unhappy ending." 
 The 30-year Treasury bond plunged about 1 point, or $10 per $1,000 bond, pushing its yield up to 6.11 percent, from 6.04 percent on Monday. Shorter-term interest rates also rose, with the yield on the two-year notes rising to 5.20 percent from 5.18 percent.
Bonds doubled a loss of about half a point after the budget negotiations were suspended until next Wednesday. "We have some fundamental differences," Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, said. The talks would be "in recess" until "the White House has new ideas to present," he said.
Many investors bought bonds in recent weeks to bet that Republicans and Democrats would set aside differences and agree on a plan to balance the budget in seven years. Such a plan would drive yields lower in part by curbing the supply of Government bonds.
The suspension in the budget negotiations is not expected to last past Wednesday, and President Clinton stressed the positive side of yesterday's talks. "We are moving closer together on the spending numbers," he said.
Even so, yields will head higher without a plan soon, said Eric Cheung, who manages $3.5 billion of bonds at the Wilmington Trust Corporation. "If everybody walks away from the talks, the market will tank," he added.
Investors have "high expectations for significant cuts" in social programs, said Kenneth Lynch, who manages $200 million of bonds at the Pitcairn Trust Company in Jenkintown, Pa. Republican plans still call for about $100 billion more of those cuts than the President will accept, he said.
Some investors say they are not rushing to buy or sell bonds based on each new twist in the budget negotiations. "After all the sound and fury, we still won't know for seven years whether it really does anything," said Jim Somers, who manages $2.25 billion of bonds at Martindale Andres & Compay in West Conshohocken, Pa.
Bonds initially rose yesterday after the Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim weekly same-store sales report showed retail sales slipped 2.6 percent for the week ended Saturday, the biggest drop in at least 10 months.
Later, bonds fell after a second study on the week's retail trade, by the Johnson Redbook Service, suggested that business could be better than expected. The service reported that January's sales were on track to exceed December's pace by 1 percent.
Even so, "any pickup in activity was pretty much a function of very heavy discounting that kicked in before Christmas," said Matthew Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston. "Budget news is still the single most important determinant of what happens in the market over the course of the next two or three weeks."

HEADLINE: John Gronouski, 76, Kennedy-Era Postal Chief

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
John A. Gronouski, a rumpled economics professor who parlayed an academic tax study and his ethnic background into a public service career that included stints as Postmaster General and Ambassador to Poland, died on Sunday in a hospital in Green Bay, Wisc. He was 76 and had lived in Green Bay since retiring in 1989 as a professor at the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas.
His family said the cause was complications from a stroke. 
 When he was tapped by President John F. Kennedy in the summer of 1963 to be Postmaster General, Mr. Gronouski was a highly regarded Wisconsin tax commissioner who had provided a crucial endorsement to Kennedy in the 1960 campaign.
Mr. Gronouski had a reputation as a militant Democrat from his role in an unsuccessful campaign to unseat Wisconsin's red-baiting Republican Senator, Joseph R. McCarthy, and as a tough-minded administrator who had revamped the Wisconsin tax system. But Mr. Gronouski had what many saw as an even more important political credential: his Polish background.
Mr. Gronouski was not only the first person of Polish extraction to serve in the Cabinet, he was also believed to be the first Cabinet officer to have actually earned a Ph.D.
Whatever reservations he may have had about being seen as an ethnic token in Presidential politics, Mr. Gronouski, whose mother was Irish, did not disappoint his patrons.
In his first 14 months in office, Mr. Gronouski, whose candor and pipe-smoking informality endeared him to the Washington press corps, held 63 news conferences, traveled 127,000 air miles, visited 132 cities and gave 445 speeches, an average of more than one a day, many of them to Polish-American groups.
But for all his political forays, Mr. Gronouski found time to become a highly effective postal administrator. Among other things he moved aggressively against racial discrimination in postal employment and spearheaded the transition to the five-digit ZIP code (after conceding that he did not know his own).
He also ordered bulk mailers to presort their own mail and moved to close many marginal post offices. It was a reflection of his unsentimental approach to postal economy that he endorsed a plan to save $4,417 a year by eliminating the rural carrier position in his own birthplace, the Wisconsin hamlet of Dunbar.
After being named Ambassador to Poland in 1965, Mr. Gronouski continued his barnstorming ways. Operating as what amounted to President Johnson's personal envoy to Eastern Europe, he used Poland as a base for what were billed as "bridge-building" trips to other Soviet bloc countries seeking to promote trade and other ties with the United States.
After President Johnson left office in 1969, Mr. Gronouski, who had helped run Hubert H. Humphrey's abortive bid for the Presidency in 1968, helped design the curriculum at the Johnson school in Austin and served as its first dean.
In 1977, he was called back to Federal service by President Jimmy Carter to become chairman of the Board for International Broadcasting, which ran Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty.
Mr. Gronouski, who grew up in Oshkosh, graduated from the University of Wisconsin before serving as an Air Force navigator on bombing missions over Germany in World War II. When his plane was shot down, he was forced to bail out and survived even though he had worn his parachute upside down.
After the war, he earned his Ph.D. at the University of Wisconsin, held a series of teaching positions, including one at Wayne State University in Detroit and wrote a number of articles on tax policy, among them a study of the Wisconsin tax system that led to a job with the state tax department.
In 1960, less than a year after he passed a civil service exam to become research director, he was named tax commissioner.
He is survived by his wife, Mary; two daughters, Julie of Seattle and Stacey of Green Bay; a sister, Rita Wilson of Sun City, Ariz., and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
As Snow Cuts Northeast Traffic, Prices for Gasoline Trade Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gasoline prices skidded yesterday on concerns about a drop in demand because of the blizzard this week in the Northeast, which brought East Coast traffic to a standstill.
The February contract lost 1.83 cents and settled near the day's low on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The exchange was closed on Monday because of the storm, so its full impact on prices hit yesterday. 
 "Any time you have the Governor of New Jersey forbidding people from driving, you're going to put a dent in demand," said Tim Evans, an analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group in New York. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had declared a state emergency and travel ban because of the storm.
The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York remained closed yesterday. On other markets, wheat and soybean futures surged in response to rumors of new exports.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 0.36 point from Monday, at 246.28.
Gasoline futures were also hurt by the latest industry data showing a rise of 5.1 million barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks.
Despite the storm and frigid temperatures, heating-oil futures closed lower, erasing sharp gains earlier in the session. Traders said the market was disappointed that crude oil failed to rise. Also, weather forecasts call for a warming trend over much of the nation later this week.
Crude for February delivery lost 31 cents and settled at $19.95 a barrel; February heating oil was 0.21 cent lower at 60.43 cents a gallon; February gasoline was 1.83 cents lower at 58.65 cents a gallon, and February natural gas was 1.2 cents higher at $2.928 for 1,000 cubic feet.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, optimism over exports propelled wheat and soybeans to substantial gains. The market was dominated by rumors that China was buying soybeans and possibly wheat, and that Russia was in the wheat market.
Wheat for March delivery gained 12 1/4 cents, settling at $4.95 3/4 a bushel, and January soybeans were 8 3/4 cents higher at $7.36 1/4 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Ex-Congressman Mike Synar, Oklahoma Liberal, Dies at 45

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Mike Synar, a liberal Democrat who served eight terms in Congress from the generally conservative state of Oklahoma, died of brain cancer today at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 45.
In the course of his Congressional career, which started when he was 28 and ended in a primary defeat in 1994, Mr. Synar took on the National Rifle Association, the tobacco industry, Western farmers who profited from low grazing fees on public lands, insurance companies and the predominance of political action committees in financing election campaigns. He refused all PAC offerings. 
 But it was his 1986 challenge to the constitutionality of a plan for deficit reduction that won him lasting renown. The majority of his legislative colleagues, including all seven other Oklahomans in Congress, backed the measure, called Gramm-Rudman for its Republican senatorial sponsors, Phil Gramm of Texas and Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire.
Mr. Synar was appointed to participate in the House-Senate conference on the Gramm-Rudman bill and succeeded in inserting a clause giving members of Congress the right to bring a legal challenge to its constitutionality. After President Ronald Reagan signed the bill, Mr. Synar took the case to the Supreme Court. His argument, that a provision intended to create an automatic budget-balancing mechanism was unconstitutional, prevailed in the Court.
At the time of his death, deficit reduction and budget balancing remained at the top of the political agenda for both Congress and the White House, but as a result of Mr. Synar's action, no more efforts are under way to deal with the issues by legislative fiat.
"I have probably been the maverick, the reformer, the outsider, probably more than any other person in the United States Congress," Mr. Synar said in 1992.
Those qualities showed in several of his votes: in 1991 against authorizing the use of force in the Persian Gulf and for a waiting period for handgun purchases; in 1992 to close down the space station program and to allow shifting of money to domestic programs from military ones, and in 1993 against requiring parental notification of minors' abortions and for increasing taxes. Although he often voted against President Clinton's programs, he listed himself as a firm supporter of Mr. Clinton.
While few of the causes he pursued in Congress resulted in legislative victories, the battles he fought remain high on the national agenda: raising grazing fees, changing campaign finance and banning tobacco advertising.
He said his political heroes were Thomas Jefferson and Harry S. Truman. In an interview last fall he said he had tried to emulate two of Truman's characteristics: "He fought special interests, and he told it like it was." Last spring he received the John F. Kennedy Profile in Courage award at the Presidential Library in Boston.
His defeat in a September 1994 primary in Oklahoma's Second District was a prelude to the Republican tidal wave that swept the House and Senate two months later. On its face, his loss by a mere 2,609 votes to a 71-year-old retired teacher who had spent only $19,000 on his campaign seemed a fluke. But Mr. Synar calculated that tobacco lobbyists, the National Rifle Association, Western cattlemen and other interests paid about $3 million to engineer his defeat. One opposition billboard carried the message "Stalin, Hitler, Castro, Synar."
"They basically poisoned the well," Mr. Synar said later. The Democrat who beat him, Virgil Cooper, was defeated in the general election by a Republican, Tom Coburn.
After Mr. Synar's loss, President Clinton appointed him chairman of the Federal Bankruptcy Review Commission. He also headed the Campaign for America Project, dedicated to changing campaign financing.
Michael Lynn Synar was born on Oct. 17, 1950, in Vinita, a town of about 5,000 in northeastern Oklahoma where his father, Edmond, was an agricultural agent. His father and five uncles have been prominent ranchers in the region. When Mr. Synar turned 6, his father bought him some cattle, which he raised into a small herd with the help of the 4-H club, the organization sponsored by the Department of Agriculture to instruct rural young people in modern farming methods.
When his college tuition bills started coming in from the University of Oklahoma and later from Northwestern University, Mr. Synar sold off steers to pay them. He also repaid the $7,000 loan with which his father had started the project. He earned a master's degree in economics at Northwestern and later a law degree at Oklahoma. Before entering politics he worked as a farmer and rancher and as a real estate broker.
Asked to define his "fondest memory" a decade ago, Mr. Synar chose being in 4-H, in which he was twice a national champion. He was said to limit his footwear to cowboy boots and a pair of jogging shoes.
Survivors include his father, of Muskogee, Okla.; a brother, Alan, of Edmond, Okla., and a sister, Edwina Synar of Atlanta.

HEADLINE: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE COST;
Some Businesses Get a Windfall, But More Suffer With the Snow

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
Mohammad Iqubal measures the blast of this week's record-book blizzard not in inches, but in dollars.
"I'm losing at least $180 for these past two days on my cab lease, and $100 to $120 a day in cab fares alone," said Mr. Iqubal, 26, who spent hours yesterday excavating his cab from a snowdrift in Astoria, Queens, only to have it blocked in by a parked car. "I've got to get my cab to the shop to fix the heat and the wipers, which aren't working because of the snow. I'm totally stuck." 
 Mr. Iqubal's livelihood was hardly the only one savaged by the snow. Countless businesses, even those that dug out and opened up yesterday, found themselves reckoning with one or two days of lost sales. Work left undone by snowbound employees hurt companies large and small.
Still, some businesses, from ski resorts to video stores, reaped serendipitous profits. And anyone with muscle, moxie or four-wheel drive could make a modest killing.
Jesse Sturgis, a Vietnam veteran who is blind in one eye, was raking in relative riches yesterday with a wobbly blue snow shovel and wet woolen gloves. After just two hours, seven snow-smothered cars and a snatch of sidewalk had netted him $70 and a cup of coffee -- enough that he snubbed a $6-an-hour shoveling gig on Riverside Drive.
"Everytime I see someone struggle with a car, I ask them if they need a hand," said Mr. Sturgis, wending his way via side streets from the Upper West Side to Harlem. "With a snow like this, might as well make me some money."
Commerce continued to be crippled for many retailers, taxi drivers, delivery services and others yesterday.
Federal Express, which normally picks up or delivers hundreds of thousands of packages a day in the Northeast, was experiencing what a spokesman, Bill Carroll, called a "real nightmare" with hobbled airports, messy roads and employees who could not make it to work.
Department stores, even those that were open yesterday, were facing losses of between $30,000 and $80,000 a day for Sunday and Monday, estimated Pamela Rucker, a spokeswoman for the National Retail Federation in Washington.
"When you have a snow closing, you don't recover that business," said Carol Sanger, the spokeswoman for Federated Department Stores, which shut 47 of its 67 Macy's stores Monday and all of its Stern's stores. "We're just happy this happened in January rather than in December."
Ronald Stoppelmann, owner of Irene Leasing in Long Island City, Queens, estimated that he had lost $100,000, with only 45 of his 170 cars running. "You cannot make it up," Mr. Stoppelmann said. "It's an impossibility. This business operates day to day."
Many restaurants across the region were closed from Sunday night until yesterday morning, faced with employees and food deliveries that did not arrive. And in Manhattan, hot-dog and knish vendors stayed inside, left without corners to stand on.
Father & Son Moving and Storage in East Flatbush had to cancel at least five moves in the last two days "until further notice," said Lisa Mills, the assistant manager. Not only is the driving tough, she said, but "it's really hard to move on the snow with dollies." Ms. Mills said some clients were worried about being charged an extra month's rent if they don't move soon.
New York's wholesale flower district, usually bustling at 5:30 in the morning with florists elbowing each other for flora from the Netherlands, Thailand and South America, was nearly deserted yesterday. Only a handful of the two dozen or so wholesale markets around West 28th Street opened, and all had closed by midmorning. And florists looking for exotic purple roses or rare orchids were forced to lower their sights to carnations and chrysanthemums that had been delivered on Saturday before the storm.
Even Elton John, across the ocean in London, suffered a bit of a slight from the storm -- an indeterminate delay in a delivery of digital audio tapes that a Queens courier service was scheduled to ship to him.
Grocery stores were a mixed bag, with some thrilled and some panicked to sell out of staples like milk, bread and meat. By yesterday, most were getting deliveries and bracing for another shopper seige in anticipation of more snow later in the week.
Prognosticators warned that the financial bite of the blizzard would ultimately be in the hundreds of millions of dollars.
Apparel merchants alone lost $400 million in the storm of January 1994, said Carl Steidtmann, an economist at Management Horizons, a division of Price Waterhouse, in Columbus, Ohio. The food business lost about $650 million in that storm, he said.
Insurance claims are sure to follow, for roof damage, frozen pipes, damaged cars. The 20-state storm of March 1993, the fifth most costly national catastrophe, resulted in $1.75 billion of insurance claims.
Still, there were small fortunes yesterday for the unemployed, the home-from-school, or those snow-savvy hustlers who got up at dawn and waited for blizzard-bound banks, pharmacies and other stores to open. Even a guest at the Marriott Marquis hotel in Midtown was picking up a little extra on the side, charging $5 to ferry other guests to boat and boutique shows at the Javits Center.
Video stores were flush with customers, hotels were stocked with the stranded, baby-sitting services, takeout restaurants and tow truck operators were making a mint, and car services that could get around found they could charge up to double the usual fare.
In Manhattan, though nowhere else, people swarmed movie theaters.
The more than 100 screens operated by the Cineplex Odeon Corporation were "busier than ever," said Howard Lichtman, vice president for marketing, "with managers sleeping over and operating the projection booths themselves."
Yesterday morning, Jeswand Singh's livery cab shimmied as he navigated 149th Street in the Bronx. The going was a little rough, but Mr. Singh could not be happier.
"It took me three hours to dig out, but I made $300 yesterday," Mr. Singh said. "I took someone 30 blocks, normally a $7 trip, and they gave me $20. People are so grateful to be taken even a few blocks that they give me really big tips."

HEADLINE: Ford, in a Shift, Is Offering Rebates to Increase Sales

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it had started offering $600 rebates and discount financing on nearly all its vehicles in an acknowledgment that it had miscalculated the strength of the market.
Wall Street analysts also said that the rebates reflected the strong reluctance of consumers to pay higher prices for cars. "The market in general has been very sticker sensitive," said Nicholas Lobaccaro, an analyst at S. G. Warburg & Company. For Ford, he added, "the first half of the year is really locked in to be pretty disappointing." 
 Ford said that it would offer rebates or discount interest rates of 4.8 percent over four years on most 1996 models sold through April 2. Typical interest rates on four-year auto loans are now twice that level.
No discounts were offered on Lincolns or several Ford models, including the Explorer, the popular sport utility vehicle; the subcompact Aspire, and the 1997 F-150 pickup, which goes on sale this month. The Bronco sport utility vehicle will offer a $2,000 rebate or the 4.8 percent interest rate.
Analysts generally agreed that Ford had missed the mark in its strategy to add as standard equipment some previously optional features and charge nearly $19,150 for the most basic of its Taurus models. That would be a 5.6 percent increase from the price of the stripped-down 1995 model, which came with a $1,000 rebate last summer. By contrast, the Chevrolet Lumina, a comparable sedan, starts at $16,355, while a Dodge Intrepid from Chrysler starts at $18,445 plus a $1,000 rebate.
Ford's rebates amount to "a recognition that the company has recently overproduced," said Scott F. Merlis, an independent automotive researcher based in Westport, Conn. "Sales were strong, but production was even stronger." He said Ford's per-vehicle incentive costs would probably rise $50 in the first quarter, to about $950.
The announcement came a week after Alexander Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive, had insisted that the company's vehicles were fairly priced and did not need the incentives recently introduced by the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation on selective models. He stressed then that Ford would not offer discounts on its flagship car, the Taurus, despite its disappointing sales in the fall.
Ross H. Roberts, Ford division general manager, insisted in an interview today that Mr. Trotman, "told you right last week; we had made up our mind to not put any incentives on it."
But then came the results of a test of incentives that Ford conducted last month in the Midwest. The test bolstered sales so much that Ford decided to offer incentives nationally.
In Cincinnati, one of the test cities, sales of selected vehicles jumped 22 percent and Taurus sales climbed 34 percent over the November sales.
The incentives are an embarrassing acknowledgment that Ford misjudged the family-sedan market, where the Taurus has been a best seller for years. Sales in the fall lagged behind 1994 levels, a downturn that Ford attributed to its decision to sell fewer Tauruses to rental fleets. But both customers and dealers have complained about the extensive redesign of the car.
Mr. Roberts said Ford had not misjudged the market. "We are just responding the way that other manufacturers have," with incentives, he said, adding that the Taurus was the industry's best-selling car in the fourth quarter.
The problem is that "the size of the pie" has been shrinking, he said, adding: "The car market has just not been that strong. We are getting a bigger piece of the pie than we had."
Mr. Lobaccaro, the stock analyst, said that on Wednesday he would probably lower his estimate for Ford's 1996 profits to $2.25 a share, from the $3.20 he had estimated in recent weeks and the $3.70 figure he had assigned in the autumn. "The earnings are clearly depressed due to launch costs" associated with the introduction of the new Taurus, Escort and F-150 pickup truck designs, he said.
As for Ford dealers, they praised the new sales incentives today, although several said Ford should have offered $1,000 rebates. Nevertheless, Doug Barbour, sales manager at Capitol Ford in Raleigh, N.C., said that even the $600 discount "should spur car sales significantly."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Two Cubans Prepare to Choose Teams and Cash In

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Cuban lottery is nearing a close, and Livan Hernandez is apparently about to win big. The only unknown piece of the lottery is which team will hold the winning ticket.
Joe Cubas, agent for Hernandez and a fellow Cuban defector, Osvaldo Fernandez, said yesterday that he has set noon Friday as the deadline for offers for the pitchers. He said he hopes they will reach decisions on the teams soon after that. 
 Cubas declined to discuss offers he has received for the two pitchers, but he acknowledged that one team, which he did not identify, has offered Hernandez a signing bonus of more than $2 million. If Hernandez accepts that offer or another at that level, it would be a record for a player coming into professional baseball in the United States.
Baseball executives following the bidding said yesterday that they have heard that the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, who will not even play in the major leagues until 1998, are prepared to offer $2.5 million and the Baltimore Orioles could go that high or higher, perhaps $2.7 million.
Hernandez, at the age of 20, is more highly thought of than Fernandez, who may be ready to pitch in the majors this season but who is 7 or 9 years older, depending on the source of his age. One executive said Fernandez was expected to receive a $500,000 signing bonus.
Hideo Nomo, who excited baseball fans with his major league debut last season, received $2 million a year ago to sign with the Los Angeles Dodgers. His signing bonus, however, is not compared with bonuses given college or high school players selected high in the amateur June draft because he had played professionally in Japan.
Hernandez is in position to gain a significantly higher bonus than a drafted player because he is a free agent. When he defected on Sept. 25, he became a resident of the Dominican Republic, as Fernandez had done two months earlier. If they had sought asylum in the United States, as other Cuban players had done previously, they would have been subject to the draft.
Cubas, a Miami-based agent, represents two other Cuban defectors, who learned Friday that they had been granted free-agent status. Larry Rodriguez, 21, and Vladimir Nunez, 20, pitched yesterday in the Dominican, Cubas said, with more than 60 representatives of major league clubs watching. The 6-foot-5-inch Nunez, Cubas said, is "another Hernandez with a better body."
Hernandez has received lucrative offers from, among others, the Yankees, Marlins, Orioles and Toronto Blue Jays. One executive said the Yankees were believed to have offered in the $1.5 million to $1.7 million range and the Marlins $1.7 million or $1.8 million.
Chuck LaMar, general manager of the expansion Tampa Bay team, said the Devil Rays had not made an offer but would by the Friday deadline. He declined to say if it would be $2.5 million.
Pat Gillick, the Orioles' general manager, who aggressively pursued Latin players when he was the Blue Jays' general manager, could not be reached to comment on Baltimore's economic interest in Hernandez.
Although LaMar didn't say so, the Devil Rays could develop a marketing program around the young pitcher and point to him as their likely starter in their opening game in 1998.
If the Devil Rays were to sign Hernandez, LaMar said, he would attend their mini-camp for signed players in May, then most likely start pitching for one of the three teams Tampa plans to have in rookie or short-season leagues.

 
 
INSIDE PITCH
 The St. Louis Cardinals continued building what they hope will be a contender for the 1996 season, acquiring pitcher TODD STOTTLEMYRE from the Oakland Athletics and signing second baseman MIKE GALLEGO as a free agent for $300,000. Both played last season under TONY LA RUSSA, the Oakland manager who has become the Cardinals' manager. To get Stottlemyre, who had a 14-7 record last season, the Cardinals gave the Athletics ALLEN BATTLE, one of their reserve outfielders, and three minor league pitchers who were high draft choices in 1993 and '94: BRET WAGNER, JAY WITASICK and CARL DALE.

HEADLINE: Expectations of Weak Earnings Contribute to Plunge in the Dow

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market fell sharply yesterday, pulled down by a selloff in technology stocks and wide-scale worries about corporate profits.
"Everyone came back from the storm and created a blizzard of selling stocks," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer of the John Hancock Funds. "We're getting into the earnings season and people are nervous." 
 Many big companies are expected to begin reporting their fourth-quarter results next week, and investors are increasingly concerned that the slowing economy will produce disappointing earnings.
Adding to the day's volatility was the breakdown in the Federal budget negotiations in Washington. Bond prices suffered sharp declines and the yield of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.11 percent, from 6.04 percent on Monday.
The Dow Jones industrial average sank 67.55 points, or 1.3 percent, to 5,130.13. At one point yesterday, the average was more than 80 points below the Monday close. The loss marked the Dow's biggest one-day drop since it gave up 101.52 on Dec. 8.
But it was the Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily weighted in technology issues, that posted the largest percentage decline among the key stock indicators, plunging 33.56 points, or 3.25 percent, to 998.81. This marked the first time that the Nasdaq closed below the 1,000-point support level since Oct. 10.
"Technology stocks were very weak throughout the day," said Arnold Kaufman, editor of Standard & Poor's Outlook. "Then that weakness spread."
Stocks were also affected by heavy computer-guided trading that set off the Big Board's uptick rule at 3:03 P.M., according to Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading. The rule, which curbs such trading in an effort to stabilize the market, was invoked for the second time this year.
Declines on the Big Board substantially outnumbered advances, 1,575 to 861. Volume returned to its recent high levels after Monday's abbreviated session, with 417.4 million shares changing hands, compared with 130.4 million on Monday.
The emphasis in the debacle, though, was undoubtedly on technology. The day began with weakness in Symantec, which said late Monday that it only broke even in the December quarter. Then further declines were sparked by pessimistic views about some semiconductor manufacturers by the Soundview Financial Group. By the close, the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index had dropped 14.99 points, to 179.6, about 40 percent below its peak on Sept. 11.
Among the decliners in this group were the day's most actively traded stock, Applied Materials, off 3 3/4, to 33 5/8; National Semiconductor, down 4 3/4, to 17, and Texas Instruments, off 3 5/8, to 45. Symantec, the second-most-active stock, fell 5, to 10 3/8.
Automotive issues were lower after the Ford Motor Company offered financial incentives on some models and reports appeared that more consumers are having difficulty repaying their car loans. Ford closed at 28 1/4, down 5/8; General Motors closed at 49 1/2, down 1 1/8, and Chrysler closed at 53 1/4, down 2 3/8.
Bank companies were also negatively affected by the higher bond yields, which usually narrow bank profit margins. J. P. Morgan declined 1 5/8, to 76; Citicorp dropped 2, to 63 7/8, and BankAmerica fell 1 1/4, to 60 7/8.
Among other issues, Rock Bottom Restaurants, which said fourth-quarter profits would drop below expectations, fell 3 3/4, to 9 1/4. Circuit City declined 1 3/4, to 25 1/2, after Merrill Lynch lowered its fourth-quarter earnings estimate. And Printronix slipped 1 3/4, to 15 3/4, after announcing a decline in fiscal third-quarter net income.
But Agouron Pharmaceuticals climbed 1 1/2, to 38 1/2, after announcing favorable test results from an H.I.V. drug. Herman Miller, which on Monday said its fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 40 percent, jumped 1 15/16, to 31 11/16. And HCC Insurance, which said it intended to buy LDG Management, gained 5 1/8, to 42.

HEADLINE: Lawsuits to End All Lawsuits;
Settlements May Limit Victims' Future Right to Sue

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
Imagine you are diagnosed with a disease linked to a toxic substance, but then discover you can't sue its manufacturer. The reason: A lawsuit settled years earlier limited your ability to do so, even though you never heard about the deal or met the lawyers who made fortunes supposedly representing you.
In a country where thousands of lawsuits are filed daily, the prospect might seem farfetched. But it is one that is increasingly being played out in courts nationwide. 
 A growing number of companies, desperate to limit their exposure to potentially ruinous litigation, are initiating class-action lawsuits against themselves. And they are getting help from an unlikely source: plaintiffs' lawyers. By negotiating settlements that cover those who may someday get sick from their products, companies are able to limit future lawsuits and cap damages.
The irony is that many of the same companies that say they are helpless victims of a predatory legal system are in fact aggressively using that system to protect their financial interests. In some cases, companies have offered to settle complaints on terms that can yield millions of dollars in legal fees. The opposing lawyers will then file and settle class-action claims against the companies resolving the claims of those not yet sick or injured.
Supporters of these so-called futures settlements insist they are an innovative way to unclog courts, cut legal costs and save companies from bankruptcy, while guaranteeing timely compensation payments to people who are truly ill.
Geoffrey Hazard, a legal-ethics expert at the University of Pennsylvania School of Law, said a recent futures agreement on asbestos claims would slash litigation costs. "The money is going to sick people and not the lawyers," he said.
But critics of the plans said they tempt companies and plaintiffs' lawyers to collude and ignore the rights of those who are not sick now but might eventually want to have their day in court. Some also regard the settlements as a de facto tort reform that supplements the broader efforts by Congress to rein in litigation against business.
"I think it is being used not for the class but against the class," said John Leubsdorf, a professor at Rutgers Law School in Newark. Deborah Hensler, director of the Rand Institute for Civil Justice in Santa Monica, Calif., added, "We are trying to bring people into litigation before their time."
Often class-action settlements -- like the pending deal involving suits over silicone breast implants -- seek to resolve both existing and future health claims at the same time. But the recent batch of cases is striking because they only cover future health claims -- those that may arise after the class-action suit is filed and settled.
Some plaintiffs' lawyers, public-interest groups and others have appealed court approval of the futures settlements, arguing, among other things, that future litigants are being stripped of their rights. But defenders of the pacts say that as in other class actions claimants who take part in the proceedings can represent those who do not.
In perhaps the most bitterly contested case, a Federal judge in Philadelphia in 1994 approved a $1.3 billion class-action settlement that would resolve up to 10,000 health claims over the next 10 years from workers and their families against 20 companies that once made asbestos or products with asbestos.
Lawrence Fitzpatrick, the president of the Center for Claims Resolution, a consortium in Princeton, N.J., that represents the companies, said they had sought the settlement so they could be more certain of their future legal exposure.
"One goal was to take asbestos litigation out of tort system," Mr. Fitzpatrick said.
The companies, representing 15 to 20 percent of the asbestos industry's liabilities, began the action by approaching two of the country's leading asbestos plaintiffs' lawyers, Ron Motley of Charleston, S.C., and Gene Locks of Philadelphia.
The lawyers agreed to file the action, but critics say the settlement sold future claimants short, providing them poorer terms than those Mr. Motley, Mr. Locks and other lawyers had just negotiated out- f court for a group of 14,000 workers.
Many of those 14,000 workers had no symptoms, but nonetheless received payments because they were exposed to asbestos. Together, the workers' claims were settled for about $215 million. Assuming an average contingency fee of 33 percent, Mr. Motley, Mr. Locks and lawyers associated with them netted an estimated $71 million in fees.
By contrast, the class-action settlement worked out by the two lawyers provides cash only for workers who actually develop an asbestos-related illness. Payouts to those who develop more serious diseases like mesothelioma, a fatal lung cancer linked to asbestos exposure, may take years, because the companies involved in the Philadelphia plan will only pay a specified number of claims annually. Similarly, only a specified number of future claimants who are unsatisfied with the companies' settlement offer will be permitted to go to court to seek higher damages.
Under the futures agreements, fees to plaintiffs' lawyers, which can range as high as 40 percent, will be cut to about 20 to 25 percent. But some lawyers, including Mr. Motley and Mr. Locks, are likely to do better than others because they have won higher settlement awards for their clients in the past.
Some legal-ethics specialists have accused Mr. Motley and Mr. Locks of selling out the interests of people who will get sick in the future for their own immediate benefit. "I don't think you want people who have a vested interest in cutting a deal deciding for you what your life is going to be like," said Susan P. Koniak, a professor at Boston University Law School, who testified in 1994 against the plan during a fairness hearing as a paid expert witness.
Mr. Hazard, who testified in the hearing as a paid expert favoring the plan, said lawyers could represent unknown, future clients with the same zeal they show toward current ones. "I don't go into shock when somebody says you can't represent someone you haven't met," he said.
Mr. Motley rejected any suggestion of impropriety by the plaintiffs' lawyers. He noted that a Federal judge had dismissed allegations of collusion in approving the plan. And, he argued, workers already involved in lawsuits deserved more because their claims had languished for years in courts -- a fate that he contended awaited other asbestos victims unless new ways continued to be found for dealing with the litigation glut.
"The horizon is even bleaker for asbestos victims if they don't seek alternative methods for dispute resolution," he said.
Legal experts say the 1994 Philadelphia settlement was the first such futures deal. Since then, at least two more have been struck. Among the knotty legal questions they have unleashed is this: How do you make people aware that they have a stake in a lawsuit if they have not even fallen sick?
Consider the case of Martha Parker, a housewife living in Winston-Salem, N.C. Mrs. Parker said it came as a shock to her when she was diagnosed in 1994 with mesothelioma. She said she had never worked around asbestos, but figures she was exposed to it as an infant during World War II, when her father and grandfather worked in shipyards where asbestos was used as insulation. "My daddy and grand-daddy used to come home covered in dust," she said.
Never suspecting she was a candidate for the disease, Mrs. Parker said, she paid no attention to local television ads instructing mesothelioma sufferers who wanted no part of the Philadelphia asbestos settlement to opt out of it. Though she retains the legal right to sue some asbestos manufacturers, her claim against the 20 companies in the Philadelphia case will be determined by an administrative board, not a jury.
Under the terms of the agreement, 97 percent of mesothelioma claims over 10 years will bring on average between $37,000 and $60,000, with the remaining 3 percent -- principally claims those from younger workers or those whose exposure was primarily to the products of the consortium's members -- could potentially bring more than $200,000. After 10 years, the companies can withdraw and face the prospect of being sued again. There is no bond to guarantee that the settlement money will last 10 years, but the court found that the companies had sufficient money to finance the deal.
The labor movement, which once took a united stand on asbestos litigation, is split over the futures deals. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. strongly backs the Philadelphia plan, but some unions and workers with asbestos-related illnesses have balked.
"I felt like my constitutional rights had been disregarded," said Paul Hildebrand, a former boilermaker in Parkersburg, W. Va.
While the Philadelphia agreement started out as a futures settlement, in other cases the prospect of future plaintiffs became more important as the case evolved.
In 1992, residents of Bryan, Tex., living near a chemical plant owned by the American subsidiary of the French multinational Elf Aquitaine, filed a lawsuit accusing the company of polluting local lakes and streams with arsenic, which can cause cancer. Though some health claims were made, the lawsuit principally sought costs related to property damage and creation of a system to monitor residents' health.
But Dennis Reich, a plaintiffs' lawyer in Houston, said that lawyers for the company subsequently approached him seeking to settle the lawsuit if it also included all future health claims from residents. Mr. Reich said that he had agreed to do so after reviewing the subsidiary's finances and deciding that it faced bankruptcy if it lost a major jury verdict arising from the pollution case. The company had already settled individual lawsuits from Bryan residents charging that birth defects and cancer had arisen from the arsenic pollution.
"When you are dealing with companies that are economically fragile, you have to decide whether to resolve the case in one fell swoop or on a piecemeal basis," Mr. Reich said.
The class-action settlement was approved last year by a Federal magistrate. But some lawyers, public-interest groups and Bryan residents have appealed the pact, arguing that the health-compensation component of the $55 million deal will expire in seven years -- too soon to cover diseases that can take far longer to develop.
"There are some people who are going to get some small pittance and if arsenic disease shows up in others at some later date they will be out of luck," said Mark O'Connor, an environmental consultant in Bryan, which is 100 miles north of Houston.
Knox Nunnally, a lawyer for Elf Aquitaine, said there was no evidence of any arsenic-inducted illness in Bryan. And Mr. Reich played down that fear, as well. "You are dealing with a risk level that appears to be small," he said.

Chart: "Settling Asbestos Cases"
 
Background
 A consortium of 22 countries faced over 70,000 health claims related to asbestos exposure. Most of the claims were bogged down in court and few were getting to trial.
 
Existing Claims
 In late 1992, plaintiffs' lawyers agree to settle 14,000 claims for about $215 million, including many claims from workers without symptoms. The deal generated an estimated $71 million in lawyers' fees.
 
Future Claims
 At the companies' request, two leading plaintiffs' lawyers who had just settled their existing claims against the companies filed a class-action lawsuit in January 1993 to resolve future health claims from workers and their families. In August 1994, a Federal judge in Philadelphia approved a $1.3 billion deal. It is now under appeal.
 
Those Who Will Collect
 Under the agreement, the companies will pay some 1,000 claims a year for 10 years. The claims will be reviewed by the companies. On average, payments on a claim related to a fatal lung disease will range from $37,000 to $60,000. Workers can still sue manufacters not in the pact.
 
Those Who May Not Collect
 Workers who have evidence of asbestos exposure but no physical symptoms cannot collect until they show signs of disease. Also, payments to those with more serious illnesses may be delayed for years and only a limited number of claimants will be allowed to sue later if they do not like the companies' offer.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

First Fidelity Securities Settles Kickback Charges
First Fidelity Securities of Newark agreed to pay $2.3 million to settle charges by the S.E.C. that it paid secret kickbacks to a former New Jersey county official to get lucrative bond underwriting business. The firm neither admitted nor denied any wrongdoing. The action is the first S.E.C. case brought against a broker-dealer firm rather than individuals for such payoffs.
First Fidelity, which First Union acquired last year, said it had installed new controls and dismissed two employees. [Page D4.]
 
Budget Talks Break Off
The Federal budget talks broke off, although President Clinton and Republican congressional leaders promised to resume bargaining next week. But it seemed less certain than ever that there was much left to talk about. Both sides haggled for four hours yesterday, then took to television to declare that they were marooned. Behind the scenes, the prospects for an accord seemed considerably bleaker on both sides. [A1.]
 
The bond market posted its biggest decline in three weeks. The 30-year Treasury bond plunged about 1 point, lifting its yield to 6.11 percent from 6.04 percent. [D5.]
 
Ford Offers $600 Rebates
Ford said it had started offering $600 rebates and discount financing on most of its 1996 models sold through April 2, in an acknowledgement that it miscalculated the consumers' desire to pay higher prices for more fully equipped vehicles. [D2.]
 
Group Seeks Internet Curbs
A leading Jewish group asked Internet access providers to refuse to carry messages that promote racism. The letter from the Simon Wiesenthal Center of Los Angeles is the latest in a growing effort to counter offensive material on the Internet. [A1.]
 
Economic Warning Signs in Germany
Germany said unemployment surged to 9.9 percent, in a report that pointed to gloomy prospects for this year, in Germany and perhaps in other parts of Europe. [D2.]
 
A Tough Act to Follow in Japan
Japan's Finance Minister, chosen last year by Euromoney magazine as the world's worst, is now expected to be named Prime Minister. And the official, Ryutaro Hashimoto, is having difficulty filling his old post. [D2.]
 
Judge in Huge Tobacco Case Dies
The giant class-action lawsuit against the nation's seven largest tobacco companies faced new uncertainty after the death of Okla B. Jones II, the New Orleans Federal district judge presiding over the case. His death will not immediately affect the case, however, because an appeals court is considering important issues. [D4.]
 
Blizzard Adds to Hotels' Troubles
Washington hotels lost 10 percent of their business during the Government shutdown, and now have to climb out from blizzard, as do many hotels and restaurants in the Northeast. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
The Unfulfilled Bargain

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Russian voters, scared by economic turmoil and furious about Government corruption, turned last month against President Boris Yeltsin's reform Government and toward Communism and nationalism. A nervous Mr. Yeltsin responded by replacing his pro-Western Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, with Yevgeny Primakov, a former spy chief. Perhaps these events will not slow Russia's traverse to democracy and markets. Perhaps there will be no resurgent militarism. But if democracy and markets thrive, that virtuous outcome will have occurred despite Western bungling.
The decisive moments came in 1991 and 1992. Mr. Yeltsin pulled Russia out of the Soviet Union, declared himself in favor of radical market reforms and democracy and appointed a band of enthusiastic reformers. Then, at the peak of his popularity, he turned westward for desperately needed help. What he got were boisterous promises and a bushel full of excuses. 
 What he did not get was cash. The West cowered. Vested interests pulled Mr. Yeltsin's fragile consensus apart. Reform policies floundered. The Russian economy sank. Voters understandably turned against the message of reform and its messenger. For the West, opportunity was squandered.
This is not merely historical hindsight. In 1991, as Communism was collapsing, prominent Soviet and American analysts -- notably Profs. Graham Allison and Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard and Grigory Yavlinsky, a Russian economist -- drew up a proposal known as the "grand bargain." The proposal called upon the West to help Moscow underwrite a specific set of market and democratic reforms. If reform stopped, the aid would stop. But the key proposal was that the West should risk hard cash early on, as market reforms were begun. The idea was to tilt the political scales in favor of the reformers.
Early in 1991 the idea of a grand bargain, as its authors noted, may have been premature. But it was not so a few months later when Mr. Yeltsin announced a radical plan for moving to a market economy and appointed the pro-reform Yegor Gaidar as Prime Minister. The proposal would have cost about $25 billion a year, of which only $3 billion would come from the United States. Russia, in return, would decontrol prices, privatize state-owned enterprises and control its budget deficit and money supply -- the rudiments of market reform. But price decontrol and other market reforms can be -- and were -- traumatic to people used to Government-supplied goods. The grand bargain would have put up a modest amount of cash to take the sting out of reform. Poland, two years earlier, had showed that Western aid tied to specific reforms could work. Indeed, Poland is now among the fastest-growing countries in Europe.
President Bush did not fully embrace the West-helps-early logic of the grand bargain. Neither did other Western leaders or important financial institutions like the International Monetary Fund. Promises substituted for action. Leaders decided that the possibility of political embarrassment that would result from losing a small amount of money on reforms that might well fail overrode the incalculable benefit that would follow if reforms took hold and Russia tied itself to the industrialized economies. The West provided some short-term credits that had to be quickly repaid. But, according to Mr. Sachs, it kicked in only a measly $1 billion in long-term cash.
No one can say whether a stronger Western commitment, and more active engagement, would have diverted Russia from its later mistakes -- notably an irresponsible monetary policy, the corrupt privatization of prized Government assets and the bailout of companies controlled by vested interests. But surely nothing was gained by denying Mr. Yeltsin help when he needed it.
Critics of the grand bargain point to Poland and Hungary, where, despite Western aid, voters have returned former Communists to power. But they should take another look. In each country, though Communists now run things, the far-reaching policies survived largely intact and command widespread support.
There are still reformers in the old Soviet Union -- in Ukraine, for example -- who are shakily pushing their countries toward markets and democracy. The lesson from Russia is that opportunities squandered are opportunities lost. MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Abuse of the Retarded By Their Caretakers

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Abuse of the mentally retarded is an investigative perennial. Expose is followed by reform is followed by expose in a dismaying round that leaves one feeling that nothing much can be done to protect the most vulnerable among us from the violence or neglect of their keepers.
In her introduction to "A Horrible Secret," tonight's "Prime Time Live" report, Diane Sawyer recalls the shocking pictures from Willowbrook, the once notorious symbol of the warehousing of the mentally retarded, which led to the closing or scaling down of many such institutions over the last two decades. This investigation, which Ms. Sawyer says took seven months and covered 30 states, found that inmates were still being tormented around the country. 
 Drawing on findings by the Justice Department, interviews with employees of a few institutions and families of the afflicted, and evidence provided by its own hidden cameras (starring one attendant who uses broom or fist or whatever is handy to discipline her charges), "Prime Time Live" reveals mistreatment in Tennessee, Alabama, Oregon and elsewhere. In some places, patients are merely ignored for long periods; in others, they are smacked, kicked, burned. One scene shows attendants folding laundry on top of a girl who is trying to sleep.
What sort of caretakers are these? Checking at an Oregon institution, the producers learned that 9 of 40 employees had criminal records.
What improvement is possible as long as the care of the troubled and troublesome is entrusted to low-paid, ill-trained people doing jobs that few want to do? The program answers that hard question with a wishful reference to the benefits of small community-based group homes. Now, where have we heard that before?
There's good news from, of all places, the Middle East. In a two-part report beginning tomorrow night, Adam Smith travels to Israel, Jordan and the West Bank city of Ramallah, which is now under Palestinian rule. "Adam Smith in the New Middle East" proves to be an upbeat journey: in Israel, Mr. Smith finds economic growth, and elsewhere a growing promise nurtured by hopes for peace.
Tomorrow night at 8 on PBS, Mr. Smith talks with Israeli officials, including Prime Minister Shimon Peres. Next week he meets Jordanian royalty, including Crown Prince Hassan, the brother of King Hussein and his putative heir, and Palestinian businessmen. They speak of the need to break down obstacles to mutually profitable deals and to a natural neighborly trade that has long been held back by enmity and boycotts.
The programs do not fail to note the disagreements within all the countries over future relations and the disparity between Israeli and Arab living standards, which may portend new sorts of troubles. But the main message is that peace and prosperity are healthy for each other.
 
PRIME TIME LIVE
A Horrible Secret
ABC, tonight at 10
(Channel 7 in New York)
 
Terri Lichstein, producer; Ira Rosen, senior producer; Ed Delgado, editor; Phyllis McGrady, executive producer. Diane Sawyer, reporter.
