HEADLINE: AT BREAKFAST WITH: Godfrey (Budge) Sperling Jr.;
Politicians and the Press, Once Over

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PASS the jampacked evasions and refried platitudes. It's time for another Sperling Breakfast, the symbiotic feast of question and answer shared for decades here by politicians on the make and political reporters on the make-and-break.
"Of course it's self-serving," said the breakfast host, Godfrey (Budge) Sperling Jr., a genteel Beltway legend impervious to suggestions that any one of the 2,800 breakfast interviews recorded thus far with politicians is as likely to find the attending columnists, bureau chiefs and reporters being had for breakfast on the half shell by the visiting politician as vice versa. 
 "They wouldn't be coming in if it wasn't self-serving," he said after almost 30 years of being the host for the informal early-morning parade of hungry Presidents and wannabes, political spin doctors and midwives in one of the capital's more long-lived, long-winded journalistic devices. "We all know it's self-serving and we all hang onto our wallets every moment. On the other hand, we don't hammer a guy on the head to show our manliness."
Mr. Sperling smiled handsomely at that as he nursed a paper cup of decaf recently at a different sort of Sperling Breakfast, a chat at his neighborhood McDonald's. He stops off there after a walk most mornings when he's not downtown at the Sheraton Carlton's Crystal Ballroom for still another 8 o'clock breakfast gathering of a score or so of scribes (no electronic news media) and a celebrity politician.
The breakfasts are on the record and can be unexpectedly important in a city where ranking journalists are ever hungry for fresh political characters to scout and new agenda items to mulch. Their own careers feed off those of the politicians. Images of rampant egos and catty talk of the near-greats and not-so-hots, of self-inflation and relentless ambition, serve to describe parts of the Beltway press corps as aptly as the candidates' roster.
"Those old guys with a forkful of scrambled eggs up to their mouths," growled one younger Washington reporter, speaking in the craft's preferred Washington mode, protective anonymity, and chafing at too many Sperling Breakfast assignments. "Then came Ed Rollins, self-destructing about the black ministers, and then Newt self-destructed about the Air Force One plane ride. And now the breakfasts are the hottest thing in town again."
Mr. Sperling accepts that ultimate compliment. Particularly since it was he who, with all his Midwestern Candide charm, innocently asked House Speaker Newt Gingrich how the Air Force One trip went. This prompted the Speaker to respond with his now famous "crybaby" rant about Presidential rudeness.
Mr. Sperling feels that the value of the breakfast was shown when Edward J. Rollins Jr., the campaign strategist for Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, arrived relaxed at the breakfast fresh from doing the usual riff of talking-head sagacity on television about the Whitman election victory as Governor in 1993. Basking off guard at the breakfast table, he casually bragged of spreading money to New Jersey ministers to suppress the black vote.
"He forgets that we've got arguably some of the best questioners in America," Mr. Sperling said of his regulars from mainline newspapers and magazines. "They're sitting quietly and aren't yelling, showing off to their publishers like you see on TV. But they're good."
By that lunchtime, the print reporters were filing stories in their favored "gaffe" genre, and Mr. Rollins was backpedaling, having been had for breakfast. "Not all of them got the import of the story right away," Mr. Sperling admitted, underlining the occupational risk of overanalyzing the shadows of the Washington cave in the name of news gathering and forgetting how to spot a breaking story.
"I love to get the stories," Mr. Sperling beamed quite simply after eight decades of life, including 50 years as a "newspaper bum" toiling here as The Christian Science Monitor's bureau chief and political correspondent. He has been roaming national elections since Truman gave 'em hell. He smiles happily from his alleged retirement at the simple joy of remaining in the know with his weekly Monitor columns and Sperling Breakfasts.
"That's what I still like to do," he said. "Just feel like I'm a part of what's going on."
He is. Mr. Sperling, who prefers his nickname of Budge far more than the Godfrey in his byline, was honored by the Establishment last September when President Clinton submitted to the Sperling group's breakfast queries and also presided over a White House celebration of Mr. Sperling's 80th birthday.
More significantly, nearly four year ago, before Mr. Clinton was a declared candidate, he volunteered on short notice for a Sperling Breakfast with his wife, Hillary. Mr. Clinton seemed determined to field questions about rumors of his philandering and so get credit for facing the subject head-on at the head table of the print pundits in a city where he was still a stranger.
"He was rarin' to go," said Mr. Sperling, who noted that his sedate regulars were reluctant at first to ask about the subject. But a Clinton aide had privately invited the grilling to better exploit the influential forum. Reporters concluded that Mr. Clinton in effect was attempting self-innoculation, rehearsing his television comments to come months later when he noted that, yes, the Clintons had problems like other couples but were determined to stay close.
Hardly all the breakfasts are that strategic. "Basically, all that happens is people come in, sit around a table, get some information, then leave," Mr. Sperling said, rating most of them, in retrospect, "a yawn." But they at least keep the press responsibly in the hunt during an era of television dominance of political news that veers increasingly toward the your-mother-wears-army-shoes level of confrontation between performance journalists and retread politicians. "I think people will tell you what they really think if you're at least civil to them," Mr. Sperling honestly insisted. "Not necessarily kind -- civil."
The breakfasts began accidentally in 1966 when Mr. Sperling thought some colleagues might want to meet someone he knew from his campaign circuiting: Charles H. Percy, the eventual Senator from Illinois and, for a while thereafter, a hot Presidential prospect. More candidate klatches followed. Because the group could not book a regular lunch spot, they settled for the breakfast hour that became the Sperling trademark.
The attending news organizations pay the cost, about $20 a head these days. For this they get, at a minimum, the chance to hear themselves sound informed early in the morning. Or they can wince at some of the first-name badinage and issue shorthand that seems to threaten Washington life with becoming an adjunct of television pretense. Or once in a while, they can come across news.
By contrast, Mr. Sperling is homespun simple over his own neighborhood morning decaf and apple bran muffin, a hungry old reporter leafing through newspapers at a McDonald's table, ignoring squalling children nearby. The host has a naive edge enviable for Washington. Spending too much time in his presence makes one feel that maybe it can actually be morning again in America.
Mr. Sperling, an octogenarian with crisp recall, remembers Gov. Ronald Reagan nervously combing his hair again and again as he first approached the Washington press corps by way of a Sperling Breakfast. Jimmy Carter seemed no less nervous there the first time he tucked into his grits.
Lately, younger reporters intent on capital immortality have shifted to cereal and fruit and away from the Sperling groaning board of bacon and eggs and fried potatoes. "Some guests never get a chance to eat," Mr. Sperling said. "There's no ceremony. We go to work and tell them the only rule: we're on the record."
Some politicians see the format as a challenge of one's openness and perhaps even courage. But the rap on the breakfasts, aside from the risk of premature boredom on a workday, is that their coziness can invite elitist, if not lazy, newspapering. Mr. Sperling warns the alternative risk is greater. "There's a certain purist who remains aloof, never to be 'corrupted,' " he noted of one sort of stylist. "But his copy will reflect that, because he hasn't really gotten to know these people. He doesn't have the story."
One guest proved hilariously aloof. "Remember Senator S. I. Hayakawa?" Mr. Sperling asked, recalling the idiosyncratic neo-conservative from California swept into the Senate by the voter backlash against counterculture student protesters. "He sat down as the group was just assembling and he hadn't said very much when I see his head droop down and I notice he's sound asleep," the breakfast host went on, obviously amazed at the memory.
"He sleeps for a while and I just let him sit there and we watch," Mr. Sperling continued, conjuring the ultimate riposte to the Washington press corps: a mover and shaker cutting zzzz's before their assembled power.
Thus went the on-the-record nap. When the lawmaker snapped awake, the Sperling Breakfast's grand mood of insiders' privilege was further punctured as the Senator put off questions, the better to wolf down the special breakfast he had ordered. "Four big sardines wallowing in some sort of thick mayonnaise, washed down with something that smelled like sauerkraut juice," the host remembered.
"It fairly turned our stomachs," Mr. Sperling concluded, laughing out loud over his McDonald's coffee at the surprises of politicians.
These days, Mr. Sperling is arranging the breakfasts at the rate of two a week as the election season looms. "Lots of interest, lots of interest," he said, invoking the news worker's mantra. "It's just like being a reporter," he said of the breakfasts. "You kind of set up a momentum in your life, and that's what we did."
After a half-century of questioning politicians for a living, the Sperling Breakfast host is far from sated. "It's simple -- all we're doing is sitting around and talking," Mr. Sperling said, sitting around and talking.

HEADLINE: Bad Weather? Just Wait

BYLINE: By John Harte and Daniel Lashof; John Harte teaches environmental science at the University of California at Berkeley. Daniel Lashof is a senior scientist specializing in climate change at the Natural Resources Defense Council.

 BODY:
As the Northeast bowed before an extraordinary blizzard, southern Californians basked in record-breaking heat. Some speculated that this freakish weather was further evidence of long-term global climate change. But focusing on individual events would be a mistake. Unusual weather conditions have always been normal.
This does not mean that global climate change is not occurring. A United Nations scientific panel recently concluded for the first time that global warming had begun and would intensify because of rising levels of heat-trapping gases emitted by burning coal, oil and natural gas. The magnitude of the change is uncertain, but over the next 100 years, the panel estimated, the planet's average surface temperature is expected to rise by 1.4 to 6.3 degrees Fahrenheit. 
 The important news about this projected rise is not going to break the way it does for dramatic weather. Continued warming is likely to result in a gradual parching of soil in many regions of the world, possibly leading to declining crop yields even as the global population rises. When does this trend become "news"?
Sea levels will also rise, slowly inundating Asian farmland, entire islands in the South Pacific and coastal cities and harbors throughout the world. Coral reefs will die in the warmer oceans, and grasslands will give way to desert shrubs that can survive on less water, reducing food for grazing animals.
Producers of coal and oil, as well as some economists, say that we should learn to live with these changes because doing so will be far cheaper than reducing carbon dioxide emissions enough to halt global warming.
Leaving aside the fact that such conclusions ignore potential social and ecological disruption that is difficult to put in monetary terms, a growing body of research and experience indicates that reducing emissions sufficiently is not only possible but makes economic sense. Although the challenge is greater in rapidly developing countries where energy demands are rising most, industrialized nations can lead the way in reducing dependence on fossil fuels.
The cost of solving environmental problems has routinely been overestimated. Take the ozone-destroying chlorofluorocarbons. Ten years ago, the chemical industry and other "experts" said that finding an economic alternative to these substances would be impossible. Yet once the industry was forced to find substitutes for them, under international agreements beginning in 1987, it managed to phase them out completely in two-thirds the time allowed for just a 50 percent cut, in many cases at a profit.
Or consider the shift in fuel economy standards. Before minimum standards were established in 1975, the automobile industry claimed that doubling fuel efficiency, as required, would force everyone to drive compact cars. Ten years later, the standard had been achieved, while the average size of a car had hardly changed.
Why were these estimates so far off? In part, opponents of the new regulations wanted to stimulate political opposition. But independent economists often made similar projections, apparently forgetting that political pressure spurs technological innovation. For this reason, some economists believe that the costs of stemming global warming will continue to fall -- but only if the pressure to change exists.
So far, the United States, with all its wealth and technology, has not made a serious commitment to reduce emissions. Only if we unleash our ingenuity to find solutions can we expect poorer countries to follow suit.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A new information technology center in lower Manhattan has so far leased a third of its space.

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein 

 BODY:
WHEN the Rudin Management Company announced early last summer that it was spending $15 million to renovate a vacant office building at 55 Broad Street and turn it into the New York Information Technology Center, some real estate people were skeptical that enough tenants could be found to fill the building's 400,000 square feet.
Now, a little more than six months later, 11 leases have been signed for a total of 39,134 square feet, and 17 leases, totaling 68,052 square feet, are out awaiting signing. One 24,000-square-foot floor will contain a Nynex lab, video teleconferencing equipment and long-distance learning systems to be used by several universities -- among them Columbia and New York University. 
 Add it all up and the total space accounted for comes to 131,186 square feet, or just under one-third of the building.
"That's a deal per week," said William C. Rudin, the company's president. "It shows that there's a market downtown -- that the skepticism was unfounded."
The 30-year-old building, at Beaver Street south of the New York Stock Exchange, had been the headquarters of Drexel Burnham Lambert and had been vacant for more than five years, since the investment banking concern went bankrupt. The moribund downtown real estate market had diminished hope that the building would come to life again. But the Rudin Company decided to install telecommunications equipment, fiber optic wiring and satellite uplinks in the hope of attracting some of the many new companies being created to plug into the computer and information explosion of the 90's.
The 11 leases signed range from 908 square feet -- for Intercom Online Inc. -- to 13,319 square feet -- for N2K Inc., a company that specializes in music, technology, multimedia and on-line services. The tenants also include the New York New Media Association, an organization of multimedia professionals, which is moving from 515 Madison Avenue to 1,659 square feet at 55 Broad. Annual commercial rents are in the mid-to-upper teens a square foot plus taxes and cleaning costs. The rents are considerably below midtown prices but in keeping with those in the high-vacancy downtown area.
Mr. Rudin credited Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Downtown Revitalization Plan -- which provides tax abatements to spur development -- for contributing to the leasing success so far. The building is eligible for the abatement so tenants will save thousands of dollars in taxes.
Mr. Rudin said that he expected the building to be fully leased by the end of summer.
In another downtown deal, Joseph Moinian, a developer who specializes in renovating properties, has purchased the office building at 90 John Street for $6.5 million.
Ron Cohen, a managing director at the Edward S. Gordon real estate company, said Mr. Moinian might convert the building's narrower sunny upper floors to residential use and keep the lower floors commercial.
Mr. Cohen, who brokered the deal, said that the 400,000-square-foot "class B-minus" office building between Gold and Pearl Streets had been troubled in recent years and had many physical problems, including difficulties with the facade. He said that renovations had already begun on the building, which is 32 percent occupied.
 
F.B.I.'s Queens Office
 The Federal Bureau of Investigation has leased 48,710 rentable square feet at Crossroads Tower in Kew Gardens, Queens, for its Queens offices. The lease, for 20 years at an aggregate rent of $28 million, was negotiated for the bureau by the Federal General Services Administration. The bureau is to move in late spring from 95-25 Queens Boulevard in Rego Park.
The 500,000-square-foot Crossroads Tower, at the intersection of the Interboro Parkway, Union Turnpike, Queens Boulevard and Kew Gardens Road, is the largest office building in Queens. Built in 1989, it languished in the real estate recession of the early 90's and fell into bankruptcy. When Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc. became its managing and leasing agent two and a half years ago, 60 percent of the building's office space was vacant. The office vacancy rate is now 7 percent. Tenants include the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance (41,000 square feet) and the Queens District Attorney's Office (45,000 square feet).
"Newmark has leased more than 200,000 square feet of space since we took over," said Brian S. Waterman, a Newmark senior managing director, who handled the deal with James D. Kuhn, the company's president.

HEADLINE: Early Ally of Suicide Doctor Now Faces the Ultimate Decision

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: FARMINGTON HILLS, Mich., Jan. 10

 BODY:
Dr. Jack Kevorkian was virtually unknown back in 1989, when Janet Good essentially started Michigan's "right to die" movement by founding a chapter of the Hemlock Society in her suburban living room.
Most would have thought Mrs. Good an unlikely crusader for suicide. A cherubic former state worker and wife of a retired police officer, she was a Republican, a nominal Roman Catholic and a grandmother. But when Dr. Kevorkian helped an Oregon woman with Alzheimer's disease kill herself in 1990, Mrs. Good leaped to support him, though he was condemned as a reckless publicity-seeker by other Hemlock leaders. 
 Since then, she has also become an important behind-the-scenes player in the Kevorkian drama, fielding calls from people seeking out the retired pathologist, referring the patients she deems to have serious needs and comforting those left behind by the suicides.
"Nobody else had the guts to help these people," Mrs. Good said of Dr. Kevorkian in an interview last week. "I was the one who was getting these terrible, hopeless, despairing calls at least three times a week. I knew how bad off many of them were."
The patients, she said, "deserved that choice."
Now she faces that choice herself.
Janet Good is dying. Her doctors have diagnosed terminal pancreatic cancer and say she has less than a year to live.
"My family took it harder than I did," said Mrs. Good, who is 72. "I am not thrilled, but I have learned to take things as they come."
Mrs. Good, a retired processor of unemployment claims, said that her belief in the right to die came naturally.
"I had seen my mother die in great agony and her doctors refuse to help her," she said, "and I have worked for civil rights and women's rights and human rights for many years, and this seemed to me just another right we should have."
She was elected to the Michigan Women's Hall of Fame in 1991 after successfully leading a drive in the 1970's to make sexual harassment illegal in the state. The state Hemlock Society chapter she founded now counts several hundred members.
"Janet Good has exactly the qualities society lacks today," Dr. Kevorkian said in an interview. "Integrity, honesty and capability."
The question now is whether Mrs. Good will ask the doctor for help: will she ask the man whose cause she champions to help her find what assisted suicide supporters call "a soft landing?"
Her first answer was no. She did not want to put Dr. Kevorkian in danger of imprisonment.
"The point is that I don't know what I want to do," Mrs. Good said last October. "Right now, I don't feel too bad, and right now I feel like I might just go on and die naturally. But I might change my mind, and it angers me that I don't have the right to do so and that by exercising what should be my right I risk putting a friend in danger."
Legally, any doctor who helps someone commit suicide in Michigan could be prosecuted. After a series of contradictory decisions, the Michigan Supreme Court ruled in 1994 that assisted suicide was a common-law felony. While Dr. Kevorkian has not stopped assisting -- 5 of his 26 suicides came after the ruling -- he already faces two trials, in February and in April, for suicides he attended in 1991 and 1993. The one time he was tried in 1994, a Detroit jury found him not guilty, even though he admitted to helping a man with Lou Gehrig's disease die.
To thwart such trials, Mrs. Good threw herself into a 1994 drive to collect 265,000 signatures to force a ballot referendum on doctor-assisted suicide. That effort failed, but it did not stop her involvement with Dr. Kevorkian's crusade.
"She is really a great lady," Cheryl Gale, the wife of one of Dr. Kevorkian's patients, said on Sunday. "She was always there for me after Hugh died."
Similar sentiments were voiced by the Log Cabin Society, a gay Republican group, which recently gave Mrs. Good an award for consoling AIDS patients and their families.
Being told that she had terminal cancer was not, incredibly, the worst thing that happened to Janet Good last year. Her eldest daughter, Donna Ungar, 51, had prepared a video documentary of the family to present to her mother on what everyone feared might be their last Christmas together.
But as the family gathered to view it on Christmas Eve, Mrs. Ungar had a heart attack and died in an ambulance.
Days before, Mrs. Good's husband, Ray, had heart bypass surgery, and Mrs. Good had to make the arrangements and appear at the funeral without him.
The week before her daughter died, Janet Good also indicated that she had changed her mind about taking the route of assisted suicide. Someone, she said, had got her "something I can use that gives me a choice if I need it," when the time comes.
And she said she also had changed her mind about having her hero assist her in death.
Dr. Kevorkian's continued conviction in the face of legal and public challenges, she said, has convinced her that it would be all right for them, together, to claim her right to die.
"I have been thinking about this," she said, "and now that I have a choice, I think it would be an honor to die with Dr. Kevorkian if he will agree to that, and if I need it. An honor indeed."

HEADLINE: Gold-Rush Town Tries To Survive on History

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: VIRGINIA CITY, Mont.

 BODY:
A year after gold was discovered here in 1863, the population swelled to more than 7,000 and this mountain-ringed town became Montana's capital.
But the gold quickly played out. The population dwindled and buildings were abandoned. The only thing that keeps Virginia City from turning into a ghost town are about 150 year-round residents who cater to the tourists who come to see a slice of America's frontier life. 
 But now the locals fear that the man who owns many of the town's historic buildings will pull the rug from under the economy by selling the structures and the thousands of artifacts they contain to out-of-state buyers, who might cart some of the historical contents away.
"If you were to board up both sides of town we'd lose 50 percent of the economy instantly," Darryl Tichnor, editor of the county's weekly paper, The Madisonian, said recently. "Then it would become another little place along the road with no meaning."
Officials at the Montana Historical Society, a state agency, and the nonprofit Montana Historical Society Foundation are scrambling for the estimated $6 million to $7 million it would take to buy dozens of buildings and log cabins and tens of thousands of artifacts owned by Ford Bovey, the son of Charles and Sue Bovey, who amassed the collection beginning in the 1940's. Officials of the groups hope to raise the money from corporate and individual donations and foundation grants.
Mr. Bovey said he wanted to sell the structures because he needed the money. He said the money he received from their opening to tourists had not even been enough to keep them maintained.
Despite the significance to Montana history of Virginia City and Nevada City, a smaller town up the road, partisan bickering kept the State Legislature from buying them last year. Then Federal budget cuts forced the National Park Service to drop a plan to purchase the towns.
"Our hope is a hero buyer will come in and buy it and operate it," said Thomas Cook, development director for the historical society foundation. "So far that hasn't happened."
Mr. Bovey owns about 21 commercial buildings in Virginia City, as well as 8 houses, an old brewery and a church, and another 95 structures in Nevada City, about a mile west on Highway 287. Nevada City grew when Mr. Bovey moved frontier-era buildings from around the state there.
Many of the old businesses in Virginia City are in their original condition, without plumbing or insulation. Owners sold their businesses to the Boveys and simply walked away. The shops are still crammed with the goods that were for sale the day they closed.
"We call it Williamsburg West," Mr. Cook said. "It has the potential to be a living history museum."
Some residents call Alder Gulch, the valley where the town is situated, the "cradle of Montana history." Gold was scratched out of the gravel in Daylight Creek in 1863 and within a year more than 7,000 people were here.
The gold drew robbers, and one of the worst was the local sheriff, Henry Plummer, who secretly led a gang of thieves known as the Innocents.
They plundered and killed until local businessmen formed a vigilance committee. Sheriff Plummer was captured and hanged in Nevada City in December 1863.
A month later, as hundreds of armed men surrounded the town to prevent escape, five men from the sheriff's gang were tried and found guilty. The next morning they were hanged from the rafters of a building under construction.
The Hangman's Building still stands, though it is abandoned. Boot Hill Cemetery overlooks the town and has the graves of 6 of the estimated 44 people hanged by vigilantes. The sheriff is not among them.
By the 1930's the gold was gone. Census figures showed 242 people in Virginia City.
Charles Bovey was from a wealthy Minnesota family, and the love he and his wife had for Western history led them to begin buying buildings and artifacts here and from around the state. Businesses they bought on the north end of town housed a brothel, a billiard hall, an opera house and a dry goods store that still has shelves full of new shoes, hardware and tins of food, all still wrapped in the original packaging and labels. There is a music hall full of coin-operated music machines, a shop filled with old wagons and carriages and an 1870's barber shop.
Wooden sidewalks line the street, and on a recent quiet afternoon the clump of cowboy boots on the planks echoed in the air.
In the summer, the buildings are open to tourists, and they include a live theater, a coffee house and several museums. About 300,000 visitors come through town each year.
"It's one of a kind," said Barb Pahl, a regional representative in Denver for the National Trust for Historic Preservation, a private non-profit group that is helping raise money for the buyout. "It's a real look into the past, and the only example of a first-generation mining town that's out there."
Many structures need repair and the artifacts are subject to freezing weather, sunlight and dust. The settlement, 60 miles northwest of Yellowstone Park, has been on the National Trust for Historic Preservation's top-10 list of endangered historic sites for three years.
"If it ended up in a mish-mash of private ownership the historic aspect would be destroyed," said Robert Gabler, the town's Mayor and the owner of a general store, Alder Gulch Outfitters. "We'd end up with 20 T-shirt shops."
But some people do not want what they call government "meddling." They are still hoping for a return to the days of the gold boom.
"If the Park Service comes in here they're talking about shutting us down," Ron Moen, who owns a mining and milling operation near Virginia City, said over bourbon and water at the Pioneer Bar.
"Gold mining's coming back," he said, as he threw a three-ounce gold piece on the bar. "I mined that, milled it and poured it. Gold will build a good economy here."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Virginia City, Mont., where 7,000 people lived in the gold rush 100 years ago, now struggles to survive on its history, with 150 year-round residents. (Jim Robbins for The New York Times)
 
Map of Montana highlighting Virginia City: In the days of gold mining, Virginia City was Montana's capital.

HEADLINE: Mr. Vallone's Brave Proposal

 BODY:
The physical condition of New York City's schools is a municipal disaster. Exploding enrollment has left children going to class in hallways, gymnasiums and even bathrooms. Meanwhile, leaking roofs, crumbling window frames and 19th-century heating systems are destroying existing buildings faster than the city can put up new ones. The present generation of New York officials has been painfully aware of the problem for a long time. But until now, no one has had the courage to tackle it.
In his State of the City speech yesterday, Council Speaker Peter Vallone tried to atone for that pathetic record of indifference. Mr. Vallone called for extending for three years the about-to-expire personal income tax surcharge, and using the $1.3 billion it raises for school construction. His proposal is sure to be controversial but is worthy of the most careful consideration. 
 The surcharge was imposed in 1990 to pay for the popular Safe Streets/Safe City police hiring program, and costs a taxpayer with a $38,000 income about $78 a year. It is scheduled to expire at the end of 1996. The Giuliani administration says it will be able to continue its successful anti-crime programs without the Safe Streets money. This is welcome news, which we hope will mean a heavier reliance on cheaper civilian workers to do office functions now performed by uniformed officers.
Mr. Vallone proposes that instead of letting the tax lapse, it be directed toward a new short-term purpose. Besides building new schools and renovating old ones, Mr. Vallone wants to put $50 million toward textbook purchases. This would address a second city scandal, the fact that thousands of New York children are learning from torn, worn and outdated texts -- 1959 science books, 1975 world histories that refer to the "ongoing" war in Vietnam, and typing manuals that were written before the advent of word processors.
Extending the income tax surcharge is a painful thought. The combination of state and local income taxes now leaves city residents paying the highest taxes in the country on their wages. A better option would be a complete overhaul of New York's unfair property tax structure, which penalizes businesses, apartment dwellers and low-income neighborhoods. But no politician has volunteered to take on the middle-class single-family homeowners who benefit from the status quo.
Mr. Vallone's alternative at least has the advantage of political practicality. He deserves applause for offering a serious proposal to raise the kind of money city school construction needs. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's only suggestion has been to sell the city's water system, in a paper trade that would raise only $200 million for the schools while casting a shadow over the city's fiscal integrity. Gov. George Pataki has been mum on the issue. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver of Manhattan supports the idea of fixing the city's schools, but has not been brave enough to come up with a concrete proposal to pay for it.
The bottom line is that the city will not be able to compete economically in the 21st century if its children have been taught to read in auditoriums where three different teachers compete to gain their students' attention. They will not be able to staff the next generation of offices with skills learned from 1971 typing manuals. They will not run the next generation of computers if their schools have antiquated wiring systems that do not permit the installation of computer rooms. They will not fill high-tech jobs with science skills learned in pre-World-War-II laboratories.
Most New Yorkers have no idea how bad the physical state of the city's schools is. But the politicians all know. They have taken the tours, read the reports, listened to the presentations. They have lacked only the courage to move. Now Mr. Vallone has taken the lead. The ball is now back to Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Silver and Governor Pataki. The city's children are waiting.

HEADLINE: A Letter to Religious Leaders Lands Ambassador in Trouble

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS 

 BODY:
The State Department's inspector general has recommended that the Ambassador to the Vatican be reprimanded because of a letter he sent to 1,000 American religious leaders last April contrasting Pope John Paul II's concern for the poor with Congress's efforts to rein in spending on Federal antipoverty programs.
An investigation by the inspector general found that the Ambassador, Raymond L. Flynn, had violated the State Department's procedures for clearing such public statements and that he had failed to avoid "the appearance of partisanship in the discharge of his official duties." 
 The investigation was undertaken in response to complaints by the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, who says the Justice Department should now look into the matter. The New York Times obtained a copy of the inspector general's report, which was dated Dec. 19, from the Senator's office.
Mr. Flynn, a former Democratic Mayor of Boston, was unapologetic when reached by telephone in Rome.
"It's not the process that Senator Helms objects to, but what I said about the mean-spirited, anti-poor, anti-immigrant, anti-working-class mood of the debate taking place in the Congress today," the Ambassador said. "It's the message he's attacking."
Mr. Flynn linked the dispute to his often-stated concept of the role of Ambassador to the Vatican as that of a globe-trotting advocate for the poor tethered to the Roman Catholic Church's involvement in humanitarian and peacemaking activities around the world. His approach has raised diplomatic hackles in American foreign policy circles and fed speculation that he has political plans back in the United States.
A letter of reprimand such as the inspector general has recommended would be a severe blow to the advancement of a career diplomat, but its significance to a political appointee like Mr. Flynn would be less certain.
In her report, the inspector general, Jacquelyn L. Williams-Bridgers, also rebuked State Department officials for what she described as laxity in enforcing rules on the need to clear statements that might appear partisan.
Asked to comment on the report, Richard M. Moose, Under Secretary of State for management, said yesterday that in part because of the recent partial shutdown of the Federal Government, no one at the State Department had yet dealt with it. In fact, Mr. Moose said, he himself was not even aware of it.
But, told of the finding of enforcement laxity, he said: "We take this very seriously. Some ambassadors are better than others about clearing statements with us."
The inspector general's inquiry was undertaken at the behest of Mr. Helms, who last July demanded to know whether Mr. Flynn's April mailing was sent at taxpayer expense -- it was -- and whether it violated an Ambassador's obligation to be nonpartisan.
The letter was mailed to the Catholic hierarchy and other religious leaders in the United States and included remarks that Mr. Flynn had made to a group of American graduate students in Rome.
The remarks, titled "From a War on Poverty to a War on the Poor?: The United States at a Crossroads," contrasted the American political mood when Pope Paul VI visited the United Nations in 1965 with the mood that Mr. Flynn said Pope John Paul II would encounter on his trip to the United States in 1995.
In his remarks, the Ambassador referred to "devastating budget cuts" since 1980 and said the 1992 Presidential election marked a reversal of "that insensitive policy." But now "Congress is tragically dismantling many of those antipoverty programs that we have spent 30 years creating," he said.
Mr. Flynn described much of the current opposition to these programs as "demagogic," "mean-spirited," "immoral and wrong," and at odds with the stance of both the Pope and the American Catholic bishops.
The inspector general's report said the mailing should have been first cleared by the State Department's Bureau of Public Affairs.
The report said the Ambassador had initially told the inspector general's investigators that he believed that his embassy had sent the mailing in advance to the department's Bureau of European and Canadian Affairs and had received no objection. Upon further consideration, the report said, the Ambassador recalled having instructed his deputy not to seek any clearance at all, because the process had taken too long -- or never even been completed -- in similar instances in the past.
The deputy told the investigators that the Ambassador's letter and remarks had been sent in advance to the Bureau of European and Canadian Affairs for its information rather than for clearance. But State Department records, the report concluded, show that the mailing was not received until the department's Vatican Desk had requested it, following an inquiry from The Washington Times.
In a letter to the Inspector General Williams-Bridgers last Thursday, Senator Helms said Mr. Flynn had deliberately tried to mislead her investigators and skirt State Department procedures. He suggested that the report be forwarded to the Justice Department for "additional actions."
Marc Theissen, a spokesman for Mr. Helms, said: "What it seems to us Ambassador Flynn is doing is campaigning for President Clinton before he's left his ambassadorial post. That may be a violation of the law, and it should be investigated by the Justice Department."
In the telephone interview from Rome, Mr. Flynn said he had sent four similar mailings to Catholic and other religious leaders without having receiving a formal clearance or an objection from the State Department. As for partisanship, he said: "I never mentioned Republicans. There are both Democrats and Republicans voting for the dismantling of these programs."

HEADLINE: New Admissions Policy Offered

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The San Francisco Superintendent of Schools has proposed a new admissions policy for the city's best high school that would require all students to meet the same academic standard.
The Superintendent, Waldemar Rojas, said on Tuesday that the change would improve the racial balance at the school, Lowell High School. Lowell compares academically with the nation's best public high schools, like Stuyvesant in Manhattan. 
 Lowell now accepts students on the basis of their junior high school grades and their scores on an entrance test. That policy resulted in an increase in Chinese-American students, now 41.3 percent. An additional 24.9 percent are from other Asian groups, 17.3 percent are white, 12.8 percent Hispanic, 4.5 percent black and 0.2 percent American Indian.
The district's settlement of a 1983 lawsuit requires that a single ethnic group not make up more than 40 percent of any school's population. In an effort to diversify the Lowell student body, the district instituted lower academic standards for members of ethnic groups other than Chinese-Americans.
Daniel Girard, a lawyer representing Chinese-American families in another lawsuit against the district, said Dr. Rojas's plan was positive but did not address the district's use of race to determine school assignments. The suit asserts that the district's school-assignment plan keeps Chinese-Americans from attending the schools of their choice.
Chinese-American students complained that they were rejected by Lowell even though they met higher academic standards than students from other ethnic groups.
Under Dr. Rojas's plan, 80 percent of Lowell's applicants who met the minimum requirement would be accepted. The remaining 20 percent would be admitted on the basis of academic achievement as well as socio-economic status.

HEADLINE: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE COST;
Experts Call It a Billion-Dollar Blizzard

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
This week's blizzard could end up costing the New York region more than $1 billion, economists said yesterday after roughly calculating the costs of storm damage and cleanup and the economic activity that was lost because of the storm.
Several economists said the figure, which some described as an educated guess, would prove insignificant in the long run because of the heft of the region's economy, valued by some at $650 billion a year. 
 But that was hardly consolation to the thousands of businesses and hundreds of communities suddenly faced with millions of dollars worth of unanticipated expenses and irretrievably lost income.
Even the most sanguine analysts pointed out that the economic damage done by the weather could multiply if more big snowfalls follow. And, sure enough, forecasters said another, though less powerful, storm is coming Friday.
"In an economy as big as ours, this thing does come under the heading of ephemera," said Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a private group that studies long-range issues in the metropolitan area. "But if we started to see a lot of these things, clearly it would make a difference."
Life was inching toward normal yesterday but had not yet arrived. Mail was being delivered, but shelters in New York City were still busy, and there was an unusually high number of complaints about lack of heat and hot water. Many subway and rail riders in parts of Brooklyn and from north and east of the city still struggled with their daily commutes.
Airport runways were open but air traffic, burdened with thousands of delayed travelers, was not expected to return to normal for several more days. Calls for ambulances in New York City were 20 to 25 percent higher than normal as people fell in slush or on ice.
At Kings County Medical Center in Brooklyn, Dr. Philip Rice, the director for emergency medicine, said there were numerous cases of broken legs and wrists, heart attacks brought on by walking in snow, and a few cases of carbon monoxide poisoning in those who had started cars with the exhaust pipe blocked by snow.
He also said some children had been treated for frostbite after they tried to make money working in the snow while wearing only tennis shoes. "I call those injuries of socioeconomics," Dr. Rice said.
The full economic impact of the storm will remain unclear for months, but some economists yesterday ventured preliminary guesses. Their numbers ranged from $1.15 billion for New York City alone, to $1.5 billion for the entire East Coast.
Alan G. Hevesi, the New York City Comptroller, said the storm cost the city government $28 million -- $21 million in overtime and other cleanup costs, plus $7 million in lost sales tax and traffic enforcement revenues.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani put the cost of snow removal alone at $36 million so far. A spokeswoman for the Mayor said the majority of that was overtime pay for city workers and payments to private snow-removal contractors.
Mr. Hevesi said the the storm had cost the city's economy between $1 billion and $1.15 billion in economic activity. The "gross city product," the value of the city's output of goods and services, is normally $1.1 billion on weekdays and $250 million on Saturdays and Sundays, he said.
Others offered more conservative estimates. Mark M. Zandi, chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, an economic consulting firm in West Chester, Pa., put the storm's economic impact on the entire East Coast at $1.5 billion.
"When we look back at this, it's going to have a very small economic effect," Mr. Zandi said. "People will put off their purchases, they won't forego them. In the grand scheme of things, it's very, very small."
David G. Hensley, vice president and regional economist at Salomon Brothers in Manhattan, said: "I frankly don't think this is a big deal. It's a big deal in the sense that it's very attention-getting and a big inconvenience."
Those who might disagree with Mr. Hensley's assessment include many retailers, some of which had not dug out and reopened for business yesterday. Sears, Roebuck & Company and Wal-Mart Stores were among the large chains that closed dozens of stores during the storm.
While some stores, including Bloomingdales, managed to stay open and reported land-office sales of such items as socks and pajamas, analysts said that overall the storm was likely to hurt retail sales for the week. Sales had already been depressed from what retailers had said was one of the worst holiday seasons in decades.
Businesses that were especially hard hit included many restaurants, theaters and companies that offer personal services that people could get by without. People forced to cancel a planned manicure or meal out were unlikely to go back and make it up. Location and access played an important role in determining whether business was up or down.
George Makkos, vice president of M & T Pretzel Company, which operates about 150 hot dog and pretzel carts in New York City, estimated that his company's income was down 90 percent in recent days. Those pretzel and hot dog sales will never be made up.
Cities and counties, too, found themselves facing significant costs. The New Jersey Department of Transportation spent $10 million clearing state highways; the New Jersey Turnpike Authority spent $2.412 million and the Garden State Parkway Authority spent $2 million, nearly all of its $2.5 million snow removal budget.
Officials in Bergen County, N.J., put their snow-related expenses at $794,518, including the costs of overtime, road salt and emergency management operations. In Hudson County, N.J., the biggest cost to government was expected to be the expense of carting off and dumping mounds of plowed snow onto county park land or into the Hudson River.
There was disagreement over the impact of the storm on sales tax revenues. Frederick E. Parola, the comptroller for Nassau County, L.I., estimated the lost income as being "in the hundreds of thousands." But Thomas Conoscenti, a regional economist who projects tax revenues for Nassau and Suffolk counties, said sales taxes would barely be affected.
"If you didn't buy it Monday, you got it on Wednesday, so there really was no problem," he said.
One place where the storm's fallout was felt yesterday was the Hunts Point Market, the arrival point for much of the fruit and vegetables eaten in the city. At 7 A.M., some 1,500 trucks were waiting to deliver four days' worth of produce.
Randy Lee, a driver hauling 1,600 boxes of tomatoes, had left Florida on Saturday night for a trip that normally takes 28 hours. His oranges had turned from green to a deep orange and Mr. Lee was getting nervous.
"This is crazy," said Ed Dawe, who had hauled 25,000 pounds of carrots from Toronto, Ont. Mike Segee, from Pageland, S.C., had 1,500 boxes of cherry tomatoes. "They ain't bad," he said. "But they're going to have to be eaten."
By late yesterday, the backup had cleared.
Elsewhere in the region, a few businesses were enjoying a storm windfall, of sorts. Arthur A. Surin, senior vice president and managing director of the New York Hilton Hotel and Towers, said the occupancy rate was 11 percentage points higher than projected, thanks in part to the blizzard.
Mr. Surin said some guests had been unable to leave, while others had checked in simply to avoid having to commute home at night. While the hotel had benefited, he said it could lose if more storms followed.
"You're talking to me on the 10th," he told a reporter. "It could be different on the 14th."

HEADLINE: BUDGET FOES SEE FIGHT CONTINUING TILL THE ELECTION

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
A day after President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders suspended their budget talks, the Republicans sounded increasingly pessimistic today about the chances of reaching a deal, and both sides spoke more openly than ever about fighting out their philosophical differences in the November elections.
The tone of the remarks, far more confrontational and downbeat than that of Tuesday evening, when the talks broke off for at least a week, was to some degree blamed for the drop of nearly 100 points in the Dow Jones industrial average today. 
 And the comments provided an early glimpse of the political themes that are likely to be sounded in a highly ideological election season.
"I am for the first time in a year pessimistic about the likelihood of our getting an agreement," Speaker Newt Gingrich said in Casper, Wyo., where he was attending a Republican fund-raising event. "It may just be that we need one more election. It may literally be that the Clinton Administration cannot agree to the kind of decentralization and lower spending and lower taxes that we represent."
Shortly afterward, having invited reporters into a Cabinet meeting at the White House, Mr. Clinton challenged the Republicans to agree to a seven-year budget-balancing plan largely on his terms, with only a modest tax cut. Then, he said, the political parties can make the Presidential and Congressional elections this November a referendum on the ideological issues about the role of government that have divided the two sides.
"This has nothing to do with balancing the budget anymore, nothing," Mr. Clinton said of the stalemate, noting that both he and the Republicans had now submitted visions of how to erase the Federal deficit by 2002. "We could balance the budget literally in 15 minutes tomorrow afternoon."
"Then," the President added, "we could have an election in 1996 about whether the American people agree with their view of Medicare or mine, with their view of Medicaid or mine, with their view of our obligations in the education and training of our work force and our children or mine, with their view of environmental protection or mine."
Mr. Clinton and the Republican-controlled Congress could yet strike a compromise, pressured by the public's dissatisfaction with political gridlock or by the behavior of the financial markets. Both sides have kept a wary eye on the markets throughout the months of negotiations, fearful of a fall if they failed to meet Wall Street's expectations of a deal.
In fact, late this afternoon, after a sharp decline in stock and bond prices, the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said in a television appearance that the Republican leaders were prepared to return to negotiations next Wednesday and that he was "very positive" about getting a budget agreement.
Those remarks were a turnabout from comments Mr. Dole had made on the Senate floor just hours earlier, when he said an agreement was possible but doubtful.
This earlier expression of pessimism reflected the reality, acknowledged by Democrats and Republicans alike, that with more than a quarter of the Government's 1996 fiscal year now passed, and despite 50 hours of face-to-face negotiations between Mr. Clinton and the Republican Congressional leaders, the sides had not found a way around profound philosophical differences over the size of a tax cut and how to scale back the Great Society health care programs of Medicaid and Medicare.
Even in his remarks later in the day, Mr. Dole said, "You know, we've got some fundamental differences." Referring to the Republicans' desire to turn the Medicaid program into block grants to the states, he said, "We have a fundamental different view than the President has on the ways that we think we ought to give more power back to the states, back to the governors."
Even if the negotiators themselves could strike an agreement, they would have to find the votes for it in the sharply partisan House. Many Democrats there would most likely vote against Medicare savings beyond those already supported by Mr. Clinton, and freshman Republicans are fervently committed to a tax cut far larger than Mr. Clinton wants. And there are political strategists on both sides of the aisle who are arguing that their party would have a starker campaign issue without a budget deal.
In their most recent offer, made on Tuesday before the budget talks were suspended, the Republicans proposed a seven-year tax cut of $177 billion. But the White House and Democratic leaders in Congress have held fast to a basic tax cut of $87 billion, which would be permitted to rise to as much as $147 billion if the economy did as well as anticipated over the next seven years.
Mr. Clinton has also remained adamantly opposed to Republican proposals to turn Medicaid into block grants, and to let Medicare beneficiaries establish private savings accounts to finance their health care. Mr. Clinton and other Democrats say these savings accounts would primarily benefit people who are healthy and wealthy, making the standard Medicare program a second-class offering for the poor and the ill.
The Senate majority whip, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said today that no matter what happened, the Republicans did not plan to force a third Government shutdown when a temporary spending measure expires on Jan. 26.
But it is not clear how Government operations will be paid for if no agreement is reached. One possibility is yet another stopgap spending measure, or continuing resolution, which would be the fourth since the end of the 1995 fiscal year on Sept. 30.
But some Republicans have suggested that the more likely tactic is further House passage of small spending bills for particular programs and departments. That approach would allow Congress to eliminate operations the Republicans dislike, by leaving them unfinanced.
The Republicans would remain unable, however, to make the changes in law that would rein in spending in the major entitlement programs. Those changes require enactment of a broader "budget reconciliation bill." Mr. Clinton has already vetoed one such measure, and the Republicans lack the votes to override him.
The Republicans are trying to woo conservative Democrats to their side to see if they can build a budget that would win enough votes to override a veto, or at least allow them to say that there is now a bipartisan budget that Mr. Clinton should accept.
Today both sides turned to an all-out battle for the public's support, with the Democrats attacking the Republicans' tax cut proposal and the Republicans questioning Mr. Clinton's sincerity in wanting a balanced budget at all.
As members of both houses of Congress began a two-week recess, Republicans headed to their districts with a sheaf of papers laying out their party's position on the budget and with instructions to campaign vigorously for it.
Standing on the Senate floor today, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Budget Committee and one of the chief Republican negotiators in the budget talks, helped kick off that campaign.
Mr. Domenici said Republicans had yielded to Mr. Clinton on virtually every budget issue, including the addition of about $60 billion in overall spending.
"There is no longer any reason for the President of the United States to say we need a budget that meets the values of the American people, that takes care of education, that takes care of environmental needs," Mr. Domenici said. "It's obvious that that $60 billion covers all these points and everything else the President has been alluding to."
Democrats sought to focus the debate on the Republican tax cut proposals, which, the Democrats say, would benefit the well-to-do. "The debate is no longer one about balancing the budget," said the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota. "Basically the issue is now the size of the tax cut, and who gets it."

HEADLINE: Man in the News: Ryutaro Hashimoto;
A Japanese Unafraid of the Summit

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Japanese Prime Ministers have tended to be weak and faceless, men who stand forlornly at the edge of the group photograph when world leaders gather and whose policies are soon forgotten even by their own countrymen after they leave office.
But as Parliament met today and formally elected him Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto made it clear that he aspires to be different. Sharp-tongued, short-tempered and arrogant, and instantly recognizable with his slicked-back hair and sideburns, Mr. Hashimoto promises to bring a more assertive style of leadership to Japan and to give his nation a more prominent role in the world. 
 As the Minister of International Trade and Industry, Mr. Hashimoto was at times hard-nosed and at times accommodating with the United States. And he has a streak of nationalism that could rattle some nerves in Asia.
Mr. Hashimoto, who has participated in two expeditions to Mount Everest without making it to the top, makes no secret of his desire to scale the heights of Japan's political world.
The fact that he has reached the summit today -- despite the fact that he is an unpopular loner among his colleagues and has some blemishes on his record -- reflects a belief by his party that an insecure Japanese public is hungering for stronger leadership, especially at a time when the economy has lost its magic, a huge earthquake and a subway gas attack have shattered the national peace of mind, and Japan has been locked in a prolonged political malaise.
Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama announced his intention to resign on Friday, and Mr. Hashimoto was a shoo-in because he was the choice of the ruling coalition, which commands a comfortable majority in both houses.
The 58-year-old politician is the president of the Liberal Democratic Party, and he will be the first Prime Minister from that party in two and a half years. The Liberal Democrats, who despite their name are politically conservative, held power continuously for nearly four decades, until they were ousted in 1993 after a corruption scandal.
Despite Mr. Hashimoto's decisiveness, however, most analysts do not expect him to bring about much change immediately. For one thing, he will still be operating in the same unwieldy coalition of his own conservative party and Mr. Murayama's Socialist Party. Moreover, Mr. Hashimoto probably will have no more than a few months in office before he calls new elections.
Mr. Hashimoto favors a stronger role for Japan in world afairs by winning a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council and sending Japanese soldiers abroad to take part in international peacekeeping operations. A more assertive Japan also could mean more independence from the policy lines laid down by the United States.
"Japan's relationship with the United States is extremely important," he wrote in his book, "Vision of Japan," which was published in an English translation in 1994. "However it is not something that we have to protect to the point of throwing away our national sovereignty."
As Trade Minister, Mr. Hashimoto resisted American demands in automobile trade talks last year.
But as Finance Minister in 1991, Mr. Hashimoto was instrumental in arranging a contribution of $9 billion by Japan to help pay for the Persian Gulf war. "He said 'yes' in 15 minutes," said Nicholas Brady, then the United States Treasury Secretary.
Some American officials have said they expect the new Prime Minister to be more active in deregulating Japan's economy and in defending the presence of American military bases in Okinawa.
But Mr. Hashimoto's nationalistic views could cause some concern for some of Japan's Asian neighbors, who suffered from Japanese occupation before and during World War II.
Mr. Hashimoto served for two and a half years as head of the Japan War-Bereaved Families Association, which represents families of soldiers who died in the war. He resigned from the group this fall, after being elected president of the Liberal Democratic Party.
The association's officials maintain that Japan fought World War II in self-defense. Mr. Hashimoto himself said in 1994 that it was a matter of "subtle definition" whether Japan was an aggressor or was defending Asia from the West. The association opposed having Japan apologize for the war, although Mr. Hashimoto, as a Cabinet member, agreed to the apology Prime Minister Murayama made in August to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Japanese surrender.
On the economy, business leaders have high hopes that Mr. Hashimoto will help Japan recover from its four-year slump. He has spoken strongly in favor of Government spending on public works projects to stimulate the economy and of tax cuts to help businesses.
Some analysts say Mr. Hashimoto is not really the reformer he appears to be. The Liberal Democrats, who draw support from farmers and small shopkeepers, have not been bold supporters of opening up Japan's markets. Mr. Hashimoto normally takes the side of Japan's bureaucrats rather than seeking to curb their power.
In 1991 Mr. Hashimoto resigned from his position as Finance Minister, in part to take responsibility for the ministry's failure to curb scandals in the banking and brokerage industries. In addition, his personal secretary admitted to having helped arrange illegal bank loans for close friends of Mr. Hashimoto, though Mr. Hashimoto himself denied any knowledge of the affair.
And Mr. Hashimoto has spent his career as a member of a corruption-stained faction of the Liberal Democratic Party. Ichiro Ozawa, another dynamic politician, who now heads the main opposition party and who ran against Mr. Hashimoto in today's election, was also a member of that faction and was a bitter rival of Mr. Hashimoto.
Mr. Ozawa developed into a master behind-the-scenes maneuverer. Mr. Hashimoto, by contrast, became known as a policy expert, which is rare for a politician in Japan, where most policy is developed by the bureaucrats.
Mr. Hashimoto was born in Tokyo in 1937. His mother died when he was a boy. He drew his inspiration for entering politics from his father, Ryogo, who although he walked only with canes or crutches as a result of a childhood disease, entered politics and became Minister of Health and Welfare.
After graduating from Keio University, the young Mr. Hashimoto joined a textile company. Three years later his father died and he won his father's seat in Parliament representing Okayama, between Kobe and Hiroshima, in western Japan.
Mr. Hashimoto has also served as Minister of Health and Welfare and Minister of Transportation.
He and his wife, Kumiko, have five children. In addition to mountain climbing, Mr. Hashimoto is an expert in kendo, the Japanese martial art of fencing with bamboo staves, which he practices on the roof of the Trade Ministry.
He is also an avid nature photographer and gives his own photographs as presents to his negotiating counterparts from other nations. Once, in an allusion to Washington's claim that Eastman Kodak is being locked out of Japan's film market, Mr. Hashimoto pointedly noted to Mr. Kantor that the picture he was being given had been taken with Fuji film.

HEADLINE: Shutdown Affecting Rate Policy

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Alan Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, said last night that the temporary halt in the Government's release of economic reports had made it more difficult for the Fed to set interest-rate policy. The Government has stopped publishing the reports as a result of the partial shutdown.
Speaking in New York at a conference of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, Mr. Blinder said the delay in economic reports would not prevent the Fed from considering interest-rate policy at the next meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on Jan. 30 and 31. 
 The Fed last cut rates on Dec. 19, lowering the Federal funds rate to 5.5 percent from 5.75 percent. The funds rate is the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans.
Asked whether the bond market was taking into account possible rate cuts of one-half of 1 percent by the middle of this year, Mr. Blinder said, "Half a percentage point or less." He declined to say whether he thought the bond market's expectations were accurate.
Mr. Blinder also said he thought the "natural" rate of unemployment was below 6 percent -- and probably closer to 5.5 percent.
That "natural" unemployment rate is the rate at which the nation's gross domestic product neither falls short of its potential nor exceeds it. That scenario is also associated with a stable inflation rate.
There's a short-term, temporary tradeoff the Fed must make between unemployment and the pace of inflation, Mr. Blinder said. Over the long term, policy makers have little choice because permitting inflation to soar will eventually damage job formation.
The unemployment rate was 5.6 percent in November, the last month for which figures were available. Consumer prices rose 2.6 percent in the 12 months ending in November.
On a day when the Republicans in Washington appeared pessimistic about the chances of an agreement to balance the budget, Mr. Blinder also emphasized the importance of deficit reduction.
"We believe it's very much in the national interest to get an agreement that puts us on the path" to lower deficits, he said.

HEADLINE: Dole Steps Up Criticism Of Telecommunications Bill

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Denouncing what he called "corporate welfare," Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, said today that a House-Senate conference committee should not approve the big telecommunications bill until the committee changes a provision that would give television broadcasters a chunk of the nation's airwaves worth tens of billions of dollars.
In a detailed speech from the Senate floor, Mr. Dole sent the clearest sign yet that he might block the telecommunications bill, which would overhaul laws for almost every segment of the industry. Mr. Dole has indicated that he is prepared to stand his ground against the politically powerful broadcasters. 
 The provision would essentially reserve a portion of the crowded radio spectrum for digital television services, like high-definition television, interactive services or the transmission of as many as six programs simultaneously over a single channel. Currently, one channel carries one program at a time.
Mr. Dole said that the Federal Communications Commission had estimated that the broadcasting spectrum that would be made available was worth about $40 billion on the open market, Mr. Dole said the taxpayers would be giving too much to big media companies.
"I question whether telecommunications reform is worth the television broadcasters' price," said Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader who is the leading Republican candidate for the Presidential nomination. "Let's, for the sake of taxpayers and for the sake of the American consumers, fix this one corporate welfare provision before we have to vote on it," he said.
Mr. Dole first objected to the broadcasting issue nearly two weeks ago. But today's speech was more detailed and carefully prepared, and he delivered his remarks in the televised forum of the Senate floor, where he would be sure they would be heard.
His opposition was the most serious challenge of the provision, which has been the focus of intense lobbying by broadcasters for years. Walt Wurfel, a spokesman for the National Association of Broadcasters, said he could not comment on Mr. Dole's remarks until he saw them.
But officials of the broadcasters' association have repeatedly argued that access to the spectrum is crucial to broadcasters trying to enter the digital age, who have said that they would give back their current analog television channels once viewers have made the switch to digital television. That change would require either new television sets or converters.
The F.C.C. is expected to give its stamp of approval later this year to a new broadcasting technology that was originally developed for high-definition television. The technology offers pictures with movie-like sharpness but can also be used to send any other form of video or computer data.
But F.C.C. officials, including the chairman, Reed E. Hundt, have been increasingly skeptical about simply giving every existing television station a second channel for digital services. Industry lobbyists have pushed hard for language in the communications bill that would take the matter out of the agency's hands.
In his speech, Senator Dole said the telecommunications bill did not guarantee that broadcasters would surrender their current portion of the broadcasting spectrum to the public, and that the bill would allow broadcasters to use the spectrum at no charge as long as they used them for advertiser-supported free television services.
"Let me get this straight," he said. "America lends broadcasters spectrum so they can increase their profit margins, but they don't think it's fair to pay rent."
The provision has long sparked opposition from consumer advocates and many conservative economists who have long argued that the broadcasters would be getting access to licenses worth billions of dollars at the same time that the Federal Government is selling licenses for satellite and wireless telephone services.
"I say hallelujah -- the conservative politicians are finally realizing that this is cyberpork," said Gigi Sohn, deputy director of the Media Access Project, a nonprofit consumer advocacy group that has argued that broadcasters should either assume heavier public obligations or help finance some public broadcasting ventures.
But the television broadcasters, who own stations in every Congressional district and are heavy political contributors through the National Association of Broadcasters, have until recently persuaded both Democrats and Republicans to lend them these licenses for a transition period of at least 15 years.
House and Senate negotiators thought they had reached agreement several weeks ago on the telecommunications bill. But the final agreements were disclosed only to encounter complaints from many rank-and-file House Republicans. None of the House Republicans have complained about the spectrum issue, however, which could prove to be a more difficult battle.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Filing Challenges To Candidates' Petitions

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The state's Republican leadership moved today to block anyone but Senator Bob Dole of Kansas from entering New York's Republican Presidential primary, saying that it would challenge the nominating petitions of two other candidates.
Faced with criticism that it was trying to deprive voters of a choice in the March primary, the leadership maintained that it was merely trying to insure that the other two candidates, Steve Forbes and Patrick J. Buchanan, followed the rules. 
 "The bottom line is that you have to come in here and demonstrate a modicum of support to get on the ballot," said Jeffrey Buley, who is on leave from his job as general counsel to the Republican state committee to work on the Dole campaign.
The party's lawyers filed notice on Monday that they were considering challenges against all of the petitions submitted by both candidates for the March 7 primary. Today, the lawyers said for the first time that they would continue the process of trying to remove Mr. Forbes and Mr. Buchanan from the ballot by giving election authorities a list of specific challenges to the petitions.
The list, which must be submitted by Tuesday, is being compiled by scores of party workers and volunteers around the state who are scrutinizing the signatures gathered by the campaigns of Mr. Forbes and Mr. Buchanan. All three campaigns filed their petitions last Thursday.
The Republican rules are the most complex of any state primary in the nation and have already scared off several other Republican Presidential candidates, including Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee, who are competing in most other states.
With the exception of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, nearly all of the powerful Republican officials in the state, including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Gov. George E. Pataki, are backing Mr. Dole, the front-runner in the Republican race. And without the support of the state party, it is difficult to enter the primary because candidates need a large staff to meet ballot requirements.
Under party rules, candidates must submit signatures from 1,250 registered Republicans in each of the state's 31 Congressional districts, or from 5 percent of the district's registered Republicans, whichever number is smaller.
The requirements are so arduous that several critics have filed a lawsuit against them. The suit is on its way to the United States Supreme Court.
Mr. Forbes, the multimillionaire publisher, spent about $1 million to collect enough signatures to get on the ballot in all 31 Congressional districts. Mr. Buchanan, the conservative columnist, used volunteers, mostly, to gather enough signatures in 17 of the 31 districts, nearly all of them outside New York City.
Thomas J. Spargo, a lawyer who oversaw Mr. Forbes's petition effort, said he expected the state party to file challenges even in districts where the Forbes campaign had collected two or three times the number of signatures it needed.
"They are not willing to give any of their voters a chance anywhere in the state to select the Republican Presidential candidate," Mr. Spargo said. "It is a defiant act against the voters."
Mindful of the criticism of the primary system, many prominent Republican officials have declined to discuss the challenges.
Mr. D'Amato's office would not answer questions about the primary but did release a statement. "People have preserved their right to give specific objections in the event that voter fraud is found," it said. "Clearly, Senator D'Amato believes that the integrity of the process must be protected."
Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's director of communications, declined to discuss whether the Governor supported forcing Mr. Forbes and Mr. Buchanan off the ballot. She said any decision on the challenges was up to the state party, not Mr. Pataki.
"If the petitions meet the requirements as set forth by law," she said, "then they will be on the ballot."
