HEADLINE: Yale's Labor Woes, In and Out of Class;
With Spring Semester Opening, Unions Threaten Shutdown

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Four years ago, unionized employees at Yale University pledged solidarity with graduate teaching assistants, vowing to strike if Yale refused to recognize a union the students had formed. The result was a symbolic one-day walkout, after the workers settled their own contracts, and Yale's continued refusal to recognize a graduate student union.
Now many graduate students are conducting a grade strike, refusing to turn in grades from classes they taught last semester until Yale recognizes them, and their leaders and union officials are again finding common cause in Yale's firm response against them. 
 Outside the Hall of Graduate Students today, as disciplinary hearings began for three graduate students taking part in the grade strike, union members -- from maintenance workers to secretaries -- linked arms with doctoral candidates in a peaceful protest. To dramatize their point, 137 of them refused a police order to vacate an intersection and were arrested on charges of creating a public disturbance.
With contracts for Local 34 and Local 35 of the Federation of University Employees set to expire Jan. 22, and Yale seeking substantial concessions from them, the pledge of solidarity was made again, with new force.
"If they're willing to treat their teachers with total disrespect, think of what they're going to do to the workers in the bargaining units who are here day to day," Robert Proto, president of Local 35, which represents dining hall and maintenance workers, told demonstrators.
"If Yale won't negotiate," he said, "we'll shut this university down."
Yale says it hopes to reach new contracts with Local 34 and Local 35 without disrupting the spring semester, which begins with the return of students next week.
But administrators say they will never negotiate with the student group, the Graduate Employees and Students Organization. The group represents a small minority of graduate students, they say, and in any case teaching assistants are students, not employees.
And as the teaching assistants complain that Yale uses them for cheap labor, in place of tenured faculty, the university has also made proposals to the other unions that make them fear reductions in their numbers and pay. Chief among them is a lower salary scale for new dining hall and maintenance workers, at the same time that current employees are guaranteed their jobs and salaries throughout the next four-year contract.
"There's no reason in our view why this contract can't be settled without a work stoppage," said Gary G. Fryer, a spokesman for Yale. "Negotiations began Nov. 2 and the unions did not make an economic proposal until yesterday."
But students' dissatisfaction with the dining halls is a major concern to Yale, he said, and while the university was willing to offer job and salary guarantees for current employees, it needs flexibility.
"We commissioned a major study of our dining hall operation that concluded Yale dining hall employees are the highest paid anywhere," he said. "We need to address that if we want to make improvements to the dining halls."
While union officials drew parallels today between Yale's stand toward them and the graduate students, the focus of the protest was three graduate students who face disciplinary hearings for failing to turn in tests and other class materials from last semester that professors need to assign grades.
Yale is trying to intimidate all graduate students by bringing charges against only three, said Robin Brown, chairwoman of the Graduate Employees and Students Organization. "We are here in solidarity with three individuals who have been singled out," she said. "They are doing exactly what everyone else is doing who is participating in the grade strike."
Yale is warning teaching assistants who do not turn in grades by Monday that they will not get teaching assignments this semester and could face further discipline. The three students whose cases began today, he said, were simply the first to have complaints lodged against them by professors or administrators. More hearings are possible as more complaints are received.
The disciplinary committee could take no action, reprimand the students, suspend them, or in the extreme, order expulsion.
Many Yale graduate students depend heavily on their teaching stipends for living expenses; a main complaint of the student group is that the stipends, $4,970 a semester, are too small. As part of their compensation, most of the students do not pay tuition.
They are also concerned about their futures as teachers, as universities increasingly rely on teaching assistants and part-time instructors instead of tenured faculty.
Of 439 teaching assistants last semester in the humanities and social-science divisions, the registrar has received grades from all but 87, Mr. Fryer said.
The student group, however, said nearly 200 teaching assistants were taking part in the strike.
While grades were officially due Jan. 2, teaching assistants are being told they have until Monday to turn in grades before they are denied jobs this semester, Mr. Fryer said.
"Our goal is to protect the undergraduates who have fulfilled their obligations and should be receiving a fair and timely evaluation of their work," he said.

HEADLINE: Judge Allows Gay Bias Suit Vs. Big Board

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
A former employee of the New York Stock Exchange has been allowed to push ahead with a lawsuit accusing the exchange of dismissing him because he is a homosexual.
The former employee's victory came three weeks ago, when Justice Stuart C. Cohen of State Supreme Court in Manhattan denied the exchange's request that the complaint be dismissed on summary judgment -- that is, without a trial. The judge's refusal to do so permits the ex-employee, Peter Degan, to proceed with his discrimination case. 
 Mr. Degan had worked for the stock exchange for 24 years before he was dismissed in August 1994, reportedly for misconduct in connection with his development, on company time, of a computer game for children called "Wall Street Adventure." Mr. Degan "asserts that this claim of misconduct was an excuse for terminating him because of his sexual orientation," Justice Cohen observed.
Raymond Pellecchia, an exchange spokesman, said last night that the exchange "categorically denies Mr. Degan's allegations. His complaint is without substance or merit."
In his complaint, Mr. Degan reported that he had received high performance reviews and "was always treated with respect, dignity and esteem" by the exchange until he disclosed his sexual orientation to a senior executive there in the summer of 1989.
After that disclosure, Mr. Degan reportedly "was verbally abused, demeaned and his work environment became hostile, threatening and abusive," Justice Cohen noted in his review of the case. Specifically, the judge continued, Mr. Degan reportedly was told he "did not fit the image" of the exchange, was reprimanded for being gay, and was subjected to "vile and vulgar comments" about his sexual orientation. Mr. Degan, who last worked as a supervisor on the floor of the exchange, also said he had been denied a promised promotion.
In his ruling, which had gone unnoticed in employment law circles during the year-end holidays, Justice Cohen dismissed several of Mr. Degan's other claims, including a common-law claim of fraudulent misrepresentation. But he permitted Mr. Degan to proceed with his charge that the exchange had violated the New York City Human Rights Law, which specifically bars bias based on sexual orientation, and a separate accusation that the exchange had subjected him to "intentional infliction of emotional distress."
Murray Schwartz, Mr. Degan's lawyer, said he was delighted with the ruling because the city ordinance "provides a broad panoply of remedies, including unlimited punitive damages" not available under state and Federal statutes.
"If a jury finds that the exchange did the things Mr. Degan said it did, and finds that was so indecent and so ugly that it wants to punish the exchange so it won't do that again, the city law permits that," he said.
According to Mr. Schwartz, Mr. Degan, who is in his late 40's, has been out of work since his dismissal but has been able to collect unemployment benefits after an administrative law judge rejected the exchange's argument that he had been fired for insubordination and should be denied jobless benefits.

HEADLINE: Dow Plunges 97.19 Points And Drops Below 5,100

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stock prices plummeted yesterday, spurred by the budget impasse in Washington and rising interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which at one time during the session was down more than 115 points, plunged 97.19 points by the closing bell, to 5,032.94. This decline of 1.89 percent marked the first time the Dow sank below 5,100 since Dec. 28 and pushed it to the lowest level since Nov. 21. Over the last two days, the average has fallen more than 3 percent -- its worst such drop in more than four years. 
 Yesterday's stock market was so volatile that the New York Stock Exchange's limits on computer-guided trading were triggered twice. The first of these "circuit breakers" was imposed at 10:08 A.M. and lifted about an hour later. The second, designed to curb program trading in an attempt to stabilize the market, went into effect at 12:45 P.M.
"People are getting increasingly concerned about the budget," said Melissa Brown, director of quantitative research of Prudential Securities. "The longer the talks get drawn out, the more uncertainty is created."
Bond prices sank on pessimistic comments about the possibility of a budget-balancing agreement from House Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole.
The 30-year Treasury bond fell 14/32 -- or $11.25 for every $1,000 invested -- while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.18 percent, from 6.11 percent on Tuesday.
"The stock market went up for 12 solid months," said Louis Ehrenkrantz, president of Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum, a securities firm in New York. "What's so surprising that it should go down 100 points in a day? The market is beginning to take these movements in stride."
Investors also appeared concerned about the effect the stalled budget talks would have on corporate earnings.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 10.97 points, to 598.48, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 8.60, to 990.21, as technology stocks tried to recover from Tuesday's drop with mixed results. Declining issues on the Big Board exceeded advancers, 1,960 to 516, a ratio of almost 4 to 1. The New York Stock Exchange recorded its fifth-largest volume ever, with turnover reaching 497.8 million shares, compared with 417.4 million shares on Tuesday.
Oil stocks, one of the leading groups on the downside, declined along with crude oil and natural gas prices. Exxon fell 2 1/2, to 80 1/4; Mobil declined 3 1/2, to 111 1/4, and Unocal dropped 1/4, to 29 1/2.
Gambling stocks, which previously enjoyed a large run-up, were also lower. MGM Grand closed at 27 1/8, off 1 1/8; Circus Circus closed at 27 7/8, off 1 1/8, and Mirage closed at 36 1/4, off 1 3/4.
The Dow Jones transportation average continued its slide, as airlines struggled to get back to normal service in the East following the blizzard. The transportation average fell 48.08 points, to 1,898.48 yesterday. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, dropped 6 3/4, to 160 7/8; AMR, the parent of American Airlines, fell 2 1/2, to 68 5/8, and Delta Air Lines declined 2 3/8, to 69 5/8.
Among the other stocks that skidded yesterday were Bell Microproducts, down 1, to 6 7/8; the company raised its fourth-quarter write-off to $1.6 million. Xcellnet was down 1 3/4, to 10, after announcing disappointing fourth-quarter earnings late on Tuesday. And Guest Supply was down 4 1/8, to 19 1/8, on news that it did not expect to meet analysts' estimates in its first fiscal quarter.
Gold stocks were a sector that moved against the overall market trend, in keeping with the $3.30 jump in the price of gold to $400.20. Homestake Mining rose 3/8, to 18; Barrick Gold increased 1/8, to 29 1/8, and Newmont Mining advanced 1 5/8, to 54 1/4.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Why Dun & Bradstreet Is Different From Disney

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Splitting big companies into smaller ones has been the norm in American business recently -- witness the breakup of corporate brand names like AT&T, ITT and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing.
But until this week, the media industry was a striking exception. Companies were merging left and right, led by multibillion-dollar deals like Walt Disney's purchase of Capital Cities/ABC and Time Warner's plan to acquire Turner Broadcasting System. Behind the mergers was a singular strategy: grab heaps of entertainment and information content, add a global distribution network and build a media mega-corporation. 
 So why is the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, a $5-billion-a-year publisher and marketer of business information, splitting up? The short answer is that the business of selling a sophisticated study of the computer disk-drive industry is a world away from marketing movies like "Toy Story" or "The Lion King."
The disk-drive study might cost several thousand dollars, compared with a $7.50 movie ticket. And while the market for the study is a small community of specialists, sensitive to day-to-day changes in products, the audience for "Toy Story" is worldwide, and the movie's characters have a timeless quality.
"There is no mass market for business information," Robert E. Weissman, chief executive of Dun & Bradstreet, said yesterday. "And because of rapid changes in technology and in markets today, our businesses are less similar than they used to be."
So Dun & Bradstreet is being sliced into three companies, each separately listed on the stock market. The first, to be called the Cognizant Corporation, will include the Gartner Group, a publisher and adviser to companies on information technology; IMS International, a market research firm catering mainly to drug companies, and Nielsen Media Research, which conducts the well-known Nielsen surveys of the nation's television-viewing habits.
A second company, which will assume the Dun & Bradstreet name, will include the Moody's bond-rating service, the Dun & Bradstreet company-credit information service and Reuben H. Donnelley, a publisher and marketer of telephone Yellow Pages.
The third company, A. C. Nielsen, will supply supermarket sales data and other information to marketers of consumer packaged goods like detergents, toothpaste and breakfast cereal.
Investors applauded Dun & Bradstreet's breakup announcement, which was made after the stock markets closed on Tuesday. On a day when stocks plunged over all, the company's shares rose $1.50 yesterday, to $65.
Since its origins in New York in the 1840's as a credit-rating agency whose analysts included four men who later became American Presidents (Lincoln, Grant, Cleveland and McKinley), Dun & Bradstreet grew by buying businesses and striving to gain economies of scale. That approach continued through the 1980's, with the purchase of A. C. Nielsen in 1983, and into the 1990's, when it bought 51 percent of Gartner in 1993 and spent an estimated $400 million on acquisitions in 1994.
With each major purchase over the years, there was a lot of discussion about the similarities between Dun & Bradstreet and the concern being bought. The corporate justification was that all the parts of Dun & Bradstreet gathered, disseminated, improved and sold business information. Approving analysts would talk of synergy and corporate marriages made in heaven.
"But there weren't really any synergies that proved long-lasting," said John McGilvray, a consultant at Input, a market research firm in Mountain View, Calif. "The only exception might be shared printing facilities for printing the publications."
Executives who used to run Dun & Bradstreet businesses say the headquarters took a hands-off approach toward the operations, except that it monitored each unit's financial performance closely.
"It was mainly just tracking the numbers, and there was very little participation in the business or trying to make it work closely with other Dun & Bradstreet businesses," recalled Frank H. Dodge, who was with Dun & Bradstreet for several years after his software company, McCormack & Dodge, was acquired in 1983. He left in 1990 to start another company, the Dodge Group, which makes specialized software for banks and insurance companies.
At Dun & Bradstreet, the most recent corporate explanation for keeping the company intact was that it was pursuing a strategy of "information engineering," or integrating technology, information and service to customize research and advice for corporate customers.
Mr. Weissman, who will become chief executive of Cognizant, said his company would continue to try to do that, by constructing customized reports and advice from research by in-house analysts. But that approach will now be taken within narrower markets for business information.
An apparent model for that approach is Gartner, whose shares are separately listed on the Nasdaq market. Gartner, whose analysts cover everything from disk drives to computer security software, charges corporate customers $19,000 a year for each service Gartner offers, though volume discounts are available for companies that buy several services. Many large corporations spend $100,000 or more a year on Gartner services.
"We're in the syndicated research business," explained Manuel Fernandez, the president of Gartner. "And as a business, we try to maximize our analysts' time, whether it is publishing on paper or over the Internet, speaking to conferences or one-to-one with clients."
And Gartner's rapid growth recently also suggests ways that the Dun & Bradstreet spinoffs may try to follow the more focused formula. In November, Gartner bought Dataquest, a market research firm, for $65 million. Almost immediately, Mr. Fernandez said, Gartner was able to reduce Dataquest's costs by 20 percent.
"We're not interested in entirely new businesses," Mr. Fernandez said. "We want to expand but still sell to the same client base with the same sales force."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Budget Block Knocks Down Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell sharply yesterday, hurt by the gloomier outlook for budget talks in Washington. The drop sent yields on long-term Treasury issues back up to the levels of three weeks ago, before the Federal Reserve cut interest rates.
On shorter maturities, however, prices were shored up by the plunge in the stock market yesterday that sent investors in a flight to quality. 
 The price of the closely watched 30-year benchmark bond dropped 1 4/32 of a percentage point, to 109 11/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, climbed to 6.18 percent, from 6.11 percent on Tuesday.
The breaking off of budget talks also sent the price of gold over $400 an ounce, its highest level in almost two and a half years. Higher gold prices often reflect inflation jitters, and gold's rise yesterday served as an excuse for some credit market investors to sell.
Early in the session, when prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in choppy trading, market participants stayed poised and ready to take advantage of any movement regarding the stalled budget talks. But as the prospects for good news dwindled, buyers moved to the sidelines and movements became more exaggerated; the long bond dropped as much as 21/32 in the cash market.
Early in the afternoon Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, was reported on Knight Ridder Financial wires as saying he was "pessimistic" about reaching a budget deal and saw the chances as less than 50-50, adding that there might not be a deal until after the elections. Those comments unnerved the market.
Traders said that prices in the longer maturities reflected the disappointment in the talks, while the shorter maturities remained fairly firm and reflected the sluggish economy and the flight to quality.
With no important economic news as a backdrop, technical factors dominated trading. Traders said the March bond contract tested support at about 119, and they worried that if that level did not hold, a break was possible to 118 16/32 -- if not below. The March bond contract was as high as 119 25/32 in day trading, while the low was 118 19/32 , before closing at 118 25/32 .
"I don't think any real significant support levels were broken today," said Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research of Boston. "But there is more to the down side. Bonds are in a large trading range, with the bottom of that trading range yet to be tested. The bottom of that range spans from 111 20/32 to 118 4/32 . And it will get tested."
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of Government bond trading at Cowen & Company, said the "bond market has fallen out of bed again, guided by rumors of the budget situation, and literally no progress."
He added, "Each day this goes on, the market becomes more nervous and less optimistic that there is going to be a settlement of all these talks."
Another item that is going to begin to bother the market is the debt ceiling situation. The temporary funding bill expires Jan. 26.
"What this market doesn't need is another obstacle to come from Washington at the same time, as they will continue to weigh on the market and to bring about nervousness from market participants," Mr. Gamba said. Nervousness in the market is generally expressed by selling.
Mr. Gamba continued: "Technically the market broke below its 50-day moving average at 118 29/32 on the March bond contract, and that has also added to the selling pressure. Today trading volume has been heavier than it was on Monday and Tuesday, with some large blocks trades."
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said that the market preferred a mediocre budget agreement to none at all, but clearly hoped for a good agreement. "Nontheless, it is becoming quite clear that reaching an agreement that was as fiscally conservative as initially proposed by the G.O.P. is now considered a long shot," he said. "This prognosis has prevented the market from rallying further and put it on hold."
Fundamentally, he contends, the economy is still weak, but the dearth of data has kept the market focused on private sector reports like ones on retail sales.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Offers More Rebates

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation announced $300 rebates today on three car models with sluggish sales, and it extended a rebate program for pickup trucks.
The moves came a day after the Ford Motor Company announced $600 rebates on most of its car and truck models, raising the prospect of price wars among the auto makers. 
 But a Chrysler spokesman said the company's announcement had been planned for two weeks and was not a reaction to the move by Ford.
Chrysler has offered rebates on most of its 1995 and 1996 cars and trucks since early November.
Today's announcement added $300 rebates or discounted interest rates on financing for buyers of 1995 and 1996 Dodge Avenger, Chrysler Sebring Coupe and Eagle Talon models. It extended to the end of January the $400 to $500 rebates offered for 1995 and 1996 Dodge Ram pickups, and added extended-cab models to the program.
The company also extended until the end of February the rebates already in effect on most other models.

HEADLINE: Vallone Pledges to Fight G.O.P. Policies

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, vowed in his annual address to the Council yesterday that he and the Council will begin serving as a strong Democratic counterweight to Republicans in New York and in Washington.
In a feisty and sharply partisan speech in the Council chambers in City Hall, Mr. Vallone challenged Republican policies, calling them "unacceptable" and harmful to the city's middle class. 
The Speaker used his annual address to introduce formally his plan for generating nearly $1.4 billion to help rebuild the city's crumbling schools -- and to offer a new idea for breaking up the city's Human Resources Administration, a superagency he described as troubled and obsolete.
But aside from those two proposals, Mr. Vallone did not back up his call for new Democratic activism with descriptions of many other specific initiatives.
Mr. Vallone criticized Federal and state budget policies as "guns" pointed at New Yorkers' heads. But he reserved his most stinging criticism for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
He applauded the Mayor's focus on fighting crime, but faulted the Mayor for neglecting other services.
"Regrettably, too often, the Mayor who campaigned for office under the banner 'One City, One Standard,' has governed under the banner 'My City, My Standard,' " Mr. Vallone said.
The Mayor said he had not had a chance to read Mr. Vallone's comments, but added: "The parts of the speech that I heard sound somewhat like a partisan speech. He seems to be drawing partisan political lines."
Asked about the Speaker's direct criticism of the Mayor's style, the Mayor said only: "I'll get a chance to give my speech tomorrow." The Mayor will offer his State of the City address today at noon.
Earlier in the day Cristyne F. Lategano, the Mayor's communications director, said it was "unfortunate" that Mr. Vallone gave what she called a "political speech" on the same day as the funeral for James B. Williams, a New York City firefighter who died Jan. 5. Before his speech, Mr. Vallone honored the firefighter with a moment of silence.
While Mr. Vallone used what has been dubbed the Speaker's State of the City speech to declare a new, more active agenda for the Council, and even as he opposed continued budget cuts at city, state and federal levels, he did not offer many specific alternatives to deal with the financial problems that the city faces.
The Speaker and the 51-member Council he strongly controls have generally been conciliatory, willing to compromise with the Mayor on budget issues. Some Council members yesterday were not convinced that Mr. Vallone's speech represented a real break from his consensus-building style.
The centerpiece proposal the Speaker laid out yesterday was his plan to extend a surcharge on the city's personal income tax for three years to pay for new school buildings and to renovate existing ones.
The tax now is used to pay for additional police officers, and Giuliani adinistration officials say they intend to maintain the department at its current level of 38,000 officers -- without renewing the tax. Council officials also want to keep police hiring at its present level, and say that the Mayor's financial plan indicates the administration will find the money to pay for the extra police officers. But city budget officials have not explained where the money will come from.
The Speaker also noted that the school plan would create thousands of jobs in the construction industry. And in a gesture to the city's unions, Mr. Vallone said he would ask the state to approve legislation requiring the city to give preference to companies based in the city.
Mr. Vallone also proposed dividing the Human Resources Administration into three agencies: a Department for Children, a Department for the Aging and Disabled, and a Department for Transitional Assistance. The Speaker called the Human Resources Administration "an out-of-date city agency badly in need of being restructured."
The Speaker believes that creating separate agencies would increase accountability and would refocus the city's efforts to provide services for children the elderly and the poor.
Republican members of the Council praised Mr. Vallone's school initiative but took exception to his partisan attacks.
"He makes the Mayor and the Governor the fall guys for 25 years of failed social policy that Democrats have forced on this city," said Thomas V. Ognibene of Queens, the minority leader of the Council's seven-member Republican contingent. "But it's a salvo in the political war."
Although Mr. Giuliani did not attend the event, former Mayor David N. Dinkins arrived to a warm reception. He heartily endorsed the Speaker's comments, calling the speech "on the money."
"And Peter Vallone, you've got to understand, is the second most powerful figure in our city government," Mr. Dinkins said. "And as he used to remind me, the City Council is a co-equal partner in this government, and Mayor Giuliani had better understand that."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS<HEADLINE>;
U.S. to Withhold Sanctions In Tricontinental Banana Rift

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration will not immediately impose sanctions against Costa Rica and Colombia in a trade dispute involving bananas, officials said today.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, announced that after a year of talks, Costa Rica and Colombia had signed agreements pledging to cooperate in trying to get the European Union to scrap trade barriers involving bananas. 
 Those barriers have been deplored by United States banana exporters, notably Chiquita Brands International, who say that the Europeans' restrictions are costing them hundreds of millions of dollars.
Steve Warshaw, executive vice president of Chiquita, said his company was not disappointed that the Administration had decided against sanctions now. He said Mr. Kantor had left the door for sanctions if negotiations in coming months did not produce favorable results.
The dispute concerns a decision by the Europeans in July 1993 to impose import restrictions on bananas with the exception of those from 70 former European colonies and protectorates. The action favored Caribbean nations like Jamaica, Martinique, Guadeloupe and St. Lucia.
These supplied about 15 percent of the European banana market, and their largely family-owned operations were having trouble competing with multinational operations like Chiquita and the Dole Food Company.
The Europeans have so far shown little willingness to back down. Prime Minister Alain Juppe of France urged the European Union this week to tighten its banana import restrictions in hopes of propping up prices for fruit from the former colonies.
The trade dispute has gotten attention in Washington. More than 70 members of Congress, including the Senate Republican leader and Presidential aspirant, Bob Dole, advocating trade sanctions against Costa Rica and Colombia unless they pulled out of the European Union's banana quota program.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Price of Gold Surpasses $400 First Time in Nearly 2 1/2 Years

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The price of gold rose above $400 an ounce for the first time in nearly two and a half years yesterday, pushed higher in part by speculative demand from investors fleeing, at least temporarily, the stock and bond markets.
Analyst said technical and fundamental factors, including supply problems and lower interest rates, also contributed to gold's rise. 
 In heavy trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York, the February gold futures contract settled at $400.20 an ounce, up $3.30 from Tuesday's close. Earlier in the session, the contract had risen as high as $403.
In London yesterday, gold was fixed at $400 an ounce, the first time it has reached that level since Aug. 3, 1993, when it was fixed at $402.65.
Yesterday's price action was a continuation of a surge that began at the start of the year.
Since the beginning of the new year, spot gold prices, which averaged just above $384 for all of last year, have risen nearly $15 an ounce.
Analysts said some of the metal's recent rise, particularly the final push through $400, was attributable to the recent weakness in stocks and bonds.
"I think you have a degree of sectoral rotation by professional investment pools coming out of things like technology stocks and into gold and gold instruments," said John Brimelow, director of international equities at BV Capital Markets in New York.
But Mr. Brimelow and others said much of the run-up had to do with an increasing realization that producers, which have been big suppliers into the market in the last few years, are currently in no position to meet the demand for gold.
Moreover, even though gold is viewed as an inflation hedge by many, it tends to do best in a world of low and declining real rates of interest.
"Gold has a causal relationship with real interest rates," said Fred Kalkstein, a vice president at Janney Montgomery Scott, the brokerage house. "When you have some combination of inflation and nominal interest rates that cause real interest rates to come down, that causes gold prices to go up."
Lower real interest rates not only reduce the cost of holding gold, but also pare returns on interest-bearing assets, forcing investors in search of better returns to look to other investments, like gold.
In Mr. Kalkstein's view, the reduction in a key German interest rate yesterday, as well as comments by officials at the Bundesbank, played as much a role in gold's rise yesterday as the steep slide in the stock market.
After the meeting at which they approved the German rate cut, the officials noted that real interest rates in Germany were still quite high, suggesting further easing in monetary policy.
"Right now the Bundesbank is a very key central bank, and this kind of talk is the stuff that gold feeds on," Mr. Kalkstein said. "It nurtures demand for gold as a monetary asset."
Still, while predicting that gold would trade in a somewhat higher price range than the last few years, few were willing to forecast that gold would continue its recent strong advance.
"At $400, I don't think we will see continued demand," said a precious-metals analyst at a European bank, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "The speculators are long gold already, and I question how much longer they can get. I don't think we can sustain these prices until we find out where the new underlying demand is coming from."
William O'Neill, senior futures strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said, "You should be careful about becoming too bullish, because the global economic outlook is not a positive for precious metals."
"What we are seeing now is a market moving to a somewhat higher trading range of around $380 to $420 an ounce," he said, "as opposed to the $365 to $395 range that has existed since 1993.
On other commodity markets, gasoline prices continued their retreat, as this week's storm in the Northeast continued to make driving difficult, thus reducing demand for fuel. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities fell 1.05 point, to 245.23.
February unleaded gasoline fell 0.46 cent, to 58.19 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Gasoline's decline weighed on other energy contracts. February crude oil fell 28 cents, to $19.67 a barrel. February heating oil fell 0.84 cent, to 59.59 cents a gallon, and February natural gas fell 1.19 cents, to $2.809 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Against Mark As the Budget Impasse Deepens

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar eased against the German mark yesterday as many investors fled battered American markets for the momentary safety of German securities.
Washington's seemingly endless talks on balancing the Federal budget bruised stocks, bonds and the dollar, particularly after the House speaker, Newt Gingrich, said that for the first time in a year he had become pessimistic about reaching an agreement and suggested it might have to wait for the next election. 
 "It doesn't seem they're going to come out with a deal any time soon," said Mark Gargano, managing director of foreign exchange at First Union National Bank.
The dollar slipped to 1.4368 marks late yesterday from 1.4395 marks late Tuesday.
But the currency climbed against the yen, since Japanese markets are still viewed with caution given the nation's political uncertainty and low interest rates. The dollar climbed to 104.86 yen from 104.65 yen.
The United States currency failed to top its overnight highs in New York, where it peaked shortly after noon. A drop of nearly 100 points in the Dow Jones industrial average and a decline of nearly a full point by the 30-year Treasury bond fueled selling of dollars for marks, currency traders said.
"The stock market is due for a bit more of a correction and that's going to keep bringing the dollar down," said James Blackwelder, vice president for corporate foreign exchange at NatWest New Jersey.
Yet the fact that the dollar held up well against the yen and lost only modest ground to the mark shows that some investors still find higher American yields tempting while the economies of Germany and Japan remain weak, traders said.
"If we had gotten the news that hit the markets in the last few weeks last year, the dollar would have dropped 4 or 5 pfennigs," one New York analyst said. "But it's occurring against a backdrop of weakness in Germany and Japan."
Each day without a credible balanced-budget deal puts greater pressure on the dollar, but traders are expecting only a modest decline in its value.
Still, the enthusiasm that caused the dollar to spike higher last week has clearly waned. "The politicians are not providing the overwhelming support they did last week," Mr. Blackwelder said.
In other trading, the dollar slid to 1.1610 Swiss francs, from 1.1623 francs late Tuesday. The British pound fell to $1.5465 from $1.5487.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A study shows bias against the ugly. Should they have recourse?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IS prejudice in hiring ever justified? Most Americans agree that discrimination on racial, sexual or religious grounds is wrong. But what about against people who just happen to be ugly?
That is the issue that Jeff Biddle and Daniel Hamermesh, economists at Michigan State and the University of Texas, respectively, have investigated. They assay the roots of discrimination against unattractive people, an ill-defined group whose legal claim to protection against discrimination is now being tested in the courts. And while their study -- just published by the National Bureau of Economic Research -- probably won't change many minds, it does air the awkward issue of whether employers should shoulder the economic and legal burden of fighting the prejudices of their customers and the community as a whole. 
 The two labor economists made a splash a few years ago, analyzing a sample of some 7,000 people and finding solid evidence that good looks translated into heftier paychecks. It remains to be seen whether the implied discrimination is illegal. For while many people dismiss the idea out of hand, unattractiveness may well fit the definition of disability in the Americans With Disabilities Act as "a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities." In 1993 a Federal court upheld a jury award to a woman who had been discharged solely because she was fat.
Now Mr. Biddle and Mr. Hamermesh are back with a study of some 2,000 graduates from a "highly selective" (but unnamed) law school that closely followed the careers of its alumni. The results confirmed the earlier study. But even more importantly, detailed information about workers in a single profession offers a chance to examine the motives for discrimination apart from the charged atmosphere surrounding race and gender.
The researchers measured attractiveness on a scale of one to five, based on a panel's rating of head-and-shoulder photos printed in booklets at the time of enrollment. Class rank among graduates during the 1970's was not correlated with looks. But after five years in the workplace, those ranked in the top third on attractiveness were earning 9 percent more on average than those in the bottom third. After 15 years this gap had widened to 13 percent.
Common sense suggests that when employers discriminate, it is to satisfy their own prejudices or those of their other employees. But that does not seem to be the case with these lawyers. For one thing, starting salaries were not correlated with looks. For another, the income gap between the most and least attractive was virtually identical for lawyers who were self-employed.
That suggests attractive lawyers are more productive, if only in the sense that clients prefer good-looking attorneys. Mr. Biddle and Mr. Hamermesh found that a disproportionate number of unattractive lawyers work for public agencies, where the "client" typically has little say in who does the work. This sorting process continues from the first to the fifth year after graduation: unattractive lawyers in the private sector tend to switch to government jobs while attractive government lawyers join private firms.
Does it really matter why job discrimination takes place? Many years ago Gary S. Becker, the conservative Nobel economist at the University of Chicago, pointed out that unfettered markets should be a potent weapon against prejudice. In a free labor market, nonprejudiced employers would be able to hire the disfavored group at bargain wages, permitting them to drive prejudiced competitors out of business. Competition for talent, for example, probably has something to do with the decisions of Apple Computer and the Walt Disney Company to champion the rights of gay employees.
But discrimination driven by the customers' tastes does not appear to be self-correcting. Law firms that bow to the pressure of the market, hiring Cary Grant types over Alfred E. Neuman lookalikes, will have a competitive edge. The paradox, Mr. Biddle suggests, is that government sanctions on employers are actually most needed when the discrimination is least related to employers' own prejudices.
Robert Topel, an economist at the University of Chicago Business School, is not impressed by this distinction. The logic of job discrimination laws, he argues, is to attain a social goal at the "lowest possible cost." And regardless of the motive for the antisocial behavior, it is easier and less intrusive to penalize employer discrimination than to police prejudiced consumers.
Still, this may not be how most people view the issue. Where economists see legal sanctions purely as deterrence, one suspects that the majority of Americans see discrimination as immoral, and justify the penalities against discrimination as punishment.
As a practical matter, the issue becomes stickier as the reach of the antidiscrimination laws is lengthened beyond what the public considers reasonable. It is one thing to throw the book at a department store that refuses to hire black people to stand behind the perfume counter. It is quite another when the department store chooses perfume sellers by their looks.

HEADLINE: Market Drop Grabs Notice Of Both Sides

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Through the months of budget arguments between President Clinton and the Republican leadership, both sides have kept a wary eye on the markets, at once amazed that Wall Street considered a political deal inevitable and fearful of the moment that investors might discover that was not the case.
The question of whether that moment has arrived has come to the fore as the Dow Jones industrial average declined 164 points in two days. A further fall could end an unprecedented bull market that has had no sustained declines for more than five years. [Page D1.] 
 The decline is hardly a disaster, but the drop has been big enough to grab everyone's attention in a financial capital and a political capital that often miss each other's signals.
Here, that left both Democrats and Republicans asking the same two questions: How big a drop is needed before the political pressure to force a deal becomes unbearable? And if the markets continue to unwind, sending interest rates up and eating away at the gains that have enriched so many, which side would take the blame?
"This has been the ticking bomb that neither side wanted to acknowledge was sitting under the negotiating table," one of Mr. Clinton's advisers said today, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "But like most small bombs, it's hard to say when it will go off or whether anyone will get hurt."
Politicians rarely like to talk about markets and the pressures they impose on the political process, though they acknowledge that in the past, most notably during the market crash of 1987, Wall Street has often provided the impetus for breaking a deadlock in Washington. In this case, with an election looming, it is particularly difficult to figure out which side can play the markets to their advantage, or which is likely to be spooked the most by the markets' sudden case of the budget jitters.
"The fact is that 150 points or so may not be enough to prompt some real action," Allen Sinai, Lehman Brothers' chief global economist, said today in a telephone interview from London. "In a market that has risen as much as this one has, a correction of 8 percent or so would not be unusual, and that would mean 400 points."
But the early guessing is that the Republicans, still stung by the polls that showed more voters blamed them than Mr. Clinton for the furlough of Government workers, might be the first to blanch at the thought of going into the primaries with voters angry over the combination of gridlock in Washington and a costly sell-off. Certainly the White House is encouraging that view.
"Perhaps a negative reaction in the market would strengthen the sentiment for agreeing on passing a budget with the $600 billion in savings we've all agreed on," said Gene Sperling, the deputy assistant to the President for economic policy. "That would leave the ideological battles over how much larger the heath care cuts and tax cuts should should be to the election," he added, exactly the strategy that many of Mr. Clinton's political advisers say would work to his advantage.
The President alluded to such a strategy this afternoon, when he told reporters that the issue at hand was no longer one of numbers -- the two sides are so close that if this was a business deal it would have closed long ago -- but of ideology.
"The issues here are policy," Mr. Clinton said. "We're only very far away if you insist on a tax cut."
Later, he added, "We ought to have an election about that."
For their part, the Republicans seem uncertain how to play the markets. In December Mr. Gingrich tried, unsuccessfully, to use the fear of a sell-off to win concessions from the White House. He warned that "you will see interest rates skyrocket and the stock market crash" if there was no deal that delivered on the promises of the Republican agenda. But the markets shrugged that warning off as so much steam and proceeded with the upward march that only ended with a two-day sell-off on Wednesday and today that amounted to a 3.2 percent decline in the industrial average.
The man whom the White House is relying on to scope out the market psychology on all of this is Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who spent most of his career on the other side of the trading screen, trying to turn political pronouncements in Washington into opportunities for profit at Goldman Sachs & Company.
Inside the White House, Mr. Rubin has talked at length about what would happen if the budget deadlock coincided with a growing nervousness in the markets that the Dow had gone too high -- exactly what appears to have happened in the past two days.
At such times, he has warned, bad news that has been ignored for a year suddenly becomes the object of investor fixation. And he often speculated that Wall Street was misled about budget prospects by its overemphasis on the numbers, which would lead anyone to think a deal was imminent, and an underemphasis on the ideological struggle.
"It's a difference of perception about what puts a deal together," he said recently. "These are things I would have missed before I got to Washington, too."
But as Mr. Rubin and Mr. Clinton's other economic advisers have also warned, a budget deadlock, even one fought on the ideological high ground of saving Medicaid and Medicare or cutting taxes, carries considerable risks.
The biggest risk is rising interest rates. No budget deal would almost certainly mean no deal on raising the Government's borrowing limit. That would force Mr. Rubin to take a number of steps of still-questionable legality to keep the nation from going into default, an outcome he has made clear he will avoid at all costs.
But even the suggestion that the Government may not be able to pay its debts could raise some uncertainty in the bond markets, where investors are accustomed to being paid for taking higher risks by receiving higher yields. And an increase in the rates on Treasury securities would ripple through the economy.
Even the cryptic chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, has warned of that side effect of budget deadlock, saying last year that "a shattering of expectation" among investors could push long-term interest rates significantly higher. That, he said, could send "interest-sensitive areas of the economy into trouble."
Mr. Greenspan's scenario is a nightmare for the White House: An economy that, at midsummer, might look more and more like the economy in 1992.
"It undid George Bush," one of Mr. Clinton's political advisers said recently. "And no one understands that better than us."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Giant Omnicom Ad Agency Agrees to Buy Ketchum
The Omnicom Group agreed to buy Ketchum Communications, the 25th-largest American advertising agency, with more than $1 billion in billings. Ketchum is perhaps best known for introducing the Acura line of luxury cars and the Orville Redenbacher popcorn products. The agency has 1,100 employees and offers a range of marketing services.
The purchase is Omnicom's fifth big acquisition of an independent shop in three years. Industry executives estimated that Omnicom was paying $35 million to $40 million in stock, outbidding Interpublic. [Page D7.]
 
Clinton and Congressional Leaders
See Budget Fight Until Election
Both President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders sounded pessimistic after breaking off their budget talks and suggested they might have to fight out their differences in the November election. [A1.]
 
In Washington, Democrats and Republicans were asking the same two questions: How big a market drop is needed before the political pressure to force a deal becomes unbearable? And if interest rates climb significantly, who will be blamed? [A1.]
 
Market Plunges on Budget Impasse
Stocks plunged again yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average losing more than 97 points after tumbling 67 points on Tuesday. That was the largest two-day decline in more than four years. The slide to 5,032.94 reflected Wall Street's anger and disappointment that the balanced-budget negotiations in Washington had once again stalled. [D8.]
 
Bond prices also tumbled, with the 30-year Treasury issue falling 1 4/32 to 109 11/32 , sending its yield up to 6.18 percent. [D17.]
 
The price of gold topped $400 an ounce for the first time in nearly two and a half years, as investors sought a safe harbor from the stock and bond markets. Supply problems and lower interest rates contributed to gold's rise. [D6.]
 
Dole Opposes Broadcasters
Senator Bob Dole denounced a provision in the telecommunications bill that would give television broadcasters a chunk of the nation's airwaves worth tens of billions of dollars. He sent the clearest signal yet that he may block the bill, and singled out the broadcasting issue as the one section of the huge bill where he had serious objections. [D2.]
 
A Tax Break for Mobile Retirees
President Clinton signed legislation that gives a tax break to tens of thousands of people who have retired to states with no income taxes or lower rates than the states where they lived when they worked. The law prohibits the states where the pensions were earned from reaching beyond their borders to tax retirees. California expects to lose $25 million a year, and New York, $9 million. [D4.]
 
Murdoch Bidding on Olympics
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is negotiating to buy the European rights to broadcast the Olympic Games from 2000 to 2008 for a reported $2 billion, for showing on pay and free channels. The company is competing against the European Broadcast Union, which bargains on behalf of European public broadcasters like the BBC, and which has shown the games in the past. [D7.]
 
Blizzard Cost Put at $1 Billion
This week's blizzard could cost the New York region more than $1 billion, economists said, tallying the costs of storm damage, cleanup and lost business activity. [A1.]
 
Blinder Cites Policy Difficulty
Alan Blinder, the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, said that the temporary halt in the release of Government economic reports had made it more difficult for the Fed to set interest-rate policy. But the Fed still will consider its policy on rates at the next meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee this month, he said. [D5.]
 
NCR Gets Its Name Back
Four years after AT&T gobbled up the NCR Corporation in what proved to be a disastrous $7.5 billion takeover, NCR got its name back, as the first step toward being cut loose as a separate company. The company, whose initials for decades stood for National Cash Register, is an important maker of automated teller machines, modern cash registers and networks that link retail registers. [D5.]
 
Bias Suit Against Big Board
A state judge let a former employee proceed with a suit accusing the New York Stock Exchange of dismissing him because he is homosexual. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Stocks Dive, Reflecting Wall St. Ire Toward Washington

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The stock market plunged yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 97.19 points, capping the largest two-day decline in more than four years.
The selling, which affected nearly all sectors of the market, came as long-term interest rates were rising and reflected Wall Street's anger and disappointment that the budget negotiations in Washington had once again stalled with no sign of a deal on the horizon. 
 A further fall could end an unprecedented bull market that has had no sustained declines for more than five years. Since 1990, investors have treated every stock market dip as a buying opportunity and have poured cash into stock mutual funds.
It is now probably up to millions of mutual fund investors to determine whether the drop will continue.
As prices fell yesterday, the talk among traders was that there was selling from mutual funds. "It is fund selling, but it's orderly," said a veteran money manager, speaking on condition he not be identified. Whether that selling represents the first wave of investors taking money out of funds or is just a case of money managers getting worried will not be clear for at least a few days, although fund companies generally denied seeing significant increases in withdrawals by their investors.
The two-day fall that brought the Dow to 5,032.94 equaled 3.2 percent, the worst move for the market since it plunged 3.7 percent on Nov. 14 and 15, 1991. As it happens, anger at Washington was blamed for that move as well. Then, it was a reaction to the Senate's surprising passage of a proposal to put a cap on credit card interest rates. The markets' swift reaction scared the politicians and the idea was dead within days. Stock prices completely recovered within six weeks.
The latest budget problems, which have sent the yield on long-term Treasury bonds up to 6.18 percent, have revived talk of a possible recession.
"A dose of rising interest rates when economic activity is already faltering is a risky proposition for the economy," warned Robert Barbera, the chief economist for Capital Investments International, a New York money manager.
If the market plunge is just Wall Street sending a message, and if the politicians react, then this fall could be as short-lived as the 1991 dip. But with share prices having been at record highs, and with the expectation that profits taken now are likely to be taxed at a lower capital gains tax rate assuming a budget deal is reached, it is possible the selling could spread. There is also concern over corporate profits, and the suspicion that the economy is weak is only being heightened by the lack of important economic data because of the Government shutdown.
Stock mutual funds have been running low levels of cash, fearful of missing out on a bull market, although there was an increase in cash in November, the latest data available. That means that any significant withdrawal activity by investors would be immediately transmitted into selling of stock by fund managers.
Many of the mutual funds that took in the most money from investors last year soared in the first three quarters on the basis of their heavy ownership of technology stocks, particularly in semiconductors. Those stocks have been among the weakest recently, and they were the ones that did worst on Tuesday. Thus the funds with the most money are also the ones that are most vulnerable to investor concerns. The Seligman Communications and Information Fund, for example, has lost 9.1 percent of its value in the last two days.
And after the close yesterday, Fidelity Investments, which had been among the biggest owners of technology shares, reported that it had sold most of its positions in a variety of such stocks, among them Advanced Micro Devices, Cirrus Logic, LSI Logic, 3Com, Silicon Graphics and Texas Instruments.
Some technology stocks, including I.B.M. and Microsoft, recovered a bit yesterday amid the falling prices of most stocks. But the widely watched Philadelphia Stock Exchange semiconductor index lost an additional 1.6 percent, on top of Tuesday's 7.7 percent plunge. It is now down 41.4 percent from its peak, reached in September. And after the close, Apple Computer, which a few days ago had fallen to its lowest level since the summer of 1994, warned of more disappointing financial results, an announcement that could put more pressure on the technology stocks today.
Moreover, financial stocks, which had been among the market leaders more recently, are also showing signs of weakness, reflecting the interest rate rises. The yield on long-term Treasury bonds, now 6.18 percent, was at 5.95 percent only last week.
The latest weakness comes at a time when some foreign stock markets are showing surprising strength. "The marginal money that was going into the States is going into Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong," said one money manager.
It used to be that market setbacks -- corrections in the Wall Street jargon that makes almost everything sound nice -- were a common occurrence. It was almost unheard of for the market to go even two years without at least one 10 percent decline in the major indexes. But this market has not had one since 1990, when prices fell in the aftermath of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the economy entered a brief recession.
The lack of corrections has been caused in large part by the willingness of mutual fund investors to buy when others were afraid, a willingness that partly reflected the decision of aging baby boomers to put more and more retirement investments into stocks and stock mutual funds.
Along the way, warnings that prices were getting high when measured by traditional valuation standards were largely ignored, amid talk that stocks were always the best investment on a long-term basis.
Now that willingness to buy is being tested again. It may be the most severe test in some time.

HEADLINE: Now Bring Democracy to Bear on Corporate Downsizing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
United States Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich ("How to Avoid These Layoffs," Op-Ed, Jan. 4) shows courage when he acknowledges that the only way to stop dramatic increases in unemployment is to require corporations to be socially responsible and to remove the corporate charters of those that are not. 
 Implicitly, Mr. Reich is telling us that the makeshift measures that the Clinton Administration introduced to retrain workers, and the search for personal solutions to the globalization of capital, are unlikely to save us.
Only a conscious democratic decision to impose restrictions on downsizing and globalization will work.
We in the politics-of-meaning movement have advocated an ethical impact report that would require corporations to assess damage to the community before beginning downsizing or reinvestment of capital assets abroad.
We have also urged President Clinton to call an international conference to explore ways for countries to coordinate policies that would restrict corporations' playing one country off against another in their desire to find cheaper labor and fewer restrictions on environmental polluting.
Yet no movement to restrict capital is feasible as long as Americans believe they are best off worrying only about their own economic survival and letting others fend for themselves.
 
MICHAEL LERNER
Editor, Tikkun magazine
New York, Jan. 8, 1996

NEW YORK CITY
 
Rituals of Firefighter's Funeral
For the mourners at the funeral of James B. Williams in Sayville, L.I., the rituals of death had become painfully familiar: a bagpipe's shuddering notes, a red fire truck reserved for funerals. Firefighter Williams, the first city firefighter to die this year, was the 10th in the last two years and the 763d to die in the line of duty in New York City. [Page B1.]

St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center announced that they were actively negotiating a partnership which, if the talks succeed, would create the largest hospital in New York City and one of the largest in the country. [B1.]

Tallying Cost of a Blizzard

Heads up: the next winter storm is expected tomorrow. But forecasters say its bite will be nothing like that of the blizzard. [B4.]
 
Plowers Declare a Victory
Sanitation Department officials, conceding that the huge amounts of snow in the city still posed enduring problems, said nonetheless that every street had been plowed -- except for the several dozen blocked by abandoned cars. [B5.]
 
Building managers, store owners and homeowners were rushing to meet Mayor Giuliani's deadline to have a path cleared on their sidewalks or face a fine. [B5.]
 
The snow will be around for months, if predictions are to be believed, but the silence has already disappeared. An appraisal. [B5.]
 
For Students, Holiday's Over
Attendance varied widely as many schools reopened, with only about half of New York City's one million students going to class with a two-hour delay. [B6.]

Scientists say this week's snowfall was unusually fluffy. [B6.]

HEADLINE: Three Black Members Quit AIDS Organization Board

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Charging that the Gay Men's Health Crisis was not sufficiently attuned to the needs of minority groups, three black members have resigned from the board of New York City's leading private AIDS organization.
Their resignations, which were submitted on Monday and made public yesterday, underscore a breach that has been growing nationwide as poorer black and Hispanic people with AIDS question whether the middle-class, gay white men who dominate many AIDS groups are capable of providing adequate attention and services to their communities. 
 The Gay Men's Health Crisis, founded in 1982 by six white men, offers everything from legal and financial counseling to practical assistance at home. It serves 7,300 people with AIDS annually, 54 percent of whom are black, Hispanic or Asian. After the three resignations on Monday, only 4 of the 29 board members are black. Two members are Hispanic and one is Asian.
The black members who resigned said problems had been building for months. They criticized the agency's search for new office space in Chelsea -- a neighborhood in Manhattan with many gay, white residents -- rather than in other boroughs, where services would be closer for black and Hispanic clients.
Those who resigned also complained that they had heard that another board member referred to them as "tokens," that a black executive at the agency had been dismissed without adequate explanation and, generally, that their counsel had been ignored.
The black board member with the highest profile was Dr. Billy E. Jones, who headed the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation from 1992 to 1994 and is now executive director of the Kingsboro Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn. He joined the board last year.
"Much work needs to be done at G.M.H.C. to make it truly inclusive and welcoming of diversity," Dr. Jones wrote in his letter of resignation. "It is also clear that such work will be a great struggle. I am resigning because I do not choose to engage in such a struggle at G.M.H.C., but rather prefer to fight for the needs of those ravaged by H.I.V."
Louis Bradbury, the president of the board, said yesterday that the search for new office space was an exercise of fiduciary responsibility, since renewing some existing leases in Chelsea would cost twice the current rent. He said the "tokens" remark would be outrageous, if true, but that it was an unsubstantiated allegation.
As to the broader ethnic and economic questions, he said: "We're struggling to see that all people feel that they are welcome and that we are there for them. There are a lot of tensions in our society and we're dealing with them."
Mr. Bradbury said all three members who resigned were "excellent people" whom he was sorry to see depart. He said the agency would continue to seek as diverse a board as possible.
Joining Dr. Jones in resigning were Dr. Richard G. Dudley Jr., a psychiatrist in Harlem, and Doug Robinson, former co-chairman of Center Kids, a family program at the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center in Greenwich Village.
"G.M.H.C. is the big brother on the block," said Mr. Robinson, who joined the board in 1994. "What they say and what they do is listened to by many people. We found, as people of color on the board, that our voices were not heard."
Among the minority board members who remain are Dennis deLeon, president of the Latino Commission on AIDS; Dr. Marjorie J. Hill, former director of the Mayor's Office for the Lesbian and Gay Community, and Thomas Morgan 3d, a former reporter for The New York Times.
"G.M.H.C. is going through a big transformation as the client base changes," Mr. deLeon said. "It's struggling with the issue at the organizational level, the staff level and on the board level. But it is struggling. That counts for a lot.
"The question is: will minority members of the board be able to be heard? I've got to play out my own efforts on the board and I intend to do that." 

CORRECTION-DATE: January 12, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the resignation of some black directors of the Gay Men's Health Crisis misstated the size of the board. After 3 members resigned on Monday, 26 remained, not 29.

HEADLINE: City Opera Appoints a Director

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
Paul Kellogg, an opera administrator who built the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., into a major attraction on the summer opera circuit, has been appointed general and artistic director of the New York City Opera, the company announced yesterday.
Mr. Kellogg, who is 58, succeeds Christopher Keene, who died in October. His contract runs for five years. Because Mr. Kellogg is not a conductor, as Mr. Keene was, the company is to appoint a music director as well. Mr. Kellogg and Irwin Schneiderman, a company co-chairman, said that they expected to appoint a director in a few weeks. They are also seeking a new executive director to replace Mark J. Weinstein, who is leaving to become a vice president of the National Artists Management Company. 
 An unusual aspect of Mr. Kellogg's appointment is that he is to continue as artistic director of Glimmerglass while running City Opera but will relinquish the administrative side of the Glimmerglass job. Because City Opera no longer performs in the summer, and Glimmerglass does not perform during the regular concert season, scheduling conflicts are unlikely. Moreover, City Opera stands to gain from the arrangement, which Mr. Schneiderman described as a particularly economical synergy.
Each season starting in 1997-98, the first season for which Mr. Kellogg is responsible, City Opera will share three or four Glimmerglass productions. Because the two companies are likely to use similar casts, the productions will already have had considerable rehearsal and performance time by the time they reach New York City.
"It's too early for me to discuss philosophy," Mr. Kellogg said, "because philosophical discussions inevitably lead to promises. I hope to build on the base that has been established by the last several regimes in terms of a balanced repertory and strong theatrical values, and on this company's tradition for being adventurous. But I have not yet sat at my desk or opened a folder, so I don't want to make any promises about how I hope to implement my vision for the company."
Nevertheless, in an interview at the New York State Theater yesterday, Mr. Kellogg made it clear that this vision is expansive. Saying that he wanted to maintain Mr. Keene's commitment to unusual repertory, he spoke of reviving works commissioned or first performed at the City Opera in its 52-year history, and of commissioning new works.
He also spoke of introducing more Massenet and early Mozart into the company's repertory; of reducing but not eliminating the company's commitment to operetta, and of hiring innovative directors and designers to stage standard repertory works. No names were mentioned, but Jonathan Miller, Mark Lamos and Martha Clarke have staged productions at Glimmerglass in recent seasons.
Mr. Kellogg also said he was inclined to reduce the number of productions the company stages every season without reducing the total number of performances. This season the company presented 114 performances of 15 productions and had a budget of $24 million. Mr. Schneiderman said that the company broke even last year and does not have an accumulated deficit.
But the company's finances have always been delicate, and another of Mr. Kellogg's dreams for the company may be expensive. He hinted that he would like to renovate the acoustically troublesome New York State Theater.
Mr. Kellogg may be able to raise the money for such a project. When he took over Glimmerglass in 1979, it performed in a high school auditorium and had a budget of $70,400. The company's budget last season was $3.5 million, and it also recently completed a $6 million capital campaign. In 1987, the company opened the 920-seat Alice Busch Opera Theater, an intimate, attractive house on the shore of Lake Otsego, which was built for $5 million.
Artistically, Glimmerglass has much in common with City Opera. Both companies are havens for young American singers. And both offer a balance of standard works and rarities, although Glimmerglass takes a more conservative view of the unusual, offering works like Handel's "Tamerlano," Berlioz's "Beatrice and Benedict" and Britten's "Paul Bunyan." Its production of Monteverdi's "Incoronazione di Poppea," a hit last summer, is moving to the Brooklyn Academy of Music for a run that opens tomorrow evening and continues through Jan. 21.
Mr. Kellogg was born in Hollywood and studied literature at the University of Texas, the Sorbonne and the University of Nancy in France and Columbia University. He has taught in both France and New York, and he moved to Cooperstown to write a novel in 1975. The book was never published: Mr. Kellogg said the invitation to become director of the Glimmerglass Opera interrupted his work on it.
Mr. Kellogg is the first City Opera director without a performing career. Most of the company's directors, including Laszlo Halasz, Julius Rudel and Mr. Keene, have been conductors. Mr. Keene's predecessor, Beverly Sills, became director after many years as its star soprano.
"One thing I learned at Glimmerglass," Mr. Kellogg said, "is that you cannot underestimate the intelligence of the public. The audience is demanding intellectually, and curious. I want to build an audience that grows dramatically every year based on the repertory we offer. And New York City is the best possible place to do that."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Budget Myths

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
From the public's perspective, the budget conflict seems to rest on a number of unchallengeable economic truths. In fact, they are myths.
1. There is a deficit crisis. 
 The Federal budget deficit, as a percentage of the budget, is the smallest of any of the world's seven leading industrial economies. And it is decreasing.
The deficit has fallen from 5 percent of the total national income in 1992 to 2.2 percent now. At the annual meeting of the American Economic Association this week virtually no economist argued that the deficit was a critical problem in need of immediate correction.
When the figure was much larger, there were warnings that the deficit would push this country into a financial crisis, that foreign investors would pull their money out and so on. Now that it is plainly no cause for alarm, the gloom artists tell us that the sky will fall in the future.
Deficit talk, in short, has become a permanent scare tactic, regardless of the facts. That is politics, not economics. House Republicans talk about a balanced budget when President Clinton has agreed to that and their actual objective is to gut government medical and environmental programs.
2. Republicans have to act to undo the profligacy of President Clinton and other Democrats.
On Jan. 20, 1981, the national debt was less than $1 trillion. On Jan. 20, 1993, after 12 years of the Reagan and Bush Presidencies, it was $4 trillion.
We now have to pay interest on the $3 trillion in Reagan-Bush debt. At a rate of 7 percent, that comes to $210 billion a year: more than the current deficit of $172 billion. Without that burden, the budget would be in balance.
3. Americans pay high taxes.
The Economist of London, that conservative journal, wrote last year: "By international standards, America remains a lightly-taxed country." That reality is underlined by authoritative figures from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. Here are the O.E.C.D. figures, for 1993, on total national tax revenue as a percentage of gross domestic product.
United States -- 29.7
Britain -- 33.6
France -- 43.9
Germany -- 39.0
Switzerland -- 33.2
Japan -- 29.1
The year 1993 is the latest analyzed in full by the O.E.C.D. It has issued partial figures for 1995 showing the European countries all slightly higher in their percentages. The only developed country marginally lower than the United States is Japan.
So U.S. taxes are not "high." And there is no professional consensus that it would be economically beneficial to lower them now. Herbert Stein of the American Enterprise Institute, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Nixon Administration, said last July: "I don't think there is any economic rationale for a tax cut at this time."
The myths are a political smoke screen. And they are worse than deceptive. They keep us from focusing attention on our real economic problems.
Of those problems, the most fundamental is the slowdown of the historic growth in American productivity. Over many years growth averaged 3.4 percent. But over the last 20 years it has been only 2.4 percent or so, discounting inflation.
That missing 1 percent (really a one-third fall in the rate of growth) has had devastating effects. It has cost the economy around $12 trillion over these 20 years. If the traditional growth rate had continued, the Federal budget would have been in surplus -- and American families substantially better off.
A second acute economic problem is income inequality. Since 1973, real earnings of the lowest-paid 20 percent of U.S. workers have fallen by nearly a quarter. The top 20 percent's have risen 10 percent, the very highest a lot more.
Disparities in American family income are now the greatest since they were first measured, nearly 50 years ago. The Republican budget, raising taxes on the working poor and slashing them for the rich, would increase the gulf.
Those are realities, not myths.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
