HEADLINE: In America;
Coast-To-Coast Blues

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
It was too brief, the majesty and ferocity of the storm, and the subsequent beauty and quiet of the city. Now it's back to the gritty madness of everyday life, and a look at the new year.
The appropriate musical genre for 1996 is probably the blues. Bad news followed by more bad news. It's a Presidential election year but look at the line-up of candidates -- a depressing collection of zeros on a scale of one to ten. 
 Hypocrisy is always at high tide in politics, but some kind of pinnacle of irony has been reached when Bob Dole starts complaining about corporate welfare and Al D'Amato's chief strategic weapon is an ethics probe.
Referring to a provision of the giant telecommunications bill that would provide a multibillion-dollar windfall for television broadcasters, Mr. Dole said on Wednesday, "Let's, for the sake of the taxpayers and for the sake of the American consumers, fix this one corporate welfare provision before we have to vote on it."
Just this one, mind you. No need to get crazy.
Senator D'Amato is so enjoying his role as a guardian of ethics that he now says he may not be able to finish his Whitewater probe by its end-of-February deadline. He may ask for more time, he said.
Mr. D'Amato, whose career was nurtured in a hothouse of corruption on Long Island, believes he can create enough of a stench from Whitewater to drive President Clinton from the White House. I wouldn't bet on it. The President may not want to match wits with Bill Safire, but he is certainly the Senator's equal in surviving the rough and tumble of scandal, ethical and otherwise.
Still, the President feels the need for a respite from Washington. He looked tired and stressed at yesterday's press conference. His answers to several questions, particularly those concerning the First Lady and his personal finances, were not to the point. This weekend, on the theory that foreign excursions can boost sagging public relations at home, Mr. Clinton will travel to Bosnia.
Meanwhile, the stock markets are wobbling, the economy looks increasingly shaky, there is no improvement in the employment picture, and nobody -- least of all the Presidential candidates (with the exception of Patrick Buchanan, a cure that would be worse than the disease) -- is paying much attention.
Casey Stengel once asked, "Can't anybody here play this game?" When you look at government -- state and local, as well as Federal -- the answer appears to be no. In Washington, the White House and the Republicans in Congress are in a stalemate over budget proposals that are equally bogus. In the first place, there is no crying need to balance the Federal budget. What is more important is to have government spending under control, with money available for capital needs and other investments that foster economic growth.
In the second place, if the goal is to balance the budget, why cut taxes?
In the third place, none of the proposals will really balance the budget by 2002. (Name the last big government effort that came in on time and on budget.)
At the state and local levels, governors and mayors are winging it. They haven't a clue as to how to cope with the local revenue shortfalls that will result from the budget-cutting that is already under way in Washington. In New York and New Jersey, Govs. George Pataki and Christine Todd Whitman rode into office on a tax-cut express. Now the treasuries in both states are in desperate shape. What a surprise.
In New York City, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is doing poorly in public opinion polls despite a remarkable drop in crime during his first two years in office. His obnoxious personality is part of the reason. But another part is that the problems in New York are the same as everywhere else -- a stagnant economy, not enough jobs, and no real leadership.
No one seems to know what to do. If we apply the theme of the blues to government, the appropriate song would seem to be Blind Willie McTell's "Broke Down Engine Blues."
A catalogue from the Smithsonian Collection of Recordings mentions the "plaintive, somehow urgent quality" of Mr. McTell's singing. A similar quality, or mood, is growing in the economically insecure portions of the population, a large segment of the electorate. The politicians who don't yet hear it will be hearing it soon.

HEADLINE: A Democrat Wins in Guatemala

 BODY:
Even after discounting for a slim margin and a low turnout, it is encouraging that Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen, a democrat, defeated a stand-in for Efrain Rios Montt, a former military dictator, in Guatemala's runoff presidential elections this week. Guatemalan democracy, however, remains perilously insecure. It is threatened by Mr. Rios Montt's ambitions, by the army and by the grievances churned in 35 years of civil war. Mr. Arzu's promised efforts to rein in the military and strengthen constitutional rule deserve strong American support.
Guatemala's political instability, including the long conflict between its army and leftist guerrillas, which has killed more than 100,000 people out of a population of less than 10 million, owes much to a crude American-sponsored coup during the Eisenhower Administration.The intervening years have brought repeated revelations of covert Central Intelligence Agency collaboration with murderous elements of the Guatemalan military. The pattern of C.I.A. involvement even outlasted the cold war. 
 This history alone gives America special reasons for helping to rebuild Guatemalan democracy. But apart from making amends, Washington has a considerable stake in Mr. Arzu's reform agenda. Sharing a border with Mexico, Guatemala has become a major transit route for cocaine and illegal immigrants bound for the United States. It also has Central America's largest economy.
Beginning with the Bush Administration, official American policy has supported the rule of law, human rights and a negotiated peace with the guerrillas. But despite the efforts of a succession of ambassadors, these goals have been undermined by continued covert C.I.A. cooperation with military murderers. That collaboration serves no American or Guatemalan interest. The most constructive support Washington can give Mr. Arzu is to end it.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Nets Are Being Sued by Childs, Who Charges Contract Fraud

BYLINE: By GEORGE WILLIS 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 11

 BODY:
The Nets played hardball with the reserve guard Chris Childs last fall by offering him a one-year contract for the minimum $350,000. Now Childs is playing his own brand of hardball by filing a civil lawsuit against the National Basketball Association team seeking compensatory damages.
Childs, who scored a career-high 21 points in the Nets' 92-79 victory over the Knicks on Wednesday night, filed the suit last month in United States District Court in New Jersey. It charges the Nets with fraud, negligent misrepresentation, wrongful interference with prospective economic advantage and breach of contract. 
 The suit stems from a series of conversations that Childs's agent, Steve Kauffman of Malibu, Calif., had with Nets General Manager Willis Reed beginning on Aug. 7, 1995. Childs contends in his complaint those conversations led him to turn down a lucrative offer from a team in Greece only to receive the lesser offer from the Nets.
Reed refused comment today when asked about the lawsuit. "Why don't you talk to his agent, Kauffman?" Reed said. "The agents always like to talk."
The events that led to the lawsuit began last summer when the Panionios Sporting Club, a professional basketball team in the Greek Basketball Federation, made a written offer to sign Childs, a restricted free agent at the time. The suit estimates the tax-adjusted value of the one-year offer worth $650,000 to $700,000.
Although the N.B.A. lockout was in effect and contractual matters were not allowed to be discussed between agents and N.B.A. clubs, the suit says, Kauffman telephoned Reed and informed him of the offer from the Greek team and added that he would recommend that Childs accept it.
The suit states that Reed "strongly implored" Kauffman to persuade Childs to reject the Panionios offer and assured Kauffman that after the lockout was lifted, the Nets would "promptly re-sign Childs to a contract that was as financially attractive as the Panionios offer."
The suit also contends that, based on Reed's representations, Childs decided not to accept the offer from the Greek team. Yet, once the lockout was lifted, the Nets' offer was a one-year deal for $350,000, the minimum for a restricted free agent.
Kauffman directed inquiries about the lawsuit to the litigating lawyer, George G. O'Brien of Cherry Hill, N.J., but confirmed that Childs proceeded with the lawsuit because "he felt he'd been the victim of fraudulent misrepresentation. It was a complete injustice."
Childs, reached at the hotel where he is residing, also refused comment.
O'Brien said the Nets had filed an answer to the complaint. The two sides will have an initial conference before a magistrate judge at a future date to establish guidelines for a possible trial.
"We think we have a very strong case," said O'Brien, who is seeking to recover about $300,000 to $350,000, the difference between the offer from the Greek team and Childs's current contract with the Nets. "There were a series of conversations between Steve Kauffman and Willis Reed and those are important. We also have a written offer from a Greek team for a specified amount of money."
Childs, 28, earned $150,000 last season when Reed plucked him from the Continental Basketball Association, where he toiled for five seasons. Childs played in 53 games with the Nets, starting in 11, and averaged a 5.8 points a game. Because he was a restricted free agent at the end of the season, the Nets had the right to match any offer. There was no other interest in Childs and he eventually had to accept the Nets' $350,000 deal.
"It was a very distasteful situation," Kauffman said. "It's difficult to get an offer for a restricted free agent, no matter who it is."
Even if Childs does not win the lawsuit, he could still get the last laugh. By signing a one-year deal, he'll become an unrestricted free agent at the end of this season. The Nets will own no rights to him.
Performances like the one Childs had against the Knicks, where he hit 4 of 9 3-pointers and played 42 minutes without a turnover, have raised his stock around the N.B.A. The good defender is a capable scorer who is averaging 8.8 points a game while shooting 40 percent from the field this season.
Kauffman said the Nets president, Michael Rowe, called about three weeks ago to discuss parameters for a new contract for Childs but has since dodged repeated efforts by Kauffman to continue the talks. Rowe did not respond to answering-machine messages left today at his office. With the Nets' starting point guard Kenny Anderson also scheduled to be a free agent, the future of the team's backcourt is precarious.
"If they don't want to sign Chris they should just trade him to a contending team where he could be the missing piece," Kauffman said.

 
 
REBOUNDS
 The Nets play the 76ers Friday night at Continental Airlines Arena. The former Net and current Philadelphia forward DERRICK COLEMAN will not play because of a sprained right ankle. Coleman has played in only six games this season.

HEADLINE: Bradley Backs Clinton on Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey issued a strong defense today of affirmative action in a state where the government has all but rolled it back, and he offered a timely endorsement of President Clinton's stands on race relations while excoriating most Republicans on the issue.
Even though he has recently been discouraging such speculation, Senator Bradley has been mentioned as a possible independent candidate for President. But his comments, in a speech to a civic group, appeared to move him closer to Mr. Clinton and the Democrats on one of the most sensitive issues in the campaign. 
 Mr. Bradley, a Democrat whose third term ends this year, is not running for re-election, and he has used his independence from campaigning to speak candidly about some critical economic and foreign policy issues. Nevertheless, in some respects, his speech today to the Town Hall of Los Angeles was heavy with platitudes about the need for different races to work together.
"Ultimately," he said, "the question is not only how do we counter the poverty, violence and disintegration but how do we all live together? But let us not abandon the quest to end racism."
He had one suggestion for the Government: that the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which investigates accusations of discrimination in the workplace, be given broader powers to order remedies for those who are found to have suffered discrimination.
He spoke appreciatively of Mr. Clinton's acknowledgment that there is racism in America and that affirmative action is an essential remedy. "I believe he is strongest when he talks about conviction related to race because I do think he has that conviction," the Senator said of Mr. Clinton. "But the question we need to hear him answer is, what are we doing to do about it?"
Mr. Bradley criticized the news media for what he said was oversimplifying the race issue and for failing to recognize the human faces behind racial problems. He said the three most visible black men in the news last year -- O. J. Simpson, Louis Farrakhan and Gen. Colin L. Powell -- had been little more than instruments for people to improperly demonize, ridicule or unnecessarily idealize blacks.
He attributed many of the current racial problems to economics. Mr. Bradley argued that job losses in American industries in recent years had angered blacks and whites, forcing both sides to look beyond faceless economic forces to stereotypes to explain their unfair treatment.
The Senator criticized whites for not acknowledging the racial privileges they enjoy: of being able to apply for a home loan, for instance, and not worry whether they would be rejected because of the color of their skin. "The freedom from fear is a white skin privilege," he said.
Those privileges are the reason, he argued, that affirmative action programs giving preferential treatment to blacks and other minorities in hiring and promotion are still essential to narrowing the economic gaps between the races.
"In some places affirmative action is the only way we can balance white skin privilege," he said.
As Mr. Clinton did, Mr. Bradley said some affirmative action programs needed to be modified to be fairer. He specifically mentioned a rule, repealed by Congress last year, that had given financial preferences to investment groups that included minorities in the acquisition of radio and television stations.
Mr. Bradley reserved some of his harshest words for opponents of affirmative action. He declined to mention names, but it seemed clear he had in mind the Republican Presidential candidates, most of whom have expressed reservations about affirmative action, as well as Gov. Pete Wilson of California, who is seeking to eliminate them entirely from the state.
He compared opponents of affirmative action to the people who created discriminatory laws against blacks, and said they "are often the same people who seldom have black friends and who will choose the white teacher over the black teacher for their children every time."

HEADLINE: Who's Who of Money Moguls in '96 Race

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
When Ernest and Julio Gallo set out in 1992 to remake the blue-collar image of their California wines, they turned for help to a reliable friend, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas.
The Gallos were unhappy with the Federal requirement that they label their sparkling wines, produced in huge tanks, with the words "bulk process." They considered the term demeaning and wanted to replace it with the French-sounding "Charmat method." 
 Mr. Dole, then the Senate minority leader, intervened for the Gallos with the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, and the Gallos won a favorable compromise.
E. & J. Gallo Winery may be far from Mr. Dole's home state, but he has long been interested in the company's welfare. The company has returned the interest, becoming his leading lifetime contributor, according to a report released today by the Center for Public Integrity, a nonpartisan research group in Washington.
Mr. Dole's assistance to a political donor is hardly unique, the report says. Virtually all the 1996 Presidential candidates have intertwined their political fund raising with their public actions in ways that are significant, but little known to the public.
An unprecedented $100 million has already been collected for the 1996 race. The research group's new report, based on an analysis of a wide range of public records, concluded that wealthy donors were increasingly able to influence public policy for personal gain.
"It's a package deal," said Charles Lewis, the center's executive director. "You're getting the politicians and their patrons when you elect them." The report, the result of more than a year of research and interviews, has been published in a book called, "The Buying of the President" (Avon Books, 1996).
"The truth is that big-money interests have already preselected our choices of who will become the next President of the United States," Mr. Lewis said.
The report did not offer any proposals for changes, but it urged voters to put pressure on the candidates by confronting them with questions about conflicts of interest.
Each candidate has been helped along by a small group of donors described in the report as the "top 10 career patrons." They provide substantial financial support and can be tapped for help in emergencies.
President Clinton's top 10 list contained few surprises. His top patron has been Goldman Sachs, the New York investment bank that has been closely tied to his Administration. Officers of the bank have given Mr. Clinton's campaigns $107,850, and Robert E. Rubin, a former co-chairman of the firm, and his wife made a $275,000 contribution from their personal foundation to the New York Host Committee for the 1992 Democratic convention. Mr. Clinton later named Mr. Rubin Treasury Secretary.
Mr. Rubin, the report said, spearheaded Goldman Sachs' move into the Mexican market, and later, as Treasury Secretary, he engineered policies that helped shore up the faltering Mexican economy, moves that ultimately helped bondholders and Goldman Sachs.
Also on Mr. Clinton's top 10 list were Arkansas companies and Washington and New York law firms.
But his fifth-ranking lifetime patron was unexpected: the Gallo family. Despite the Gallos longstanding support for Senator Dole, they began donating to Mr. Clinton in early 1992, as his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination began to gather strength. Steve Swasey, a spokesman for Gallo, said the Gallos would not comment on the reasons for their political contributions.
They have been even more generous to Mr. Dole, and their donations continue. Over his lifetime in politics, Mr. Dole has received more from Gallo, its officials and employees than from any other donors. They have given more than $381,000 to his campaigns and another $790,000 to the Dole Foundation, a charitable entity Mr. Dole formed in 1983 to help the handicapped.
In the wine labeling matter, Mr. Dole and then-Senator John Seymour of California wrote to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms on Gallo's behalf. In the end, the company was permitted to change the words "bulk process" to "secondary fermentation before bottling." But perhaps the most significant help Mr. Dole offered the company came in 1986, when he was majority leader and a senior member of the Finance Committee. He helped to push through the Senate an amendment to a tax reform bill that would save the Gallo brothers' heirs more than $100 million in inheritance taxes. Dole campaign committees received $20,000 from Gallo family members while the bill was being drafted, the report says.
Over his career, from 1973 to 1995, Mr. Dole has raised more than $70 million, "more special interest money than anyone running for President in 1996," Mr. Lewis said. The report says Mr. Dole "rarely championed" reform of the political process. Spokesmen for Mr. Dole, who has been in politics longer than anyone else in the race, did not respond to questions about the report.
Senator Phil Gramm's top lifetime patron was the National Rifle Association, the report said. The group has given him more than $440,000 since 1979, more than it has given any other politician. "Gramm has not disappointed the N.R.A.," the report said. In the last decade, he has introduced, sponsored or voted with the organization's interests on 18 major gun bills, the researchers found.
Mr. Gramm also has a close relationship with the American Medical Association, his second-ranking lifetime patron. Its members have given his campaigns more than $140,000 over the years. Mr. Gramm has stood staunchly with the group's interests, helping to defeat aspects of the Clinton Administration's managed care proposals. Mr. Gramm's campaign spokesman did not respond to questions about the report.
Both houses of Congress have passed measures limiting gifts from lobbyists and requiring greater disclosure of their activities. But efforts at campaign finance reform have met with fierce resistance in Congress in the 20 years since the first campaign finance laws were enacted as a response to Watergate and related scandals.
"We are basically asking the foxes to lock themselves out of the chicken coops," Mr. Lewis said. "Most foxes won't do that."
But some have said recently that there is a growing movement in Congress to deal with the issue this year.
Ann McBride, who heads Common Cause, the public affairs lobby, said today that disgust with the system had led to unusually strong bipartisan support for a bill that was recently introduced by conservatives, liberals and moderates. The measure would establish spending limits for campaigns, provide free and reduced-cost television time, and ban so-called soft money, the loosely regulated party political funds that attract large donations that are banned for individual candidates.
"There is overwhelming anger about this issue around this country," she said, "and a real desire for change."

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET;
Excerpts From President's News Conference on Impasse in the Budget Talks

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the opening statement and the question-and-answer portion of President Clinton's news conference, held today in the East Room of the White House. It was provided by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Good afternoon. I want to report to you this afternoon and to the American people about the progress we've made toward achieving a balanced budget that reflects our values. 
 . . .
 After many weeks of public debate and private discussion, historic agreement on a balanced budget is within reach if we set aside partisanship and work to seize this moment. I'm optimistic that we will balance the budget, and I know we have come too far to let this opportunity slip away.
In the 12 years before I took office, for the first time in America's peacetime history, our Government deficit skyrocketed. Our Administration has already cut the deficit nearly in half, but our need to pay off the interest on the debt run up in the last 12 years is giving us a deficit.
Indeed, but for the interest payments on the debt run up in the 12 years before I became President, our budget would be in balance today.
We have already reduced the size of the Federal Government by more than 200,000, so that it is smaller than it has been at any time since 1965. As a percentage of the civilian work force, the Federal Government is the smallest it's been since 1933.
We've cut hundreds of programs. We're eliminating 16,000 pages of rules and regulations, but it's time to finish the job.
Let me be clear. We can balance the budget. We can do it in a way that invests in our people and reflects our values -- opportunity for all, doing our duty for our parents and our children, strengthening our communities, our families and America.
As all of you know, I have submitted a plan to balance the budget in seven years, using the conservative estimates of the Congressional Budget Office.
Let me repeat, with this letter, which I am carrying around with me to remind everyone that we have done it, Congress's own economist confirmed what we have said all along. We can balance the budget without excessive cuts in Medicare and Medicaid, without cutting education or the environment or raising taxes on our hardest-pressed working families.
Now, as all of you know also, the Republicans in Congress are insisting on cuts in Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment that I believe are well beyond what is necessary to balance the budget, well beyond what is necessary to secure the solvencies of programs, well beyond what is necessary for the Congressional Budget Office to say we have to do to balance the budget.
We all know, too, that there are two strings at work in the Republican effort. There is the genuine desire to balance the budget, which I share. But there are those who want to use the balanced budget, and a huge tax cut crammed within the balanced budget, to strip our national Government and our country of our ability to do our part here in Washington to help people out in our communities with the challenges they face.
We shouldn't let our fundamental agreement on a balanced budget be held hostage to a narrower agenda that seeks to prevent America from giving Medicare to senior citizens or quality nursing home care or educational opportunity for young people, or environmental protection to all of us. We could quickly find common ground on balancing the budget, and providing appropriate modest tax relief. We could do this in 15 minutes, after the tens of hours we have already spent together.
What has held up this agreement is the insistence of the Republicans on cuts that I believe are excessive in Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment, and the insistence on a tax hike on the lowest-income of our working families.
These things are not necessary to balance the budget. Having said that, let me say we have come a long way. We have agreed on well over $600 billion of savings, far more than necessary to balance the budget. This should be a moment for national unity, a time to put aside partisanship, to reject ideology, to find common ground for the common good.
A balanced budget that reflects the best of both parties, the best of our values, and will pass on to the next generation a stronger America -- that is within our grasp. We should get it done now, and I believe we will get it done in the near future.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Hillary Clinton
Q. Mr. President, some newly released documents raise questions about some statements by Mrs. Clinton on the White House Travel Office, firings and her role in representing the Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan Association. Do you think it would be good idea for her to testify before Congress to clear up these issues?
A. Well, she has said that she will do whatever is necessary to answer all the appropriate questions, and I think that she should do that. And I think that we will determine in the days ahead together what is necessary. She has begun to answer those questions. We'll be doing some more of that before the week is out, and I presume we'll be doing quite a lot of it in the days ahead.
And as you know, there was a hearing, I think, today on part of this matter in the Senate and will be another one next week. These questions should be answered. Let me say for four years, as these questions have come up, we have tried to answer them all. We have tried to be fully cooperative, and we will be in this case. And I think she should do what is necessary to answer the questions. That's what she said she'll do, and I think that's what will happen.
. . .
 
The Negotiations
Q. Mr. President, Speaker Gingrich seems to have thrown in the towel on the budget. Thinks, says something about there won't be a budget, not until the next election. And you talked to Senator Dole today. Did he agree with that? What's going to happen? Is there a meeting on Wednesday? And is there -- also, the last proposal you put on the table, did that make a lot of new major concessions?
A. Well, let me try to answer all those questions. First of all, we all pledged, all the parties, that we would not discuss our proposals that would require all of us to agree. So I don't believe that I should violate the understandings that we had in our meeting to discuss the specifics. Let me say that we have come very close together. I believe we have come most of the way. The differences in dollars are not as different now as some of the differences in policies.
. . .
 I called Senator Dole today because I just kind of wanted to check in with him and get a reality check. I said you know when we left that meeting, I asked you and I asked the Democratic leaders to consider a proposal that I made because I had not made it to the Democrats either. I wanted them, all four, to look at it. We had an agenda of things that our staffs were going to work on during this week.
And we characterized it, quite consciously, as a recess. And I still feel that we can and should reach an agreement, and I just want to make sure you feel that way and, if so, we'll keep working together. And I got a pretty good response.
Now I've not had a chance to talk to the Speaker. But I can tell you this: When we left, we agreed that they would consider the last suggestion I made, all of them. We agreed that there would be certain things that we would work on together and with the governors. We agreed that this would be a recess, and we agreed that we would meet on Wednesday. So I assume that all that is still the way it was agreed.
Q. Are the American people going to have to tolerate one shutdown after another and in neglect of all its services?
A. Well, as you know, I don't approve of any of these shutdowns. I think Congress was wrong to do it the first time. I think it was wrong to continue. I was pleased when Senator Dole said that that policy should be abandoned, and I was pleased when the Speaker said that it was morally indefensible to hold the Federal employees hostage. So I do not believe it will shut down again. There is no need to have a shutdown again.
. . .
 Q. The offer that you made over the weekend -- certified now, as you point out, by the Congressional Budget Office -- has extracted from the Republicans a rather substantial set of concessions, the most substantial they've made yet. In light of that, they seem to be expecting you to counter that with a similar offer of your own. If you did, and you're as close as you say they are, it seems that would almost clinch it.Why not go ahead and do that, sir?
A. Well, that's my speech. You just made my speech for me. [laughter] I have, first of all, I believe if you look at the spending concessions and you start from equal points, whether you start from our beginning budget offers or the ones that were made back in December, we have both made substantial concessions away from our original point.
My belief is that we should go for a balanced budget that is scored in a way that Congress recognizes, because that's what the law requires. But that having done that, we should not violate the other conditions of our previous agreement, which is to take any risks with Medicare or Medicaid or do things that we know will cause us to undermine our investment in education and the environment.
Now, we can do that and get a tax cut. We still have some differences on policies relating to Medicare. We're trying to work out our differences over Medicaid. We still have some significant differences on environmental polices, but I believe all that can be worked out. And so that's why I say I have been somewhat surprised at some of the negative tone of the stories coming out since we adjourned because I frankly felt quite good, and I did make them, as I said, an offer that I hoped that they would sleep on and work on.
Q. Well, is now the time for the President to come forward and say: Let's split the difference?
A. It's not as simple as splitting the difference. It's not just -- there's more than money at stake here.
There are policies at stake, and if you split the difference again, according to the rules of the Congressional Budget Office, there must be policies which back up whatever number that you pick. So that's why I say that if we know we can balance the budget, and we know it'll work over seven years, we shouldn't go beyond that in any kind of gratuitous cuts in Medicare and Medicaid.
. . .

Mrs. Clinton
Q. Mr. President, when you campaigned in 1992, you and the First Lady both said that the American people would get two for the price of one. I wondered if that's still going to be a slogan in 1996, and if the First Lady has really taken the role that you envisioned for her, as First Lady, or if she's just simply become too controversial?
A. Well, first of all, I think she's done a fine job. I probably, I may have asked her to do more than anybody should ever have been asked to do when I asked her to undertake the health care effort. But there are worse things than wanting every American child to have health care coverage; that's the way every child in every other advanced country in the world has.
I believe that, you know, in the last six months or eight months she wanted to take a lot of time off to write her book, which she did do, and I think the book is a very important contribution to America, which reflects 25 years of work, learning and exposure on her part, and I expect that she will continue to be an enormous, positive force in this country. And, in terms of controversy, very often in this town, you know, you don't make yourself controversial -- someone else makes you controversial. So I don't think you can do anything about that, especially in the wake of the health care issue.
Q. If I could just follow up, sir. Are you saying that her conduct, especially involving the travel office and the discrepancies in what she said about her involvement in Madison Guaranty, whether, that these things have nothing to do with the controversy?
A. Well, let me tell you, you are assuming something that has not been proved. No discrepancies have been established. Now, we were all concerned, as we have all said, that we kept hearing all these reports after we got here that there were problems with the Travel Office. It turns out there were problems with the Travel Office, and they were serious. An accounting firm said they were serious. Those have been corrected. The American people should feel good about that.
We also said -- Mr. McLarty did, who was then the Chief of Staff, undertook his own review and said the matter wasn't handled well and detailed why. There have been something like seven reviews of the travel office, so I would just, I would dispute your characterizations. An allegation is not the same thing as a fact.
And particularly I would remind the American people, when it comes to the whole Whitewater issue, the allegations have often -- and, matter of fact, virtually always -- borne no relationship to the facts. That's really the story of this for the last four years: an allegation comes up and we answer it, and then people say, "Well, here's another allegation. Answer this." And then, "Here's another allegation. Answer this." That is the way we are living here in Washington today. We're going to do it, and I would ask that -- the American people are fundamentally fair-minded, and, as I would say, I just ask all of you to listen to the answers and do what the American people would do: Make up your own mind.
Q. Mr. President, do you worry about the cumulative effect of this drumbeat which is getting louder? As of close of business today, there will be more people under subpoena in the travel office matter than were fired in the travel office matter and, second, you must have discussed why it is -- even if cleared in the end of all charges -- why it is your wife, the First Lady, appears to be the, arguably, the most controversial First Lady, at least in modern politics.
A. Since Eleanor Roosevelt, for many of the same reasons, from many of the same sources, and that's just part of what we're living through. The American people can make up their own mind about the facts of it.

Personal Finances
Q. To kind of stay on this theme of controversy, the end result seems to be that it's taken a toll financially on your obligations, and there's a magazine report out that's assessed your situation and basically decides that you're pretty close to bankruptcy. Could you give us a little bit of the financial toll?
A. You know, I feel worse, I suppose that that probably is right. I've never added it all up, but that's probably right. And I would like to remind you that today, finally at long last, records that everybody knew existed that weren't released apparently have been released.
Apparently the Republicans finally agreed to release the Resolution Trust Corporation report, which spent another $4 million of the taxpayers' money, to say what we said all along -- that there is no basis even for a civil action against us, that we told the truth about the land agreement we had. That we'd lost the money we said we'd lost. That we had nothing to do with operating the savings and loan. That we took no money from it. Just like we said all along.
So I think that that's apparently part of the price of this. I tell you, I feel a lot worse about all the innocent people who work here, who don't have particularly high salaries and don't have the net worth that we brought here, who had to hire lawyers and pay legal fees, too, who were completely innocent of any wrongdoing and who have to deal with that.
. . .
 But I do think it is interesting -- when you were talking about getting the budget balanced, and the controversy over Medicare, that this Congress has had over 40 hearings on Whitewater and one hearing on its Medicare bill. . . .
 
Program Cuts
Q. Back to the budget for a second, if the Republicans agree to reduce their tax cut, would you in turn agree to make more cuts in Medicare and Medicaid?
A. Let me say again: I think it is wrong. First of all, I agreed not to discuss the negotiations retrospectively. And I've had a hard enough time negotiating in private. I can't do it with you as well as them. But I want to make two comments. First of all, it is important that the budget numbers have integrity. Therefore, it is important that the budget number be supported by policies to achieve that number.
And I have not offered anything that I did not think there was a policy to back up that would actually save money without hurting our efforts to provide Medicare to the seniors or to help poor and disabled children or the seniors in nursing homes that get the benefit of the Medicaid program.
. . .
 Now, as a general proposition, I don't think that I or any Democrat -- and, I believe, any Republicans -- want to be in the position of appearing to have cut Medicare and Medicaid to fund an excessive tax cut. On the other hand, we can have some modest but significant tax relief in this budget bill if we do it right.
 
The Markets
Q. Mr. President, back to the economy again. In assuming that perhaps some of the pessimism might be justified as the markets have done in the past couple of days, are you willing first of all to consider a long-term C.R. [continuing resolution] that would keep the Government operating but not settle the budget question until, as you say, there is an election about it. And, two, are you willing to pay the economic price of that happening, considering the way the markets reacted over the past couple of days on news that there may not be a deal?
A. Well, let me answer you -- let me give you two answers to that. First of all, if that happens, I'll cross that bridge when I come to it, and we'll all have to talk about it. But every time we have started to talk about what would happen if we didn't reach an agreement in our private meetings and how we would move forward, we stopped after about two minutes because at least in the context of our private conversations, no one has wanted to acknowledge that we could not reach an agreement for a plan over seven years because we are close enough to do it and because we know we owe it to the United States to do it. . . .
 So I would say to the American people and to the financial markets, we're going to get this budget deficit down until the budget is balanced, but the best way to do it is to sign an agreement now so people can see. It's like the man on the moon -- the budget will be balanced by X date. And that's what I think we should do, and I still believe that we will. Yes, sir.
 
Tax Cut
Q. Mr. President, back on the budget, the Republicans propose a tax cut. You propose a tax cut. How will a tax cut, a modest tax cut, reduce the deficit?
A. Well, first of all, the tax cut won't reduce the deficit unless it leads to increased growth in the context of the deficit-reduction plan. If it does lead to increased growth, if it's part of -- if it's a balanced plan, so that the deficit reduction still has credibility, then the tax cut can play an important part of that by helping to provide some extra income, particularly to hard-pressed families with children, who've had a more difficult time the last 10 or 15 years.
. . .
 
The Economy
Q. Mr. President, no budget deal could well mean no increase in the Government's borrowing authority, and I'm wondering whether you are willing to risk default as one of the costs of having no deal, or whether you're willing to invoke some emergency powers to increase that authority, even though the Treasury has been concerned that they may not have the legal basis to do that?
A. The Secretary of the Treasury has done a very good job in managing that so far, and has not done anything that he has not been told he's on solid ground in doing.
I think it would be wrong and almost inconceivable for the United States to default on its debt. It was bad enough to shut the Government down. It was harmful to the American people and to the good people who work for the Federal Government. That was wrong as part of some sort of strategy, and this would be wrong. We have never refused to pay our debts. We are a great nation, and I don't believe we'll do that.
 . . .
 Q. Mr. President, do you see any danger to the economy if there's no budget deal this year at all, such as a recession?
A. There should not be. We have the lowest combined rates of inflation and unemployment in 27 years now. We have worked very hard to keep unemployment going down -- keep it well down under 6 percent -- and to keep the inflation low. The underlying fundamentals are good, and our economic analysts say that they expect continued growth with no inflation in 1996.
I think it would -- let me just say this, I think that if we could get a budget agreement, it would be better for the economy because I think it would be a spur for even lower interest rates and to have a longer recovery with longer, more stable growth. So I don't know that anything bad will happen if we don't get it, but it would be considerably better if we did.
. . .
 
Budget Issues
Q. Mr. President, what are the issues you think should be deferred to the election? You've mentioned Medicare and Medicaid several times as things you just can't tolerate that degree of cuts.
A. I think -- and the structure of Medicare. You know, we can try some experiments, but to fundamentally change the structure of Medicare so that it would no longer be a recognizable guarantee for our seniors, I think that is going too far in the direction of just turning it over to insurance companies and other private providers.
Whether Medicaid should be a block grant instead of a guarantee from the nation to our poor and disabled children and to seniors in nursing homes, that's something I think could be deferred to the election.
But we can make an 80 percent agreement because I am in favor of letting the states have much more flexibility.
. . .
I don't see why we should cloud this budget agreement with controversial items like whether we should drill in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Those things are not necessary to balance the budget.

HEADLINE: A Change in Japan? Style, Not Direction

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Ryutaro Hashimoto pledged "reform and creativity" upon becoming Japan's new Prime Minister on Thursday, but he appointed a Cabinet that is likely to continue existing policies in many areas.
Mr. Hashimoto, who at 58 is relatively young for a Prime Minister, is known as aggressive and assertive and is expected to bring a new freshness to Japanese politics. But the Cabinet he chose is a fairly conventional one. 
 In the biggest surprise, Mr. Hashimoto appointed a Socialist, Wataru Kubo, to the powerful position of Finance Minister, a job no one wanted because it will involve defending the Government's unpopular plan to resolve a banking crisis by spending nearly $7 billion in taxpayers' money.
The other top posts went to members of Mr. Hashimoto's Liberal Democratic Party, with the members chosen from the various factions, as is the norm.
Mr. Hashimoto's election returned the Prime Minister's job to the Liberal Democrats, who governed Japan continuously for nearly four decades before being ousted in 1993 because of corruption and failure to enact electoral reforms. But the party must still share power in the coalition with the Socialist Party and the smaller Harbinger Party.
Mr. Hashimoto made only a few remarks on Thursday to the press. In addition to his promise of reform and creativity, he pledged support for the United States-Japan security alliance, while noting the opposition of many people in Okinawa to having American bases concentrated on their island.
"I will try to make Japan-U.S. ties deeper and ask for understanding by the people toward the firm maintenance of the bilateral security system," the Kyodo News Service quoted Mr. Hashimoto as saying.
Mr. Hashimoto's election was never in doubt. Members of the lower house of Parliament met on Thursday and each wrote his or her own name and the name of their choice for Prime Minister on a piece of paper. They brought their ballots to the front in a long procession.
Mr. Hashimoto garnered 288 votes out of 489 cast, well ahead of the 167 recorded by Ichiro Ozawa, the head of the opposition New Frontier Party. When the results were announced, Mr. Hashimoto stood up to applause and bowed deeply in three directions.
A similar vote was held in the less powerful upper house, where Mr. Hashimoto got 158 votes and Mr. Ozawa 69.
After being officially inducted into office by Emperor Akihito, Mr. Hashimoto and his Cabinet had their first meeting around midnight on Thursday.
Experts do not expect bold changes in direction, in part because the same coalition of three parties is still running the Government and because the Prime Minister does not have that much power in Japan.
But there could be changes in style from the administration of Tomiichi Murayama, the docile Prime Minister who resigned and will now concentrate on protecting the Socialist Party from extinction.
"This administration will make necessary decisions more quickly," said Seizaburo Sato, research director of the Institute for International Policy Studies, a nonprofit research institute set up by Yasuhiro Nakasone, a former Prime Minister.
Mr. Ozawa, the opposition leader, blasted the coalition Government once again on Thursday for transferring power from Mr. Murayama to Mr. Hashimoto without holding an election. Mr. Hashimoto is the fifth Prime Minister in three years and the fourth since the last election for the lower house was held, in July 1993.
Mr. Ozawa, who is every bit as strong-willed as Mr. Hashimoto, is facing possible defections from his own party and wants new elections as soon as possible. In the coming session of Parliament, he will attack the new administration with gusto, focusing on the plan to bail out mortgage corporations, known as jusen, that ran up billions of dollars in bad debts through reckless lending.
"Ozawa is desperate," said Shigenori Okazaki, a political analyst with SBC Warburg Securities in Tokyo. He predicted that Mr. Hashimoto "will be completely bogged down with the jusen problem and he'll be on the defensive."
The job of defending the bailout plan, at the risk of ruining his own political reputation, will fall to Mr. Kubo, who is the second-ranking official in the Socialist Party. A former high school history teacher who will turn 67 on Monday, Mr. Kubo has never held a Cabinet position, although he has served on the finance committee in the upper house of Parliament.
The important position of chief Cabinet secretary -- who serves as the Government's chief spokesman and as the Prime Minister's right hand -- was given to Seiroku Kajiyama, 69, a strongly conservative veteran strategist for the Liberal Democratic Party.
As Justice Minister in 1990, Mr. Kajiyama caused a furor in the United States by comparing foreign prostitutes in Japan to American blacks who move into white neighborhoods and "ruin the atmosphere." He was the secretary general of the Liberal Democratic Party in 1993 when it fell from power, after some of its members abandoned the party because of its failure to enact electoral reforms.
The new Foreign Minister will be Yukihiko Ikeda, 58, a former chief of the Defense Agency and a son-in-law of the late Prime Minister Hayato Ikeda.
The 21-member Cabinet has one woman, Justice Minister Ritsuko Nagao, 62. A former bureaucrat in the Health and Welfare Ministry, she is also the only Cabinet member who is not a member of Parliament.
If arguments in the Cabinet become heated, swords might be drawn -- literally. Like Prime Minister Hashimoto, the Finance Minister, Mr. Kubo, and the new chief of the Defense Agency, Hideo Usui, are all masters in the martial art of kendo, a Japanese style of fencing.

HEADLINE: Whitman Puts Standards Above Money For Schools

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today told a Legislature with no cash to spare that New Jersey would achieve educational fairness between rich and poor school districts by rewriting the rules of education, not by writing new state school-aid checks.
The Governor turned her second annual message to the Legislature into an extended expression of her view that the problem with New Jersey's schools is not the lack of money -- more is already spent for each pupil than in any other state -- but the lack of uniform standards for all students. In her address, she sought to lay out the philosophical underpinnings of her education proposal and did not attempt to provide details. 
 New Jersey is under an order from the State Supreme Court to produce a plan to eliminate the spending differences between the mostly prosperous suburbs and 30 poor urban and rural districts by September. During the two decades that this legal battle has been fought, various administrations have focused on achieving parity in per-pupil spending among the districts, a task that would cost the state $450 million a year in additional school aid.
But with the justices of the State Supreme Court arrayed below her as she addressed a joint session of the new State Legislature, Mrs. Whitman said today that the state financing plan, due out later this month, would be based on how much it costs to provide a constitutionally mandated "thorough and efficient education," not on chasing the ever-higher spending levels of the richest suburbs.
"It has become increasingly clear that making a direct link between high spending and high achievement leads to a false conclusion," the Governor said. "A great deal more goes into a successful education than an expensive education program."
The Governor singled out a handful of districts, mostly small and well off, that have managed to produce strong testing results while spending less per pupil than the state average. Only late in her speech did Mrs. Whitman address the role of poverty and social chaos in the plight of children in the poorest cities, saying those districts should be given "added resources to help counter the negative effects of poverty on learning."
All but missing in Mrs. Whitman's second annual address was the usual catalogue of good news and self-congratulatory backward glances that typically grace such moments. The Governor took only a few lines to note that the centerpiece of her career as Governor and as a national Republican figure, the 30 percent income tax cut completed last year, took full effect on the first of this month.
The Governor credited the tax cuts with creating 117,000 new jobs since she took office two years ago. But she devoted more time to thanking the cleanup crews from this week's big storm.
Also missing were the big-canvas national themes on social justice and individual rights that Mrs. Whitman has used in the past to burnish her reputation as a leader of her party's moderate wing, as the Republican Presidential nomination process enters its final months.
Instead, Mrs. Whitman's narrowly drawn speech fit the mood of the state and its Legislature these days. The tax cut and a state economy that shows signs of weakening have left state lawmakers with no money to spend on new programs and considerable forebodings about the task of writing a new state budget this spring without the $1.2 billion in taxes forfeited by the tax cut.
Moreover, the recently announced layoffs of 7,000 employees at New Jersey's largest private employer, AT&T, has rattled a state in which unemployment rates, once the lowest in the region, have crept past the national average and now stand at 6.1 percent.
"As many laid-off white-collar workers have now discovered, a good education has its limitations when there are no jobs available," Joseph V. Doria Jr., the Assembly Democratic leader, said after the speech.
Mrs. Whitman acknowledged the concern over the AT&T cuts, which amount to the loss of 13 percent of the company's New Jersey work force. Resorting to a euphemism that she would probably have spurned in more cheerful times, the Governor said, "while we can't stop corporate downsizing, we can create a climate that insures that lost jobs are replaced with others."
The school financing plan, developed over the last year by Education Commissioner Leo T. Klagholz, would work like this: the state would determine a core curriculum and how much it should cost, including salaries, books, laboratories, sports and so on. It would then use that figure as the basis for state aid, which consumes a third of New Jersey's $16 billion budget, shifting money from rich to poor to insure that the poor districts reach the minimal per-pupil level.
If a district wishes to spend more than the base figure, it would be free to do so, but at its own expense.
Democrats and Republicans alike said they agreed with Mrs. Whitman's philosophy. Democrats criticized the lack of detail in the speech, while Republicans were more supportive.
"It was a good speech," said State Senator Peter A. Inverso, a Republican from the Trenton suburb of Hamilton. "The question is, how much is she going to take from a place like Hamilton to make it work? That's what we're waiting to find out."
Mrs. Whitman's speeches on education have not only been marked by an absence of detail, but also by a lack of follow-through. The Governor came into office in 1994 speaking aggressively about promoting school vouchers and about the need for recertification -- meaning an end to tenure -- to root out teachers who are burned out.
The school voucher plan has been relegated to a study commission, and the Governor has not raised the subject of teacher testing since the teachers' union imposed a special membership tax to defeat the plan.
To illustrate her argument that money does not buy scholastic achievement, Mrs. Whitman offered the example of Holmdel High School, in Monmouth County, as a district with the highest Scholastic Assessment Test scores in the state -- 595 in math, 509 verbal -- while spending $8,364 per pupil per year, below the state average of $8,700.
She did not mention that Holmdel is one of New Jersey's wealthiest communities.
Several Democrats said the Governor had no choice but to play down the role that money plays in education, given the constraints imposed on the state budget by her tax cuts.
"If we are in a box that limits our ability to fund a quality education," said Assemblyman Joseph J. Roberts Jr., a Camden Democrat and party leader on fiscal issues, "then it is a box that the Governor designed and built with her tax cuts."

HEADLINE: The Divine Write-Off;
Republicans Tiptoe Around the Mortgage Deduction

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The Republican flat-taxers' vision of an income tax so simple that it could be filed on a postcard, with everyone paying the same rate, is about to run into the middle class's devotion to its single-biggest tax break: the deduction for home-mortgage interest.
Next week, a private commission appointed by the Republican leaders of Congress to promote the flat tax -- a concept the Republicans hope will help secure their control of Washington for decades -- is to issue its report recommending what supporters see as the best way to revive the economy through a new tax system. 
 But the panel, headed by Jack Kemp, the former Congressman and Housing Secretary, is expected to veer around the mortgage-interest deduction on the ground that it is so deeply embedded in middle-class hopes and financial planning that to challenge it would be political suicide.
The 25-page report from the National Commission on Economic Growth and Tax Reform, which was still being refined last Friday, according to Grace-Marie Arnett, its executive director, was unanimously approved by the 14 commissioners.
Privately, the commission has promised not to denounce the deduction, said Stephen D. Driesler, chief lobbyist for the National Association of Realtors. "The worst thing now would be for them to remain silent," said Mr. Driesler, who hopes at best for a modest statement supporting the deduction.
With Mr. Kemp as chairman, there was never any doubt that the commission would support the general idea of a personal flat tax -- with only wages and salaries above a certain minimum being taxed at a single, relatively low rate.
The problem the panel faces is that eliminating preferences, loopholes and deductions is the mantra of the flat taxers. Deductions not only favor one type of investment over another -- housing over stocks, say -- but every one that is preserved costs the Government revenue and means the flat tax rate must be that much higher to collect the same amount. In the case of the mortgage-interest deduction, even the National Association of Home Builders, an ardent defender, says the break costs the Treasury $60 billion a year.
And if one special interest -- in this case homeowners -- gets to keep its tax break, then Washington policy makers will find it harder, analysts predict, to say no to others.
"It will be perceived as a loophole," said Daniel J. Mitchell, an economist at the conservative Heritage Foundation who advised the Kemp commission. "If you leave it in, then it is easier to justify the next one. I want to start out pure."
Today, though, more than 80 years after it was introduced as part of the original income tax code, the mortgage interest deduction is seen as an entitlement. It is built into the economic calculations of every significant player in the $8 trillion housing market -- of buyers, sellers, brokers and builders. It props up property values, restricting who can afford home ownership and how much buyers make on their investments. Likewise, it colors the assumptions of local governments that rely on property taxes to finance their operations.
"The mortgage-interest deduction is the middle-class experience," said Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a Washington nonprofit group, which is supported by unions and other liberal groups, that contends the tax code favors the rich. "True, only 28 percent of taxpayers take it in any given year, but 10 percent plan to take it and 15 percent used to and everyone selling their house expects the buyer to take it."
Elke Heitmeyer, who owns an import-export business in Los Angeles, is typical of those would-be homeowners who factor the deduction into their financial planning. "Mortgage interest is one of the few ways left to keep some of the money you make," said Ms. Heitmeyer, 41, who hopes this year to move from her rented home to one she will buy with the help of a mortgage.
As Mr. Kemp and his colleagues have discovered, there is no comparable mass constituency that favors getting rid of the deduction. Instead, that case is made by economists who, from across the ideological spectrum, argue that eliminating the deduction might -- in the long haul -- have salutary effects.
Initially, housing prices would fall because the value of the mortgage interest deduction inflates prices, though just how much is debatable, and the shock could well have a strong negative effect on the economy. But if interest rates fall, too -- as advocates predict -- more people would be able to own their own homes. Interest rates should fall, the economists Robert Hall and Alvin Rabushka say in their book "The Flat Tax," because interest from any source would no longer be taxable as income and, therefore as with municipal bonds, lenders would accept lower rates.
Senator Richard Shelby, an Alabama Republican who is co-sponsor, with the House majority leader, Dick Armey of Texas, of a flat tax plan introduced in Congress that would eliminate the mortgage-interest deduction, acknowledges that house prices might fall in the short run. But in his view, the long-term benefits -- like making it possible for more people to buy their own homes -- outweigh that cost.
"People are less concerned with a home-mortgage deduction than they are with having money in their pockets," Senator Shelby said. And Ms. Heitmeyer, for one, supports his opinion. "I'd need to calculate whether it's better," she said, "but I'm in favor of whatever makes housing more affordable."
Among industrialized countries, the mortgage-interest deduction is far from universal. The Norwegians discarded theirs several years ago, and Canada and Australia maintain high levels of home ownership without providing such a tax break.
But in Washington and across the nation, saying it might make good fiscal sense in the long term to get rid of the mortgage-interest deduction is a little like advocating the metric system: economic logic may not be enough to persuade Americans to learn a new economic math.
Polls show that about two-thirds of the public -- slightly more than the portion that owns homes -- favors the mortgage-interest deduction, looking on it as the one big break remaining after the income tax overhauls of 1981 and 1986.
That high level of support for a policy that bolsters the cost of housing is not really surprising: Americans, 64 percent of whom live in owner-occupied homes, have half their net worth tied up in their houses. Indeed, the lower a homeowner's income, the larger a home looms as a share of his or her personal wealth.
About 40 percent of homes are owned free and clear. Of the 60 percent of homes with mortgages, about half were bought with less than the traditional 20 percent down.
That means that a drop in prices caused by eliminating the mortgage- interest deduction could leave millions of people with little equity -- or even owing more than their houses are worth. Homeowners, lenders and local real estate markets would almost certainly reel if the deduction was eliminated.
Various studies have put the short-term decline at from 4.8 percent to 30 percent, with the highest-price homes taking the biggest hits. "The immediate impact would be devastating," said David Lereah, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association. "We estimate that default rates, now about 1 percent, would rise to about 4 percent" -- a rate high enough to make some lenders fold.
Mr. Mitchell of the Heritage Foundation said that any short-term decline would be offset by a rise in stocks and other investments.
Still, the extent of middle-class support for the deduction -- and the importance politicians attach to it -- obscures the fact that more affluent homeowners garner the greatest benefits from the break.
The deduction saves taxpayers making $40,000 to $50,000 an average of $944 a year on their Federal income tax bills, with the greatest benefits accruing in the early years of home ownership, when most of each monthly payment reflects interest, not principal. But those making $100,000 to $200,000 a year save four times that much, according to an analysis by Peter Dreier, a professor of public policy at Occidental College in Los Angeles. The top 1 percent of taxpayers, those with taxable incomes above $200,000, shave an average of $8,348 off their tax bill by taking the deduction, Professor Dreier found.
Over all, Professor Dreier said, more than 44 percent of the tax benefits go to the top 5 percent of taxpayers, who together save $22 billion annually.
"You can't defend this on policy grounds," said Mr. McIntyre of Citizens for Tax Justice. "It is a stupid subsidy, because the more money you make the more subsidy you get."
In fact, the main defense of the deduction offered by its backers could fairly be described as inertia.
"When you see a large tax expenditure that is going to a relatively small group you have to question it," allowed Dave Crowe, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders. "But it is in place, and it works, and discontinuing it would cause such dislocations."
The Kemp commission was lobbied heavily by the two main supporters of retaining the mortgage interest deduction, the National Association of Realtors, with 750,000 members, and the National Association of Home Builders, with 185,000 members.
Others who support maintaining the deduction would tinker with it to focus the benefit on the less well-off.
"The provision of some concession to home ownership is appropriate in the tax system," said Max Sawicky of the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research center in Washington. "But it doesn't have to be nearly as expensive as it is now, and it doesn't have to be skewed" to the rich."
Earlier this year Robert Packwood, a former Republican Senator from Oregon who was chairman of the Finance Committee, proposed limiting the mortgage interest deduction to interest on the first $300,000 of mortgage debt. That restriction, according to the home builders' association, would fall hardest on California, New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Maryland, Virginia and Florida because they have three-fourths of all homes valued at $250,000 or more.
During his now-abandonned campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania suggested not allowing a deduction on mortgage balances above $100,000.
Republicans running for their party's nomination are divided on the mortgage-interest deduction. Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. wants to eliminate it; Patrick Buchanan wants to keep it, and Senators Bob Dole and Phil Gramm have, so far, avoided a hard position.
But any radical change would probably require some transition.
One plan would be to grandfather those who already have mortgages, letting them deduct mortgage interest until they sell their homes or refinance; another possibility would be to phase out the deduction, say at 10 percent a year for a decade. One problem with a phase-out is that people with adjustable rate mortgages might see their rates fall and reap the benefit of lower rates and a tax deduction.
"The problem," said Rick Meyers, a spokesman for the Kemp commission, "is in the transition."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Names A Socialist as Finance Chief

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Japan's new Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, surprised the financial community today by naming a former high school history teacher to the nation's most prestigious Cabinet post of Finance Minister.
The former teacher, Wataru Kubo, 66, who is the secretary general of the Japan Socialist Party, has limited experience in finance. But Mr. Hashimoto needed to appoint a leader of the Socialist Party, which is a member of the ruling coalition, to a senior Cabinet post. Several more prominent members of Mr. Hashimoto's Liberal Democratic Party turned down the job. 
 The Finance Ministry is at the apex of the bureaucracy. It is the institution that governs Japan's markets, tax collection, the banks and the budget process. Mr. Kubo also won the honorary title of Deputy Prime Minister.
For his first major mission as Finance Minister, he will need to summon all his negotiating skills, and perhaps his ability to wield a sword -- like Mr. Hashimoto, Mr. Kubo has a high rank in kendo, the sport of fencing with a bamboo sword. Mr. Kubo will face a hostile opposition in the Diet, Japan's Parliament, on Jan. 22, when he presents the Finance Ministry's proposal to tap into taxpayer funds to help clean up a pile of bad housing loans.
"He runs the risk of being a scapegoat," said Toru Nakakita, a professor of economics at Toyo University. "If the forthcoming debates in the Diet do not go well, he may well become a target of criticism."
Mr. Kubo is expected to have little impact on the investment climate, and it is unclear what his views are on financial relations with the United States. At least in the initial stages, he is likely to endorse the current measures of the Finance Ministry.
But he could face an embarrassing set of questions when he meets with finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrialized economies later this month.
"He has to answer a lot of questions from his counterparts," said a senior Government official, who declined to be identified. The official added, however, that the spotlight was more likely to be focused on the American budget deficit problems than on Japan's banking troubles.
During his nearly 20 years of experience in politics, Mr. Kubo has had some exposure to the nation's financial problems, particularly as a member of the budget and finance committee in the Upper House. And he has been considered his party's shadow "finance minister."
His most notable public financial crusade was in 1989 when he led his party's unsuccessful campaign against the Finance Ministry's proposal to introduce a consumption tax. As a Socialist, he will test his allegiance on that and other prickly issues.
The Finance Ministry plans to put into effect an increase in the consumption tax in the next few years. Moreover, Mr. Kubo's party has long been an advocate for the poor, and the ministry has been criticized for representing the interests of wealthy bankers.
Nonetheless, Mr. Kubo is likely to receive a crash course in financial issues from Finance Ministry bureaucrats and is likely to rely heavily on them at first.
A number of Liberal Democrats turned down the job, partly because of the messy banking problems the ministry faces and partly because of potential scandals involving fellow politicians who may be investigated.
Today, Mr. Kubo vowed to investigate the nation's financial problems.

HEADLINE: Ending Statistical Drought, Fed Reports on Debt

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Ending a four-week void in official economic figures, the Federal Reserve reported today that consumers added to installment debt at a substantial 10.4 percent annual rate in November.
Although the consumer credit numbers are not considered a major indicator by economists, the report's appearance today was welcomed as a sign that the long void in Government statistics had ended. Throughout the Government, statisticians struggled to reschedule publication of figures delayed by the three-week shutdown. 
 "The January collection is sort of an emergency," said William G. Barron Jr., deputy commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which has not published any economic figures since mid-December. "We've got to get that started."
Because of the backlog of work, the agency could not clearly determine where it stood; it finally announced that it would disclose its plans for publishing postponed data, including crucial information on December employment and inflation, "no earlier" than 2 P.M. on Tuesday.
But indications from the two Cabinet departments involved with the jobs report, Labor and Commerce, were that the labor-market data would be published next Friday, two weeks later than originally scheduled.
This is the same day that the Commerce Department plans to publish a voluminous set of figures on the gross domestic product that had been planned for Dec. 19. The department issued a list of new release dates for indicators this afternoon.
The new set of figures will consist of revisions of the G.D.P. over the years, from 1959 through the third quarter of 1995; the intention is to switch to an emphasis on so-called chain weighting in an effort to prevent outmoded prices from distorting national output, usually by overstating it.
The fresh figure for the third quarter of last year will represent the first updating of the department's initial estimate, made on Oct. 27, that the economy expanded at a 4.2 percent annual pace during the summer, using the traditional fixed-weight basis, or 3 percent on the chain-weight basis.
The department said the G.D.P. for the fourth quarter, originally scheduled for release on Jan. 26, was now planned for mid-February.
Officials at both agencies said that while the delays were substantial -- the Commerce Department said it would be May before it fully resumed its schedule before the Government shutdown -- it was likely that barring further interruptions, they could avoid any serious compromise in the quality of the data.
Steven Landefeld, acting director of the Bureau of Economic Analysis, said the strategy was to "trade off timeliness for quality," waiting as long as necessary to maintain the integrity of data.
Officials generally assigned higher priority to making sure that possibly irreplaceable January figures were collected than on processing December figures gathered before the shutdown.
Still, the first tally of payroll employment for December will be based on a smaller number of responses than usual, and analysts noted that there would be an unusually long six-week gap between the December and January surveys.
The first Commerce Department release, on Tuesday, is to be housing starts for November, followed by data on international trade on Wednesday. Both reports had been planned for original release the week before Christmas.
The new schedule, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said, "meets our objectives of maintaining standards for consistent statistical quality and avoiding any gaps."
Some officials of both Cabinet departments -- probably more than 100 at the Bureau of Labor Statistics -- are expected to work over the weekend and on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday on Monday to get the existing data published and to collect information for January.
The Federal Reserve, which does not depend on Congressional financing and closed only after this week's blizzard, reported today that the November increase in consumer-installment debt -- 10.4 percent annual rate -- compared with a 13.7 percent annual rate in October. Growth in revolving credit, mainly credit cards, eased to a 9.2 percent pace from 16 percent the month before.
Credit for automobiles and for another category that includes loans for varied expenses like education and boats, grew slightly less rapidly than in October.
"I don't think consumers are treating debt as an inhibiting factor," as some economists contend, said Elliott Platt, a senior analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
This series does not provide extensions or repayments but only a net figure and has other flaws, which is why economists do not consider it a major indicator.
