HEADLINE: NYC;
A Bull Market For Cynicism On Wall Street

BYLINE: By Clyde Haberman 

 BODY:
WALL STREET laid an egg or two this week, as Variety once might have put it, but the Dow Jones bounced back nicely yesterday, staying within range of the record levels it has enjoyed for months. Too bad this enthusiasm is not shared on the street itself.
That's Wall Street, the thoroughfare, not the metaphor. These are far from banner days for many in the financial district, where more companies than anybody cares to count have downsized, outsourced, attrited, restructured -- you pick the euphemism to describe a steady flow of jobs out of lower Manhattan. 
 "The street itself is substantially weakened," said Andy Czegledi, part owner of Wall Street Camera, a photo shop at Wall and Water Streets. "I've been here since 1969. I remember when it was that if you tried to walk in rush hour against the crowd, they'd pick you up. Now, if you lay down in the middle of the sidewalk, nobody would even know you're there. That's how empty it is."
Empty, it isn't. Not really. Just the same, Wall Street's ranks have been thinned to a point that businesses there feel the pain every day. Bankers, brokers, clerks and secretaries who used to be their customers are simply not around anymore.
In 1988, with high hopes, Rick Preston opened Neuchatel Chocolates, one of several stores in a mall that is part of the J. P. Morgan building at 60 Wall. The stock market had survived its 1987 free fall, and Mr. Preston, whose capital came partly from his savings through years as a Plaza Hotel doorman, figured that he had nowhere to go but up. Like the market itself.
"WE do O.K., but it's not what we expected," he said. "We never thought that people who buy the gourmet items would be affected by layoffs -- you know, people who pay $30 for a pound of chocolate. But those are the people who are hurting. We used to have five or six regular corporate accounts in the area. Now, everyone's looking for a deal."
For those who make their living on the street, there was zero shock value in the headlines on post-Christmas retail figures, which confirmed that stores nationwide had their worst December in five years. No kidding, they said acerbically. You don't have to be a rocket scientist to understand that people without work are not going on buying sprees.
"I'd venture a guess that, between Battery Park and City Hall, we've easily lost 150,000 jobs since 1988," said Marvin Rafeld, who owns 14 Wall Street Jewelers. "Now, if 1 percent of those 150,000 are my customers, that's 1,500 customers. You do the math. I need the bigger-ticket sale now to make my expenses. But I'd rather make a lot of $50 sales then have to depend on one $5,000 sale."
"It ain't the 80's, I can tell you that," he said. Still, Mr. Rafeld gets by -- with smarter bargaining, he says, with a little downsizing of his own ("I don't even like the word") and with financial understanding from his building's managing agent, John Wheeler.
To say the least, kind thoughts about the agent are not shared by maintenance workers from Local 32B-32J, who have been on strike at 14 Wall and 1,000 other office buildings for the last week. Those on the picket lines along Wall Street especially resent how the financial markets that they help keep functioning cheer every time a big company announces huge layoffs.
IT happened again last week when AT&T announced it would eliminate 40,000 jobs; the Dow Jones industrial average shot up 60 points that day. This reaction hardly fills the maintenance workers with confidence in management assurances that their own jobs are secure for the long run.
"They must think we're stupid because we clean their buildings," said a striker on Wall Street who says that she belonged to the Solidarity labor movement in Poland before emigrating in the mid-80's.
Bargainers for the building managers call it crucial for the industry's survival to have the starting pay for new maintenance workers cut by 40 percent. No one now employed will be thrown out of work, they promise.
To which the unionists reply is a succinct, Yeah, right. "Eventually, they'll get rid of me," said John Spriggs, a picket outside the Bank of New York building at Wall and Broadway. "They'll find someone else who'll do it cheaper."
You could see the depth of the cynicism along Wall Street by following a few pickets who had taken time out last Sunday to attend services at nearby Trinity Church. It was a day after the feast of the Epiphany, and in church they heard the story of the three kings retold. A striker named Dave left saying that a modern version would have been downsized, with the infant Jesus being visited by two kings.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Rise, Retaking Some Ground

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities regained some ground yesterday in choppy trading after a big decline on Wednesday. Traders cited a number of positive factors, including the belief by many investors that a balanced budget agreement can be reached.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 20/32, to 109 29/31 to yield 6.14 percent, down from 6.18 percent on Wednesday. 
 Some other positive factors for bonds were a steady dollar and lower commodity prices.
Early in the day, comments from Federal Reserve officials seemed to indicate that chances were unlikely for another cut in interest rates coming as soon as this month, and that took some steam out the market.
William J. McDonough, president of the New York Federal Reserve, speaking at a conference of the Mortgage Bankers Association in New York, said the Fed had to be careful not to overstimulate the economy. Some market participants decided that Mr. McDonough, who is a voting member of the Federal Open Market Commitee, would lean toward not easing short-term interest rates at the committee meeting on Jan. 30 and 31.
While disappointment on the stalled budget negotiations continues to point to higher yields, traders said, market participants continue to buy on price dips, since many refuse to believe that the budget talks will come up short.
In an afternoon news conference, President Clinton said that an agreement on a balanced budget was within reach. "We have come too far to let this opportunity slip away," he said.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said prices of Treasury securities had been moving in a "budget zone" over several sessions.
"The two dynamics at work," he said, "have been a disappointment over the budget talks and the more fundamental state of the economy, where we continue to see anecdotal evidence of a weak economy that has been expressed in rising price for bonds."
At the start of the month, two-year notes were trading at a price to yield at 5.16 percent and the long bond at 5.95 percent.
Mr. Alexy said the market was trying to reprice itself to reflect the new environment and find a bond yield attractive enough to draw buyers into the market. He said he thought it might be 5.90 to 6.25 percent. But without supporting economic data, he said, the market is having a difficult time telling what level will be attractive to investors.
A retreat yesterday in commodity prices was not as big a factor as Wednesday's increase, he said. "But we have seen overseas buying supporting bond prices," he added, and "that suggests we are seeing less disenchantment from foreign buyers about the budget talks than we are seeing here."
Mr. Alexy said he believed a yield of 6.15 to 6.25 percent on the long bond would attract buyers.
Larry Berman, senior fixed income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said he was encouraged by overnight buying, with good flows coming from Japanese investors. The tone was set early for bulls to jump in on weakness, as the yield on the long bond approached 6.20 percent.
"The lack of information and focus on the failed budget agreement has brought to question the future of the economy," Mr. Berman said. "With the dollar on the rise, uncertainties regarding the economy, the rush of economic reports in the pipeline and concerns about Fed action, the market will likely be very volatile in the next few weeks. And on the technical front the market should be well supported at 6.20 to 6.25 percent. If these levels fail, the market could see a more substantial price decline toward 6.50 percent."
Mr. Berman said he was still holding his estimates of a continued rally that might lower the yield on the long bonds to 5.75 percent in the second quarter.
In observance of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, markets plan an early close today at 2 P.M. and a full closing on Monday. This will affect trading of Government securities, mortgage securities, over-the-counter investment grade corporate bonds, and secondary money market trading.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Energy Prices Drop on Forecast Of Above-Normal Temperatures

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Prices of energy futures plunged yesterday as a forecast by the National Weather Service for above-normal temperatures across the United States over the next 6 to 10 days indicated that demand for heating oil would lessen.
Adding pressure to energy prices, snow in the Northeast threatened to keep many cars off the road. 
 The broad retreat on the New York Mercantile Exchange was led by heating oil futures. The retreat extended into a technical rout as investment houses bailed out of the market, said Tim Evans, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group in New York.
"It was a rush for the exits," Mr. Evans said. "We've gone from being very optimistic to being very near panic."
In other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures sank; precious metals slid on profit taking, and coffee futures rose to a three-and-a-half-week high. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 2.33 points, to 242.90.
Light sweet crude oil for February delivery settled 88 cents lower at $18.79 a barrel, the lowest price since Dec. 12; February heating oil fell 3.43 cents, to 56.16 cents a gallon, the lowest since Dec. 7; February unleaded gasoline fell 3.75 cents, to 54.44 cents a gallon, also the lowest since Dec. 7, and February natural gas fell 3.19 cents, to 2.490 for 1,000 cubic feet, the lowest since Dec. 26.
Traders' initial rush of optimism, brought on earlier this week by the blizzard that socked the Northeast, began fading on Wednesday after prices failed to break through psychological resistance points, Tom Bentz, an analyst at ING Futures and Options, said. "It was the first sign of weakness in the energy markets for at least a month, and the retreat just snowballed," he added.
Grain and soybean futures prices sank on the Chicago Board of Trade as thundershowers brought needed water to corn- and soybeans-growing regions in Argentina and Brazil.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against the Mark On Rebound in American Stocks

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar climbed slowly and steadily against the German mark in light trading yesterday, bolstered by a strengthening of battered American stocks and bonds.
Foreign investors sold off the dollar in overnight trading in anticipation of further losses in the United States, following a steep two-day drop, but when Wall Street stocks and bonds firmed, the dollar managed a comeback. 
 "We saw a lower dollar overnight on expectations for capital markets to drop, but the market really didn't get any satisfaction," said Paul Farrell, managing director for foreign exchange trading at Chase Manhattan Bank.
The dollar rose to 1.4408 marks late yesterday from 1.4368 late Wednesday and edged down to 104.77 Japanese yen from 104.86.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 32.16 points, regaining some of its 3 percent decline over the previous two trading sessions. The 30-year Treasury bond also rose sharply, helping guide the dollar higher, traders said.
A momentary stalemate in the heated battle between the White House and Congress over the Federal budget added stability to the market and supported the dollar's rise.
"The budget is becoming a mess, but people still expect it to be resolved," said Alex Scarsini, director of foreign exchange at Barclays Group P.L.C.
President Clinton said he remained "optimistic" that he and Republican Congressional leaders would reach an agreement on a balanced budget.
"A historic agreement on a balanced budget is within reach if we set aside partisanship and seize this moment," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference.
Aside from the rebounding markets, economic weakness in Europe and Japan appears to have helped the dollar avoid a big selloff.
"Confidence in the American markets is the highest in any country," Mr. Scarsini said. "Any currency in Europe would've sold off 3 or 4 percent under this kind of pressure."
The dollar may have gotten a modest lift from reports that a German finance official visiting the United States said that the mark was too strong. Such remarks support a widely held belief that Germany prefers to strengthen the dollar against its own currency.
In other trading, the dollar rose to 1.1622 Swiss francs, from 1.1603 on Wednesday. The British pound slipped to $1.5440 from $1.5465.

HEADLINE: For City Council

 BODY:
Residents of Manhattan's East Side are being asked to trudge through the snow next Tuesday to vote in a special election for the Fifth District City Council seat. Two aides to local politicians are vying to replace Charles Millard, a Republican who resigned to become head of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
Judy Marcus, Mr. Millard's director of constituent service, has a long history of working with the community on neighborhood problems. Ms. Marcus, who has the backing of Manhattan's Republican organization, held the same job under Mr. Millard's predecessor, a Democrat, and deserves plaudits for her long service to the area. However, her grasp of citywide issues seems weak. 
 Gifford Miller, her opponent, headed the district office for the Democratic Congresswoman Carolyn Maloney. Mr. Miller is only 26, but his understanding of the issues seems much more sophisticated than Ms. Marcus's. Mr. Miller has deep roots on the East Side, where he grew up and served briefly as a full-time volunteer for the Parks Council before working for Ms. Maloney.
The winner of this election could occupy a peculiar position in the city government. Because of the term-limits law, all but one of the Council members will be forced to retire in 2001. If the new Council member from the East Side remains in office, he or she will be one of the few surviving members in a year of widespread turnover.
The East Side should elect a member who has the capacity to grow in office and become a leader. Both candidates are worthy, but Mr. Miller seems more likely to fill that job description.

HEADLINE: 2 Win by Not Quitting 42d Street;
Milstein Brothers at Last Get In on Renewal Plan

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
For 15 years, a stretch of property facing the Port Authority Bus Terminal has been part of the widely heralded and richly tangled effort to rehabilitate Times Square. Although the site is now a parking lot, it is expected soon to become much more. Behind this plain plot of land is a classic tale of New York development, and the story of two tough and shrewd brothers, Seymour and Paul Milstein.
While state and city officials have plodded away at the huge public-subsidized urban renewal plan known as the 42d Street Development Project, an ever-changing cast of characters -- from the Kennedys of Massachusetts to the Crows of Texas -- has been linked to this single 40,000-square-foot plot at the southeast corner of 42d Street and Eighth Avenue. 
 The seemingly indistinctive piece of land was the topic of contentious meetings between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Edward I. Koch, and it has been the subject of protracted courtroom debates.
Now, as the last major property not yet designated for development in the 13-acre site of the $1.6 billion project, the tract is becoming the focus for officials who must decide how it will fit into the plan to transform 42d Street into an entertainment and tourism center. As a result, the Bronx-bred Milstein brothers are poised to score a real estate victory reminiscent of Peter Minuit's purchase of Manhattan for $24.
It is a reversal of fortune for the Milsteins, developers who have tried for nearly 15 years to become part of the Times Square plan, only to be repeatedly rejected by the officials responsible for designating developers. The Milsteins, who have a long history of developing well-known sites, have managed to retain ownership of the site at 42d and Eighth, despite a recurring threat of condemnation from the state.
And now that the Walt Disney Company has started renovation of a historic theater on the block and other attractions like Madame Tussaud's wax museum and the AMC movie chain are also committed to 42d Street's renaissance, the Milsteins' property has grown in value to more than $32 million since they bought it in 1983 for $5 million, real estate appraisers say. Moreover, people involved with the Times Square project have revealed that the Milsteins bought the land shortly after state and city officials passed on an option to buy it from a now-defunct savings bank for only $1 million.
Despite the government's rejection of the Milsteins as developers in the project, "they're coming out on top anyhow," said State Senator Franz S. Leichter, the Bronx Democrat who has been a vocal opponent of various aspects of the 42d Sreeet plan. "They're going to make out like bandits on this."
The Milsteins -- Paul, 73, and Seymour, 75 -- became two of New York's wealthiest citizens by building their father's floor-covering company into one of the nation's largest flooring subcontractors and transforming it into a conglomerate of corporations and real estate holdings throughout the city.
They have also developed a reputation as difficult businessmen. Their skirmishes with public and private entities have reached legendary proportions. In 1981, for instance, they outraged the Landmarks Preservation Commission by demolishing the famed Palm Court lounge and gilded landmark clock, which they had promised to preserve from the old Biltmore Hotel on Madison Avenue. Over the years they have also filed several lawsuits against the city, some related to the Times Square project.
It once seemed that the Milsteins would never win on 42d Street. In the early 80's, they applied to become the builders of the four huge office towers that are expected to anchor the project. But officials of the 42d Street Development project, a joint undertaking of city and state, chose a then lesser-known developer, Park Tower Realty.
Then, in 1983, so sure they would win the right to build a giant merchandise mart that was planned for the area, the Milsteins bought the site at 42d and Eighth in advance, because it was the property the state had designated for the mart. The purchase seemed risky, because under the guidelines of the urban renewal plan, the state has the right to condemn an owner's land, pay the owner fair market value for it and give the property to a developer chosen by public officials.
Instead of the Milsteins, public officials first courted the Kennedy family, because of their success in developing the Merchandise Mart in Chicago. Those talks did not go far, and ultimately, after a struggle between Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo, the designation went to a partnership that included the New York developer Jerry Speyer and Trammel Crow, the Dallas real estate magnate who has built marts in Atlanta and Brussels. Again, the Milsteins had been passed over. But a weakened market ultimately killed the mart plan anyway.
Last year, after many developers had come and gone without building a thing, the Milsteins' relentless pursuit was stymied twice more, as public officials rejected their proposal to develop a multiscreen movie theater, then shunned a separate Milstein plan to build two hotels, one on their own site and another across the street on publicly owned land.
Tishman Urban Development, in a partnership with Disney, was chosen for the hotel on the public land. Disney will be a retail anchor in the project. And Forest City Ratner was later designated as the movie developer. As Senator Leichter said in a recent interview, the state and city officials responsible for the project "saw the Milsteins as pariahs of some sort."
Public officials are "fearful" of including the Milsteins because of their combative reputation, and the project has stalled as a result, said William J. Stern, who worked closely on the 42d Street Project as chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation in the early 80's. In a recent interview, Mr. Stern cited the Milsteins' infamous fights with public officials over proposed projects like the Biltmore, the South Street Seaport and Times Square.
"They are barbarians," said Mr. Stern, who added that he had personally favored selecting the Milsteins for the merchandise mart but had been overruled by Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo.
After they were passed over as developers of the office towers and the mart, the Milsteins sued the city, charging favoritism in the selection of developers. Meanwhile, they began planning to develop an apartment building on the site. A State Supreme Court judge ultimately dismissed the suit, and the Milsteins were denied Federal mortgage insurance for the apartment tower because of the state's plans to condemn the property. The legal actions held the project up for years and enabled the Milsteins to hold on to their investment, which they hold in partnership with Weiler Arnow Management Company, as it grew in value.
Both Milstein brothers, as well as Paul's son, Howard, who manages many of the family's holdings, refused to be interviewed for this article. Apparently the brothers have decided that, as Seymour put it several years ago, "Part of our problem is that we don't interview well."
In one telling moment during a 1981 interview with The New York Times, Paul Milstein, a gruff man who favors pinky rings, expounded on his reputation for toughness. "We live in a jungle," he said in his gravelly Bronx accent, as he hit his index finger on a table for emphasis. "In order to survive in a jungle, I guess you've got to be tougher to be a winner. My competitors, my adversaries and my friends cannot really say I'm tough. They don't understand the word tough."
The Milsteins have also proved to be astute developers and investors. In addition to the Biltmore, now the Bank of America Plaza, their holdings include three apartment towers with more than 2,000 units in the Lincoln Center area, and several other office and apartment buildings. They are principal owners of Emigrant Savings Bank.
Some people even credit the Milsteins with having initiated the revival of Times Square by rehabilitating an Eighth Avenue hotel called the Royal Manhattan, originally the Lincoln, which they reopened in 1980 as the Milford Plaza. And when most other developers fell on hard times during the late 80's, the Milsteins were not affected because they had not left themselves exposed to market conditions as many highly leveraged developers had.
Mr. Stern said of Paul Milstein: "He should have been brought into the process, but they keep freezing him out. He's got money and resourcefulness, so he screws it up and delays it. I hate to say, 'I told you so,' but he's still sitting there."
Of the 280 tenants on the once notorious strip between Seventh and Eighth Avenues five years ago, all but one -- the Milsteins -- have been forced to move out as a result of the state's power of condemnation.
According to Robert Van Ancken, executive managing director of appraisals at the Grubb & Ellis real estate firm, the property's estimated value is now $32 million to $40 million. Mr. Van Ancken said the recent commitments from Disney and other entertainment and retail tenants, as well as the visible signs of renewal along the street, had helped the Milsteins. "All of this will enhance the value of their property," he said. "The Milsteins will benefit either way. Whether they develop it, or if the state takes it through condemnation and develops."
On the Milsteins' ultimate role, Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Project, said: "Deciding what to do with that site is the next step, the final step. I don't know how the Milsteins will fit in."
Abby Hamlin, the president of Weiler Arnow, the Milsteins' partner on the site, said they were considering proposing to the state that it be used for a no-frills business hotel or an office tower.
The site is now so valuable that state officials admit they are unable to pay condemnation costs on it unless a private developer puts the money up first -- which makes it more likely that the Milsteins will finally get to build as they choose. "The Milsteins have had some disappointments on that site," said Charles Aug, chairman of Garrick-Aug Associates, a New York-based retail store leasing firm. "But they're going to come out smelling real good."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
An England Where Heart and Purse Are Romantically United

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR 

 BODY:
The Jane Austen bandwagon barrels along. "Sense and Sensibility" and "Persuasion" are in movie theaters. Versions of "Emma," which was given a contemporary spin in "Clueless," are in the making (and an audiotape edition, produced for BBC Radio, can be found in bookshops). And tomorrow, after setting ratings records in England, the best Austen of all, "Pride and Prejudice," begins a three-night, six-hour run on A&E.
This splendid adaptation, with a remarkably faithful and sensitively nuanced script by Andrew Davies, is a co-production of the BBC and A&E. One word of warning: this is not, as might be expected, a presentation of public television's "Masterpiece Theater." There will be commercial breaks. 
 Opening with what Austen considered a universally acknowledged truth, "that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife," "Pride and Prejudice" is a witty mix of love stories and social conniving, cleverly wrapped in the ambitions and illusions of a provincial gentry. The surface froth is deceptive. W. H. Auden claimed he was made most uncomfortable by seeing an English spinster of the middle class "reveal so frankly and with such sobriety the economic basis of society." Love was one thing; financial security through marriage was another, and perhaps even more important.
And so we find Elizabeth Bennet (Jennifer Ehle), the practical and decidedly virtuous narrator of this tale, casting a keenly sharp eye on anyone venturing into her vicinity. She realizes that Mrs. Bennet (Alison Steadman) is one of the silliest and most exasperating mothers in England, and that Mr. Bennet (Benjamin Whitrow) verges on being irresponsible with his protective cynicism. Of her four sisters, Elizabeth, or Lizzy, confides only in sweet-natured Jane (Susannah Harker). The others are empty-headed twits, especially Lydia (Julia Sawalha) who will drag the family into scandal.
But for all her special insight, Lizzy is not beyond being duped herself, at least in first impressions. She is only too willing to sympathize with the rotter Wickham (Adrian Lukis) when he bad-mouths Mr. Darcy (Colin Firth), whose seeming arrogance greatly irritates Lizzy. But will the dashing Mr. Darcy, who does a lot of riding about on a white horse, turn out to be the true love of Lizzy's life, especially since he has a substantial annual income and a grand home that looks like something out of a fairy tale. The ending is never really in doubt, but Austen is positively ingenious in getting us there.
Scattered portions of this handsome production might seem a bit slow for American viewers (British imports are often snipped and speeded up for consumption here). There are perhaps too many languorous walks across meadows, and one or two ornately choreographed dances seem to go on forever. But like the novel, the production overflows with memorable set pieces.
There is, for instance, Mr. Collins (David Bamber), the fawning vicar whose marriage proposal is quickly rejected by a horrified Lizzy. Mr. Collins's scenes with his patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, are hilarious as he obsequiously sings the praises of her condescension. And Barbara Leigh-Hunt turns Lady Catherine into a marvelously imperious witch.
But the story never ventures far from Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. Miss Ehle, daughter of the fine actress Rosemary Harris, manages to make Lizzy strikingly intelligent and authoritative without being overbearing. And Mr. Firth brilliantly captures Mr. Darcy's snobbish pride while conveying, largely through intense stares, that he is falling in love despite himself. There is an element of wishful fantasy in "Pride and Prejudice." Austen died in 1817 at age 41. She never married.
 
PRIDE AND PREJUDICE
A&E, Sunday at 8 P.M., Monday and Tuesday at 9 P.M.
 
Screenplay by Andrew Davies, based on a novel by Jane Austen. Directed by Simon Langton; produced by Sue Birtwisle; music by Carl Davis; photography by John Kenway; Peter Coulson, film editor; Susie Conklin, script editor; Julie Scott and Fiona McTavish, associate producers. from A&E and BBC-TV. Delia Fine, A&E executive in charge; Michael Wearing, executive producer.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Hillary In Lower Slobbovia

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
By week's end the blizzard had lost its charm and worn out its welcome. Much of the East Coast still looked like Lower Slobbovia, that miserable country invented by Al Capp, where the entire population lived eternally in shoulder-deep snow.
Except for Boston, whose winters often seem blood kin to Buffalo's, the geographical reach of this storm seemed contrived to create maximum and despairing helplessness. 
 The blasted cities, where winter is normally temperate, haven't the experience to cope with snow hitting the boulevard by the ton every minute, nor the equipment to do so, nor the big money required to keep great snow-removal systems ever ready to clear the streets.
So -- just when half-mad parents began to fear that the children would never go back to school again, just when cabin fever was beginning to crush the spirits of millions, just when you thought you might shoot the television set if it told one more tale of an unplowed cul-de-sac -- just then, the Republicans to the rescue!
Once again they sank their teeth into Hillary Clinton, into the infamous "travelgate" adventure, into the impenetrably confusing Whitewater story.
Good old Republicans. They had been taking a shellacking on the budget fight with President Clinton. People of all varieties, except those who phone Rush Limbaugh and C-Span, were as tired of the Government's being eternally "shut down" as they were of unplowed cul-de-sacs.
And now for something completely different!
Not Monty Python's Flying Circus, unfortunately, but a complete change of subject anyhow, and bless the Republicans for bringing it onstage: The Hillary Follies.
What does it all mean? Only a hardened nitpicker could care in a winter like this. You meet reporters who swear they understand the Whitewater deal and put you to sleep trying to explain it, and why it was or wasn't nastier than the really big-time swindles that characterized the glory days of the savings and loan business.
So what if it happened back at the dawn of time when she was a young lawyer and he was a young Governor? It goes to the "character issue," doesn't it? The press is always ready to throw its vast forces of nobility into the fray when the issue is "character."
What works for the Republicans is the rapid change of subject. Ill-tempered Newt departs the TV and front pages. So do stories about shutting down the Government, which make people think of old-time schoolyard quarrels -- before schoolchildren started quarreling with knives and guns.
By cutting suddenly to Hillary, the Republicans are able to stir up personal passions about her. A well-stirred personal passion always goes down well in today's politics of personal attacks. Hillary seems to stir easily.
There at the center of things, stirring, is New York's own Senator Alfonse D'Amato, only recently released from the threat of a "character-issue" attack himself by the Senate's experts on ethics. It is all too rich, and Hillary is so easy to pillory.
What about that firing of the old White House travel bureaucrats and of their being replaced by Hillary pals? What right does the lady have to throw her weight around like that in the White House? Who elected her?
And anyhow, even if "travelgate" doesn't make a very big hill of beans, what about the Vince Foster suicide? Suicide was it really? Can we be sure it wasn't murder by persons who wanted Foster silenced about Whitewater?
And so on. It has always been easy to turn Hillary into a political issue, perhaps because she really does have a hunger for power. First Ladies are not supposed to, but they sometimes had in the past.
Eleanor Roosevelt is said to have kept Franklin's energies focused on social and economic issues when he might have been willing to let them go by the boards. Nancy Reagan, of course, seems to have run the White House with the advice of an astrologist and even to have fired President Reagan's chief adviser, Donald Regan.
More heavy snow is forecast for the dismal mid-Atlantic states this weekend. If another week of Lower Slobbovia is in the cards, Hillary may be tempted to curse the blizzard.

HEADLINE: An Election With Partisan Shadows

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Five minutes into a discussion about his political aspirations, A. Gifford Miller reiterated his party affiliation no fewer than a dozen times, speaking about "Democratic ideals." Meanwhile, Judith G. Marcus has mailed material to voters highlighting her endorsements by prominent Republicans. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's name is at the top of the list.
Tuesday's special election to fill the seat for City Council District 5, representing the Upper East Side of Manhattan and Roosevelt Island, is officially a nonpartisan choice. In fact, the City Charter forbids candidates to use the names of established political parties -- an effort to minimize the impact of parties in special elections. Nonetheless, party affiliation, and the power behind it, is clearly playing a central role in the candidates' political strategies. 
 After the resignation of Charles Millard, the Republican Councilman who has represented the district since 1992, five candidates filed petitions to run for the seat. But only two gathered enough signatures. Officially, Mr. Miller, a top aide to United States Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, will run on the East Side Neighbors ticket and Ms. Marcus, a deputy to Mr. Millard, will carry the Community First Party banner.
But both candidates are trying to make the most of the formidable political machines behind the parties with which they are, unofficially, affiliated. Ms. Marcus, for example, is hoping to benefit from one of the strongest Republican operations in New York City, the East Side organization. It is led by State Senator Roy M. Goodman and includes Mr. Millard, who resigned to become the president of the Economic Development Corporation in the Giuliani administration.
Ms. Marcus, who dealt with constituent complaints when she worked for Mr. Millard, is now getting help from several of Mr. Goodman's Manhattan Republican proteges, including City Councilman Andrew Eristoff, from the adjacent East Side district, and Assemblyman John A. Ravitz. Citizens Union has also endorsed her.
She has also mailed district voters a letter from Mayor Giuliani praising Ms. Marcus as "an extraordinarily capable candidate."
Mr. Miller, meanwhile, is not without his political muscle. Virtually every prominent Democrat in Manhattan has endorsed him, including Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, Public Advocate Mark J. Green, Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. -- who is also the chairman of the Manhattan Democratic county committee -- and the entire Manhattan delegation in the City Council.
He also has the support of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the city's largest municipal employees' union. Its members are running telephone banks in the candidate's behalf.
In addition, Mr. Miller is to receive $1,775 from C-PAC, the political action committee of the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone. And Mr. Vallone has given him the services of Harris Leitstein, the City Council's chief of operations, as campaign manager.
At 26, Mr. Miller would be the youngest person elected to the Council. If Ms. Marcus, 51, wins, the Republicans will keep the seven seats they held in the 51-member Council before Mr. Millard resigned.
Ms. Marcus's strategy is to paint her opponent as a young, well-intentioned political novice with little knowledge of either the problems of the district's constituents or the bureaucracy that can solve them.
"What differentiates me from Mr. Miller is the fact that I've been working in the community for 14 years," Ms. Marcus said in an interview in her campaign headquarters in the basement of the Metropolitan Republican Club.
But Mr. Miller said his Republican opponent embodied "the Republican agenda, which is hurting the city." He added: "She changed to be a Republican at the same time that Newt Gingrich was passing his Contract With America, and George Pataki was proposing budgets which devastate the city. I think that says a lot about her and her philosophy."
Campaigning in New York's Fifth Council District is a challenging business. The Upper East Side is the home of many of the city's wealthiest residents, which has given the area its nickname, the Silk Stocking District.
For most New York City politicians, subway stops are the best places to meet voters. But there are only two subway stations in the district, on Roosevelt Island and on Lexington Avenue at 86th Street. And those -- as well as many of the stops nearby -- are used by people who live in other districts and commute in to work. Also, many constituents live in apartment buildings with doormen, making door-to-door campaigning impossible.
As a result, the candidates have taken to the phones, both to raise money and to talk with potential voters.
Each candidate has raised about the same amount so far, about $70,000; the campaign finance laws permit spending up to $120,000 each. Each also has about 100 volunteers.

HEADLINE: At Yale, a Decent Life Is a Radical Idea

BYLINE: By Debby Applegate and Bruce Tulgan; Debby Applegate is a doctorate candidate in American Studies at Yale University. Bruce Tulgan is the author of "Managing Generation X."

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
The first baby-boomer administration at Yale is reliving its radical youth -- but this time as the Establishment.
On Wednesday, 137 protesters were arrested on the campus for civil disobedience. This unrest is the latest episode in a five-year battle between the administration and the Graduate Employees and Students Organization, which is seeking to unionize the university's graduate students. 
 Many graduate-student teachers are withholding undergraduate grades until the administration agrees to negotiate. In response, Yale has singled out three student leaders for disciplinary action and has threatened other students with expulsion and lockouts.
Unlike the campus protests of the 1960's, the current unrest is not about an unpopular war or the counterculture. Nor is it about political correctness, tenured radicals or multiculturalism. Instead, the demonstrations are over mundane issues like health care and job training.
Yale set the protesters' agenda. After riding the stock market to a $4 billion endowment in the 1980's, the university announced that in the austere 1990's it would be run more like a corporation.
Following downsizing trends in the private sector, Yale initiated a severe economic restructuring, cutting faculty, services and clerical and custodial staff. It also continued admitting large numbers of graduate students to fill its need for inexpensive teaching labor, even as job opportunities were diminishing throughout academia.
Yet Yale insists that the graduate students remain within a traditional apprenticeship system, which was set up to groom them for tenured positions that are now in short supply. Until 1990, after the students organized, the apprenticeship system offered no teacher training, no effective grievance procedure and no job-placement services.
The Draconian response to the student protests by Yale's president, Richard C. Levin, indicates that he doesn't understand the changes in the profession and the career concerns of our generation.
The university leaders of his generation remember their own era of student agitation as idealistic, concerned with abstract principles like peace, civil rights and personal freedom.
Because today's students are protesting their own working conditions, Yale dismisses the students as mere malcontents, unwilling to pay their dues, motivated by self-interest rather than boomer-like ideals. But our generation's battleground is the workplace. Unlike our predecessors, we don't have the luxury of choosing our causes.
The students in the 1960's earned graduate degrees during the biggest expansion of higher education in American history. They willingly lived on the brink of poverty for six years, but they knew that almost everyone would get a job, win tenure and live happily ever after in an ivory tower.
Today's students face a very different marketplace. Grant money is evaporating and institutions are hiring fewer tenured faculty and more part-time adjuncts. Yale has backed out of the traditional workplace bargain but still demands that graduate students pay dues to a club that no longer exists.
The university's graduate students are using the strategies of the labor movement to address the diminution of job security. Unlike the activism of the 1960's, the student union movement is a hotbed of realism, not radicalism.

HEADLINE: Long Bond Loses Ground; Other Prices Up Slightly

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
With the exception of the bellwether 30-year bond, prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday in an abbreviated session ahead of a three-day holiday weekend.
For the second time in a week, Federal offices were closed because of a snowstorm. Meanwhile, investors sold long maturities while waiting for some signs of progress in talks aimed at producing a balanced budget. The stalled talks between the Administration and Congressional Republican leaders have pushed interest rates on the long bond up nearly 20 basis points, or one-fifth of a percentage point, since the start of the year. 
 The benchmark long bond fell 2/32 , to a price of 10929/32 to yield 6.14 percent, unchanged from the previous session. Traders said talk of a large hedge fund's buying short maturities helped shore up prices in Treasury bills, which were up a basis point.
The only data released yesterday -- the Atlanta Fed index for December, which showed a sharp drop -- helped push bond prices higher. The data reflected the most recent survey of regional business activity.
While news of a foundering factory sector is hardly surprising, it was all that was needed to squeeze out any remaining shorts who would be looking to get out of the market ahead of the long weekend. On Monday no trading is scheduled in government securities because of the Martin Luther King Jr. Birthday holiday.
James Hale, fixed-income analyst at MMS International in San Francisco, attributed most of the weakness in the long maturities to investors' moving away from the long end into the shorter maturities to protect themselves against further price volatility during the budget negotiations.
"The Atlanta Fed survey said manufacturing activity deteriorated considerably last month," Mr. Hale noted. "The index dropped to minus 19.9 from a revised minus 11.1 in November, and if translated and included in the National Association of Purchasing Management index, the N.A.P.M. would fall to 45.8 percent from 48.7 percent."
Theodore Ake, government trading manager at Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago, said the early focus of market activity was the optimism generated by the first economic number in some time. The partial Government shutdowns experienced during the budget talks have wreaked havoc on the gathering, compilation and timely release of economic statistics.
The weak economic data and disappointing car sales, managed to raise expectations among some investors that the Fed could cut short-term rates once more. The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee meets on Jan. 30 and 31.
Mr. Ake said of President Clinton's plea for negotiations now to hammer out a budget deal before the November elections, "He seems to be telling the market that he may make some concessions and that has raised market expectations of a settlement."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up but Gains Are Curbed As Traders Await Fresh Data

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen and the German mark yesterday as traders sold low-yielding Japanese investments, but gains were limited as the market awaited the first major American economic reports in a month.
 In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.4420 German marks, from 1.4408 marks on Thursday, and to 105.20 Japanese yen from 104.77 yen. The British pound edged up to $1.546 from $1.544. 
 The Federal Government's partial shutdown and bad weather have delayed Government reports while the economy seemed to falter. Even modest growth signals when the reports resume next week are likely to bolster the dollar, analysts said.
 "You don't need 5 percent growth here," said Graham Broyd, a senior vice president at NatWest Bank P.L.C. "Two percent will outdo most of Europe, and that may be enough to stimulate the dollar vs. European currencies."
Weak economies in Europe and Japan have encouraged many foreign investors to hold their American securities, giving the dollar a modest gain.
 "The potential recession that's going to hit Europe should help the dollar," Mr. Broyd said. "When Europe cuts interest rates again to stimulate the economy, that lifts the dollar."
 Investors in Asia lifted the dollar against the yen, selling the Japanese currency for marks. Japan's low interest rates were attributed for the selling.
"The trend is money going into high-yielding markets, playing off interest-rate differentials," said Chris Iggo, an international economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "The yen continues to slip against everything else."
 The dollar was modestly firm in trading throughout the day, and traders said it was likely to rally next week if there was any positive economic news, like some resolution of the Federal budget dispute.
"The dollar seems to be looking for a reason to rise and if it gets one, it probably will," Mr. Broyd said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Russia's New Foreign Minister Sets a More Assertive Tone

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Russia's new Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, set the tone today for Russian foreign policy until the presidential elections next June. And in keeping with the emotional political climate at home, the tone was decidedly nationalistic.
"Russia was and remains a great power," he declared in his first news conference since he was appointed on Tuesday. "Her foreign policy should correspond to that status." 
 Mr. Primakov said he intended to make Russia's partnership with the United States more "equitable" and reiterated his opposition to NATO expansion. He stressed that Russia needed to show more leadership in its relations with the republics of the former Soviet Union and play a more significant role in Bosnia and other hot spots around the world.
But for all his tough talk, Mr. Primakov avoided any statements that might set off alarms in Washington or in Western Europe.
Self-assured and echoing the recent statements of President Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Primakov's smooth presentation helped explain why Mr. Yeltsin chose him to take over from Andrei Kozyrev, who was accused of being too accommodating to the West. With his decades of experience and solid Soviet credentials, Mr. Primakov is far less likely to become a target of nationalists and Communists, and could help defuse foreign policy as a political issue at home.
His performance also shed some light on how Mr. Primakov, 66, who until this appointment was director of Russia's foreign intelligence service, managed to stay in the inner circles of power first under Leonid I. Brezhnev, then Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and now Mr. Yeltsin.
"He's pragmatic, not ideological, and he is very loyal," said Georgi Mirsky, a senior research fellow at the Institute of World Economy and International Affairs, who has known Mr. Primakov since their student days. "And he is very good at changing his loyalties to match the powers that be."
Some policy makers in Washington have expressed reservations about Mr. Primakov, concerned that his background as an Arabist -- he studied Arabic and was a reporter for Pravda in Cairo in the 1960's -- might prompt him to try to expand Russian influence in the Middle East.
Mr. Primakov earned the enmity of former Secretary of State James A. Baker just before the Persian Gulf war, when, on the instructions of Mr. Gorbachev, he tried to persuade his old acquaintance Saddam Hussein to withdraw his army from Kuwait. Mr. Primakov's attempt to broker a face-saving withdrawal for Mr. Hussein succeeded only in annoying the Bush Administration, which viewed his efforts as meddling.
Mr. Primakov, who said he had agreed to meet with Secretary of State Warren Christopher in February, will almost certainly reflect Russia's new belligerence about its status -- and insecurity about Western intentions. But unlike Mr. Kozyrev, he will be able to speak for Mr. Yeltsin with confidence.
Mr. Primakov was born in Kiev, Ukraine, but grew up in Tbilisi, Georgia, before entering the prestigious Institute of Oriental Studies in Moscow. After reporting for Pravda in the Middle East, he worked at various official research centers and was sufficiently respected as an administrator and international affairs analyst to be inducted into Mr. Brezhnev's circle of more progressive foreign policy advisers. Mr. Gorbachev recruited him to help implement perestroika, and he served the last Soviet leader loyally, defending him during the failed coup of August 1991. But when power shifted to Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Primakov was able to transfer his loyalties once again.
"He has managed to conserve his roots in the old establishment while taking part in the Yeltsin revolution," said Aleksei Pushkov, a foreign affairs columnist for The Moscow News, "and in that sense he represents continuity."
But there are those in Moscow who say he is more rooted in the past than the present. "His experience belongs to previous times," said one former colleague in the Gorbachev Government who spoke on condition he not be identified. "I don't know whether he will have a fresh approach in appraising new information and new situations."
Russians who know Mr. Primakov well say he would probably like to increase Russia's influence in the Middle East, but that he is a realist about his chances. Mr. Mirsky said Mr. Primakov was more likely to concentrate on repairing Russia's relations with former republics of the Soviet Union like Ukraine, areas that Mr. Kozyrev was widely accused of neglecting.
Mr. Primakov did permit himself one joke today. When a Polish reporter asked how Russia's plans to play a more assertive role in the world would effect Central Europe, and Poland in particular, Mr. Primakov smiled sardonically. "Well, of course, we're not going to send in tanks, if that's what you are worried about."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Yevgeny M. Primakov, the new Russian Foreign Minister, at a news conference yesterday. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: PLOWING;
For Sanitation Chief, Many Tough Battles

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
Walking rapidly at the crack of dawn, smiling earnestly despite plenty of reasons not to, Sanitation Commissioner John J. Doherty dropped in on one of his department's garages in lower Manhattan yesterday morning, a commander come to salute his snow-besieged troops.
"It's been tough," Mr. Doherty said to one of the many plow drivers whose hands he shook. "You should be proud of the way you held up." 
On some level, Mr. Doherty was undoubtedly talking to himself as well. For while his workers suffered something akin to hell week, the Commissioner endured a trial by even hotter fires.
He was battered not only on the professional front, dealing with one of the worst blizzards ever to hit New York City, but also on the personal one.
On Saturday, a day before the first flakes fell, his son Brian, 27, was arrested for possession of cocaine and an unregistered 12-gauge shotgun. And a week before that, Mr. Doherty's 91-year-old father, also named John, had a stroke.
In an odd way, Mr. Doherty said late this week, it was the blizzard that sustained him.
"This was the one you had to get right," Mr. Doherty said. "That kept my mind a little more focused on what I had to do here. I couldn't dwell on other problems."
Just how right Mr. Doherty got it will surely be debated for some time. He did not help himself by predicting at one point that all city streets would be plowed within 24 hours of the snow's end. He fell at least nine hours short.
But friends and colleagues said that his venture out onto that limb was typical of a man whose exuberance, optimism and, above all, intensity carried him from an entry-level job as a trash collector in February 1960 to the helm of the Sanitation Department in August 1994. Mr. Doherty is only the 5th of 40 commissioners in the department's 115-year history to have risen through the ranks that way, and the first to do so in more than three decades.
"He puts too much pressure on himself," said Joe Timpone, one of Mr. Doherty's longtime friends. Mr. Timpone worked with Mr. Doherty for 30 years in the Sanitation Department but left about a year ago to join the Alliance for Downtown New York, a business improvement district.
Mr. Timpone said the risky 24-hour call was indicative of something else about Mr. Doherty: he is perhaps not as attuned to the political dimensions of his job as he is to the practical.
"He will put his neck on the line just because it's the best way to get the job done," Mr. Timpone said, speaking of the failed prediction. "I think he wanted to put that out as the challenge to his folks, so they would get it done as fast as possible. I think he knew he was going to take it on the chin."
Mr. Doherty, a red-haired whirl of energy whose fleet gait and athletic physique make him seem a good decade younger than his 57 years, smiled mischievously at that assessment, neither disputing nor confirming it.
"I thought we had a real good chance," he said with ambiguous conviction. "It ended up as 33 hours, I think."
Whatever the count, it does not seem to have winnowed Mr. Doherty's legions of admirers or tempered their regard for him.
Current underlings, former supervisors, front-line workers, sideline observers -- all expound at length on Mr. Doherty's honesty and dedication, and all say that he is doing a mostly excellent job, abetted by his personal knowledge of every facet of the Sanitation Department.
"I think that John Doherty is -- and I say this unequivocally -- the best public sector manager I've ever worked with," said Emily Lloyd, his predecessor as Sanitation Commissioner. Mr. Doherty served as her first deputy commissioner.
Even critics who disparage Mr. Doherty's recycling record, which they cite as his one glaring failure so far, digress to make their general respect and affection for him perfectly clear.
"His rise through the ranks is inspiring," said Eric A. Goldstein, a spokesman for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a city environmental group. "In many ways, it's the quaint New York success story: sanitation worker makes it to the top."
It is not a place that Mr. Doherty ever consciously set his sights on, and he said he still frequently finds himself a bit stunned to be there, particularly when he surveys his enormous wood-paneled corner office at 125 Worth Street in Manhattan. It comes with an annual salary of $133,000.
A lifelong resident of Staten Island, where he and his wife of 35 years still live in the three-bedroom ranch they bought for $20,000 in 1964, Mr. Doherty grew up with ill-defined ambitions.
His father, a carpenter, immigrated to America from Ireland in the 1920's only to encounter desperate economic hardship the following decade. He told his three sons they must do one of two things after high school: attend college or take the civil service exam. Civil servants, his father said, were among the only workers who still drew paychecks during the Depression.
None of the Doherty boys chose college. Mr. Doherty's brothers became firefighters, which is what he would have done too, but a neck injury blocked his way. The city offered him a job in the Sanitation Department instead.
He accepted it grudgingly. "It was the stigma," he said. "In high school, they used to say, 'If you don't do your homework, you're going to be a garbage man.' It was looked down upon."
About a year later, he said, he found himself sweeping a street in downtown Manhattan right outside a bank where he had worked briefly as a clerk. "I had my hat down over my head," he said. "I was ashamed to be recognized."
But he worked hard and rose far, taking every promotional exam he could, catching the eye of his bosses, becoming indispensable to them. He said that at no point was he reaching for the brass ring of commissioner, and those who know him well agree.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that Mr. Doherty's ability to identify with workers at all levels of the Sanitation Department has been an essential tool in the city's ability to negotiate contract changes with sanitation workers that have increased their productivity. "He has the confidence of the work force," the Mayor said.
Several sanitation workers interviewed yesterday at the garage Mr. Doherty visited said they felt a kinship with him that they did not feel with his predecessors. "You can relate to him better," one of the workers, Roy Edmonds, said.
Still, the Sanitation Department has problems. Its uniformed work force has been cut by more than 15 percent in the past five years, and "you do shrink the services, no doubt about it," Mr. Doherty readily conceded.
Mr. Doherty said that streets could be cleaner than they are, and that he is unhappy with what he sees. He also admitted that the percentage of municipal trash being recycled, which is supposed to be increasing steadily, has fallen in the last two years from 15 percent to below 14.
But in regard to snow removal, he made no apologies, saying his department did exemplary work. To oversee it, he spent about 20 hours a day on the job, sleeping most nights on a cot in his office. During his rare pauses, he called home to check on both his father and his son.
"You raise your children, you give them all you can," said Mr. Doherty, who has four in all, plus three grandchildren. "Then they go out on their own, and sometimes one of them slips."
He finally found some time on Thursday night to return home and sit down with Brian. But yesterday morning, he had little to say about it. He was back on the job, more snow was about to fall and there was no time to think about anything else.

HEADLINE: Fannie Mae Increases Its Mortgage Limit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The Federal National Mortgage Association has raised the limit on the size of the mortgages it buys.
The company, better known as Fannie Mae, said today that it would now buy mortgages as large as $207,000, up from its $203,150 limit. The decision could help lower mortgage rates for more Americans, since Fannie Mae is the largest investor in United States home mortgages. 
 The move comes weeks after the company's main competitor, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation , or Freddie Mac, lifted its own limit on the mortgages it buys from lenders.
Keeping two separate loan limits created "a two-tiered system that undercut the standardization and competition the two companies brought to mortgage finance," said David Jeffers, vice president for corporate relations.

HEADLINE: Stocks Off in Volatile Day; Earnings Reports Awaited

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stocks inched lower yesterday in a volatile trading session, as the market prepared for the flood of fourth-quarter corporate earnings reports expected to begin next week.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose almost 25 points at the opening, apparently in reaction to President Clinton's remarks on Thursday that a budget agreement was within reach. But by midday it plunged more than 40 points after a report by the Atlanta Federal Reserve indicated an economic slowdown would be forthcoming. At the close, the Dow was down 3.98 points, to 5,061.12, marking the third decline this week. 
 "Next month when the Atlanta report comes out, there might be a big yawn," said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist of Van Kampen American Capital. "However, we're starved for information now, and the whole market moved on that number," he said, referring to the lack of Government statistics during the recent shutdown.
Among the broader-based indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.88 point, to 601.81, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 2.87 points, to 1,008.23. Advances and declines were about even on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,206 issues down and 1,102 issues up. With many traders in the Northeast leaving early because of a new winter snowstorm, volume dropped to 383.4 million shares, from 408.8 million shares Thursday.
Looking ahead, Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation, said, "Declining short-term interest rates, continuing economic expansion, mergers and acquisitions, and stock repurchases should support the stock market." But he added that "investors may have to settle for only a fraction of last year's gains."
The selloff in high-technology stocks resumed yesterday after three securities concerns cut their fourth-quarter earnings estimates for Dell. Dell dropped 4 7/8, to 28 5/8; Apple, which said that it expected to report a loss for the quarter ended Dec. 31, tumbled 1 1/8, to 33 7/8, and Motorola eased 3/4, to 49 3/8.
Retailers were also weak, amid concerns that the recent storms after a poor Christmas selling season would hurt profits. Kmart, whose debt ratings were downgraded by Standard & Poor's, closed at 7, off 5/8; Wal-Mart ended at 22 1/4, down 5/8, and Dayton Hudson closed at 72 3/4, off 1 1/4.
Oil issues slipped on forecasts of lower demand later this year. Exxon declined 1 1/8, to 79 5/8; Texaco fell 1 3/4, to 76 1/4, and Mobil dropped 2 3/4, to 110.
Other decliners included Cincinnati Microwave, which announced it had defaulted on a bank loan; its share price plunged 1 3/8, to 2 1/2. Tyson Foods, which said that price jumps in corn and other feed grains would add at least $125 million to its fiscal first-half costs, fell 1 1/8, to 23 7/8. And Hollywood Entertainment, which disclosed that it had changed accounting firms, dropped 1/2, to 6 3/4.
In contrast, the Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, which yesterday announced a 14 percent rise in fourth-quarter net income, led some financial services stocks upward. Sallie Mae gained 5 1/4, to 70 1/4; Citicorp climbed 3/4, to 63 1/4, and BankAmerica advanced 1 7/8, to 61 1/4.
Some of the drug issues, whose profits are less likely to be affected by the extent of overall economic growth, were higher as well. Merck closed at 62 1/8, up 5/8, and Pharmacia & Upjohn closed at 37, up 7/8.

HEADLINE: THE 1996 ELECTION: THE IOWA DEBATE;
Race Is Still a Blur, With a Month to Focus

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The nun came to play "You Are My Sunshine" on her accordion before Senator Phil Gramm spoke at a chili supper in Dubuque on Thursday night. But that did not mean she supported his candidacy -- or anyone else's, for that matter.
"I have not made up my mind," said Sister Mary Jean Evelyn Menster. "I don't know enough about any of them." 
 The candidates will gather here for a debate on Saturday, and Iowans will caucus one month from today. But many Republican voters say they are just beginning to focus on the race, even though some candidates have been running here for more than two and a half years.
Voters say they are pleased with their alternatives, but are still searching for meaningful differences in what can seem like sound-alike messages. Some of the candidates trailing Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican front-runner, find ground for hope in the many bumpers without stickers and lawns without political signs.
"I haven't made any decisions yet," said Dwight Glenney, a farmer and seed salesman in Muscatine. Mr. Glenney's ambivalence was surprising, since he was the host at a political appearance that Senator Gramm was making in his barn. But Iowans' expectations of coddling by candidates are notoriously high.
Mr. Glenney said he was trying to learn more details about each candidate's agricultural policy. "We still need a program that has some safety net in it," he said.
For his part, Mr. Gramm, standing before a John Deere tractor, declared himself "an ethanol senator" -- that is, a booster of plans to use a corn derivative as fuel. And the Texas Senator promised to improve the locks on the Mississippi River.
Senator Dole still has a commanding lead in Iowa, but his opponents are hoping to exploit the voters' apparent open-mindedness.
"In Iowa, people are still holding back," said Pat Buchanan, the conservative commentator and candidate. At Saturday's debate, Mr. Buchanan said, he hopes to draw clear lines between himself and the other candidates on economic issues.
Mr. Buchanan has made trade a big issue in his campaign, and on Thursday he unveiled billboards around the state promising, "He'll Bring the Jobs Home."
The candidates are also taking to the airwaves more intensely, carving up the near-monopoly on commercials of Steve Forbes, the millionaire publisher who is financing his campaign with his personal funds.
Recent polls here show that, after Senator Dole, Mr. Forbes is the only candidate in double digits, and just barely so.
But the state party chairman, Brian Kennedy, recalled that former Vice President Walter Mondale appeared to have the Iowa Democratic caucuses locked up at this point in 1984, only to see then Senator Gary Hart of Colorado finish a strong second, and then go on win the New Hampshire primary before Mr. Mondale eventually won the nomination.
"That's a good analogy," Mr. Kennedy said. "Everbody's wondering, is one of them going to grab some momentum and surge ahead in January, or are they just going to stay in that pack?"
Even when they say they support a particular candidate, some voters sound like they are still hoping to be swayed by another. Bill Egleston, of Marshalltown, said today that he supported Mr. Gramm, in part because Mr. Dole is 72 years old. "I would like to see Dole say, 'I would run for four years, and I would like Gramm to be my Vice President, and I want Colin Powell to be Secretary of State.' "
Mr. Egleston's wife, Marylin, said she was leaning toward Mr. Dole. "She'll vote the way I say," Mr. Egleston said.
"I'll listen to his arguments," she amended.
Popular support here does not necessarily translate into a strong showing at the caucuses. Historically, candidates need networks of aggressive volunteers to turn out supporters in the state's 2,142 precincts. So Senator Gramm, who has emphasized organization, could achieve his stated goal of a strong second place behind Mr. Dole, even though he is now stuck in single digits in the polls.
"My prediction is Gramm is going to score an upset in Dubuque County," said Rob Blum, the Republican county chairman. "Pat Robertson in '88 scored an upset, because of his organization, and Gramm has a lot of the Robertson people."
"We have literally thousands of people now who are involved as volunteers," Mr. Gramm said. "We have an active volunteer phoning program working every night in Iowa. We have an aggressive mail program, we're on radio and television, and I believe we're gaining ground."
In a two-day swing through the state before the debate, the Texas Senator presented himself as the candidate most committed to balancing the budget. But he found himself fielding questions on everything from health care to gun rights from voters who seemed almost to have scorecards with which they were tracking the candidates.
When Mr. Gramm stopped taking questions after the chili dinner for more than 300 people on Thursday night, one sixth grader's hand was still frantically waving in the air. Her teacher, Sister Mary Lee Cox, offered solace, saying that perhaps only a resident of this state or New Hampshire could expect to be told, "Save it for the next candidate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, running for the Republican Presidential nomination, greeted supporters before a campaign stop in Muscatine, Iowa, on Thursday. The Iowa caucuses are scheduled for next month. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. Strengthening Patrols Along the Mexican Border

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Just one week after Congress increased its budget by 24 percent, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it was beefing up enforcement along the Southwestern border to prevent any increase in illegal immigration that might be caused by Mexico's severe economic problems.
Local law enforcement agencies will help the Border Patrol, and the armed forces will continue providing assistance, officials said. 
 Attorney General Janet Reno said the immigration service was sending 200 Border Patrol agents and 100 additional inspectors and investigators to California and Arizona. About 2,200 agents now patrol that section of the border.
Doris M. Meissner, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, said that local law enforcement officers would help the Border Patrol but that "they cannot arrest people" on suspicion of violating Federal immigration laws.
Mrs. Meissner said Mexico's economic crisis, including the devaluation of the peso, "definitely is creating migration pressures."
On Jan. 6, President Clinton signed legislation increasing the budget for the immigration service to $2.6 billion, from the $2.1 billion provided in 1995. Most of the additional money is for border enforcement and detention of illegal aliens.
Jeffrey M. Weber, budget officer for the immigration service, said the agency was planning to hire 3,200 new employees, raising the total to 24,200. These numbers include an increase of 800 Border Patrol agents, raising the total to 5,700.
Mexican officials, including Foreign Minister Jose Angel Gurria, have expressed concern that Mexico will become an issue in the United States Presidential election, and they tend to see actions by Washington as motivated by domestic American politics. Some Mexican officials suggest that the United States is militarizing the border as part of a strategy to encourage hostility to Mexico.
But Ms. Reno said today: "It's quite to the contrary. We are trying to control against illegal immigration. Alien smuggling is against the law in Mexico. I think Mexican officials share the same concern we have."
Rahm I. Emanuel, a White House aide who handles immigration policy, said the armed forces had provided support for civilian law enforcement along the border since January 1995. "Their actions and involvement are consistent with their mandate in protecting national security," Mr. Emanuel said. "After years of neglect, we are finally restoring the rule of law, locking down the Southwest border."
Mrs. Meissner said her agency was planning better coordination with the military but no increase in the 200 to 300 members of the armed forces already helping the immigration service along the Southwestern border.
The Pentagon provides surveillance and intelligence information to the Border Patrol, builds roads and fences, and handles some communications along the border. Soldiers also help with sophisticated equipment, like night-vision equipment and ground sensors.
Hispanic groups have often criticized efforts to crack down on illegal immigration. But Raul Yzaguirre, president of the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic-American advocacy group, today praised the Clinton Administration's latest effort as "both sound policy and good politics."
"It is sound policy," he said, "because the most effective, most humane method of reducing undocumented immigration is enforcement at the point of entry, including the Southwestern U.S. border. It is good politics because I.N.S. efforts in this area stand in sharp contrast to some of the high-profile, irresponsible and draconian proposals currently being debated in Congress."
One of those proposals would require citizens and immigrants to carry identification cards. Another would deny United States citizenship to children born in this country to illegal immigrants. Under the 14th Amendment to the Constitution, such children now become citizens automatically.
As part of the new initiative, immigration officials said, they are transferring 40 inspectors to San Ysidro, Calif., to check the documents of people crossing the border. Eventually, they said, there will be 220 new inspectors, in addition to the 170 already assigned to the Southwestern border.
Mrs. Meissner said the Border Patrol would deploy 79 new agents in the San Diego area, 48 around El Centro, Calif., 21 in Yuma, Ariz., and 52 in other parts of Arizona, including Tucson.
Mrs. Meissner said the immigration service would assign 60 plainclothes agents to combat the smuggling of illegal aliens through airports in Los Angeles, San Diego, Phoenix, Tucson and Las Vegas, Nev. "As we tighten enforcement on the border," she said, "smugglers increasingly use airports as transportation hubs to get people into the United States."
In the 1996 appropriation for the immigration service, Congress said that $4.3 million should be spent on a fence along the border near San Diego. And $11 million was earmarked for the construction of a jail for illegal immigrants in Batavia, N.Y.
Alan D. Bersin, the United States Attorney in San Diego, said there were few precedents for the collaboration by the Border Patrol, the armed forces and local sheriffs.
