HEADLINE: America's Small-Town Team;
Packers Play for Touchdown Not for Profits

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Most football fans know who owns the Dallas Cowboys -- the ultra-aggressive Jerry Jones, a one-time oil wildcatter who bought the team and Texas Stadium for $140 million in 1989, hired and then fell out with Jimmy Johnson as his coach, won two Super Bowls and stars in Pizza Hut commercials with Deion Sanders.
Now, name the Green Bay Packers' owner. You can't. There are too many. 
 Fred Trowbridge Jr., James Nelson and Dick Peal, who grew up in Green Bay, each own part of "The Pack." So do Willie Davis, the Hall of Fame defensive end; Bud Selig, baseball's acting commissioner; The Green Bay Press-Gazette and nearly 1,900 others.
This study in corporate contrasts, matching up Big D against small town America, will be on view tomorrow at Texas Stadium in the National Football Conference championship game. The winner will advance to the Super Bowl on Jan. 28. Led by the legendary coach Vince Lombardi, the Packers won Super Bowls I and II in 1967 and 1968 but have not returned since.
The Packers are not only an anomaly in the National Football League, but also in all major league sports. The team is a nonprofit corporation owned by stockholders whose shares yield no dividends, do not appreciate and are not publicly traded.
And in a turbulent time for professional sports, with more and more teams up for grabs to the highest bidders, the Packers are also a refreshing exercise in public pride and a mutual long-term commitment.
"We're a community project," said Mr. Trowbridge, a 65-year-old lawyer whose father owned shares before passing them on. Both Trowbridges have been members of the Packers' board. "That's what makes us different," he said.
Mr. Peal, a 59-year-old marketing consultant, added, "It's just special that the team is where it belongs."
To be sure, playing in a city of barely 100,000 people in northeastern Wisconsin, the Packers are an anachronism that could not exist without help from the league in the form of revenue sharing. Still, teams in much bigger cities receiving the same amount of help often find themselves in a bind or simply become itchy for greener pastures. In the N.F.L., the Cleveland Browns are trying to move to Baltimore and the Raiders and Rams left Southern California before the past season.
How Green Bay has managed to hold on to the Packers is increasingly a matter of interest to local government officials around the country who are keenly aware of the growing value of a major sports franchise to a city's economy and prestige.
While the Packers are now firmly rooted in Green Bay, the early years were precarious. The team was created in 1919, but its founders, led by the coach, Earl (Curly) Lambeau, were nearly broke by the end of 1922. Local businesses, including The Press-Gazette, lent the team $2,500.
There were other financial woes in the years before the N.F.L. became widely accepted. In 1934, local businesses raised $15,000 to rescue the team from receivership. Fifteen years later, the team played an intrasquad game on Thanksgiving to raise $50,000. A year later, in 1950, it sold stock to the public, this time to raise $118,000.
"I was 15 years old, making $5 a game selling programs, which I used to buy my share," said Mr. Peal, whose father was among the founders.
"That was a time when there was talk the team would move to Milwaukee," 100 miles away, said Mr. Nelson, 68, an electrical engineer who now lives in Arlington, Tex., and has not been to a game in 40 years. "So I bought a share."
Each of the 4,634 shares is worth the same $25 as when it was issued 46 years ago. A share can be passed from one relative to another, but it cannot be sold to outsiders unless first offered to the team to retire. No one can own more than 200 shares.
And there is no profit motive for the 1,898 shareholders. If the team were sold -- and N.F.L. teams now sell for at least $150 million -- the proceeds would go to build a war memorial at a local American Legion post.
"The founders were a bunch of guys who wanted something to do on Sundays," said Robert Harlan, the Packers' president. "They thought they'd operate it for a few years, and if it made a little money, it would go to the legion."
The legion, whose honor guard presents the colors before each Packers game, "would get the damnedest war memorial anyone's ever seen," Mr. Harlan said.
But no one can imagine the Packers being sold. The team is a bedrock franchise, whose only major move was from an old high school park it used for 33 years to Lambeau Field in 1957.
It had net income of $2 million in the fiscal year that ended March 31, 1995, a period in which several teams lost money in the N.F.L., not to mention those with losses in other sports. The Packers financed construction of 90 luxury boxes this past season, for a total of 198, then handed ownership of the suites to the city, which owns the stadium.
The team's loyalty is matched only by the fans' dedication. Early last Sunday morning, about 8,000 fans crowded the airport to cheer the return of the team after it upset the San Francisco 49ers the day before.
Fans around Wisconsin are buying Packers' goods in the familiar green-and-gold colors so rapidly that the jackets, T-shirts and caps are the fastest-selling of all 30 teams, said N.F.L. Properties, the league's licensing arm.
Maybe the truest indicator of the current wave of Packermania is the shortage of the foam cheese heads worn proudly by Green Bay fans. "There's a black market in them," said David Rosenwasser, president of the Green Bay Area Visitors and Convention Bureau. "The company that makes them got behind in production making sourdough heads for San Francisco last week."
Green Bay has retained the Packers long after teams in other smaller markets in the Midwest -- like Decatur, Ill., Akron and Canton in Ohio and Evansville, Ind. -- faded into history or moved to large urban centers. Green Bay is the 199th-largest city in the United States, and its television market, which includes Appleton, Wis., is ranked 71st.
Teams in other cities inspire devoted, even fanatic, followers. But the Packers may be more important to Green Bay than other teams are to their cities, for its sports domination of a small market and for its quaint ownership structure.
The convention bureau estimates the team creates direct spending of $30 million to $35 million, and counts on the free advertising from Packers' television games to lure tourists to local attractions like the railroad museum, the Oneida Casino, the Neville Museum and the Weidner Performing Arts Center.
"In 100 years we couldn't afford to pay for the exposure we get from the games," Mr. Rosenwasser said. And thanks to the Packers' presence in the conference title game, WLUK-TV, the local Fox affiliate that will televise the contest, has raised its rates 25 percent from the regular season, said Steve Banka, the station's vice president for marketing. Packer viewership borders on the astounding: this season's average local Nielsen rating has been a 56, meaning that 56 percent of all televisions in the area were tuned in.
Despite its wild popularity, the team needs the league's assistance to make a profit. Under N.F.L. rules, each team, regardless of size, gets an equal share of media and licensing revenues and 40 percent of the gate receipts at away games.
"We're only here because Pete Rozelle convinced the owners to share that money," Mr. Harlan conceded, referring to the former N.F.L. commissioner. The current four-year network and broadcast televison contracts total $4.4 billion.
For the 1995 fiscal year, the Packers got $37.3 million from television and radio contracts, and $2.6 million from N.F.L. Properties. Revenues from road games totaled $6.4 million. Those shared funds represented 74 percent of the Packers' total revenues of $62.2 million, with much of the rest coming from receipts from home games.
"It's testimony to the way the league is set up because no one starting a league now would put a team in a city that small," Alan Friedman, editor of Team Marketing Report, a Chicago-based sports newsletter said. "They support their team as well as a city 10 times their size."
All of the Packers' profits are plowed back into team operations and capital improvements. The team has spent $38 million over the years to expand the stadium, add the suites and build a practice facility.
All of the suites are sold out -- for a league low of $19,000 to $24,000 -- as is the entire 60,790-seat stadium game after game. The team is contemplating raising suite and ticket prices, but realizes the modest admissions charges (the top price is $28) forge a bond with the middle-class fan base. "But we know we're leaving a lot of money on the table," said Lance Lopes, the team's general legal counsel.
There are 23,000 names on the waiting list for season tickets. Mayor Paul Jadin, a season-ticket holder, figures that his children will get their own tickets in, say, 20 to 30 years. "This team is like our Statue of Liberty," he said.
The team's finances are helped by a favorable city lease: the Packers get all ticket, concession and parking revenues in return for rent of $400,000, which will rise to about $1 million under a new 20-year extension.
"This franchise isn't leaving," said John Underwood, the president of Firstar Bank in Green Bay, and the team's treasurer. "We don't have an owner who needs or wants the money. We just have a different perspective."
That perspective has drawn interest from cities fearful of losing teams. "There was an awful lot of envy from the other cities for the Packers and the city," Mr. Jadin said, describing a recent meeting with other mayors in Cleveland. They want to find a way to make sure a team stays, and think nonprofit public ownership offers that assurance.
But the Packers' setup is permitted only because of a grandfather clause in the N.F.L.'s ownership rules, which now seek to have one individual motivated by profit who owns at least 30 percent of the team and has the authority to make decisions.
"Maybe it's a thing that could only happen in 1919," Mr. Jadin said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Isetan Sues Barney's,Calls Attitude Deplorable
 
Isetan of Japan sued Barney's Inc., accusing its management of deception. "The attitude of Barney's management up to this stage is totally deplorable," said a statement from Isetan, which bankrolled the Barney's expansion. 
 This week Barney's Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection, and set off a public battle with its partner by filing its own suit seeking to recover $50 million in payments made over two years. [Page 37.]
 
German Company Seeks Maybelline
 
A German cosmetics company went after Maybelline, saying it wanted to top L'Oreal's $660 million bid, which the American cosmetics company accepted in December. Maybelline was noncommittal about what it would do now. The new suitor, Joh. A. Benckiser G.m.b.H., makes Coty and Lancaster cosmetics. [36.]
 
Financial News Service for Sale
 
Knight-Ridder gave up its hopes of making its electronic financial news service into a leading competitor, saying it would put the service up for sale at auction this spring. Knight-Ridder's stock rose $3.375, to $63.25. The financial service competes against services from Reuters, Dow Jones and Bloomberg that deliver constantly updated news, prices and analysis to traders, and those companies are considered potential bidders. [37.]
 
Kmart Given Junk Bond Rating
 
Standard & Poor's lowered the Kmart Corporation's bond rating to junk status. The retailer, which reached new agreements with its lenders on Thursday, said the move was "excessively severe" but unlikely to cause any immediate cash problems. [37.]
 
Clinton Pushes Fairness Theme
 
President Clinton portrayed the budget battle as a test of fairness, saying the nation must choose between "a society where winner takes all, or a society where everybody's got a chance to win." In Tennessee, he revived some of the economic themes that characterized his 1992 campaign. [1.]
 
Taiwan Rejects Capital Gains Tax
 
Taiwan's Parliament defeated a proposed capital gains tax on stock profits, relieving the market which had plunged 6.7 percent earlier this month after opposition legislators voted to levy a 14 percent tax on capital gains. The latest vote left the tax on stock transactions unchanged at three-tenths of 1 percent. [36.]
 
Another Drop in Heating Oil
 
Heating oil prices fell for a third day, as forecasts for warmer weather signaled weakening demand for fuel. Heating oil for February delivery tumbled 2.59 cents, to 53.57 cents a gallon. That brought its two-day loss to 9.8 percent. [38.]
 
Sony Sees Eventual Public Sale
 
Sony's president envisions selling stock in the company's American entertainment and electronics operations to the public, though not soon. Sony, which forced the resignation of Michael P. Schulhof as the president of Sony of America last month, does not intend to replace him, but instead wants the heads of the movie, music and consumer electronics businesses to report to Tokyo. [36.]
 
Stocks Fall at End of Rocky Week
 
Stocks edged lower in volatile trading as the market prepared for a flood of fourth-quarter corporate earnings reports next week. At the close, the Dow was down 3.98 points, to 5,061.12, for its third decline this week. The Nasdaq composite index fell 2.87, to 1,008.23. Dell, Motorola and Apple were lower. Retailers and oil were also weak. [39.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose slightly in a short session, but investors sold long maturities while waiting for signs of progress toward a balanced budget. The yield of the 30-year bond stayed at 6.14 percent. [45.]
 
Moody's Questions Pataki Budget
 
Moody's questioned the assumptions of Governor Pataki in formulating his 1996-97 budget, saying he relied too heavily on Federal changes that are far from certain. The Governor needs to close a projected $3.9 billion shortfall in the year beginning April 1. [26.]
 
Dollar Makes Limited Gains
 
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen and the German mark as traders sold low-yielding Japanese investments, but gains were limited as the market awaited the first major American economic reports in a month. In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.4420 German marks, and to 105.20 yen. [38.]

HEADLINE: Bond-Rating Firm Frowns On Pataki's Budget Plan

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Raising sharp questions about Gov. George E. Pataki's plans to shrink state government, a firm that rates New York State's bonds released a report today saying that the Governor's 1996-97 budget proposal relies far too heavily on Federal changes that are far from certain.
In its preliminary review of Mr. Pataki's proposed budget, Moody's Investors Service said the Governor presumes changes in Federal Medicaid and welfare rules that would provide more than two thirds of the savings needed to close a projected $3.9 billion shortfall in the fiscal year beginning April 1. But, the report says, "Recent Federal budget negotiations leave it unclear whether New York State will be able to rely on the assumed savings." 
 Moreover, the report notes that local governments in New York State have already begun demanding a share of the $1.3 billion savings that Mr. Pataki hopes to receive under a proposal that would require the Federal Government to pay a larger portion of Medicaid, the Federal, state and local health care program for the poor and elderly.
If the local governments succeed, Mr. Pataki and the Legislature would be forced to find new cuts in other programs.
Finally, the report says that budget negotiations with the Legislature are likely to be "lengthy, controversial and contentious," with Republicans and Democrats expected to fight to restore much of the $1.1 billion Mr. Pataki wants to cut from the state share of Medicaid.
Moody's has given an A rating to New York State's general obligation bonds, the second lowest rating among the 40 states it grades. Only Louisiana's rating is lower. Standard & Poor's Corporation, the other major bond rating firm, has given New York its lowest bond rating.
Peter Murphy, a spokesman for the state Division of the Budget, called the Moody's report overly pessimistic. "We agree that there are uncertainties," he said. "But these are pretty reasonable assumptions."
The report does say that Mr. Pataki's budget is based on reasonable assumptions about the general shape of the economy and reduces reliance on nonrecurring sources of revenue -- the bane of bond raters. But it says the plan makes little headway in reducing the state's long-term debt of $7.5 billion.
The Moody's report was released just as Mr. Pataki was proposing amendments to his $63.8 billion budget. The changes would restore $52 million to a range of programs, almost all of which would be offset by lower than anticipated costs for welfare and debt payments, state budget officials said.
The release of the amendments today marks the completion of Mr. Pataki's budget proposal and the official beginning of negotiations between the Governor and legislative leaders over the plan.
The largest change is the addition of $13 million for the state AIDS Institute, which distributes grants for education and treatment programs. The change raises the institute's proposed 1996-97 budget to $70 million.

HEADLINE: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE DAMAGE;
At Least 14 Hurt as Snow's Weight Brings Down the Roof of an L.I. Supermarket

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
At least 14 people were injured, one seriously, when half the sprawling roof of a Waldbaum's supermarket in Massapequa, L.I., collapsed late yesterday, dumping a mountain of snow, slush and debris among the nearly deserted aisles of foodstuffs and household goods. The store appeared to be a total loss.
In a week of winter storms, including a historic blizzard that left up to three feet of snow and paralyzed much of the Northeast, it was one of at least 10 roofs that fell under the weight of snow in the New York region. Roof and ceiling collapses were reported in residential and public buildings up and down the East Coast yesterday. 
 The roof of an 85-year-old Harlem church partly fell yesterday, with damage estimated at $1.5 million. Later, as pounding rains added to their burdens, the roofs of a shop in Blue Point, L.I., and a printing plant in Voorhees, N.J., fell in, injuring one person in each case. Earlier in the week, roofs caved in at three industrial sites on Long Island, a state office in Elizabeth, N.J., a clothing store in Edison, N.J., and a paper factory in Danbury, Conn.
In Massapequa yesterday, a cashier was trapped briefly in a collapse that left a 100-foot crater and almost wall-to-wall snow and debris inside the store at Hicksville Road and Jerusalem Avenue about 5 P.M. But fellow employees and rescue workers extricated the cashier, who suffered severe facial cuts.
"I could hear her screaming from under the debris," Mouded Siddiqui, 19, a Waldbaum's worker, said of the trapped cashier, whom he called Melanie. "So I crawled in and pulled apart the wires and chunks of the roof and took her hand. She was soaking from all the water that came down from the roof. She was freezing to death -- that's why I gave my jacket to her."
The terrified woman pleaded with him to remain with her, he recalled. "I wanted to stay in there longer, but you could smell the propane gas and that was very dangerous," he said. Though ordered out by his manager, he said, he returned later and with the help of a firefighter and a medic pulled the woman to safety.
Witnesses said the collapse might have been a deadly disaster if there had been more customers in the store at the time, and if there had been no warning. But many shoppers had stocked up Thursday night in anticipation of yesterday's storm, and instead of the usual Friday night crowd only a relative handful of people were there. Many ran for the exits when the building began to shake and groan and ceiling tiles began to pop moments before the collapse.
"I felt it shaking, heard a tremble, looked up and the whole roof was coming in, front to back, the whole length of the store," Neil Hurley, who was working in the frozen food section and escaped without serious injury, told The Associated Press. "I started running toward the back of the store."
Carolynn Hansen of Massapequa was just outside when the roof fell.
"I never actually got into the store," she said. "I was just entering and it just came crashing down right over the cashiers. All you saw was feet and feet of snow. The lights immediately went out and it was pitch black. There was a smell of gas and it looked like water or oil was pouring into the store."
Detective Frank O'Connor, a Nassau County Police spokesman, said 14 people were taken to nearby hospitals with minor injuries, mostly cuts and bruises, after the roof caved in, apparently under tons of snow from the blizzard, the added burden of yesterday's sleet and rain, and an air-conditioning unit, which also fell into the store.
As darkness came and a steady, freezing rain pounded the site last night, searchlights played over the store and the police and firefighters continued searching the debris. Gas and electricity were shut off. Ambulances and other emergency vehicles stood by, but all store employees had been accounted for and no one was believed to be trapped in the rubble.
The store was a bizarre sight. From a helicopter overhead, a 100-foot crater full of snow and debris was visible, and a large dark mass -- apparently the air-conditioner -- jutted up out of the snow.
From a parking lot in front, through ground-to-ceiling windows that still bore decals of snowmen in red scarfs popping champagne corks to celebrate the holidays, one could see a wall of snow filling the interior, burying shopping aisles, foodstuffs, household goods, carts and cashiers' checkout stations.
Angelo Delligatti, a Massapequa resident and an Oyster Bay Town Councilman, said the building had been erected about 20 years ago and had had its facade replaced about two years ago.
"We'll let the Police and Fire Department do what they have to do and then the building inspector will have to determine what caused the collapse and if there were any code violations that might have contributed," Mr. Delligatti said. "At this point, it would seem like it was just due to all the snow we've had and then the rain that we got on top of that today."
Alan Landman, superintendent of the Oyster Bay Department of Buildings, said he thought the supermarket had been built in the 1960's in accordance with the state building code, which specifies minimum "snow load" strengths for commercial structures. He said it had probably been built to exceed those standards and, as far as he knew, had no history of structural problems.
"As the snow and rain is coming, it's just exerting extraordinary pressure on these roofs," Mr. Landman said, adding that the roofs of three industrial buildings in his area had collapsed in the previous three days.
On Monday, as the Blizzard of 1996 reached its height, three roofs collapsed: at the State Unemployment Office in Elizabeth, N.J., which had 28.5 inches of snow; at a T. J. Maxx clothing store in Edison, N.J., which had 30 inches of snow, and at a paper factory on Main Street in Danbury, Conn., which had 21 inches of snow.
In Harlem yesterday, the roof of St. Philip's Episcopal Church partly collapsed over the sanctuary and altar area. Emily Frye, the church's senior warden, said the damage could total $1.5 million. "We have someone working on the roof now to see if they can stabilize it and prevent further damage," she said of the church, which was built in 1911.
In Suffolk County, the roof of a Linens 'n' Things store at Gateway Plaza in Blue Point, collapsed about 4:50 P.M. A spokesman for the Suffolk County Fire Department said there was only one minor injury.
And in Voorhees, N.J., last night, one man was injured and trapped for an hour when the roof of AFL Printing Company collapsed under the weight of snow and rain. Nine or 10 other employees escaped when it occurred about 7 P.M., but the injured man, whose name was not released, fell face down under debris.
Mayor Pamela Hammer said the man had yelled to rescue workers that he was lying prone in rising rainwater and was in danger of drowning. A plastic tube was used to enable him to breathe while rescue teams used a hydraulic jack to extricate him. He was listed in stable condition at Cooper Hospital-University Medical Center in Camden.

HEADLINE: Clinton Casts Budget Battle As Test of Nation's Fairness

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Before hundreds of cheering truck assembly-line workers in a state important to his re-election hopes, President Clinton today called his budget battle with the Republican majority in Congress a choice between a vision of "a society where winner takes all or a society where everybody's got a chance to win."
In back-to-back appearances at the Peterbilt Truck Factory and a Democratic fund-raising lunch, Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore provided a taste of how they might take the budget theme to the hustings if the November elections become a referendum on the two parties' competing visions for shaping the Federal Government. 
 Impassioned, folksy and quoting lines from a country-western song in the city that is home to the Grand Ole Opry, Mr. Clinton returned to some of the economic themes that had characterized his first race for President in 1992 -- an emphasis on the needs of the middle class.
"We want to grow the middle class and strengthen the underclass," Mr. Clinton said. "We think the best way to make more millionaires is to have more successful working people buying what they're putting out, whether they're products or services."
Mr. Gore, returning to his home state, where Republicans captured the Governorship and both Senate seats two years ago, called Republican prescriptions "an extremist agenda" and tied them to the 'trickle-down economics" of the Reagan Administration. And going on the offensive on the Whitewater controversy, he said that the Republicans were using "character assassination" tactics against Hillary Rodham Clinton because they could not "make any progress talking about the issues Americans care about."
Mr. Clinton left Nashville at midday on an overnight flight to Bosnia, where he planned to meet Saturday with American troops stationed in Tuzla as part of the NATO peacekeeping mission. He also planned to meet with the presidents of Bosnia and Croatia. [The President arrived on Saturday morning at Aviano Air Base in northern Italy and was expected to go on to Tuzla.]
President Clinton asked the truck-factory workers to applaud three of their co-workers who had been sent to Germany with National Guard units to provide support for the deployment of United States troops to Bosnia.
"We have worked hard, not to fight a war, but to win a peace," he said, "for the humanitarian reasons that involved the people there and to keep that war from spreading in ways that could hurt the United States and our friends and allies in Europe."
Mr. Clinton's two stops in Nashville, however, mainly focused on campaign-style appeals for support in Washington's budget fight, just a day after he declared at a news conference that he was optimistic that a budget deal could be reached "if we set aside partisanship and work to seize this moment."
Describing the 50 hours of face-to-face negotiations he has had with the Republican Congressional leaders, Mr. Clinton said the talks had often reminded him of the lyrics of a country-western song, "It's hard to soar like an eagle when I'm stuck with a turkey like you."
"Sometimes they think that about me. Sometimes I think that about them," he said in reference to the Congressional leaders -- drawing hoots of laughter.
The President's appearances came while Congress was taking a short recess and both parties were maneuvering for advantage in the budget standoff, either to force a deal on their terms or to prepare for a long-term political battle during the November elections.
More than a quarter of the 1996 fiscal year has already been passed without a budget agreement, and a temporary spending bill that returned Federal workers to their jobs after a three-week partial Government shutdown expires on Jan. 26.
Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, continued sharply castigating Mr. Clinton today, saying he had misled the American people by accusing Republicans of seeking excessive cuts in Medicare, Medicaid and other social-welfare spending. Mr. Gingrich said Republicans wanted to slow the growth in the costs of the programs. "I don't know how you have good-faith negotiations when somebody does that," Mr. Gingrich said after the Clinton news conference on Thursday.
But today Mr. Clinton went on the political offensive, calling Republican proposals to rein in Medicare spending and turn Medicaid into a block grant to the states a strike at the pockets of the middle class. The Medicare debate, he said, was not just about the elderly but about "people like you," who "will have to spend more money on your parents and you'll have less money to send your kids to college."
Mr. Clinton said that increased Medicare charges proposed by the Republicans would cost older couples an additional $400 a year.
"Well, if you're making a good living, $400 may not be very much," the President said. "But there's a lot of retired people in the hills of Tennessee and rural Arkansas for whom $400 is a whole bunch of money."
It is not clear how Mr. Clinton arrived at his estimates. Under his own proposal for Medicare, the monthly Medicare premium, $42.50, would rise to $67.90 in 2002. Under the Republican proposal, it would rise to $88.90 in 2002.
The President said that Medicaid, known primarily as a health plan for the poor and disabled, "is the program that pays for middle-class folks to send their parents to nursing homes so that they don't have to go totally bankrupt and their kids don't have to go totally bankrupt."

HEADLINE: Mayor Sees More Cuts if Rate Plan Fails

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday he might have to make deeper cuts in spending in response to Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi's decision earlier this week to refuse to approve a plan to reorganize New York City's debt for an infusion of cash.
The Mayor's office had quietly drafted the refinancing plan -- not unlike a homeowner refinancing a mortgage -- as part of its efforts to close a widening shortfall in the city's $32 billion budget. Halfway through the fiscal year, that shortfall has now reached at least $600 million and possibly much more, forcing Mr. Giuliani to act if he hopes to keep the budget balanced. 
 In the past, similar proposals have come under criticism from the city's fiscal monitors and bond raters, who consider them to be fiscal gimmicks -- "one shots" in budget parlance -- that push the city's debt costs into the future to provide immediate relief. A slightly smaller refinancing last spring led in part to the lowering of the city's credit rating by Standard & Poor's last July.
In talks with the Mayor's aides earlier this week, Mr. Hevesi, a Democrat who as Comptroller has the authority to approve the sale of city bonds, objected to the latest plan, which would save $157 million immediately by reorganizing principal and interest payments on $553 million in bonds now coming due.
Mr. Hevesi, who has feuded with the Republican Mayor recently over several fiscal issues, including the proposed sale of the city's waterworks, said in an interview yesterday that Mr. Giuliani's latest proposal would saddle future mayors with higher debt costs for nearly a decade, starting in 2001.
"In order to accomplish this immediate savings, you blow up your budget for the next decade," he said. "It's mortgaging your future. It's wrong."
Mr. Giuliani disagreed with the Comptroller, saying the refinancing was arranged to take advantage of lower interest rates. Even though the plan would mean higher costs in some years, he said, the city would save $7 million over the life of the new bonds, through 2014.
"It's almost irresponsible not to take advantage of opportunities like that," the Mayor said at a news conference at City Hall. "Almost any sophisticated city in America does refinancings like this all the time."
Bond raters and fiscal monitors, however, agreed with Mr. Hevesi.
Richard P. Larkin, managing director of Standard & Poor's, said the refinancing seemed to be intended to give a cash infusion now by putting off payment of principal. That, he said, provided one-shot savings without addressing rising costs in next year's budget.
Mr. Larkin said his agency lowered the city's rating to BBB+ from A- because of these kinds of budgetary ploys. "I guess the best way to put it is the city is living down to our expectations," he said.
Mr. Giuliani said he still hoped to address the Comptroller's concerns. He warned, however, that Mr. Hevesi's continued refusal would worsen the city's fiscal affairs. "The consequence would be that there'd be more stress and more cutting that would have to be done," he said.
The dispute, which, officials said, became public when the men were overheard shouting at each other over the telephone on Thursday, underscored the efforts Mr. Giuliani is making to balance his budget.
The Mayor has ordered city commissioners to cut $200 million more, or 18 percent, from their budgets for supplies, contracts and other non-salary costs by the end of January.
The Mayor's budget director, Joseph J. Lhota, said the refinancing was intended to save $157 million this year, as well as small amounts in the next four years, before costing $50 million a year in higher costs for seven years, starting in 2001, then providing savings thereafter. The sale would have to take place before Feb. 1, when the city must pay off $150 million in bonds that have matured, officials said.
Mr. Lhota and the Mayor said the refinancing met a new set of criteria imposed by the Comptroller last year -- a step praised by the State Financial Control Board -- by saving money over the life of the bonds.
Mr. Lhota argued that the Comptroller had injected arbitrary criteria by insisting that the costs not increase in any one year in the future, although Mr. Hevesi said that was a criterion all along.

HEADLINE: Japan Retailer Files $168 Million Suit Against Barney's

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The Isetan Company, the upscale fashion retailer in Japan that bankrolled the recent expansion of Barneys New York, strongly suggested today that it had been misled by the Barneys management and filed suit against the owners of Barneys.
"The attitude of Barneys management up to this stage is totally deplorable," a statement released here by Isetan said. 
 On Thursday, the parent company of Barneys announced that it had filed for bankruptcy protection, setting off the public battle with Isetan by filing its own suit seeking to recover $50 million in payments to Isetan over the last two years.
In response, Isetan's suit, filed in New York today against the two brothers who head the company, Bob and Gene Pressman, seeks the return of roughly $168 million in short-term loans made by Isetan of America, a subsidiary of the Japanese retailer. The loans, Isetan said, were personally guaranteed by the Pressmans and are now in default.
In a statement, Isetan said it had been kept in the dark until late November about major financial problems at Barney's Inc., the parent of the high-fashion retailer, Barneys New York.
Barney's is a private company and does not publicly release its financial statements, but it disclosed them to Isetan as its financial partner. After six years of submitting annual statements showing profits, including reports on the fiscal year that ended in July 1995, certified by its accounting firm, Isetan said that Barney's executives surprised them by announcing that Barney's had sustained large pretax losses instead.
"At the official meeting, which took place in Tokyo on Nov. 28 and 29, 1995, the chairman of Barney's gave the top officials of Isetan for the first time the incredible explanation that Barney's had been drastically in the red on the basis of recurring business profits," the statement by Isetan said.
[In New York, Charles W. Bunstine, president and chief operating officer of Barney's, called the accusations "absolutely not true."
["There was no issue of disclosure," Mr. Bunstine said. "We showed them current scenarios that could have a material effect on the company based upon the treatment of the global partnership. On an operating level, it made no difference."]
Isetan would not disclose the actual amount of the loss or how long a period the loss covered, but it said that the disclosure radically altered the nature of negotiations over its joint venture with Barney's.
"The biggest trouble is that top management at Isetan thinks that Barney's top management is not faithful," said Seiichi Yamada, a retail analyst at UBS Securities Ltd.
Analysts said that Barney's entered bankruptcy proceedings mainly as a strategic move to extract the maximum concessions in its dispute with Isetan. While both sides professed an interest in maintaining the six-year-old financial partnership, the relationship between Isetan and Barney's may be doomed.
Analysts here said that the different styles in management, the miscues and the lack of communication played a role in undermining it. Company officials agreed.
"Their way of thinking and our way of thinking are very different," said Kunihiko Murata, a spokesman at Isetan.
Isetan may be regarded as a fashionable department store in Japan, but its management is highly traditional, shunning confrontation and valuing friendship and loyalty.
Partly because it is a private company, Barney's has always been secretive about its financial position, and it kept up a high level of discretion even with Isetan. Isetan said it pressed Barney's repeatedly for more financial information, but was unsuccessful.
Yet Isetan continued to step up its investment, effectively spending 61.6 billion yen, or $592 million, in real estate purchases, loans and other investments to finance the expansion of Barneys from its original location in lower Manhattan to Madison Avenue and other locations in major American cities. So some analysts fault Isetan for falling into a trap.
"If they didn't have any information about the financial statements," said Mashahiro Matsuoka, a retail analyst at BZW Securities (Japan) Ltd., "why did they pay such a huge amount to Barneys?"
Analysts also said that the balance of power may have shifted to Barney's once Isetan had financed the big new stores on Madison Avenue, in Beverly Hills, Calif., and in Chicago.
In filing for bankruptcy, "Barney's really pulled a fast one on them," said Victoria T. Melendez, a retail analyst at Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd. "From a human perspective, it is not a warm and friendly thing to do. From a business perspective, you really cut down on your credibility from a partner's perspective."
Isetan may be in an awkward position now. Isetan introduced to Japanese shoppers here two flamboyant Barneys stores, replete with elegant doormen, and it has numerous other arrangements with Barneys.
Mr. Murata, Isetan's spokesman, refused to disclose financial results on its overall tie-up with Barney's. But analysts said that Isetan could lose up to 24.5 billion yen, or $236 million, from its various loans to Barney's and preferred shares.
[John Campo, a lawyer for Barneys, disputed Isetan's claim on the $168 million it is seeking in its suit. "What they are calling loans the company doesn't believe are true loans," Mr. Campo said. "They were part of the investment that Isetan made in the joint-venture properties."]
Japan's stagnant economy has taken its toll on Japanese retailers and in its fiscal year ending in March 1995, Isetan reported profits of only $21 million, on revenues of $6.1 billion. Analysts said, however, that Isetan could cover extraordinary losses by selling marketable securities and valuable properties.
After last March, the Barney's management stopped paying interest to Isetan on the short-term loans, and it failed to pay rent to Isetan this month. Still, Isetan has suggested that it may want to continue its relationship with Barney's, and analysts said that Isetan might be interested in continuing the use of the Barneys brand name in Japan.
"We have to see what happens in court, but we are not saying that we definitely have to sever ties with Barney's completely," Mr. Murata said.

HEADLINE: New York City Plans Market In Its Tax Bills

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
In a bid to raise $125 million quickly from New York City's huge backlog of unpaid property taxes, the Giuliani administration is moving to market the tax bills in the same way that Wall Streets sells securities, investment bankers in New York and Philadelphia said yesterday.
The deal, which would require City Council approval, is a historic departure from the city's past methods of collecting property taxes and is quite different from the practice in most cities. For delinquent New York commercial property owners, the plan will mean dunning calls to pay up, one investment banker said. 
 Two former city finance officials said that historically the city was not aggressive in trying to collect unpaid property taxes. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani recently said he wanted the city to shift its focus from foreclosing on properties with taxes that have gone unpaid for years and instead help people keep their homes and help merchants stay in business.
The city's plan to bundle up some of its $2 billion of unpaid property tax bills and market them wholesale also differs from the much more common municipal practice of handling such debts at the retail level, auctioning off tax bills one at a time to investors, who then try to collect the unpaid tax bills. Failing that, the investors can foreclose and take ownership of the properties.
New York City has been circulating to investment bankers a request for proposals on how they would manage a sale of securities backed by tax liens, Eamon Moynihan, a spokesman for the city Finance Department said. The proposals are due on Tuesday. The plan was first disclosed by Private Placement Report, a newsletter affiliated with the trade paper American Banker, in an issue that subscribers are to receive on Monday.
About $200 million of unpaid tax bills would be sold to a trust, which would then borrow an estimated $125 million from pension funds and other institutional investors by issuing them senior notes. The city would then get junior or subordinated notes for the balance of the face value of the unpaid tax bills. As an incentive to the collectors, the city would give them a share of that money.
The pension funds and other investors would thus lend the city about 62 cents on the dollar for the unpaid tax bills, according to a senior city finance official.
That means that for each dollar the investors lend the city, they would have $1.60 of collateral, compared with a typical home mortgage where at the outset the lender has $1.25 of collateral for each dollar lent. At that level of collateral the lenders' risk is tiny, five investment bankers in New York and Philadelphia said yesterday.
The deal has such low risk because of the high level of collateral that one Manhattan investment banker said the interest rate the city would have to pay for the loan might be just three-quarters of one percentage point above short-term commercial borrowing rates, which are currently a little above 6 percent.
The city would then hire private companies to collect the overdue tax bills.
Once enough of the overdue tax bills had been collected to repay the loan with interest, the city would then get all the extra money that was collected.
How much the city can borrow against its unpaid property taxes depends on whether the unpaid tax bills represent a large or small portion of the value of the real estate being taxed, said Ben Hayllar, the finance director in Philadelphia, where a similar financing deal is being developed.
"The lower the tax-lien-to-value ratio, the better the chance that the taxes will be paid to protect the owner's investment," Mr. Hayllar said. "This is a way to clean out a city's inventory of unpaid taxes."
New York relies on property taxes for $8 billion of its $32 billion budget. Tax delinquencies are currently running $400 million, or about 5 percent, up from just 2 percent before the 1988-90 recession, the city finance official said last night.
"Basically, a lot of people are borrowing money from the city by not paying their taxes until the last minute," the official said. He said that while the city charges 18 percent annual interest on past-due property taxes, many companies that delay payment could not borrow the sum elsewhere at lower interest rates.
"We become a lender whether we want to or not," the official said. "We view this as an enforcement tool; it just happens to have the effect of producing revenue. If we can push our collection rate up just one percentage point the city will bring in $80 million more."
Both Jersey City and New Haven have made similar deals in the past. New Haven borrowed $19 million in 1994 against $26 million in tax liens and paid an interest rate that was 2.2 percentage points above market, Private Placement Report said.
Pittsburgh is also looking at wholesale marketing of unpaid property taxes, according to Mr. Hayllar, who was previously Pittsburgh's city finance director.
Mr. Hayllar said cities could also just sell property tax bills outright at a discount, much as merchants sell their accounts receivable at a discount to financiers known as factors. But by using the loan technique, he said, cities can maintain control over methods used to collect property taxes, and they can also substitute one tax lien for another in the event such a switch would benefit the city by making possible a new industrial development or a deal that would create jobs.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 15, 1996, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about New York City's plans to offer a new kind of security backed by unpaid tax bills misstated in some copies the amount to be raised and the value of the bills being used as collateral. The city hopes to raise $125 million, not $200 million; the collateral is $200 million, not $1.5 billion.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1097 words

HEADLINE: Elbow Room

BYLINE: By William D. Nordhaus; William D. Nordhaus, the A. Whitney Griswold Professor of Economics at Yale University, writes frequently about environmental issues.

 BODY:

HOW MANY PEOPLE CAN THE EARTH SUPPORT?
By Joel E. Cohen.
Illustrated. 532 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $30.
WHAT is the history of human populations on earth? How might we project future population growth? And how close are we now to the limits of sustenance of our finite orb? These are the questions that this fascinating volume addresses. 
 The author, Joel E. Cohen, heads the laboratory of populations at Rockefeller University in New York City. A distinguished biologist, he has written on mathematics, demography and mathematical ecology. In "How Many People Can the Earth Support?," his most ambitious book, he tackles one of the central questions facing humanity: Has the rapid population growth of the last two centuries pushed us dangerously near a cliff, beyond which lies decline or disaster? Although these issues have been addressed by scientists for more than three centuries, they have assumed heightened importance as population and environmental concerns take center stage in the post-cold-war era.
It would be hard to conceive of a better book for those interested in a scholarly and nonideological review and analysis of population issues. You will find in the early pages a historical census of human numbers along with a sophisticated review of methods for projecting future populations. Mr. Cohen then tackles the issue of the carrying capacity of the earth. This concept is defined dozens of times in the study but is best understood as motivated by the concern that "the world has, or will soon have, more people than the world's economies, environments and societies can accommodate in acceptable ways."
Mr. Cohen's major contribution is his review of alternative approaches to estimating how many people can live on earth. He analyzes different ways of calculating the constraints imposed by land, food production and water supply. And he reminds us that social and political institutions, human ingenuity and time itself are equally important. Woven throughout the book are reflections on the choices faced by humans, either individually or collectively, that can reduce whatever modest or catastrophic threats we may face as a consequence of population growth.
Not surprisingly, studies of the earth's capacity generally rely on one of its finite resources, like space or food. Apparently, the first estimate of the maximum number of people the earth could support was made in 1679 by Antoni van Leeuwenhoek, a Dutch microscopist who turned to larger game. He assumed that the binding constraint on human populations was living space and that the upper limit on human density was that of Holland. From this, he concluded that the limit on human beings on earth was 13.4 billion. (The world's population was estimated to be 5.3 billion in 1990, and the United Nations projects world population in 2100 to range somewhere between 6 billion and 19 billion.)
Following Malthus's "Essay on the Principle of Population" (1798), most estimates assumed that food was the limiting factor. One of the most influential approaches was that of the German geographer Albrecht Penck, who published his findings in 1924. He divided the earth into 11 climatic zones and estimated the possible food production in each. From this, he concluded that "the potential population of the earth may be set between eight and nine billion."
With governments of high-income countries paying farmers not to produce, and with obesity becoming a major health problem in countries like the United States, Malthusianism appears increasingly obsolete. More recently, scholars have begun to look elsewhere, emphasizing environmental issues or combinations of factors. These approaches got off to a bad start around 1970 with the infamous studies on the limits to growth by the Club of Rome, which concluded that the added carrying capacity of the world had essentially reached zero. This "systems approach" never recovered from being (not inaccurately) caricatured as Chicken Little with a computer.
MR. COHEN'S survey of scientific estimates of carrying capacity finds a wide variety of results, but the conclusions are sobering. First, estimates of sustainable population range from 5 billion to 20 billion. Second, because of their explosive growth, human numbers have now reached the lower estimates. Hence, combining United Nations projections of future population growth with Mr. Cohen's survey of carrying capacity, we must take seriously his warning: "The human population of the earth now travels in the zone where a substantial fraction of scholars have estimated upper limits on human population size."
This volume is a fascinating and lucid survey of population issues, but caveat lector: While its impressive erudition covers a wide variety of disciplines, it does not succeed in bridging the gulf between demography and the other social sciences. An economist's reaction to the study might be the following: If the earth is reaching its carrying capacity because of land or food or energy shortages, where are the warning signs? Why have economic growth rates increased rather than slowed in the last two decades virtually everywhere? Put differently, if the globe is reaching its limits on land and resources, the increased stress should be accompanied by rising prices of land, food and energy. But these prices have been declining relative to labor for two centuries and particularly over the last 15 years. Markets provide signals of scarcities, yet Mr. Cohen doesn't explain why there are so few signals of resource shortages if we are approaching earth's capacity.
A second flaw is that the work is encyclopedic yet its material is curiously undigested. If you lay all the studies end to end, they still don't reach a conclusion. Each one reveals further levels of complexity, which on reflection produce yet more subtleties. Hence, after hundreds of pages of analysis and mathematics, we conclude that the number of humans the earth can durably support lies somewhere between one billion and one trillion; that the number changes over time and with technology; and that the factors determining the number are a complex and poorly understood interaction of land, water, social institutions and ingenuity. A reader can hardly help feeling disappointed that a labor of such intelligence and erudition leaves us with so little progress in charting a course between the "alarmist tracts" and the "cornucopian lullabies."
But of course few works of art or scholarship are perfect. These are only minor flaws in what is a gem of a book.

HEADLINE: Mud Wrestling

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Kolbert; Elizabeth Kolbert reports on media and politics for The New York Times.

 BODY:

GOING NEGATIVE
How Attack Ads Shrink and Polarize the Electorate.
By Stephen Ansolabehere
and Shanto Iyengar.
Illustrated. 243 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $24.
IN the last Presidential election cycle, candidates for all manner of public office sprang for an estimated $300 million worth of television advertising. Apparently they accepted the conventional wisdom. Put simply: advertising works. But does it? And if so, how? 
 Four decades after television advertising became a major expense in American politics, scholars are still surprisingly divided about its impact. Some argue that campaign commercials, with their ominous imagery and evocative music, can persuade voters to do pretty much anything -- including even to vote against their best interests. Others maintain that political ads actually provide more substantive information than the press does. And then there are those who say forces like the state of the economy so overshadow the ads' effects that they are hardly worth talking about.
In "Going Negative: How Attack Ads Shrink and Polarize the Electorate," the political scientists Stephen Ansolabehere and Shanto Iyengar offer the latest, and for fans of participatory democracy perhaps the most discouraging, theory of how ads affect our political culture. By the authors' account, it is not so much what negative advertising persuades viewers to do that matters; it is what it persuades them not to do. Such ads, Mr. Ansolabehere and Mr. Iyengar maintain, encourage viewers to opt out of electoral politics altogether, and they are used strategically by candidates who believe they would benefit from a low turnout. "Political advertising -- at least as it is currently practiced -- is slowly eroding the participatory ethos in America," they write.
Mr. Ansolabehere, an associate professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Mr. Iyengar, a professor of political science at the University of California, Los Angeles, base their dispiriting conclusions on an exhaustive set of experiments involving some 3,500 potential voters. These voters were paid to show up at rented offices, watch videotapes of news broadcasts studded with political ads and fill out lengthy questionnaires. The controlled circumstances give the authors' conclusions heft but are also likely to invite skepticism: this, after all, is not the way most Americans watch television.
A central target of the book is the oft-repeated notion that television advertising's rise has meant party loyalty's demise. Mr. Ansolabehere and Mr. Iyengar reach the opposite conclusion: advertising, they maintain, tends to reinforce partisan ties. Democrats are more likely to respond to political ads with a positive message, a tendency they attribute to the Democratic view of government as problem solver. Republicans, in contrast, are more likely to respond to negative ads. The good news, they say, is that advertising does not "manipulate" voters; rather, commercials are effective only to the extent that they resonate with beliefs voters already hold.
The bad news, though, is that an increasing number of Americans don't hold any particular party loyalties, and these people respond only to negative appeals, which, in turn, reinforce their already low opinion of politics. The paradoxical result, Mr. Ansolabehere and Mr. Iyengar argue, is that both parties can engage nonpartisan voters only through attacks that end up persuading large numbers of them simply to sit the election out.
WHAT can be done? Well, the news media tried to help by introducing the "ad watch," a feature aimed at exposing the distortions and inaccuracies of political commercials. This well-intended effort, according to the authors, has "clearly backfired," because what sinks in is the candidate's hostile message, not the reporter's criticism of it. Mr. Ansolabehere and Mr. Iyengar end up arguing in favor of stronger national party organizations, which, they claim, would work against individual candidates' efforts to depress turnout. The argument seems pretty flimsy, though, in the face of what almost everyone acknowledges to be the fallen state of the two major parties.
Among political professionals, the central message of "Going Negative" is not likely to raise many eyebrows. Insiders have appreciated for years the chief virtue of the attack ad: persuading the opponent's voters to stay home. But the message deserves a good deal more attention from the public at large, and with another slash-and-burn election season upon us, it couldn't have arrived at a better time.

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER 

 BODY:

ARISTOCRATS: Caroline, Emily, Louisa, and Sarah Lennox, 1740-1832
By Stella Tillyard. Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.
Women's part in history was often enacted in the wings, but this author has moved it center stage in her story of the daughters of a powerful British duke. Drawing on their correspondence, she shows that their lives, though largely domestic, were nonetheless dramatic. She "has devised a form of history in which character has the depth of fiction," Lyndall Gordon said here in 1994.
 
FELICIA'S JOURNEY
By William Trevor. Penguin, $10.95.
An examination of the nature of good and evil, this novel is on the surface a thriller: the title character, a pregnant Irish girl, leaves her father's home to search in England for her vanished lover. There she attracts the attention of an obese and seemingly genial middle-aged man who, it is soon revealed, has a mysterious history involving young women like herself. " 'Felicia's Journey' confirms the maxim that to understand all is to forgive all," our reviewer, Patrick McGrath, wrote last year, "and it demonstrates . . . that in hands like Mr. Trevor's, fiction is a tool without equal for creating such understanding."
 
A PIECE OF THE ACTION: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class
By Joseph Nocera. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.
The author shows how computers, credit cards and mutual funds changed the American economy, opening up financial opportunities to people whose dreams had previously kept pace with their paychecks. He chronicles this history "with rare insight and considerable flair," Lawrence S. Ritter said in these pages in 1994.
 
THE PAPERBOY
By Pete Dexter. Delta, $11.95.
Men who are wounded -- frequently physically, always emotionally -- populate this author's fiction. Ward James, who fits both categories, is a Florida reporter investigating the possibly wrongful conviction of a man on death row. His story is "eerie and beautiful," Brent Staples wrote in the Book Review last year.
 
ANTISEMITISM IN AMERICA
By Leonard Dinnerstein. Oxford University, $15.95.
The author shows how war and economic crises have often caused Jews to be cast as scapegoats, while evangelical Christianity has portrayed them as enemies. "Mr. Dinnerstein . . . warms to his subject," David Klinghoffer said here in 1994. BLACKS AND JEWS: Alliances and Arguments, edited by Paul Berman (Delta, $12.95), analyzes the recent polarization of these two groups. Including essays by authors like Henry Louis Gates Jr., Andrew Hacker, Cornel West and Cynthia Ozick, it "provides much insight into the history and underlying causes of the current tensions," our reviewer, George M. Fredrickson, said in 1994.
 
THE FOLLOWING STORY
By Cees Nooteboom. Translated by Ina Rilke. Harvest/ Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace, $9.
A former teacher who fell asleep in his Amsterdam home wakes up in a Lisbon hotel where he slept with another man's wife 20 years earlier. His meditation on his life, which appears about to end, is one in which "you can feel the fury and melancholy only just under control," Penelope Fitzgerald wrote in these pages in 1994.
 
AN HONOURABLE DEFEAT: A History of German Resistance to Hitler, 1933-1945
By Anton Gill. Owl/Holt, $14.95.
Always small in number, they were even fewer by the end of the war. But those Germans who tried to undermine the Reich -- from clergymen to soldiers -- enjoyed moral if not substantive victories. "Mr. Gill fluidly conveys the attitudes and personalities of key figures," Richard Breitman said in the Book Review in 1994. The extent of popular support for Hitler is demonstrated in THE 12-YEAR REICH: A Social History of Nazi Germany, 1933-1945, by Richard Grunberger (Da Capo, $17.95). Just restored to print, this book shows that renewed prosperity and an authoritarian mentality led ordinary Germans either to support or to blissfully ignore Government atrocities. "Full of dry wit and bitter irony, Grunberger's book is invaluable," Terence Prittie said here in 1971. Also reissued is HITLER'S LAST GAMBLE: The Battle of the Bulge, December 1944-January 1945, by Trevor N. Dupuy, David L. Bongard and Richard C. Anderson Jr. (Harper Perennial, $15), which concentrates on the operational aspects of one of the bloodiest battles America ever fought. "Dupuy has a keen eye for technical military factors that are very important but often ignored," one critic wrote in 1994.
 
FAIR LAND, FAIR LAND
By A. B. Guthrie Jr. Houghton Mifflin, $10.95.
Now restored to print, this novel is a sequel to "The Big Sky" and "The Way West," the first two books in the author's series about the American frontier. Unfolding between 1845 and 1870, it focuses on two of Guthrie's earlier protagonists and the despoiling of the landscape. "Mr. Guthrie has passionately avoided the myths of the West," The New York Times said in 1983. The same publisher has also reissued another novel in the series, THESE THOUSAND HILLS ($11.95), which records the struggles and moral compromises of Lat Evans, a young Montana rancher in the 1880's. "Mr. Guthrie is moved by a fictional purpose as high and valid as his historical purpose is big," Walter Van Tilburg Clark wrote in The New York Times in 1956.
 
A FEATHER ON THE BREATH OF GOD
By Sigrid Nunez. Harper Perennial, $10.
Like the author, the narrator is the child of a German mother and a Chinese-Panamanian father. Through ballet, she tries to transcend her parents' clashing cultures and postwar poverty. This "is a forceful novel by a writer of uncommon talent," our reviewer, Bharati Mukherjee, said last year. LAUREL GRAEBER

SECTION: Section 6; Page 14; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1100 words

HEADLINE: On Language;
What's an Extremist?

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
NOT A DAY GOES BY," WROTE THE Wall Street Journal editorialist, "without some Clinton official using the word extremist to describe something in Washington."
That was surely the word of the year for President Clinton. "If the Congress gives in to extremist pressure," one statement began; a radio broadcast included, "We can't let welfare reform die at the hands of ideological extremism"; a farewell to a rejected nominee began, "By choosing to side with extremists who would do anything to block a woman's right to choose," and in a philosophical moment, he observed, "Ideological purity is for partisan extremists." 
 What "economic royalists" were for F.D.R., and "the do-nothing 80th Congress" was for Truman, extremists are for Bill Clinton: the villain, unnamed but clearly labeled, and you know who you are.
The noun was apparently coined in the magazine The Eclectic Review during the Polk Administration, was noted in Joseph Worcester's 1846 dictionary and was popularized in 1850 by Senator Daniel Webster in connection with views about slavery and its abolition: "The extremists of both parts of the country are violent."
An earlier term, extremite, did not catch on: in 1546, Bishop Stephen Gardiner, criticizing a Protestant leader, noted, "Folowynge the newe scoole of extremites, he denied all degrees of grace." Another form of the noun was used in an English proverb cited in 1639: "Extremity of right is wrong."
But extremist triumphed, and as night follows day, the -ist led to the -ism. The Daily Telegraph of London wrote in 1865 of "these days of extravagance and extremeism," trying it out with an e before the -ism.
In our time, when the label was tagged on Senator Barry Goldwater by supporters of moderate Republican Nelson Rockefeller, he blasted back at the 1964 G.O.P. convention with a contrapuntal line submitted by the speech writer Karl Hess: "I would remind you that extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice." A roar went up from his partisans as he continued: "And let me remind you also that moderation in the pursuit of justice is no virtue!"
That only defense of the word in its history led to political disaster for its user. I was there in the Cow Palace of San Francisco, vainly pulling along a banner reading "Stay in the Mainstream," and looked over at Richard Nixon's box: in the pandemonium, Nixon was sitting on his hands, shaking his head; he knew that Goldwater lost all chance of winning with that refusal to move toward uniting the party. A few weeks later, Nixon pointed out to the G.O.P. standard-bearer that his applause line was being construed as an endorsement of extremism, and Goldwater responded he should have said that "wholehearted devotion to liberty is unassailable and that half-hearted devotion to justice is indefensible." But it was too late to rewrite the speech.
The Clinton use of extremist was encouraged by his public-opinion adviser, Richard Morris, as part of a plan to "triangulate" -- to rise above party and to place Mr. Clinton as a man of moderation between the liberal left and the true-believer right. (This Washington vogue term was bottomed on the Nixonian strategy of exploiting the break between Russia and China; "playing the China card" was in that era synonymous with triangulation.) That led to the adoption of extremist as a regular part of Clintonite rhetoric, its effectiveness endangered only by possible overuse.
True believers of the right are searching for a word to serve as a rhetorical riposte to extremist. It is hardly effective to counteraccuse the labeler of being a moderate or centrist, words that are losing their pejorative connotations as the position becomes more popular than leftist; more pointed is compromiser, or waffler, or -- if an extreme reaction is wanted -- unprincipled sell-out artist.
 
What Nature Abhors
 A part of speech can be the basis for a series of angry speeches.
After the Senate Whitewater committee wrested a memo from the White House with the threat of a court suit, attention focused on one word of one line in the memo written by the associate White House counsel, William Kennedy 3d: "Vacuum Rose Law Firm files."
Republicans read vacuum as a verb, meaning "clean out; sanitize; empty." The verb was formed to describe the action of a vacuum cleaner, invented in 1903, which uses a partial vacuum to suck particles of dust into a bag.
The White House counsel, Mark Fabiani, in charge of rebuttals of Whitewater accusations, was able to present a different interpretation of the note by changing the verb to a noun. Thus, vacuum was treated as a short form of "information vacuum," or a regrettable lack of copies of documents in the Rose Law Firm files. Changing from verb to noun changed the meaning from suspicious act to innocent fact. This creative deconstruction of the line was widely hooted at by journalists, but sometimes a stretch is better than no explanation at all.
Both noun and verb come from the Latin vacuus, "empty"; the adjective vacuous means "empty-headed, stupid."

Vulgar? Moi?
 The same euphemistic technique -- this time in reverse, from noun to verb -- was employed by United Nations diplomats to soften a controversial word. Madeleine K. Albright, the United States Ambassador to the United Nations, said in a closed meeting of the Security Council that a proposal by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to draw American forces into Eastern Slavonia would be "misguided and counterproductive."
 Those words would be taken as polite conversation in most political discourse, but diplomats accustomed to soft words found them at the outer edge of diplomatese. The Secretary General, speaking in French, said he was "shocked by the statement of the American spokesman and shocked by its vulgarity." (He must have just come from a showing of "Casablanca.")
Ambassador Albright slammed right back with "to use a word like vulgar is unacceptable." Seeking a diplomatic way out, the translator suggested that it may not have been the noun vulgarite, but could have been the verb vulgariser, which means "to disseminate to the public," from the Latin vulgus, "common people."
Again, few bought the reinterpretation -- this time from offensive noun to inoffensive verb -- but many admired the creative twist. A French diplomat smoothed it over further with "We don't think vulgarity was the most precise translation of what the Secretary General said. We think the term he had in mind was 'tastelessness.' " Nice try, but counterproductive does not strike most nondiplomats as tasteless.
