HEADLINE: Where Is the Glory That Was France?

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
FRANCE'S VERY IDEA OF ITSELF AS a nation is mirrored in the rich cultural fare permanently on offer in Paris and provincial cities. Just about everyone agrees that it is a good idea for the Government to spend $3 billion a year on the arts. And no one
questions that cultural excellence is a good way of exhibiting France's belief in its spiritual and intellectual superiority, of demonstrating to the world that this former great power is still best at something.
Yet for all of France's commitment to culture, for all the money being poured into the arts, something is amiss: French creativity has lost its spark. Few French artists, musicians or writers alive today are considered true masters of their craft. And French singers, dancers and movie directors are faring little better. Indeed, if cultural life is still flourishing here, it is now largely thanks to foreign artists and performers. 
 Perhaps it doesn't matter. Artistic creativity often comes in bursts, followed by fallow periods. And, in any event, from Lully to Picasso, foreign creators have always enriched French culture.
"I know we're chauvinistic, self-satisfied and arrogant, but for centuries we have found a place for foreign writers, composers and painters," said Jacques Rigaud, the author of "The Cultural Exception," a study of postwar cultural policy in France.
Still, France's creative malaise is causing concern here, not least because it is hard to explain. It could be just a symptom of France's broader crisis of confidence as the country is buffeted from all sides by change. At home, the good life is slowly being eroded by high unemployment, slow economic growth and the emergence of a social underclass. And many developments abroad -- whether global trade deregulation or the creation of an international superhighway -- are seen as unnerving challenges.
But there are other variables. A good many people blame the bureaucracy spawned by large Government arts budgets for trying to "manage" culture and for turning artists into civil servants. Then there is the powerful tradition of French intellectual snobbery, which requires that commercial success in the arts be scorned, particularly if it involves anything remotely linked to American popular culture. One way or the other, French culture seems to have taken refuge in the past.
The highly successful Cezanne retrospective at the Grand Palais, which has just closed after receiving some 550,000 visitors in three months, is a case in point. In recent years, Paris has also presented blockbuster shows of works by Seurat, Poussin, Toulouse-Lautrec, Matisse and Sisley. But no living French painter has been so honored.
"The last important French painter was Jean Dubuffet," said the Colombian painter Fernando Botero, who keeps a studio here. "The only thing that money cannot buy is the ability to create."
 
Government Subsidies
 
A Lot of Money,Little to Show
Could too much money be the problem? Do Government subsidies stifle creativity? Must artists be starving to be original? Jack Lang, who as France's Culture Minister for 10 years in the 1980's and early 1990's tripled Government spending on the arts, sees no link.
"The Government's role is to create a climate, an atmosphere," he said. "It is, so to speak, to irrigate the land to encourage creativity. But it's always difficult to measure the vitality of an era. How many writers and artists have been ignored in their own time?"
True, yet how does one explain the fact that foreign talent continues to emerge? Over the last 15 years, successive French Governments have invested heavily in the visual arts, not only in building, restoring and expanding museums but also in creating new art schools and regional centers of contemporary art. At last year's Venice Biennale, France was represented by Cesar, a sculptor who is now in his 70's. Where are the younger artists? Where are the Bill Violas and Damien Hirsts of France? Literally hundreds of artists working in Paris open their studios to visitors once a year, but educated French people would be hard-pressed to name one of them.
Christian Boltanski and Annette Messager, for example, are certainly considered important contemporary artists, but even they are not household names here. In fact, both have been helped by attention in the United States.
"Lots of Americans even think Boltanski is American," said Marie-Claude Beaud, who runs the American Center in Paris. "The problem here is that the public doesn't support artists as they do, say, in Britain.
"There's an interesting generation of French artists between the ages of 30 and 40," she continued. "But as soon as someone is a bit successful here, he's frowned on for being 'commercial.' I'm not pessimistic, but I was disappointed no French artist was in the recent Carnegie International," a major survey of contemporary art mounted every few years by the Carnegie Museum in Pittsburgh.
 
Classical Music
 
After Boulez, Who?
Backbiting is rife in the world of French classical music. There, the dominant (some would say domineering) force is the 70-year-old composer and conductor Pierre Boulez, who is probably France's best-known creative figure.
That alone is enough for some French musical circles to blame him for the crisis in French music. They complain that his Ensemble Intercontemporain and his Music and Acoustic Research and Coordination Institution, known as Ircam, have absorbed a disproportionate amount of Government money. And they say that he has imposed his atonal style on an entire generation of composers to the exclusion of anything more melodic and popular. Last year, he was the principal target of a book called "Requiem for an Avant-Garde" by Benoit Duteurtre.
Along with Georges Pretre and Michel Plasson, Mr. Boulez is also one of France's established conductors, but the three belong to a postwar generation and have no obvious successors today. Instead, foreign conductors are recruited here. The new music director of the Paris National Opera is an American, James Conlon, succeeding a Korean, Myung-Whun Chung, and before him, an Israeli, Daniel Barenboim. A Russian, Semyon Bychkov, is music director of the Orchestre de Paris, while a German, Christoph von Dohnanyi, and an Italian, Carlo Maria Giulini, are this month's guest conductors. It also took an American, William Christie, to revive interest in French baroque music through his ensemble, Les Arts Florissants.
In opera, French music critics are gambling that the 32-year-old Roberto Alagna, who was born in France of Sicilian parents, will emerge as a world-class tenor (he will make his debut at the Metropolitan Opera of New York in "La Boheme" in April), but the very fact that he is being busily promoted in the French press suggests he is France's only opera hope. Certainly, lead roles in productions at the Bastille Opera and the Theatre du Chatelet routinely go to foreigners, many of them rising stars from the former Soviet bloc.
"With the possible exception of Alagna, I would say there are between 10 and 20 French singers who are quite good, but none of them is really great," said Hugues Gall, who took over as director of the Paris National Opera last year.
"For me, part of the problem is that provincial cities once served as a breeding ground for young talent. But Government subsidies have disturbed all that. Now places like Nice or Toulouse have enough money to pay for international-level performers. So young singers, who cannot survive on their own when they come out of the conservatories, have nowhere to go."
 
Dance
 
Nurturers To the World
In the world of modern dance, on the other hand, France has played a crucial role as nurturer, albeit often of foreign companies, including those of the Americans Trisha Brown, Lucinda Childs, Caroline Carlsson, Merce Cunningham and William Forsythe. Groups like these are encouraged, presented regularly and even given temporary homes here.
"Many companies would not exist if France wasn't paying for them," said Yorgos Loukos, director of the Lyons Opera Ballet, where the American choreographer Bill T. Jones is currently installed with his company. "France keeps a lot of world dance alive."
By turning France into a dance capital, the Government, of course, also hoped to stimulate French modern dance, perhaps even to find a successor to the country's best-known choreographer, Maurice Bejart, who is now 68. It has had some success, with Angelin Preljocaj, Maguy Marin, Jean-Claude Gallotta and Philippe Decoufle, all young choreographers of repute. Even in France, however, they do not stir the same frisson as, say, the annual visit by the Pina Bausch Company from Germany. And outside France, they are relatively unknown. "I don't think they export themselves that easily," Mr. Loukos said.
 
Theater
 
The Avant-Garde Vs. 'Boulevard'
When it comes to theater, the French language prevents local productions from traveling far (although the Comedie Francaise will take Moliere's "Dom Juan" and Marivaux's "Inconstant Lovers" to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in New York in the spring). But this has not prevented prominent foreign directors from working here. The British director Peter Brook has made his home at the Theatre des Bouffes du Nord here since the 1970's. Lluis Pascual of Spain succeeded Italy's Giorgio Strehler as head of the Theatre de l'Europe at the Odeon. And the American Robert Wilson has worked so often in France that he is almost considered a national. Most recently, he brought his one-act play "Hamlet: A Monologue."
France itself is not without talented theater directors. But here the perennial divide between the intellectual and the commercial reappears.
Ariane Mnouchkine is an important and innovative director of theater and occasionally of movies (her 1978 film, "Moliere," is considered a classic) who has a small but loyal following at home and abroad. Patrice Chereau, who also directs movies ("La Reine Margot") and opera, draws audiences with his name (his production of Bernard-Marie Koltes's "In the Loneliness of the Cotton Fields" will go to the Brooklyn Academy next month). Yet it is rare for directors working in avant-garde and experimental theater to cross over and direct crowd-pleasing plays in what is known disparagingly as "boulevard" theater.
Is excessive intellectualism smothering French creativity? Is French culture suffering what Markus Hansen, a young Paris-based German artist, calls "death by theory?" Is French culture a victim of France's philosophical and analytical tradition? Bernard Fixot, who has his own imprint at the Robert Laffont publishing house, blames what he calls the tyranny of Left Bank intellectuals for the introspection of much French creativity.
"And it's not just in literature," he said. "It's the same in theater, cinema, whatever. It's more important to study your bellybutton, even though no one understands what you're saying, than it is to entertain. Any book that does well is by definition an intellectual sellout because the broad mass of the public is by definition stupid."
Jean-Marie Domenach, a sociologist and essayist, echoed this view in a recent book, "The Twilight of French Culture?" Claiming to speak for a "silent majority" of readers who found contemporary French fiction "boring," he argued that, instead of democratizing culture, Government spending on the arts had strengthened a privileged elite.
"A chasm separates artistic creation from much of the public," he said, "because a tiny group of 'intellocrats' decides what is good or bad." French book reviewers, who often favor the obscure over the readable, duly poured scorn on Mr. Domenach's thesis.
 
Film and TV
 
Fear and Loathing Of Americanization
One problem is that many French intellectuals view mass entertainment as synonymous with Americanization of French society, with the triumph of the vulgar over the sophisticated. They therefore applaud the Government for trying to limit the impact of American popular culture by applying quotas that insure an audience for French movies, television dramas and popular songs.
At present, 50 percent of movies and television fiction broadcast by France's five television channels must be French. And under a new law that went into effect this year, French songs must account for 40 percent of popular music broadcast by French radio stations between 6:30 A.M. and 10:30 P.M. each day.
The crucial question, of course, is whether protectionism stimulates creativity or only perpetuates mediocrity? In the case of television, the quota system seems designed mainly to protect jobs, because French television soap operas are no better or worse than their American counterparts. But this situation is also the fault of intellectuals. Unlike "serious" playwrights and theater directors in Britain who often work in television, their French counterparts would not lower themselves to do so. And if the music quota is to work, it has a long way to go. France's biggest pop star is still Johnny Halliday, who began his career 30 years ago as the French Elvis Presley.
Most critical, perhaps, French cinema still lives in the past. It showed the way with the New Wave movement of the 1960's, when the likes of Francois Truffaut, Jean-Luc Godard (a Swiss who worked in France) and Claude Chabrol were acclaimed as daring innovators. But their main legacy in France was to define cinema as art, not entertainment, and to enshrine directors as "auteurs" who have first and last word over the final product. As a result, the industry is forever dreaming that a new New Wave will suddenly appear to breathe life into French movies. But it has not happened.
Instead, while the Government and, by law, French television companies pour money into the industry through subsidies and investment, French cinema's share of the domestic moviegoing audience has continued to slide, reaching just 35 percent in 1994. Both established and new directors of talent exist, but all too often they make films for their intellectual peers and not for the public at large.
"Too many young directors still think it's enough to have their film reviewed in Le Monde and be seen by 300 people," said Josiane Balasko, an actress and director whose latest comedy, "French Twist," just opened in New York.
But it is also risky to be different. For his second film, "Hate," Mathieu Kassovitz looked at the social tensions tearing at immigrant-filled Paris suburbs. The movie was well received at last year's Cannes Film Festival, but critics began sniping at it after it did well at the box office. And Luc Besson's sin was to make his last film, "The Professional," in English -- and still to insist it was a French movie. Jean-Marie Poire, though, has given up worrying about critics. His recent comedies, "Les Visiteurs" and "Guardian Angels," are among France's most successful postwar movies.
Will French artists and creators ever bridge the gap between elitist culture and popular entertainment? Can French novelists, playwrights and movie directors learn to tell stories instead of just philosophizing? Can they break free from their nostalgia for a past when the world bowed before "la culture francaise"?
"All I know is that no matter how much it spends, the Government can't order creativity," said Mr. Rigaud, the author of "The Cultural Exception." But the Mexican writer Carlos Fuentes, who knows France well, did offer a solution. "What France needs is an anti-Cartesian revolution to revive dreams and imagination," he said. "It's that simple."

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Why Reality Will Never Compute

BYLINE: By Sidney Lumet; The director Sidney Lumet has recently finished shooting "Night Falls on Manhattan," his 38th film, in New York City.

 BODY:
IN A RECENT ARTICLE IN THE NEW YORK TIMES about the technological changes overtaking the movie business, the director George Lucas weighed in heavily in favor of digital film making. Computers, he said, make shooting films on location obsolete. Furthermore, "there's no esthetic advantage whatsoever" in shooting on location, he said. "The issue is economics."
It's very hard to disagree with George Lucas. For one thing, he is a brilliant movie maker. For another, he has been responsible for some of the greatest technological advances ever in movies. Lucas has done extraordinary work on everything from sound quality and projection in theaters to the creation of breathtaking films. I can see why he has arrived at his notion that technology can replace location. He is really interested in creating myth, and for that task, reality gets in the way. There is no use for it. 
 Generally, however, movies, including all of mine, have tried to use reality by pushing it or exploring it. Lucas goes in exactly the opposite direction, and through the creation of fantasy he may achieve the same goal. It all depends on the kind of movie one is making.
I don't think it's worth taking actors to Algeria simply to have them march through the desert. If you want sand, there's a desert in California. And certainly that kind of visual element can be provided through computer technology. But for me the single biggest difference between shooting on location and constructing a digital location with computers is the quality of the performance I get from the actors. Would anyone want to see a film in which New York City had been inserted via computers?
Clearly, actors on stage know they're in a theater. In a 1983 Broadway play called "K2," about two climbers stuck on a mountain, the actors could see the audience members in the front row. The mountain was made of Styrofoam, but the performances were great. Actors can adjust to a simulation of reality. In the theater, however, there are no intangibles.
In movie location work, it's the intangibles that make it exciting. By intangibles, I mean the unexpected.
I am not suggesting taking a camera to the corner of 42d Street and Broadway and waiting for two cars to crash. I mean simply that the things I love best about location shooting are the textures, the incidental qualities of a sound or of the weather, be it really cold or hot.
I've just finished shooting "Night Falls on Manhattan," my 38th film and the 29th film I've made on location in New York City. The environments in which I shoot have made a palpable difference in almost every one of my pictures. I love capturing the unrehearsed, the unplanned, what I like to call the hot take, where that click happens inside the actor and he goes off into a dimension he didn't expect, one I didn't expect, one the writer didn't expect.
Obviously, a hot take can happen on a studio set, and it might happen on the kind of set Lucas is talking about -- where everything except the actor is manufactured by computers. But in my experience, a hot take often happens because we are on location; real-life detail stimulates that click.
In my film "Serpico," on the first day of shooting, Al Pacino had a scene in which he was arresting a guy who was dropping off a bribe. We shot it at the meat market on 14th Street and Ninth Avenue. There is a very tiny version of the Flatiron Building there, about four stories high. One reason I picked the location was that the building was painted red.
Pacino was dressed as a meat worker, in hard hat, bloody white apron and boots. When he looked at that building, he turned to me and said something remarkable: "It's an important scene, isn't it?" He understood why I picked that particular place, and I know it made a difference in his performance. That kind of connection happens over and over again when you're on location.
Locations are characters in my movies. It's one reason I shoot in New York. The city itself -- with its hills, its rivers, its architecture -- is character-rich just geographically. The city is capable of portraying the mood a scene requires. Location reinforces and expands what the actor is doing.
In "Night Falls on Manhattan," there's a scene in which Andy Garcia makes a phone call to his girlfriend after a horrendous night of walking the streets of the city alone and in distress. In the frame of the shot (we used a very long lens, 150-millimeter, I think), all you see is Garcia leaning his head on the phone, and behind him, the columns of the United States Court House. What Garcia's character is wrestling with is a moral question about the justice system. It's subtle. I don't want it to jump out at anybody, but there it is. It reminds you, on an unconscious level, what is causing his pain.
The sounds and textures of the city account for everything I look for. I know Lucas would say: "Sidney, we can design all of this. Why go and look for that red building, when all you have to do is tell me, 'Here is the kind of building I want'? We'll supply you with the building."
But here's the philosophical difference. I'm older than Lucas -- I am 71, he is 51 -- and I remember when science was promising us everything. When Kubrick's "2001" came out, it did not seem at all impossible that by the year 2001 those spaceships would actually be flying around. Kubrick chose to use the logo of Pan Am, the most successful airline of its time, on the Earth-to-Moon shuttle. And look. It's 1996, and Pan Am doesn't even have a building anymore, much less a plane. Science, you see, has continually failed us.
We keep winding up with the worst of science. Atomic energy was supposed to liberate us, and now we don't even know where to bury the waste that atomic energy has produced. As we advance medically, we are discovering that some germs have become immune to antibiotics. We have cured old problems only to find that we have created new ones. So I don't quite have faith that the scientific world will solve human problems.
I suspect that digitally creating a location background separately from the actors may have an impact on their work. I'm talking about the difference between good acting and inspired acting. I think you will always have good acting, because the general level of American acting is extremely high. But going for that inspired moment, you need everything to contribute to the fortunate accident that makes for exceptional work. For that, a real place, if you're doing a realistic piece, is absolutely necessary.
Once, I did a film that used computer-generated images throughout a 90-second title sequence. A wonderful technician did it for me, a great artist. However, it wasn't creatively satisfying. It looked good, and it was almost what I had in mind. But it wasn't completely what I had in mind. And that's a big difference.
Tom Pollack of MCA said, in the same article, that digital technology "will eventually become the way almost all movies are made." And he added, "You will be able to create just about all of your backgrounds on a computer."
Not mine. I want to start with my own imagination, or a photograph. The problem is that we are willing to pay more for a replication of reality than we are for reality itself.
MUSEUM DIORAMAS, which were popular at the turn of the century, became popular because people thought they were getting the real thing. But I don't think anyone's heart has ever leapt at a diorama of the African veldt as it has at footage of the real African veldt.
In a way, method acting is a geographical construct as well as an intellectual construct. But then I'm a realistic director, and who says that realism is the only way to make movies? As George Lucas has proved over and over, fantasy films not only are more popular than reality-based films, they also have higher grosses.
On the other hand, I would love to ask Lucas if he thinks that "American Graffiti," a superb American film, would have been the same movie if he had done it with digital backgrounds.
My feeling is no.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Al Pacino, right, and Biff McGuire walking the streets of New York City in "Serpico"--Exploring reality. (Paramount)

HEADLINE: Giving Home Buying a Lift in Urban Neighborhoods

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
AFTER shopping for a house almost every day for a year, Genevieve Wilkins found just the thing in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn -- a three-family brick and frame house on Claremont Avenue that a bank was selling out of foreclosure for $145,000.
But she had a problem. She had saved enough for the down payment, but not enough to manage the additional closing costs of $12,000, covering legal fees, title search, the bank's mortgage-lending fee, and the mortgage transfer tax. 
 What rescued the situation was a closing-cost loan program developed by Bankers Trust Company and Neighborhood Housing Services of New York City, which is part of a national network of nonprofit housing companies that assist homeowners and home buyers in low- and moderate-income neighborhoods. Income-eligible buyers are offered up to $15,000 in a 10-year loan, currently available at 8 percent interest, to help meet their closing costs.
"I only needed $12,000," said Ms. Wilkins, a 27-year-old art director at a graphic design company, who also made a down payment of 5 percent of the purchase price to buy the house. "I was excited when I found out I could borrow it."
The closing-cost loan program is only one of several approaches taken by Neighborhood Housing Services to help low- and moderate-income households both in buying houses and in keeping and maintaining them through the vicissitudes of ownership. To hear its staff members tell it, financial help is not the whole story. People need guidance, and encouragement, too.
"Many people get themselves overextended," said Harriet Lee, director of homeownership programs at the Jamaica, Queens, office of Neighborhood Housing Services. "Foreclosure becomes a big issue with seniors. Some people have been suckered into high-interest loans for home repairs and then they can't service the loans."
The diverse educational and training activities undertaken by Neighborhood Housing Services underscore the fact that availability of mortgage credit is not the only requisite of strengthening home ownership in older urban neighborhoods.
"In 1995 and 1996 for the first time we have had a large amount of mortgage-lending capacity available," said William A. Whiteside, the publisher of Creative Interfaces, a monthly newsletter in Washington aimed at nonprofit development companies and their corporate and banking supporters. "Now we have to focus resources on buyer education. You cannot assume people will be terrific home owners."
Accordingly, N.H.S. offers home maintenance training and guidance as well as home buying counseling. It assists people in hiring contractors for repairs, and offers repair and rehabilitation loans. It acts as an intermediary in dealing with banks and public agencies. It also has a development arm that rehabilitates and resells vacant buildings. In addition to its neighborhood offices, a central homeownership center opened last July. It is in a ground-floor space of the Dime Savings Bank of New York branch at 380 Flatbush Avenue Extension in downtown Brooklyn (718-797-5799).
In its role as intermediary for homebuyers seeking mortgage financing, it participated in generating 270 purchase loans totaling $35 million last year. That was twice the number of loans it generated in the two preceding years combined. The typical beneficiaries are people with household earnings of $40,000 to $60,000 a year.
One key role it plays is helping people in straightening out their credit problems. A shaky credit history has been a major barrier to home ownership in moderate-income locations.
The closing-cost loans come from a pool of funds assembled by Bankers Trust from 15 wholesale and foreign banks not generally involved in community lending but nevertheless obliged to meet community lending requirements under the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977. The act is aimed at making credit more widely available in low- and moderate-income areas.
Available since 1994, these unsecured loans have so far reached 75 home buyers in New York City, said Gary Hattem, who heads the bank's community development group. After an initial test of the program, the pool of funds available for these loans has been increased to $2.5 million.
The loans have averaged $8,500, and are available to borrowers who accept mortgage counseling through N.H.S. or some other approved mortgage counseling agency. Current terms provide that buyers' income may range up to 165 percent of median income in the metropolitan area, so that a family of four earning as much as $70,000 a year would be eligible. Most of the loans are generated through one of the field offices of N.H.S, which are in Bedford-Stuyvesant and East Flatbush in Brooklyn; Jamaica and Corona in Queens; Wakefield in the Bronx, and West Brighton in Staten Island.
F IELD offices run by nonprofits have taken a growing role in channeling mortgage credit into urban neighborhoods. "Local people often feel intimidated about walking into banks," said Phyllis Rosenbloom, senior vice president of the New York Mortgage Coalition, a consortium of 14 banks that also works through community-based nonprofits. The coalition last year originated 350 loans totaling $53 million for metropolitan-area home purchases.
But the availability of mortage credit is no longer the chief issue inhibiting urban home buying, said George Knight, executive director of the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation in Washington, the Federally chartered umbrella organization for Neighborhood Housing Services.
"It's 'How do I get to closing,' " he said. "People are very lendable on a post-closing basis." Among buyers who have closed, he said, 76 percent have been found to be paying under 30 percent of their gross annual income for housing, a widely accepted standard of housing affordability.
Dealing with the practical issues of "getting to closing" and of ownership itself have become the specialty of the New York City Neighborhood Housing Services offices. Over the last 15 years it has helped about 45,000 families with a great diversity of homeownership issues, said Francine C. Justa, the organization's executive director.
Trying to let people know that these services exist has been a problem for N.H.S., which does not have an advertising budget, Dr. Justa said. Another problem is inadequate funding for hiring people who speak the language of many potential clients, especially Chinese and Indian dialects.
At the Bedford-Stuyvesant office, Byron Todman, a housing counselor, said homeowner insurance has been the main problem for several new purchasers. They bought houses with only a one-year insurance commitment, issued by a broker, and then found they were rejected for a renewal after an inspection by an insurance underwriter.
In Jamaica, Ms. Lee told of one homeowner, a retired postal worker caring for her daughter and a 15-year-old grandson, who found herself struggling to pay off three mortgages totaling $1,225 a month on a fixed income, after some expensive borrowing four years ago to make home repairs. Using a funding company rather than a bank, she now owes $77,000 at 18.9 percent interest.
For Eric and Mabel Dundas, retired homeowners at 377 Linden Boulevard in Flatbush, the practical problem turned out to be borrowing $8,000 at moderate cost to renovate an attic bathroom and repair two ceilings and a front porch. Neighborhood Housing Services has a rehabilitation loan program that lent them the money.
And for Arthur Alfredsen, 35, the manager of an electrical-supply warehouse, the practical problem was finding money for the down payment when he had to move from a rental apartment in a three-family house in East New York that the owner was selling. He got the loan from N.H.S. and much advice as well. Now he lives in a two-family house on 102d Avenue in the Ozone Park section of Queens, with a wheelchair-bound mother, his sister and her baby, and his brother and his brother's son.
"People should know about these programs," he said. "They're great!" He may still need them. "I just got a water bill for $500," Mr. Alfredsen said. "We got a pool as a gift last summer. Who knew we were going to have to pay so much for water?"

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A New Attraction for the Six Flags Neighborhood

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FOR the last 25 years the owner of a 55-acre wooded site in the northwestern corner of Jackson Township in Ocean County had let its property lie fallow while considering its best use.
It reached its decision last year and in November ground was broken on the 200,000-square-foot first phase of what ultimately will be a 300,000-square-foot factory-outlet center on the site. It is at the juncture of Interstate 195 and Route 537, less than a mile from Exit 7A of the New Jersey Turnpike and from Six Flags Great Adventure Theme Park. 
 The center, estimated to cost $22 million, is being developed by the site's owner since 1971, New Plan Realty Trust. The Manhattan-based company, among the oldest and largest real estate investment trusts, or REITs, owns five other factory-outlets in the nation and 116 shopping centers, including four in New Jersey. (A real estate investment trust is an entity that invests in real estate but pays out most of its earnings as dividends to shareholders.)
A difference with the Jackson project is New Plan's joint marketing and promotional agreement with Six Flags, which allows, among other things the use of the amusement company's name for the outlet center. Six Flags Theme Parks, based in Parsippany and a subsidiary of Time Warner Entertainment, owns and operates 11 parks across the nation. The largest is the one in Jackson, comprising a 125-acre theme park, a 350-acre drive-through animal park and 1,500 undeveloped acres. (Last year Time Warner sold 51 percent of Six Flags to Boston Ventures, but has the right to buy it back in the future.)
Six Flags Factory Outlets Center, designed in a village-like setting, will have about 90 stores, with an average of 3,000 square feet of space. Ninety percent of the stores are to be factory outlets; the rest will be retailers selling goods at outlet prices, generally 20 to 70 percent lower than conventional retail prices.
There will also be a 12,000-square-foot food court and 1,800 parking spaces. Six Flags will run the food court and a free shuttle between the center and the park, now open from April to October.
The 200,000-square-foot first phase, with 55 to 60 stores, is to open by late summer. The hope is the entire project will be completed by the spring of 1997, said Arnold Laubich, New Plan's president. The project will be financed by company funds.
The project is proceeding at a time when many retailers in New Jersey and the nation are suffering. Contributing to their woes are a highly competitive retail climate, lackluster sales capped by an anemic holiday season and an uncertain economy pressuring consumers to spend less and save more, industry analysts said.
Ted Kraus, who heads TKO, a Mercerville real-estate advisory firm, called 1995 "one of the worst retail years." Though the state's store vacancy rate was just under 5 percent, virtually unchanged from the year before, he said, sales were generally down in every market segment, including outlets.
"Consumers are looking for more value," said Mr. Kraus, adding that "all retailers" today were responding to that demand.
Despite the competition factory outlets continue to grow. Nationwide, there are some 12,000 outlet stores today, up from 5,758 in 1990, according to Retail Value News, a trade journal.
Twenty-three outlet centers opened in 1995, bringing the total to 334, up from 183 in 1990. New Plan entered the outlet sector in 1992 and since then has acquired five centers. About two years ago, Mr. Laubich said, his company felt an outlet "was the highest and best use" for the Jackson site.
T HERE are other factory outlets in New Jersey, including long-established ones in the Secaucus Meadowlands and Flemington as well as one under construction in Elizabeth. The Freehold Raceway Mall is also less than 10 miles away.
Even so the Jackson site's location is "a natural" said Mr. Laubich, emphasizing three points -- it is accessible to major highways, including the Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway; more than 5 million people live within a 40-mile radius and it is close to Six Flags.
Last year the park drew just over 4 million people, making it the top-attendance seasonal park in North America, according to Amusement Business, a trade journal.
Analysts say marriages between outlets and tourist attractions have proven mutually beneficial. Officials at New Plan and Six Flags are optimistic theirs will be, too.
In recent years, Time Warner has invested heavily in the 11 parks in the chain, including some $100 million in the Jackson park.
That helped reposition the park, which had gained a reputation as a destination for teens, to one for families.
The company is now "looking to create a regional destination," said Scott W. Bernstein, president of Six Flags. "The issue for us is to offer a mass of entertainment." He added that the center "will give people another reason to come and to keep them here more than one day."
"It also makes it more feasible for us to extend our season," he said, noting that a Christmas season promotion was to be added this year. Mr. Bernstein said plans also were expected to be announced this spring for developing a good part of the park's undeveloped acres. Beyond adding more attractions, plans also include hotel rooms.
The outlet project is good news for Jackson, as is the expansion of Six Flags. Over the years the 101-square-mile township has been among the fastest-growing municipalities in Ocean County, itself a growth area. From 1980 to 1990 alone Jackson's population grew by 29.6 percent, from 25,644 to 33,233. But commercial development has been limited.
"The desire is to attract clean, commercial growth to offset taxes and not impact on municipal services," said Mayor Peter H. Carlson of Jackson.
U NDER its 1988 master plan the township -- half of which lies within the 1.1-million-acre Pinelands region, where the state limits building -- targeted much of that growth along the I-195 corridor.
The outlet center and the Six Flags projects help meet that goal, said Mayor Carlson, noting that the outlet center when completed was expected to generate $500,000 in taxes annually. They will also "have a domino effect" on future development in the area, he said.
Further stoking that effort is a new sewer line connecting Six Flags to the Ocean County Utilities Authority sewage-treatment plant in Brick, replacing an existing sewage plant at the park. This opens up development along portions of the corridor and enable the park to expand.
The Jackson Township Municipal Utility Authority will sell bonds to finance the more than $10 million project, construction of which is to begin this summer. Six Flags will guarantee the bonds.
Though the center will not tie into the new line, New Plan will develop a septic system to serve the project. It will also make the necessary road improvements, including adding a turning lane to the center's main entrance along Route 537.
Mr. Laubich said negotiations were under way with tenants for the initial 200,000 square feet of stores. At opening, close to 90 percent of the space will be filled, he said.
New Plan would not comment on prospective tenants, but industry brokers say they include Tommy Hilfigger, Oshkosh B'Gosh, Mikasa, Lenox, Guess Jeans and Nautica.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
They Can Take Him Off the Arena . . .

BYLINE: By JIM FLORIO; Jim Florio, the former Governor, is a member of the law firm Florio & Perrucci.

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY'S Open for Business," goes our state's unofficial slogan. To which you now can add this correlative: "And everything is up for sale if the price is right, including civility."
One hopes that those who had a part in the recent decision to rename the arena in the Meadowlands (the right price, in this case, was $29 million) at least have the good grace to be somewhat embarrassed by an action that is, at best, insensitive and tacky. 
 Under the prevailing social ethic, the argument for the name change is obvious, I suppose. If former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne had more cash or airplane tickets to offer than Continental Airlines, his name rather than theirs might still be on the arena. In New Jersey these days, life is an auction.
As distasteful as this whole episode has been, making New Jersey look crass and disrespectful, its major importance is as an example of a larger national trend. We as a society are conferring an almost religious significance on the operation of the marketplace.
Most of us accept the premise of our free-enterprise system that in economic matters, the marketplace is the best allocator of resources and determiner of price. But in the era of the Contract With America, commercialism has begun to frame our values as well.
It has long been a unifying American value that government has a responsibility to insure a common degree of environmental protection, educational opportunity and health-care coverage to all, regardless of purchasing power. That does not appear to carry much weight anymore. We are all on our own, to do the best we can with the resources we have, and whoever has the cash calls the tune.
Most people would agree that in order to have a good society, we must have a good economy. It is becoming apparent, however, that it is possible to have a good economy without having a good society. Forty thousand AT&T employees can testify that high productivity and increased profits do not guarantee good social outcomes.
When all is said and done, Governor Byrne has the very real satisfaction of knowing that his many accomplishments, like preserving the Pinelands and providing for greater equity in education financing, will long be admired and appreciated. The behavior of those who presided over the arena decision only serves to point up the contrast between their values and his own.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Who Builds What, How Fast: The Coming Land-Use Debate

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Virtually all the state's 567 cities and towns have zoning boards and planning boards, whose volunteer members pore over plans for everything from side yards to streetscapes, patio decks to shopping centers. But soon these boards may find their roles greatly reduced.
In recent months, there has been increasing talk about rewriting the state's land-use law, which has governed the powers of local planning and zoning boards since 1976. Many planners defend the law, saying it provides a necessary framework for citizens to plan their communities. But developers and others say the process is often far too cumbersome. A measure to revise the law is expected to be introduced in the next few months of the new Legislature's term. 
 "It's an extremely important debate," said Peter A. Buchsbaum, a lawyer in Woodbridge who specializes in land-use law. "We have a very complicated process that doesn't really work and needs to be straightened out."
But preliminary ideas have been controversial. Last year, builders' groups drafted a proposal calling for the establishment of a new position in each municipality: a land-use review official who would ride herd on the zoning and planning boards to speed the approval or denial of permits. The proposal also called for a simpler appeals process, and conditions under which some permits could be approved automatically.
Planners attacked the proposal as a dangerous shortcut that would undermine the authority of local citizens. "It will take away some of the control municipalities have over their own land use and put it in the hands of the state," said Susan Borg, the planning director of West Orange, which has a strong tradition of public participation. "It is taking away the process that citizens have to express their feelings about their town: how they see it, how they want it."
To preview the debate, an advocate on each side was asked to discuss it.

Peter S. Reinhart
President of the New Jersey Builders Association and senior vice president of K. Hovnanian Enterprises, a leading residential builder.
 
Q. Why a need for land-use reform?
A. Since 1975, there has been a plethora of additional permits and approvals required at other levels of government. So we have this whole system now, just layer upon layer of permits required from various state agencies, county agencies, regional entities, in addition to the municipal approvals.
Q. What are some typical difficulties?
A. Let's say you want to do a residential subdivision. All the aspects are reviewed at the local level; that includes zoning, drainage, sewer, streets, lighting, landscaping, water, other utilities, sidewalks, all the things you can see above and below the ground. In New Jersey, the average time from start to finish is about three years; in other states, it's generally a matter of months. This has an impact on quality of life: our cost of living is higher, our property taxes are higher, and you have to pay higher wages, which makes New Jersey less competitive.
Q. What changes would you suggest?
A. We need to reduce or eliminate the number of levels of bureaucracy; we don't need five engineers for what one engineer can do. You can put the reviewing burden on a competent, licensed professional, make sure that person has the education and the skills and the training.
Part of the confusion is that people see reviewing site-plan applications as planning; to me, that's reviewing. Planning is deciding what the future of your town or your county or your state should look like, and planning for the development and the land uses and the intensity and density you want. If an application conforms to all of those, then a technical review doesn't need to be done other than by technical people.
 
Joseph E. Doyle
Executive director of New Jersey Planning Officials, in Warren Township.
 
Q. What's your take on the land-use law?
A. I think the municipal land-use law has been serving as a model set of legislation for municipalities to balance the interests of developers and residents. Municipal review is a healthy, economic factor in that it allows for a good, substantial look at something in its proposed stage as it may affect a municipality for time immemorial. A mistake along the way is costly to market values and the character of the municipality.
Q. Is there any legitimacy to the developers' arguments for reform?
A. A lot of factors go into the costs of development. It's the rising cost of land, interest rates, manpower that are contributing to the house prices -- not land-use regulations. I think the developers are making a grand grab at all regulations in the name of their interests, which are narrow and focused.
As far as state permits go, yes, I agree the process can take a long time. There's nothing worse than approving a development and seeing it sit there. Things should be expedited, but don't exclude participation by the public.
Q. What do you think should be done instead?
A. The current system is best. I think every redundant permit should be scrutinized. But let's not go out and scrap the whole thing; let's not throw out regulation. You see thousands of decisions made by these planning and zoning boards every year, and they conduct hearings at least once a month.
Don't you think that if the process was such a screaming factor of abuse, the newspapers would've caught onto this long ago? My argument is that the developers are trying to tamper with the local planning process and have not proven that the process has to be reworked.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The system of land-use regulation "makes New Jersey less competitive," says Peter S. Reinhart, above. Joseph E. Doyle calls it a "model." (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
No More Help With Bags At Amtrak's Trenton Station

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Baggage service for Amtrak passengers at Trenton ended last week. Amtrak says the elimination of service is an economic necessity, born of a huge cut in its Federal subsidy, from $392 million last year to $185 million this year. Other cuts have been felt as well: cuts in management jobs, delays in computer purchases, delays in graffiti removal, increases in some fares.
In Trenton, baggage service was generating only about $4,000 a year in fees -- with each of the station's three handlers toting an average of six bags a day, at a cost of $141,000 a year in salaries and benefits, the company said. The handlers won't be out of a job; each is high on the seniority chain. But three junior employees are out of luck. 
 With Trenton out of the picture, only 27 of the 100 or so stations in Amtrak's Northeast region will have baggage service. The nearest stations with such service are Philadelphia and Newark. DAVID W. CHEN

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
Are Layoffs the Only Way?

 BODY:
Dozens of New Jersey employers, most recently AT&T, have said that laying off workers is the only way they can survive. Is there a better way?
 
With Workers Gone, Who'll Be Able to Buy?
The rationale is quite clear. Get rid of the older employees who are making more money and replace them with minimum-wage fodder. 
 Don't spoil the new ones with such nonessentials as pensions, health benefits orjob security.
The stockholders get richer, and the Governor claims new jobs more than compensate for the losses.
But what do the new jobs pay?
When the dust settles and Wall Street has made money, who will be left to buy the houses, vacations, restaurant meals, cars and other consumer goods?
 
JEAN BURNETT
Forked River
 
Profits Come First, And We Pay the Price
When employers like AT&T say the only way they can survive is to lay off workers, they really mean that laying off workers is the easiest way to maximize profits for their investors.
As long as our nation puts profits ahead of people, we will continue to waste human productivity and creativity, poison our environment, retard the development of our children and shorten the life spans of millions of citizens.
Profits should be limited by progressive income or corporate taxes. Human needs should be the central objective of both government and economic system.
 
MEREDITH SUE WILLIS
South Orange
 
A Plan of Attack: Dropped? Then Drop Them
I have been doing a lot of reading about the current phenomenon of corporate downsizing. I am convinced that these corporations will pay dearly in the future for the actions they are taking to satisfy the vultures of Wall Street.
What these companies are doing is firing their customers. AT&T just announced it is firing 40,000 workers. It's too bad the average employee has little retaliatory power, but one thing these folks can do is immediately switch to MCI or Sprint. AT&T would lose 40,000 accounts in one fell swoop.
It may not be much, but if everyone who is laid off from any company immediately switches loyalty, upper management may get a message.
One question that bothers me about the AT&T affair is: If there are actually 40,000 excess employees, what does that say about past practices of the top managers who are doing the firing?
Not much.
 
BRUCE LONG
Westfield

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
She Gave the Speech, But Where Was She?

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
January is time for the Governor to deliver the annual self-congratulatory look back known as the State of the State message.
Here are a few excerpts:
* "New Jersey's economy bounced back from the recession with more strength and resilience than did the economies of most other states in the region or in the nation." 
 * "More New Jerseyans are employed today than at any other time in our state's history."
* "We now stand ready to launch a major, comprehensive initiative to improve the plight of urban schools."
These lines may have been ghostwritten at the same Emile Coue school of perpetual improvement that Governor Whitman (and governors everywhere) employs, but she never uttered them. Thomas H. Kean spoke those words in 1984, the last time a Republican governor stood at midpoint in his first term.
It will surprise no one that Mrs. Whitman said many of the same things in her annual message on Thursday, about how we're all doing better, and we're going to help those city kids some day. Yet the real story is not about how little things change around here, but how much.
For besides looking proudly back, Mr. Kean was able to talk about new programs and initiatives. He announced that the Port Authority would share some of its hoard with New York and New Jersey, notably by providing the seed money for the renewal of Newark's Passaic River waterfront, which has since grown into a magnet for commercial development filled by ex-New Yorkers.
He announced legislation to promote urban development by essentially forgoing the sales tax within the zones. (This is now costing the state $78 million a year.)
And he made his now-famous statement that New Jersey teachers should be paid at least $18,500 a year, and pledged the state to pay the difference between current salaries and the new minimum.
Mrs. Whitman devoted all of last week's speech to education, and to her administration's program to spell out, once and for all, what constitutes a constitutionally valid "thorough and efficient education" for New Jersey's one million schoolchildren.
But the similarity to her Republican predecessor ends there. Where Mr. Kean -- and James J. Florio after him -- spoke of spending money, particularly for schools, Mrs. Whitman's speech was anti-money: "Money alone does not equal learning." "A great deal more goes into successful education than an expensive spending program." And the rhyming bugle call no speech is complete without: "We must stop chasing dollars and start creating scholars."
So the language of tax cutting for New Jerseyans has turned out to be a little like the language of love, starting out with promises of rapture and ending with platitudes.
Well, this is what a lot of New Jerseyans wanted, after all. The Governor's reason for putting state government on a forced diet of tax cuts was to wean the state from its old taste for Santa in January, for annual messages and annual budgets that spent more and promised more than the one before.
The question is: Is this what people are going to want, a pudding with no theme, an administration full of "shoulds" but no "shalls"? There are plenty of signs that the legislators may be of a different mind. In his own annual address, Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Senate President and future candidate for governor, said he would make another kind of tax cut his goal for the year: letting homeowners deduct property taxes when they file their state income tax returns. The state cannot afford to let that happen, but once you start cutting taxes, its hard to say when.
And Jack Collins, the new Speaker of the Assembly, has already brought some of his South Jersey independence to the State House, signaling his opposition to the Governor's proposed cigarette tax increase and otherwise acting like someone who is happy just representing Elmer, N.J., and who doesn't sit by the phone waiting for the Governor to call.
Except for the part where she thanked the snow emergency crews, neither of these leaders heard much from Mrs. Whitman to justify the clapping on Thursday. What was missing was the voice of the Governor talking about herself, what she believed and stood for besides disapproving of wasteful spending.
When Jim Florio tried his hand at solving the problems of urban schools, his Education Department came up with Quality Education Act, but it was Mr. Florio who stood up and made the speech -- and paid the price of outraged suburbanites who did not want to see their state aid shifted to the poor districts.
Mr. Florio's identification with the Q.E.A. helped him lose his job, and Mrs. Whitman seems to have noticed. When the time comes to reveal her administration's plan, she suggested, she would be somewhere else.
"After Education Commissioner Klagholz makes his formal recommendations next month, the board will hold public hearings before finalizing them," she said.
It was the key paragraph of her speech, but she was not in it.

HEADLINE: It's a Long Trip to the Orchestra Pit

BYLINE: By ROBIN F. DEMATTIA 

 BODY:
THEY go to more Broadway shows each year than just about anyone else, yet they never get to see what is happening on stage. They are the Broadway musicians, and their view from the orchestra pit gives them an interesting perspective.
"A lot of people think we have it made because we are in the pit and nobody sees us," says a Stamford resident, Bob Zottola, who has been part of the orchestra for "Les Miserables" for nine years. "But the on-stage performers have an advantage because they communicate with the audience and the audience responds. We still have to come up with an enthusiastic performance and we don't have that response." 
 For Mr. Zottola, the challenge is to play the same music eight or nine times a week, year in and year out, and to do so with enthusiasm. He tries to find inspiration from the impact the show has on people.
"I help provide a musical service that brings a tremendous amount of pleasure to people," Mr. Zottola said. "With 'Les Miserables,' people have been back to see the show 60 times. I find that incredible. They're like Trekkies. They compare the performers in the different roles.
"Other people come for the first time," he continued, "and they're crying and sobbing. They're so overwhelmed by the performances and you know you're a part of it, whether or not they acknowledge you."
Unlike the actors and actresses who thrive on the exposure Broadway can give them, musicians seek pit work because it can provide a steady paycheck.
"Since work for musicians is pretty scarce, everyone who works is really happy," said Yuval Waldman of Westport. Though he had not worked on Broadway for 20 years, he returned as concertmaster (first violinist) with "Showboat" last year.
"It's different today than it was years ago," he said, "because the pay scale is quite high, and so the orchestra can get very good quality musicians." Broadway musicians earn an average of $1,000 to $1,500 a week. Mr. Waldman said he was also enticed by the current musician's union contract, which allows Broadway musicians to take off up to 50 percent of the time. "You get freedom and security, which is what a lot of people are looking for," he said.
With that type of flexibility, most Broadway musicians also work in symphony orchestras, teach music or have their own bands.
Mr. Zottola performs weekly in a jazz group and takes part in recording sessions for singers, commercials and films. It is that variety that helps him enjoy staying with one show for nine years.
"Part and parcel of being a musician, or any creative person," he said, "is that you always want to be improving, changing, fixing or enhancing. You need to be looking at other challenging opportunities to keep yourself fresh. Plus, Broadway musicians know that a show doesn't run forever, so you always have to be doing other things."
Mr. Waldman has toured the world as a violin soloist and conducted several groups, including the Mid-Atlantic Chamber Orchestra in Washington, D.C.
Joseph Russo, of Weston, who played string bass in several Broadway shows and still performs with symphonies, works as a contractor, helping place other musicians in shows. And because regular musicians can take off so much time, many musicians work as substitutes on the shows.
"I'm open 24 hours a day," laughs Phil Bashor of Darien, who substitutes on "Showboat" and plays with several choral groups. "Sometimes you get a call at 11:30 at night for a 10 A.M. rehearsal. You always have to be 100 percent in shape and ready to work."
Mr. Bashor says substituting is a tough job, because the regular musicians have the music memorized and the person substituting has to fit in with them. If the substitution is planned, the new player usually sits in the pit observing the person they are going to replace. Then they rehearse alone at home.
But often this does not prepare them for timing changes or other unforeseen developments. Mr. Russo's wife, Susan, recalled her first performance as a substitute. "I practiced so hard for two weeks that I even knew the dialogue," she says of her preparation work for "Phantom of the Opera." "Then right before the downbeat, the conductor stood up and said 'Mr. Webber is in the audience.' I was so nervous."
Getting work as a musician on Broadway, either as a regular or as a substitute, is not easy. As is the case with many job searches, it is often knowing someone that counts. "The whole business is set up on a referral and networking basis," Mr. Russo said. "But often musicians go on the road first to break in."
That's exactly what Mary Stephenson of Greenwich is doing. In July she joined the Raoul Company for a one-year national tour with "Phantom of the Opera." She moves every six to nine weeks, recently having left California for Arizona.
"In a way I am paying my dues to get to a goal," she explained. "I'm very thankful for this job. I was waiting for a break like this."
Ms. Stephenson has done orchestral work and taught music, but is finding that living in Connecticut makes it a little difficult to obtain work in New York City. "To get in the door, it helps to have the right address," she said, adding that life as a musician takes more skills than she learned at the Cleveland Institute of Music or CUNY at Brooklyn College.
"You have to be a jack of all trades," she said. "You're in business for yourself. You have to learn to how to market yourself, and you have to be your own secretary."
Connecticut musicians working on Broadway also have to adapt to the commute and hours that can be very odd indeed. Mr. Waldman admits to falling asleep on the train during late-night commutes home. "I got to know and like a New Haven cab driver well," he laughs.
Mr. Bashor says working on weekends makes him stand out among his neighbors, most of whom hold Monday through Friday jobs.
And Mr. Zottola uses the time to listen to music or books on tape as he drives in to Manhattan. Street parking near the theater is not a problem, he said, because the business people have left by the time he arrives. Most musicians travel lightly; their instruments and formal clothing are kept in lockers at the theaters.
There are some physical discomforts to watch out for in a Broadway pit: extreme cold or heat, noise from stomping and dancing on the stage floor, dust being kicked up, steam from fog machines flowing in, or loud music reverberating in the pit. A friend of Susan Russo's was hit, but not seriously injured, by a prop when it tumbled off the stage during "Into the Woods."
Despite these bits of excitement, life in the pit can verge on the boring for musicians in a long run. Because they usually cannot be seen, many read or work on crossword puzzles during down time. "You know the show after all these years, and it's not going to affect anything," Mr. Zottola explained.
Still, Mr. Waldman says: "It's really a challenge to keep your level of concentration. You cannot not pay attention. You have the danger of becoming too relaxed, because you think you know the show too well. But things happen on stage -- a curtain doesn't open or a new star changes the speed of something -- so you have to watch the conductor."
Closed-circuit television cameras in the pit help conductors watch all sections of the stage, and aid musicians who must turn away from the conductor to play certain instruments.
The excitement involved in live performances is what draws many audience members to Broadway, but many musicians are concerned about the future of their role.
"There is a movement going on to cut down the size of Broadway orchestras or eliminate them completely and use recorded music," explained Mr. Zottola. "Part of it is economics and part has to due with the new electronic instruments and recording devices available."
He says the idea did not make sense to him. "Things change; somebody decides to walk on-stage and they're off a couple of seconds. The conductor watches for this and makes those alterations," he said. "Can you imagine if a tape continued to play?"
Mr. Russo agreed with Mr. Zottola's assessment. "Gershwin would shiver in his boots if we said we were going to put 'Porgy and Bess' on tape," he said.
For now, at least, Broadway musicians will continue to enhance theatergoers' experiences. And every now and then, they may even get to see a show.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bob Zottola, of Stamford, warms up for yet another performance of "Les Miserables." (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1361 words

HEADLINE: Economy Is Seen As Slightly Stronger

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
RUNNING AGAINST THE WIND" was the song that callers heard last week while trying to telephone Local 1104 of the Communications Workers of America in Farmingdale.
"That's what it is these days," the president of the local, Robert P. Lilja, said. "Everybody has two, three, four jobs. Everybody in the family has to work. U-Haul is having trouble keeping up. Plenty of people are just walking away from their houses. And once they go, they can't ever afford to come back." 
 In an era of corporate downsizing, long-vanished military contracts, low-paying retail jobs and rising taxes and electric rates, many Long Islanders enter the second half of the 90's with fear and trepidation.
It is not that the economic news is all dismal. Indeed, as Long Island dug out last week from the blizzard that shut down a region of 2.6 million people, experts and economic analysts said the economy was in far better shape than in the early 90's.
The region's recession has ended, the experts said, and a modest recovery is afoot. "We still have a relatively strong economy," an economist, Thomas Conoscenti of Smithtown, said. Mr. Conoscenti predicted that the Long Island economy would grow 1.2 to 1.3 percent this year.
Office space, which until a few months ago was experiencing a glut, is gradually filling up, planners and developers said.
Vincent Polimeni, president of Polimeni Enterprises in Hauppauge, a builder of offices and shopping centers, said major developers had even found a way to overcome the reluctance of Long Island banks to finance expansion and improvements of commercial spaces.
"Wall Street has replaced the banks, as far as I am concerned," said Mr. Polimeni. He has turned to a method called securitization to raise capital, involving the packaging of loans by brokerage houses for sale in the bond market.
Another builder, Reckson Associates of Melville, has formed a real-estate investment trust to raise money directly from investors.
Despite reports of weak Christmas sales for retailers, county officials who depend on the tax receipts to hold down property taxes said they expected that revenues would exceed expectations. "If we look at 1995 as a whole, we were ahead of our projections," George Gatta, Deputy Suffolk County Executive for Economic Development, said. "And I see positive signs for 1996, because I work directly with companies that are expanding and growing and staying and investing right here on Long Island."
Some taxes, like the 8.5 percent sales tax in Suffolk, have decreased. The rate dropped to 8.25 percent on Jan. 1. And a tide of fiscal conservatism in Washington, Albany, Mineola and Hauppauge tells of politicians who are hearing cries for less spending and lower taxes.
For the fully employed and for investors whose stocks soared in a bull market, last year was far from harsh, and prospects looked bright.
"Long Island is still a marvelous place to live, if you are gainfully employed," said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
Yet Mr. Koppelman said a recent drive he took through Stony Brook showed economic distress. "There was not a block where I didn't see one, two or three 'for sale' signs," he said. "These are people who are losing their jobs and have to get rid of their homes."
For Local 1104 of the C.W.A., shaken by the announcement by AT&T about laying off 40,000 employees, a sense is growing that a stable job with good benefits is a rare commodity on Long Island. Mr. Lilja said the announcement had left 1,000 AT&T employees in Nassau and Suffolk waiting for the ax.
The four C.W.A. locals on the Island have a total of 6,000 members. Nynex, which has also been downsizing, employs most of those workers. Mr. Lilja said contracts for Nynex workers on Long Island signed in 1994 guaranteed jobs until September 1998.
The AT&T employees, Mr. Lilja said, were suffering most. "These people don't know their fate from one minute to the next," he said. "There is no loyalty to the people who gave their lives to this company. AT&T is only interested in the bottom line. They are the greatest corporate pigs we have ever encountered."
The company said the layoffs were necessary to keep it competitive as it split into three units. Mr. Lilja and others said the layoffs showed anew that even jobs that once seemed rock solid were on the block.
At the Long Island Lighting Company, a proposal by the Long Island Power Authority to break up the company among five or six owners has filled the more than 5,000 employees with apprehension, some employees have said in interviews.
The chairman of the authority, James F. Gill, has said jobs would be protected. Workers said many doubted that.
Nearly 20,000 Federal workers who live in Nassau or Suffolk have been facing hardship as the deadlock over the Federal budget closed many Government offices.
State figures show that the average Federal worker earns $750 a week, meaning that the furloughs disrupted a work force that pours more than $14.3 million into the regional economy. "The impact of those furloughs is going to slow us down," said Mr. Conoscenti.
In a winter that is just beginning, the costs of snow removal and lost commerce from severe storms also exact an economic price. But a more unsettling prospect, experts said, is a coming shakeout among retailers that would affect Long Island.
"It's coming as part of a national trend," Mr. Polimeni said. "In each major retail category there are now four or five major competitors, and there just aren't enough dollars to go around. The pie isn't getting any bigger either."
The growth in retail industries spurred an expansion of the service sector that partly made up for the loss of more than 100,000 manufacturing jobs over the past seven or eight years, mostly among military contractors.
Now, Mr. Koppelman and others said, too many major stores and high vacancy rates in shopping centers showed that the retail market had exceeded its limits. "We had this whole spate of new retail construction and we kept saying there is just so much disposal income," Mr. Koppelman said.
A result, he added, is the further decline of downtown shopping areas, new shopping centers without tenants and disappointment among retailers about lower-than-expected sales. "It's not that the economy is bad," he said. "It's that we overbuilt in the retail and commercial sector."
Mr. Koppelman said another crucial area of service industries, relatively high-paying banking and back-office jobs, had been diminished by consolidations and downsizings. "We were hoping to expand as a back-office headquarters," he said. "But these consolidations are often at the cost of massive layoffs."
"We certainly recognize that we are now in a structural transformation on Long Island and that we are facing a double whammy," Mr. Gatta said. "We have moved away from defense, and at the same time you have got businesses changing the way they do business. So we are facing those forces at the same time, which makes the challenges we face all the more difficult."
Mr. Gatta said the headlines about the AT&T layoffs had overshadowed news about job gains among small- to medium-size businesses that were to have been an economic core for Long Island.
Mr. Koppelman noted that more than 85 percent of jobs created on the Island over the last 30 years were with companies that began locally.
The Long Island Association has identified five industries -- biotechnology and bioengineering, electronics, graphic communications, medical imaging and health-care information and software -- as sources of nearly 28,300 new jobs over the next five years.
The business group is studying steps that would assist the industries as part of an overall initiative to boost the regional economy. Tax subsidies, public financing and lower electric rates are being discussed.
Critics of the plan said subsidies and other publicly financed aid had backfired in the past. The critics pointed to the extensive assistance for the Grumman Corporation, whose role on Log Island shrank dramatically after being acquired by Northrop.
