HEADLINE: GOOD EATING;
Cozy Ambiance In the West 70's

 BODY:

BERTHA'S ++
(212) 362-4955; 2160 Broadway, at 76th Street;  no credit cards
The big windows, comfortable couches, carved wood bar and butcher block tables make this cousin of Benny's downtown one of the more pleasant burrito restaurants in the city. Moreover, the tasty, gargantuan burritos here remain a popular and economical way to eat. The selection includes the "mission," a soft tortilla stuffed with rice, beans, cheese, guacamole and sour cream, and "Bertha's Bay," a burrito with beef or chicken. There is also a barbecued pork burrito with honey-chipotle sauce, and a vegetarian, nondairy one with spinach. Among other options are tacos, grilled chicken or beef fajitas served with rice, beans, sour cream, onions, jalapeno peppers and chipotle mayonnaise; quesadillas, and shredded pork, chicken or beef enchiladas topped with cheese and accompanied by beans and a zesty sauce. ($25 and Under: 5/26/95)
 
CHAZ & WILSON GRILL ++
(212) 769-0100; 201 West 79th Street;  all major credit cards
This bustling neighborhood bar and grill that serves tasty American fare is casual and inviting. Monday and Tuesday nights are particularly enticing because every entree is $9.95. For starters, one might try the house salad, an assembly of romaine lettuce, chicken, cheddar cheese and bacon tossed in a light Russian dressing; fried calamari with a spicy cocktail sauce; grilled portobellos on a bed of arugula with olive oil and garlic, or steamed mussels in white wine, onions and parsley. Main courses include meatloaf and mashed potatoes topped with mushroom gravy, roasted chicken seasoned with garlic and herbs, grilled salmon in ginger-teriyaki sauce and served with steamed rice and vegetables, and pan-seared sirloin steak with fried potatoes. ($25 and Under: 4/7/95)
 
FISHIN' EDDIE *
(212) 874-3474; 73 West 71st Street; $ all major credit cards
This engaging seafood house is full of the rustic charm one might expect of a little place in Maine. It has a small bar with Shaker pegs for hanging coats, a partly exposed kitchen and a cozy back room with a skylight and country-style furniture. The cooking is straightforward and gratifying. For appetizers there are mussels steamed in an herb-infused broth, salmon and tuna tartars flavored with shiso and sesame and paired with homemade chips, crab cakes garnished with corn relish, and fried oysters with a vibrant cilantro-lime sauce and fennel slaw. Among the main courses there is a seafood stew, grilled salmon over arugula, blackened mahi-mahi brightened with tartar sauce, and tuna steak served with peppercorn sauce and crisp french fries. (Review: 4/24/92)
 
LOUIE'S WEST SIDE CAFE ++
(212) 877-1900; 441 Amsterdam Avenue, at 81st Street; $ American Express, Mastercard, Visa
Brick walls, cloth-covered banquettes and wicker chairs convey a feeling of warm conviviality, and the home cooking is reliably satisfying. Current appetizers include steamed mussels in white wine and fresh herbs with tomatoes; wild mushroom ravioli with a tangy tomato sauce; cured salmon with mustard-dill sauce, and onion soup with pieces of beef and topped with cheese croutons. Entrees include beef medallions in Cognac and peppercorn sauce with french fries, lamb chops complemented with flageolet beans, herb-roasted chicken with spinach and mashed potatoes, pot roast with red cabbage and sweet potato fritters, and grilled skirt steak with caramelized onions and french fries. ($25 and Under: 9/4/92; article: 6/2/95)
 
MAD FISH ++
(212) 787-0202; 2182 Broadway, at 77th Street; $ all major credit cards
The imaginative cooking of Keith Rennie, formerly of Pisces in the East Village, is the lure at this new spot, which attracts a cross section of Upper West Siders. Mr. Rennie blends textures and flavors in a most compelling way, as in his perfectly fried fish flavored with fennel and drizzled with lemon juice, or his salad of watercress and delicately grilled spicy squid. The fish and corn chowder with black mussels and rosemary is also a winner, as is the goat cheese and roasted pepper salad. Recommended main courses include a tempura of wolffish blended with curry sauce and served with a crisp vegetable spring roll. barbecued bluefish with smoked onion compote. lobster risotto with roasted mushrooms, and pan-roasted monkfish with a root-vegetable sauce and stewed white beans. ($25 and Under: 12/8/95)
 
MONSOON ++
(212) 580-8686; 435 Amsterdam Avenue, at 81st Street;  all major credit cards
A ceiling with a bamboo motif and several green plants are a lovely backdrop for the beguiling Vietnamese cuisine that can be found here. Summer rolls come with the traditional peanut dipping sauce flavored with star anise; chao tom, sugar cane wrapped in grilled shrimp paste, is served with a sweet dipping sauce called nuoc cham, and steamed rice crepes are filled with chicken or shrimp. Savory garnishes of pickled carrots and turnips with tiny onionlike bulbs come with all appetizers. Among main courses are marinated pork chops with lemon grass and garlic; stir-fry of chicken with lemon grass, bell peppers and onions mixed in a red chili sauce, and a seafood casserole with crab, fish, calamari, scallops, shrimp and mussels. ($25 and Under: 1/6/95)
 
RESTAURANT 222 **
(212) 799-0400; 222 West 79th Street; $$$ all major credit cards
The alluring and warm town house setting, beguiling food and attentive service contribute to a sophisticated yet neighborly atmosphere at this popular Upper West Side establishment. While the a la carte menu is expensive here, a three-course prix-fixe dinner for $24.50 is offered every Sunday through Thursday. Current starters include a warm salad of sugar snap peas with shiitake mushrooms and string beans in a lively black peppercorn vinaigrette, a creamy polenta cake ringed by a wild mushroom ragout and topped with warm Gorgonzola, and ravioli of foie gras and mushroom duxelles in a madeira sauce. For main courses, there are seared sea scallops complemented by sweet corn risotto and mango, charred sirloin steak well matched with horseradish-flavored mashed potatoes, roast rack of lamb marinated in red wine wine and herbs, and pan-roasted salmon atop an aromatic medley of fingerling potatoes, fennel and wild mushrooms. (Review: 4/12/93; Diner's Journal: 6/10/94)
 
Healthful Fare
 
JOSIE'S ++
(212) 769-1212; 300 Amsterdam Avenue, at 74th Street;  American Express, Mastercard, Visa
The health-conscious food with an emphasis on organically grown products and dairy-free preparations attracts a steady crowd at this unpretentious little spot. To begin, there is seared Thai-style shrimp over udon noodles, steamed potato dumplings on tomato coulis with white truffle oil, and grilled polenta on a bed of spinach with warm mushroom vinaigrette. Main courses include catfish served with a warm tomato vinaigrette, and grilled chicken sausage with honey-mustard sauce. ($25 and Under: 6/3/94)

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Suzuki X-90;
Built by Japan (Body by Fisher-Price?)

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
ON his second birthday, my son received a toy gas station that came with a miniature cartoon-design car. The single-person passenger compartment sat on a squat body with bulging fenders. It was strikingly similar to the cars that screamed through the streets of Toontown in "Who Framed Roger Rabbit?"
When a 1996 Suzuki X-90 recently arrived for a road test, it was as if my son's toy had come to life. In addition to its distorted proportions, the X-90 was even the same color -- "lava red," Suzuki calls it.
 It is hard to fit this odd little bird into the usual automotive pigeonholes. The X-90's two-seat passenger compartment feels like a sports car's. Its available four-wheel drive and relatively high ground clearance make it suitable for off-roading. It is best described as a two-seat sport utility vehicle, though its utility is debatable since it lacks the cargo- and people-carrying capacity of other vehicles in that category. 
 Although it is a creation of Suzuki designers in Japan, the X-90 was conceived with the American market in mind. Gary Anderson, vice president of sales and marketing for the automotive division of the American Suzuki Motor Corporation, insists that Americans, more than people in other cultures, view their vehicles as a form of personal expression. Suzuki says the X-90 is aimed at the "young and young at heart" who want something completely different from anything else on the market.
Indeed, the X-90 attracts attention with its original styling. Quirky, gawky or just plain cute are some of the terms my friends and neighbors used to describe it. No matter how it is characterized, the X-90 does grab attention, usually in the form of "What is that thing?" Other mothers made comparisons like mine to their sons' toy cars.
In terms of size, the X-90, based on the two-door Suzuki Sidekick (sold by Chevrolet dealers as the Geo Tracker), is 146 inches long with a wheelbase of 87 inches and a width of 67 inches. In comparison, the two-door Jeep Wrangler is 152 inches long with a 94-inch wheelbase and 66-inch width.
Inside, the X-90 features all of the amenities of a typical car, except a back seat. These include standard power windows, power door locks and a pop-off T-top for open-air motoring. The four-wheel-drive model adds as standard equipment a cruise control, anti-theft alarm and premium sound system. Safety features include dual air bags; door beams for protection in side-impact accidents; daytime running lights, which are illuminated whenever the vehicle is running, and four-wheel anti-lock brakes.
In stark contrast to the curves of the outside, the interior lines are rather straight, and the cabin has all the shapeliness of a box. There is room enough for two, legroom is ample and the bucket seats are comfortable. The controls are easy to read and operate, except for the radio. Its on-off button is smaller than the eraser on a No. 2 pencil -- impossible to operate when wearing gloves. Considering that the vehicle is aimed at young people, the audio system is likely to be a much-used feature.
In light of the X-90's playful appearance, I expected the X-90 to be fun to drive. It is not.
Powered by the 1.6-liter, 16-valve four-cylinder engine used in the Sidekick and the Suzuki Esteem sedan, the X-90 strained to keep up with rush-hour traffic. It took more than 10 seconds to accelerate from 0 to 60 miles an hour, and the top speed is limited to 94 m.p.h. I can't imagine cruising in the X-90 at that clip; when I was traveling at 65, it felt as if I were doing 90.
The 95-horsepower engine is paired with a five-speed manual transmission; a four-speed electronically controlled automatic, with overdrive, is available on the four-wheel-drive version. The tested model came with the manual transmission, which felt as though it had come out of a truck.
Even more trucklike was the ride. And make no mistake: the X-90 is a truck. Cruising down the pothole-laced Southfield Freeway in Detroit, I felt I was riding in a metal crate. The slightest blemish in the concrete reverberated through the cabin and tossed me from side to side. On snow-covered roads, the X-90's rear end twitched sideways; engaging the shift-on-the-fly four-wheel drive, with its automatic-locking front hubs and two-speed transfer case (providing regular and extra-low gears), helped to maintain some stability.
Another incongruity struck me as I drove the X-90. As I tried to envision the locales where the X-90 would have its strongest appeal, Daytona Beach, Fla., came to mind. But a driver can invite only one friend -- and one who travels light. The trunk was surprisingly deep for such a small vehicle, and the 8.4 cubic feet of space was perfectly adequate for errands around town. But the opening to the cargo bay is so small that a large ice chest may be out of the question, not to mention a surfboard.
The X-90's best feature may be the price, since only a few sport utility vehicles are currently available for less than $20,000. The two-wheel-drive version starts at $13,499, including shipping charges. A four-wheel-drive X-90 with a manual transmission starts at $15,389; with an automatic, the price is $16,339.
With its small engine, the X-90 is cheap to run; its fuel economy is rated at 25 miles a gallon in the city and 28 on the highway.
Drivers will indeed stand out from the pack behind the wheel of an X-90 -- for now. But several auto makers plan to enter the market for small, inexpensive sport utilities, starting this spring with the slickly designed and much more utilitarian Toyota RAV4. Ford and General Motors are believed to be working on designs for small, car-based sport utilities in the under-$20,000 range. And, in Southern and Western regions where its dealers are established, Kia, the South Korean auto maker, is offering the Sportage, a utility vehicle in the $15,000 price range.
Some better choices will surely emerge from this new crop of vehicles.
 
INSIDE TRACK: The X-90 may look like a toy, but driving one is not child's play.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Ostensibly a sport utility vehicle, the small Suzuki X-90 defies classification. Detachable T-top panels let in a breeze. (American Suzuki Motor Corp.)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UNION SQUARE;
From Suppers of Legend to a Spot on Dormitory Row

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
The vacant lot on East 14th Street was once Luchow's, the storied German restaurant where Diamond Jim Brady slaked his thirst on overflowing steins of beer, Theodore Roosevelt tucked into plates of schnitzel and, local legend has it, Gus Kahn was inspired to take pen to tablecloth and write "Yes, Sir, That's My Baby."
Luchow's migrated north in 1982 and then closed. Its abandoned 14th Street shell became a haven for squatters, drug dealers and prostitutes before it was demolished last year after a suspicious fire. And when an apartment house for low-income and formerly homeless families opened next door, some residents feared that no developer would buy the old Luchow's site, a 19,000-square-foot lot at 106-112 East 14th Street, from Astoria Federal Savings. But last week New York University announced that it has -- for $5.8 million -- and that it plans to build an undergraduate residence hall. 
 The hall will expand the stretch of Third Avenue from St. Mark's Place to Union Square and its surrounding streets that has become known as Dormitory Row. In the last decade N.Y.U., Cooper Union and the New School for Social Research have reached beyond their commuter-college roots to draw students from around the nation. The newcomers need a place to live.
"Urban universities are in," said Virgil Renzulli, a spokesman for N.Y.U. "In 1980, 17 percent of our students came from outside the metropolitan area. Now around 70 percent do. And with the high cost of real estate, we had an increase in demand for student housing."
The dorms have helped transform Third Avenue's economy. Some porn and pawn shops have disappeared, and fast-food restaurants, clothing stores and the Sony East Village multiplex have opened. "There's a real energy created by the student population," said Robert Walsh, the executive director of the 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District. "When you walk down Third Avenue south of 14th Street, it feels like a mini college town."
But some neighbors are not so sure. "The jury is still out as to whether the changes are all going to be for the better," said Arlene Koenig, president of the East Eighth Street and Ninth Street Block Association. "Many new businesses are student-oriented. We could use a variety of businesses that are practical for the community and attract some tourists. How many junky dungarees and junky T-shirts can a person buy?"
 MICHAEL COOPER

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
City Agrees to Curb Helicopters

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Responding to growing criticism, the city has agreed to cut back the East 34th Street heliport's operating hours and to bar many flights from flying over densely populated East Side streets. They will fly over the East River instead.
But critics, who want the heliport moved, say the concessions will not eliminate copter noise and fumes. A final decision will be up to the City Council. 
 The 34th Street heliport -- one of four in Manhattan and the world's busiest -- has long been a nuisance to residents along the flight pattern, who complain of a racket from dawn till nearly midnight. As the tourist boom generates more sightseeing flights, complaints have spread across Manhattan. Bringing the issue to a head was the recent expiration of the heliport's lease and an application from the city's Economic Development Corporation, which oversees heliports, for a zoning permit. The heliport has been operating without one for two decades. The development corporation agreed last fall to cut landings and takeoffs 47 percent, to 28,000 a year or 77 a day.
This month the corporation's new president, Charles Millard, announced more concessions to take effect in a new lease this year. They include limiting the operating hours, now 7 A.M. to 11 P.M., to 8 A.M. to 8 P.M., with weekend tour flights curbed to 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. North-south routes for sightseeing will be limited to the East and Hudson Rivers. And a new panel with local representatives will monitor the heliport.
Councilman Andrew Eristoff, who campaigned for the restrictions, called them "a big win for the community that will bring welcome relief." But many critics disagree.
Last week the Planning Commission endorsed the zoning permit by a 7-to-2 vote. The dissenters questioned why the latest rules were in a letter and not in the application, and voiced concern about enforcement and the lack of an overall helicopter plan.
A day after the Planning Commission acted, Community Board 6 opposed the application, 34 to 1, and the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, also opposed it. The dual opposition means the the Council must review the application.
"We can still have helicopters buzzing by buildings at eye level and waving at you," said William Oddo, chairman of Board 6's transportation committee. He noted that the flight path rules apply only to sightseeing helicopters, not to corporate, private, commercial and commuter flights. He also said the development corporation ignored calls to ban weekend flights, to shift all sightseeing to the downtown heliport, to limit how close helicopters may fly to buildings and to require markings so residents can identify flights. "Things would really change," he said, "if they were flying over Gracie Mansion and the Mayor had to go to sleep with this every evening." BRUCE LAMBERT

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tourists board a sightseeing flight at the East 34th Street heliport, the world's busiest. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Segregated Schools Can Do Students No Good

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Whatever the problems the Yonkers public schools are experiencing as a result of integration, it is outrageous to suggest that segregation constitutes a viable educational strategy (letter, Jan. 7).
Students of color who attend segregated schools are hindered in their ability to advance within society. To be sure, if such schools offer dedicated teachers and well-financed programs (often not the case), students could succeed academically. 
 Even when such conditions are present, students are shortchanged, for racial isolation may compromise their ability to succeed in college and in the job market.
Such students may experience culture shock and may feel intimidated upon entering a predominantly white college or the predominantly white business world. They will succeed in such situations less frequently than those students of color who have attended integrated schools.
Segregated schooling also harms students of color because, having been deprived of contact with minorities, whites who attended segregated schools will be less inclined to build interracial bridges in college and in job settings.
Such whites may become distrustful of minorities, leading to diminished economic opportunities for people of color.
Thus segregated schools perpetuate racial inequality in society at large.
 
JONATHAN FELDMAN
Maplewood, N.J., Jan. 10, 1996

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
34th Street Has a Corner For Disney

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
When it comes to store locations, it doesn't get much better than 34th Street at Fifth Avenue, the intersection of two famed retail thoroughfares and the site of the Empire State Building with its thousands of office workers and three million tourists a year.
It appears to be an ideal spot for the Walt Disney Company to open a branch, and the owner of the vacant storefront at 39 West 34th says that is exactly what is in the works. 
 "It's definite," said James C. Schvarcz, the manager of Gotham Realty Management, which took over the building last year. "They're coming in." The Italy department store there closed earlier this month, after Gotham bought out its lease "so we could bring in a bigger fish," Mr. Schvarcz said. Warner Brothers, Levi's and Barnes & Noble expressed interest before the search narrowed to Disney, he said.
Disney's headquarters in California declined to comment, and some real estate sources familiar with the site said a contract is being negotiated. Alan Grossman of Georgetown Realty, which has been working with Disney on its expansion into New York, confirmed that his company has been "aggressively pursuing 34th Street" sites, but he declined to say more.
Relatively few empty spaces remain on 34th Street, which lost major stores like B. Altman's in the recession but has been rebounding in recent years.
Despite the seemingly sure-fire location, the Italy store appeared to do mediocre business, said Daniel Pisark, of the 34th Street Partnership business improvement district. He and other experts blamed bad marketing strategy. Benjamin Fox, the executive vice president of Spectrum Realty, described it as "a schlock store" out of step with the neighborhood's upscale trends. The Gotham building is "the ultimate location," Mr. Pisark said. The building's 10,000-square-foot ground floor would be a logical extension for Disney, which has announced plans to open one store at 42d Street and Seventh Avenue and another at 711 Fifth Avenue near 55th Street, both this year. Disney has 454 stores worldwide, including 340 in the United States. They feature stuffed animals, videotapes, books, toys, jewelry and cartoon cels of Disney characters. BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: 'Budget Crisis' Defined

BYLINE: By Felix G. Rohatyn 

 BODY:
The stalled negotiations over the Federal budget run the risk of creating significant instability in the financial markets.
This is the result of two different factors. The first is largely emotional. The gloomy predictions by politicians and economic officials that the markets may collapse if no agreement is reached could become a self-fulfilling prophecy with no basis in reality. The second factor is much more dangerous and could lead to market unrest. It is the continued threat of default on the $4.9 trillion national debt if the Congressional Republicans refuse to raise the legal debt limit in February. 
 The country's financial situation is very strong. Over the last three years, as a result of the Clinton Administration's fiscal policies and the Federal Reserve's monetary policies, the budget deficit has been cut in half, to less than 2.5 percent of the gross domestic product.
 Interest rates have decreased significantly, and the Dow Jones industrial average is near an all-time high. In addition, our trade deficit is coming down, and the dollar has strengthened. Even though the economy is slowing down, this is not the stuff of financial crisis.
 It is important to look at the reality of the budget negotiations. Both the Administration and the Congressional Republicans agree on a fundamental principle: a balanced budget in seven years based on Congressional Budget Office projections. Their differences in numbers in their respective budget plans are relatively small -- about $100 billion over seven years, which is about 1 percent of the $10 trillion the Federal Government is likely to spend over that period.
But the difference in philosophy between the two sides is very wide. Should the states be given responsibility poverty programs like Medicaid and welfare? Should entitlements like Medicare be means-tested? Where should taxes be cut and whom should they benefit?
These are important issues, on which compromise may not be possible in an election year. But that is no reason for a calamity in the markets. If no agreement is reached in the next few weeks, the voters can decide in the Presidential election which approach they prefer. That is what democracy is all about.
The markets may well prefer the Republicans' approach over the Administration's, and, from a financial point of view, they may well be right. But the markets cannot be the sole arbiters of Government policy. The biggest losers in the continued uncertainty over the budget are state and local governments, which find their own budgets in a state of near chaos because .
There are flaws in both budget plans. The Administration's plan fails to deal realistically with the growth in Medicare costs and its spending cuts are excessively back-loaded. The Republican plan includes needless tax cuts, and, in calling for the states to take over poverty programs that would be financed by block grants, takes significant risks with the social safety net.
 Both plans avoid the opportunity of creating significant savings by a downward adjustment to the Consumer Price Index, as recommended by many economists. The fact remains, however, that both sides are locked into a principle of balance over seven years.
If there is no budget agreement in the near term, the markets may very well go down, but that in itself should not start a crisis.
After a 40 percent increase increase in the Dow Jones industrial average over the past year, a 10 percent to 15 percent correction could happen for any number of reasons, the simplest one being is that the market was too high in the first place. Furthermore, a slowing domestic economy is generating disappointing earnings, and a significant slowdown in Europe is creating a risk to our exports.
It is true that the financial markets have to be dealt with very carefully. They are something like a rhinoceros. They are powerful and very dangerous, but they are rather near-sighted and they have a small brain. But even though the talk of financial crisis has become routine for any number of events, none has occurred so far, none is on the horizon and need not be set in motion on the budget issue, unless one is created by relentless media speculation and overblown rhetoric.
The danger of a default on the national debt, however, is a far more serious and could create a catastrophe on two counts.
Politically, it could appear to the world that the functioning of our democratic institutions had collapsed and that the Government is no longer governable by traditional means.
Financially, a default could trigger a global financial crisis of completely unpredictable proportions. It could wipe out the equity capital of hundreds of the world's largest financial institutions. This is simply reckless.
The Federal debt is approaching $5 trillion. More than $500 billion is held abroad. No one knows how much additional credit is supported all over the world by Treasury securities.
 Tens of billions of dollars in Bank loans, defeased municipal bonds, all types of securities and other financial instruments are secured by those securities, as are tens of billions of derivatives. Defaults could start a chain reaction of defaults all around the globe, with horrifying social and economic consequences. The amount of credit put at risk would be many times $5 trillion.
In normal times, the idea that this could happen in order to force a resolution of budget differences that are small in numbers, but significant in public policy, would be inconceivable. But we have witnessed the shutdown of the Federal Government over this very issue. This is a sign that we are not living in normal times.
There is no conceivable reason for any of this to happen. After all, the Congressional Republicans have achieved the core of their Contract With America: a balanced budget in seven years, in accordance with Congressional Budget Office numbers. We should not, however, overlook another equally important contract -- the contract with the holders of American debt and American currency. That contract cannot be broken.
Every effort should be made in the next few weeks to reach an agreement on the budget. If no agreement between the Congressional Republicans and the White House is possible, then a veto-proof agreement between Congressional Democrats and Republicans might be an acceptable alternative. But if no agreement can be reached, let the voters decide how it should be done.
 Ultimately the financial markets will not allow Washington to escape from a commitment to balance the budget, no matter who the next President is.
In the meantime, the nation should not lose sight of other fundamental economic issues: slow growth, lack of individual security, insufficient private and public investment, a failing tax system and growing disparities in income. These are fundamental and should not be buried in the fight over the budget.
The United States is the world's most successful industrial democracy because its currency and its credit set the world's standard. A default would not only seriously damage our currency and our credit. It would cast a dark shadow over a political system that has been the envy of the world for more than 200 years.

HEADLINE: Asia's Unlikely Tycoons;
Don't Tell These Hong Kong Women It's a Man's World

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
JADE CHOW was happy in Los Angeles. She had received her master's in business administration from the University of Southern California, finished off two years at a medium-sized accounting firm and had just gotten married. She was on her way to becoming an American success story. Then her mother phoned.
"She was running our silk company," Ms. Chow recalled. "She said I had to come home to help. I said, For how long? She said at least three months. That was in 1990." 
 Every morning now, Ms. Chow is picked up by her driver in Hong Kong and taken across the border into China to the family's silk garment factory. There, she oversees nearly 1,000 cutters, sewers, dyers and office workers for one of the largest silk garment companies in Shenzhen, one of China's first special economic zones, created in the early 1980's to encourage foreign investment.
Ms. Chow's story is familiar in a region dominated by family businesses -- the dutiful child returning to assume the reins of business from aging parents. But this story is different, for it is typically the sons who inherit businesses. Indeed, when a family has only daughters, it is not unusual for the daughters' husbands to assume command.
In Hong Kong's world of male chieftains, only a handful of women run their own empires. A few younger women are emerging, but there are still formidable obstacles to the ascent of female tycoons; an ingrained Chinese preference for male heirs and male kingpins means that the road to the top is dotted with land mines. In the professions, in academia, and particularly in local politics, women have become a formidable presence; only at the summit of business do they remain a rarity.
Yet there is a sprinkling of women tycoons. Some have taken over after the death of husbands, while some have stepped in when there are no male heirs or when male heirs are indifferent to the cloistered world of a family business. Indeed, even as women tycoons remain rare, it is occasionally said that the tradition of male inheritance does not always enhance a family empire.
"This has its roots in Chinese history and tradition," explained S. Gordon Redding, a professor of management at the University of Hong Kong. "Chinese Confucianism accords power and authority to the father figure. The woman is always the fallback."
Few tycoons here, or anywhere in Asia, have rivaled Nina Wang in success -- or in secrecy.
Trailed by three tightly braided pigtails, Ms. Wang scampered through her offices one day recently to show a visitor her latest project, a model of a slim blue tower that evokes the Chrysler Building in New York.
Her fingers traced the scalloped summit of a model almost as tall as the diminutive Ms. Wang herself. "We want this to be the highest building in the world," she said. "We need this kind of landmark for Hong Kong."
Few who have watched Ms. Wang wade through Hong Kong's intensely competitive and combative property and development market doubt her resolve. Indeed, as the "chairlady" -- her preferred term -- of the Chinachem Group, the largest privately held company in Hong Kong, Ms. Wang is used to getting what she wants. And since the kidnapping, and presumed death, of her husband in 1990, Ms. Wang has grabbed the reins with unrestrained -- and, to her male counterparts, jarring -- gusto.
Amid Hong Kong's male-dominated family empires, Ms. Wang sticks out like a shaft of light in a grim gray room. Given to fire-engine-red vinyl mini-skirts, T-shirts emblazoned with silver lame hearts and patent-leather platform shoes, Ms. Wang is intolerant of convention and impatient with tradition. Obsessively secretive about her wealth -- generally believed to be well over $1 billion -- Ms. Wang pursues her developments and overseas investments happily free of shareholders' whims.
Ms. Wang's role as corporate titan began six years ago. In 1990, as Ms. Wang's husband, Teddy Wang Teh-huei, set out for work from their house on Victoria Peak, he was abducted by a group of armed men. The kidnappers demanded $60 million in ransom. Ms. Wang paid slightly more than half, but her husband, whose family had started the business, was never heard from again; rumor has it that he was killed on a boat in Hong Kong's waters and dumped overboard. In fact, it was the second abduction of Mr. Wang; after he was kidnapped in 1983, Ms. Wang paid $11 million to to free him.
MR. WANG had been regarded as Hong Kong's 15th-richest person. Today, it is difficult to place Ms. Wang in the hierarchy of those here with astronomical wealth because she steadfastly refuses to take her company public.
"From time to time, we've talked about it," she said, "but the timing is never right."
In the meantime, Ms. Wang has steadily expanded Chinachem's reach. While she declines to value her holdings, the company -- 90 percent of whose stock belongs to her -- owns or has interests in about 200 buildings in Hong Kong, including industrial, commercial and residential projects. She has made two small investments in Henan province in China and has invested in two biotechnology companies in California, Sequus Pharmaceutical and Genslab. She said she was contemplating a gold mining venture, but preferred not to discuss it.
But it is the Nina Tower that seems to provoke the most excitement for Ms. Wang now, and the most frustration. Her plans are under siege by other tower projects around Asia, each shooting for the record height. "We started with 468 meters," she said -- 1,535 feet -- "but the towers in Kuala Lumpur were a little bit taller. So we'll go higher. I've always liked the Chrysler Building. I've seen it again and again. I want to do something like that. I don't want to copy it, but something that resembles it." She now says, "We want it to be higher than 500 meters," or 1,640 feet.
With the site preparation done, she is impatiently awaiting clearance from Hong Kong's airport authorities, who are worried that the height of the building may interfere with the new airport's radar systems. She said she was sure that approval would ultimately be granted.
And how, she was asked, does she intend to finance this building, which may cost $1 billion? "Cash," she says simply. "Cash."
SALLY AW SIAN, the dean of Hong Kong's women tycoons, is far less flamboyant, yet no less influential. And while she inherited the family business from her father, she did much to expand it both here and abroad.
Hard against the tarmac of Hong Kong's aging, frenetically busy airport looms the fortress-like gray concrete building that houses the newspapers of the Sing Tao Group. Striding through the newsroom of the morning paper, she surveyed her domain with a quick eye before heading to London to celebrate the installation of new lights for the Nelson monument in Trafalgar Square, lights she has paid for.
"They come to us foreigners for donations," she said, shaking her head at the demise of the colonial power. "England doesn't have enough money, so we lend a hand."
Hong Kong's only female newspaper tycoon, Ms. Aw took the wreckage of her family's fortunes and built an empire that straddles the globe. And while her flagship paper, The Sing Tao Daily, is neither the largest nor the most influential of Hong Kong's 76 dailies, it is the centerpiece of a chain of papers printed across Asia, North America and Europe.
Ms. Aw was born in Burma in 1931, into a family of herbalists. Her father invented one of the most widely known traditional medications in Asia, Tiger Balm, an all-purpose liniment that users rub on their abdomens to ease stomachaches or on their temples for headaches. The ointment is seen everywhere in Asia, although Ms. Aw no longer controls the company that makes it.
In the 1930's, Ms. Aw's father started newspapers in Singapore and China. "He paid so much for ads that he thought it would be cheaper just to open a few newspapers," she said. "He used to drive around in a car built like a tiger. That's why he thought at the same time he wanted to voice his opinion in a newspaper. My uncle's side of the family took Tiger Balm and we were left with the papers."
"My father was ahead of his time," explained Ms. Aw, whose crisp but conservative jackets and slacks emphasize her no-nonsense style. "But he passed away when I was young, when I was in my 20's. So I've been in business more than 40 years."
Last year, Sing Tao had about $260 million in revenue and a market value of $280 million. But the cost of newsprint has begun to eat rapidly into the company's profit, just as it has at other newspaper companies worldwide. Still, the circulation of the morning paper, at about 65,000 daily, ranks it securely among the territory's top five.
One of the company's biggest money makers is the comic book division, called Culturecom, which dominates the market here in Asian comic books. A foray by The Sing Tao Daily into the World Wide Web is, as are most such efforts, still unprofitable. "I don't know how long it will take to make money with this," she said. "Nobody knows. That's the big question."
Like other Hong Kong newspaper owners, Ms. Aw has been wooed aggressively by Beijing, mainly for her access to the global Chinese diaspora through editions published in Canada, the United States, Australia, New Zealand and Britain. On her first visit to Beijing several years ago, she was received by President Jiang Zemin, a meeting that she took for what it was, an effort to win her over.
Both Ms. Aw and Ms. Wang are candid about their relative isolation atop Hong Kong's business world. "During my generation, there are almost no women," Ms. Aw said. "I don't think I behave any differently from men, but in meetings I always find myself as the only lady."
"Some people are a little uneasy dealing with a woman," said Ms. Wang, who demurred when asked her age, but is probably in her 50's. "At building sites, workers swear a lot. But when I go there, they don't. Development people are a little old-fashioned, so I talk to the younger generation more. The older people don't approve of me. I wear miniskirts all the time. They never invite me to those dinners they have."
Indeed, when a group of Hong Kong tycoons established a foundation this year to bolster the territory's image, Ms. Wang was not among the founders. "They didn't even ask me," she said.
WHILE Ms. Aw and Ms. Wang represent the older generation of female tycoons, a new wave of women are making their presence felt. In 1990, Laura M. Cha left a lucrative position at Coudert Brothers, the American law firm, to become an executive director of the newly created Securities and Futures Commission, the Hong Kong counterpart of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
"I wanted to be in the ring where the action is," she said. "At the time I joined I was the only woman. Now, 3 out of the 15 directors are women, but I'm the only woman of the 5 executive directors."
"In the business community here," she continued, "there are not a lot of women at the top. In the financial world, there are even fewer."
And there are other women, like Lulu Man-ying Yu, the 34-year-old scion of the Yu family development empire built around Kumagai Gumi (Hong Kong) Ltd. Apart from being a director of the company, Ms. Yu also helps manage its hotel interests in China and runs her own chain of bakeries and restaurants here. "It's always the sons who inherit," said Ms. Yu, who is single, "but in our case, there was only a daughter."
And then there are the Chows, who while not tycoons in the grand Hong Kong sense, demonstrate the local entrepreneurial ethos. And yet, although there was an elder son, they turned to Jade to take control.
"My brother was helping out," Ms. Chow explained, "but I don't think he was happy. He couldn't deal with the problems of a manufacturing business. My brother was constantly worried about face, about keeping face. I'm not so concerned about face. If I make a wrong decision, I'll turn around and take it back."
With about $13 million in sales last year, and about 1,000 employees, Ms. Chow's Elegance Industrial Company -- which does not disclose its profits -- is among the largest silk garment manufacturers in Shenzhen, across the border in China. She brought her husband, David, into the company and he now runs its marketing operations.
But Ms. Chow, 32, said that if she were single, she probably would not have been easily lured back to the unglamorous life of running the family company.
"A large percentage of daughters don't want to run the family business even if they are given a chance," she explained. "All my friends are U.S.-educated and they aren't interested in the family business at all. The family business is not very glamorous, not something for a woman. If I wasn't married, I wouldn't be doing this. I mean, what's glamorous about running a silk garment factory in China?"

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 910 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Why a Budget Deal Isn't Really a Big Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SO go figure: For more years than anyone can remember, Wall Street has been screaming that America's budget deficit is dangerously high, and the only way to save the nation from financial ruin -- and high interest rates -- is to balance the budget.
After a year of wrangling, Democrats and Republicans agreed to do exactly that in the next seven years. And what happened? Investors panicked over the fact that ideological arguments over the last few cuts have prevented a final deal, even though the disputes amount to less than two percent of the total Federal budget. For most of the week, they hit the sell button with a vengeance. 
 All this is a reminder of how easily the little picture can obscure the big one when Washington and Wall Street interact, especially in an age when the linkage between politician's jaws and trader's fingertips is tighter than ever. Certainly there is a lot riding on how Bill Clinton, Newt Gingrich and Bob Dole resolve their differences, charging ahead with deeper tax cuts (as the Republicans insist) or permitting Medicare and Medicaid some more room for growth, as the Democrats demand.
But for investors, as opposed to citizens, the outcome should be of little importance. In the cold calculus of the bond markets, it should make little difference whether the Government spends its resources on health care, helium reserves or hot dogs. The only thing that matters is whether revenues match expenses by an agreed upon date. As the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, has said, the biggest change in Washington is that a "culture of deficit reduction" has overtaken both parties.
 
Most Financing Is in Place
 Moreover, the numbers suggest that even if a complete deal is not struck, the economy is not likely to plunge off a cliff. Most of the biggest spending bills, enabling the Pentagon and other big Federal contributors to the national economy to order planes and supercomputers, have already been signed. The corners of the Government that have not yet been financed, including the Education, Commerce, Labor, State and Justice departments, accounted for about $125 billion in spending last year, a small slice of the $1.6 trillion Federal budget, and they could almost certainly operate all year on scaled-back "continuing resolutions."
Those resolutions would probably exclude programs President Clinton supports and Republicans despise, from "Goals 2000" to the Commerce Department's technology initiatives. But the best guess is that the economic impact would be, as one Administration official put it last week, "small potatoes on any national scale." Congress would most likely cut out $10 billion to $15 billion, not much in a $7 trillion economy.
"It is not the kind of crisis that would cause a big contraction of the economy," said David Hale, the chief economist for Kemper Financial Services of Chicago. "You might lose half a percentage point of G.N.P., once it all echoed through the economy. But it might not even be that severe."
This is, of course, the flip side to the much-discussed death of fiscal policy. In the age of the New Deal and the Great Society, the Government was able to spur the economy by spending heavily, and used that power to ease the effects of recessions. But now such spending -- building public housing or highways, retraining workers and investing in non-military research -- is so small that it can't help the economy in bad times nor slow it much when it is cut back even further.
So if the deficit is coming down and the economic impact of political gridlock is minimal, why is Wall Street so worried? A lot, of course, has to do with economic and political perceptions, which always move markets (and voters) more than statistical realities. The markets had optimistically assumed that there would be a deal. But investors underestimated the ideological gulf, and when that became apparent this week they mourned the might-have-beens: Interest rates might have fallen to historic lows, especially if Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin had been able to end his fiscal dance to sidestep national default.
And there is always the other side of the market dynamics: Some hope that the jump in interest rates and the fall in the stock markets might yet force an accord. Markets have scared politicians into deals before, and in this case Mr. Clinton is not eager to take risks with the economy in an election year, and Mr. Dole needs to look like a statesman. "If it was up to Dole himself," one of the budget negotiators said last week, "this would have been done weeks ago."
But when you talk to economists and corporate executives, there is also something else at work in the markets' edginess. Not to put too fine a point on it, nobody believes the seven-year economic assumptions on which all the balanced budget proposals rest.
Seven years, of course, is an economic eternity. In fact, so is one year. Respected economists surveyed by The New York Times last month about their predictions for 1996 gave answers that varied from a shrinkage of the gross domestic product of 1.1 percent -- a major recession -- to growth of 3 percent.
June O'Neill, the Republican-appointed head of the Congressional Budget Office, offered a revealing answer when asked recently how she came up with her numbers. "Well," she said, "we used a consensus figure from a number of economists for the first 18 months. After that, we just straight-lined it."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Sell Pols, Buy Bonds

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The tug-of-war between President Clinton and Newt Gingrich over a balanced budget entered a new, and fascinating, phase last week.
To understand what's going on, you have to understand this: Over the past decade global financial markets have grown more powerful than governments and have acquired the ability to move capital at lightening speeds from countries practicing bad economics to those practicing sound economics. This has forced political leaders to look over their shoulders at the global stock and bond markets and to worry constantly whether those markets are giving a thumbs up or a thumbs down to particular economic policies. Politicians know that a thumbs down means money could quickly flow out of their country, leading to soaring interest rates, falling stock prices and lost elections.
In the last week we saw this game taken to a whole new level. Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Clinton are no longer just looking over their shoulders at the bond and stock markets, they are actively trying to enlist these markets onto their sides in the budget negotiations, by uttering statements calculated to make these markets go up or down. In other words, the bond market, which was seen as a passive referendum on fiscal and monetary policies, is now being actively courted or provoked by politicians to gain advantage in a budget fight. 
 At the moment, the President and the Speaker are not playing to the New Hampshire or Iowa caucuses. They are playing to the Wall Street caucuses. We are now in what Goldman Sachs economic expert Robert Hormats calls, "the Lower Manhattan primary."
Here's the new game: Mr. Gingrich knows that if the markets dive, it will hurt Mr. Clinton much more than him, because a sitting President will ultimately be held responsible by the public for rising interest and mortgage rates, or declining stock values -- in an already weak economy. Mr. Clinton knows this too, and so his goal is to keep hope alive that a budget deal is just around the corner, in order to keep markets up and give himself room for maneuver. So on Wednesday Mr. Gingrich declared: "I am for the first time in a year pessimistic about the likelihood of getting an agreement. It may just be that we need one more election." Mr. Gingrich never mentioned a word about markets, but there was something about the deliberateness of his pessimistic message that made you know he was talking beyond voters directly to bond traders and all but screaming: SELL BONDS! Result: the Dow fell almost 100 points and interest rates soared.
So the next day I went to hear President Clinton's news conference, and I saw that same Dow Jonesy look in his eye, when he declared that a balanced budget deal was "within our grasp." Translation: Forget about Newt's pessimism. There will be a deal, interest rates will go down, so BUY BONDS! But minutes later, Mr. Gingrich was back trying to respin the market. Mr. Gingrich said of Mr. Clinton's press conference: "It does not give me much encouragement." Translation: KEEP SELLING BONDS!
Clinton political adviser James Carville once quipped that in his next life he wanted to come back as the bond market, because it was so powerful. It looks like Mr. Carville won't have to wait for his next life. Politicians are becoming the market. This is a case of life imitating money.
One certainly has to worry about the volatility effect on global markets that could result from U.S. politicians trying to spin them in the same cavalier manner they try to spin the public and the press. Then again, the bond market didn't become all-powerful by being all-stupid. It will only take a couple more rounds of this, if not less, before it catches on to what Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Clinton are up to, and goes back to focusing entirely on economic indicators, not calculated statements for its benefit.
Which is why the President and the Speaker would be well advised to recall that exchange in Shakespeare's "King Henry IV," when Glendower boasts to Hotspur: "I can call spirits from the vastly deep." And Hotspur responds: "Why, so can I, or so can any man. But will they come when you do call for them?"

HEADLINE: For Many Japanese, Changes in the Government Seem to Bring No Real Change

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 13

 BODY:
As the Japanese political system tries to absorb its eighth Prime Minister in seven years, the biggest challenge in the long run may come from unassuming young people like Kumiko Uematsu.
"Hashimoto?" Miss Uematsu asked the other day, pausing on a shopping excursion in Tokyo. "Who's he?" 
 Her friend, Seiko Ueda, also 16, looked scandalized at this display of ignorance. "Hashimoto!" Miss Ueda whispered, trying to cue her friend in. "Isn't he somebody who's hated by a lot of people?"
Informed that Ryutaro Hashimoto was the nation's new Prime Minister, the two looked unimpressed.
"We don't talk about politics at all," Miss Ueda explained. "There are lots more interesting things to chat about. Like boys."
The Japanese Government faces enormous disillusionment with politics, but it does not often take the form of wanting to "throw the bums out." Judging from conversations with random Japanese on the streets, the mood is not so much rage as a home-brew of anxiety, apathy and feelings that it is all irrelevant.
"I don't think it's going to make any difference in my life," said Yoshiaki Takimoto, a 21-year-old who works for a moving company.
His buddy Ryo Kubota, a university student, offered a similarly bleak view.
"I think they're mostly bad people," Mr. Kubota said. "There's not much hope, really."
The mood in the United States almost seems optimistic by contrast. The fury that Americans sometimes feel for Washington at least implies a hope that ousting incumbents might do some good. Japanese, in contrast, seem virtually to have given up hope.
"There isn't anybody with leadership ability," grumbled Hiroshi Sakurai, a 57-year-old hotel company executive. "Japanese politics seem to be quite backward and shameful."
Many Japanese complain that it makes no difference who is elected, a not-entirely-irrational conclusion based on the political circus of recent years. For decades the only real opposition to Government policies came from the Socialist Party, but then the party chairman, Tomiichi Murayama, became Prime Minister in 1994 and abandoned nearly all his policies so that nothing much changed.
Mr. Murayama resigned on Jan. 5 and effectively picked Mr. Hashimoto of the Liberal Democratic Party to be his replacement.
The Liberal Democratic Party had run Japan for most of the post-war era until voters became so disgruntled at its corruption and calcification that they ejected it in a landmark vote in 1993. Yet the Liberal Democrats managed to form a coalition with their traditional enemies, the Socialists, and so through deal-making they have recovered the Prime Minister's post without any new election.
Politics in Japan in recent decades has mostly been a struggle for power among factions, rather than a competition among people with different ideas. That has added to the perception that Japan is really being run by bureaucrats, and that politicians are kind of a second-tier imperial family -- granted fine titles and lots of television time, but entrusted with little power.
"Nothing ever changes even when the prime minister changes," said Tomoko Yagi, a 17-year-high school student. Her boyfriend, Takeshi Ishimura, also 17, looked increasingly puzzled as he listened to the conversation. Finally, he interrupted.
"Oh, did Murayama resign?" he asked. "I didn't know."
One of the most common complaints about politicians is that they are corrupt, taking kickbacks from construction companies, for example, in exchange for approving new public projects. That is said to be one reason why new bridges and railroad lines abound even when half the population lacks such basic services as a sewer hook-up.
The perception of widespread graft was intensified when Shin Kanemaru, a craggy-faced political power broker who at the time was arguably the most influential person in Japan, was discovered in 1993 with $50 million worth of gold bars, cash and bearer securities in his home.
Perhaps because most people are passively disaffected instead of passionately angry, there is no pressure for term limits or other populist steps that are gaining ground in the United States.
"If you had term limits, you would just get more movie stars and people like that," complained Chiharu Atsumi, a housewife. "There'd be no change."
Mrs. Atsumi said she was particularly indignant at the frequency with which seats in Parliament are passed down from father to son almost as hereditary titles -- another parallel with the royal family.
Mr. Hashimoto, for example, was elected to Parliament at 26 after the death of his father, who had filled the seat for many years. The leader of the opposition, Ichiro Ozawa, also inherited a seat from his father.
Overall, 31 percent of the members of Japan's lower house, from which the Prime Minister is chosen, are second-, third-, or even fourth-generation legislators. And in the Liberal Democratic Party, where real power lies, 48 percent of the seats are inherited.
The result is the rise of families of political power-brokers. Mr. Hashimoto's family has formed one such clan, with his younger brother serving as governor of Kochi Prefecture.
Often the clans, through strategic marriages, ally themselves with wealthy industrialists, creating a neat merger of financial and political resources. The result, critics often charge, is a modern version of the feudal lords who ruled parts of Japan a few centuries ago.
"Here in Japan only sons or daughters of a politician can become politicians," Mrs. Atsumi said, cheerfully exaggerating. "Even the police are connected and don't prosecute them.
"So even if citizens like me raise their voice," she concluded, "it doesn't make a difference."
Polls find comparatively low satisfaction in Japan in the way their democracy works. Only 35 percent of Japanese say they are satisfied with their democracy, one of the lowest figures in any industrialized country. In contrast, 64 percent of Americans say they are satisfied with American democracy.
Japanese seem filled with a vague anxiety about the future, deepened by last year's devastating earthquake and poison gas attacks. A poll last month for the Yomiuri Shimbun, a major newspaper, found that 83 percent of those interviewed were uneasy and dissatisfied with politics, economics and society.
So Mr. Hashimoto and other politicians are pledging change.
"We're facing the need to fundamentally restructure the system," Mr. Hashimoto declared at a news conference on Friday. But he has given no example of specific important changes, and the Cabinet members he chose are deeply tied to the very system that inspired the malaise.

HEADLINE: Bangladesh Facing an Election Crisis

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: DHAKA, Bangladesh, Jan. 12

 BODY:
This South Asian country of 120 million people faces a deadline next week that may determine whether the shaky parliamentary democracy that has prevailed for the last five years continues or yields once more to the autocracy, military rule and political violence that have been Bangladesh's lot for 15 of its 25 years as an independent country.
After 22 months of political stalemate between the Government of Prime Minister Khaleda Zia and opposition parties, neither side has yielded in talks aimed at setting terms for a new parliamentary election. Under the Constitution, an election must be held by Feb. 22, and closing day for nominations for the 300 parliamentary seats is Jan. 18. 
 Mrs. Zia, 50-year-old widow of one of the two army generals who ruled here as President from 1975 to 1990, has twice put off the election date since the Parliament elected in 1991 ended its term in November.
Senior Government officials have said they are ready to hold an election without the opposition, a development that many here fear could lead to worsening violence and to intervention by the army.
In several weeks of talks mediated by the United States Ambassador, David N. Merrill, Mrs. Zia and her main political rival, Sheik Hasina Wazed, have failed to settle a dispute that has been marked by streets protests, general strikes, bombings and perhaps a score of deaths since an opposition walkout from Parliament in March 1994.
This week alone, Dhaka and the country's other main cities, including Chittagong, the main port, were virtually shut down for two days by a work boycott. With less than a week before election nominations close, foreign diplomats and prominent Bangladeshis who have sought to resolve the impasse are gloomy about the chances of a compromise.
"There's very little give and take," said a Bangladeshi who has been a go-between. "It just doesn't seem to be part of the political culture. And the level of personal mistrust is incredible."
Sheik Hasina, 48, has demanded that the elections be held under a neutral "caretaker" government, as in the 1991 voting, which was widely hailed as the fairest ever held in the country. Mrs. Zia has offered to step down before the polls, but has insisted that executive power in the election period rest with the figurehead President, Abdur Rahman Biswas, who was appointed by Mrs. Zia's Bangladesh National Party.
Antagonisms have been sharpened by the personal links Mrs. Zia and Sheik Hasina have to Bangladesh's violent past. Sheik Hasina is the daughter of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, regarded by many Bangladeshis as the country's founding father.
She was the only member of his immediate family who was not present on Aug. 16, 1975, when army officers assassinated Sheik Mujib, then the President, and 15 of his close relatives. Sheik Hasina remained abroad, mostly in India, until returning to contest and lose the 1991 election as leader of the Awami League party her father headed.
Mrs. Zia's husband, Gen. Ziaur Rahman, who was not related to Mujibur Rahman, took power with a military government after the assassinations, but was killed in 1981, also while serving as President, by dissident military officers.
A third woman at the center of the impasse, Raushan Ershad, is the wife of Hussain Mohammed Ershad, an army general who succeeded General Zia as President, resigned in 1990 and is now serving a 20-year jail term for corruption.
The impasse has imposed a heavy cost. The opposition parties, including a Muslim militant group, Jamaat-e-Islami, have called more than 30 days of general strikes in the last year, shutting down factories, transport and ports and setting back an economic surge that many had seen as the beginning of Bangladesh's ascent from poverty.
Although free-market reforms have generated growth, particularly in the garment industry, Bangladesh remains one of the world's poorest nations, with a per capita income of barely $250 a year.
The political risks were pressed home this week when Sheik Hasina led a rally in Dhaka that drew more than 100,000 people in commemorating the 25th anniversary of her father's triumphant return from jail in Pakistan, where he was held during the civil war that brought Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan, into existence in December 1971.
At least three million people died in the brief conflict, and 10 million fled to India. But the euphoria passed as Sheik Mujib's Government became increasingly autocratic. By 1974, he had imposed a one-party system. When he was killed, many in Bangladesh celebrated.
Now, all the political leaders say they are trying to uphold democracy, but many Bangladeshis say the positions of the two main figures reflect a zeal for power.
"Our politicians think only about power, about their own greed," said Joynal Abedin, a 27-year-old shopkeeper here.
One major figure who has remained silent amid the growing turbulence is the army chief, Lieut. Gen. Abu Saleh Mohammed Nasim. Appointed last year by Mrs. Zia, General Nasim has avoided public comment on the political tensions, and diplomats believe that he, like other recent army chiefs, has a strong disinclination to involve the army in politics again, after the bruising experiences of the Zia and Ershad periods.
Some leaders of the Awami League seem to feel that their party has little to lose. If the Government goes ahead with the elections, they say, the strikes and protests will spread.
"What you will see will not be a whimper -- it will be a series of bangs," said Abu Hassan Chowdhury, an Oxford-educated lawyer who is a close aide to Sheik Hasina.
As for an army takeover, he said: "The world has changed. There aren't any sponsors for that kind of thing any more. Anyway, the army doesn't want to dirty its hands."

Sheik Hasina Wazed, center, leader of the opposition Awami League, has demanded that the elections be held under a neutral "caretaker" government. She attended a rally last week in Dhaka, the capital. (John Giannini for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Australian Open Gains More Clout and Seles To Its Lineup for 1996

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY 

DATELINE: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 13

 BODY:
A year ago, on the eve of the Australian Open, the women had no sponsor, no Monica Seles and equal prize money. A year ago, Pete Sampras was a gifted player with little hold on public sympathy, Andre Agassi still had some hair left on his head, and the only place Thomas Muster was considered No. 1 material was in his native Austria.
Much has changed in the last 12 months, and when all of the world's marquee players with the exception of Steffi Graf begin slugging it out on the rubberized hard courts at Flinders Park on Monday, even the Australian Open will be different. 
 Expansion has become the costly hallmark of Grand Slam tournaments in the 1990's, and since Agassi beat Sampras in last year's men's final, Flinders Park has nearly doubled in size with 11 new outside courts, a grassy square dominated by a mammoth video screen and additional meeting rooms and parking. While its retractable roof, built in 1987, remains the focal point, the new courts have shifted the tournament's principal backdrop from the adjacent cricket ground to the considerably more telegenic Melbourne skyline. "This means that Flinders Park is again the world leader," said Geoff Pollard, the president of Tennis Australia.
With the United States Open and Wimbledon busily building, such leadership will not last long, but Pollard will certainly settle for a form of parity with his wealthier counterparts. Long fourth in the Grand Slam pecking order and the only one compelled by economic necessity to have a title sponsor (Ford), the Australian Open is the biggest beneficiary of the three-year deal reached last fall with the ATP Tour.
That agreement gives extra weight to the Grand Slam events in the men's computer rankings, and more important for the Australian Open, all of the Slams are now worth the same number of points. In the past, the Australian was worth less than the others because it offered less prize money.
But before Australian Open officials could rejoice for long, they had a different problem on their hands. In order to meet the requirements of the agreement with the ATP, the tournament had to raise prize money for men significantly. Even though it succeeded, it did not raise it equally for the women, prompting threats of a boycott from some players.
Ultimately, Pollard held firm -- the women will receive roughly 90 percent of what the men receive -- and the boycott fizzled, in large part because of commitments made to the new WTA tour sponsor, Corel.
"All the players were upset, but there are better solutions than a boycott," said Mary Pierce, the defending champion here.
Clearly, the best solution to what has been ailing women's tennis is Seles, who returned to the tour last summer after more than two years away and instantly re-energized the public by winning in Toronto and pounding her way to the United States Open final, where she narrowly lost in three sets to Graf.
Seles did not play again in 1995 because of lingering tendinitis in her knee, torn ligaments in her right ankle and a virus. She debated withdrawing from this event -- which she has played in and won three times, in 1991, 1992 and 1993 -- because of the illness.
Though less than thrilled with her overall fitness, Seles was fit enough to reach the final of the tune-up event in Sydney without losing a set and was scheduled to meet Lindsay Davenport in Sunday's final.
Seles, seeded first at the Open, has a fine draw here, made even better by the absence of Graf, still recovering from surgery to remove bone splinters from her left foot. The only other members of the top 20 missing are No. 6 Magdalena Maleeva and No. 11 Jana Novotna. The most vulnerable of the stars in Melbourne is Pierce, who after dominating this tournament last year failed to reach the quarterfinals of another Grand Slam event. This year she has Lisa Raymond and Amanda Coetzer in her eighth of the draw, which could mean more early difficulties.
On the men's side, the favorites remain Sampras and Agassi, but neither has been trouble-free of late. Sampras, seeded No. 1, injured his right hamstring during the United States' emotional Davis Cup victory over Russia in December and arrived late here after being bed-ridden with the flu at home in Florida. Agassi, seeded No. 2 and defending champion, missed most of the fall season because of a badly strained chest muscle and has not played an official event at full strength since winning at Flushing Meadows.
"It's not ideal to come here without having played for a few months, but I think that, with my game, I can get through the first week and then get through the second week playing my best tennis," said Agassi, who, with head freshly shaven, will face the qualifier Gaston Etlis in the first round.
While Agassi remains a crowd favorite, Sampras is now a sentimental favorite in Melbourne after his emotional quarterfinal match last year against Jim Courier, which Sampras won despite shedding tears for his coach, Tim Gullikson, who had recently been diagnosed as having brain cancer. Gullikson did not make the trip to Australia this year.
The title is not all that will be at stake at Flinders Park. Muster, the reigning French Open champion, also has a chance to reach No. 1. Unlike Sampras and Agassi, Muster has no computer points to defend here, and if he wins or both Sampras and Agassi falter early, the top spot would be his.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Monica Seles has reached the final of the Australian Open's tune-up event, the Peters International in Sydney, without losing a set. (Reuters)
