HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Owners' New Strategy: Take the Team and Run

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
As National Football League franchises race to find enough cash to pay ballooning player salaries, team owners are discovering that their ultimate reward is no longer a gaudy, diamond-bedecked Super Bowl ring.
Rather, it is financial tribute paid by cities eager to offer a rent-free stadium, erase all outstanding debts and unleash a geyser of cash from the sale of luxury boxes, club seats, food, concessions and parking. 
 With the Super Bowl two weeks away, the league that was once a paradigm of stability is in the grip of 1990's economics. Free agency requires vast new revenues. Teams with inadequate stadiums or unattractive leases hunt for fortunes. Cities seeking big-time status are willing to make owners happy with sweetheart deals.
The trend has made the unthinkable routine: In one year, the Browns said they will leave Cleveland for Baltimore, the Oilers will depart from Houston for Nashville and two teams left Southern California, the country's second-largest market.
And a raft of questions have been raised:
*How loyal can the league be to its fans?
*Will the league get Congressional protection from antitrust lawsuits that would let the league block franchise moves?
*Most important, how will the league mediate an economic clash between the collective good of a 30-team business that shares most of its revenues and the individual owner's right to increase his profits?
"This may be the biggest problem the league has ever faced," said Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L.'s former commissioner, who launched the league's big-money era with steadily increasing network television contracts. "It's very serious. The integrity of the league and its stability is hinged on local support."
Nothing illustrates the league's local roots better than the conflagration over Art Modell taking his Browns to Baltimore after 50 years in Cleveland.
Angry Browns fans have flooded the league with anti-Modell faxes, hanged the 70-year-old owner in effigy, compared him to one of the Three Stooges and taken their case to Congress and owners' meetings. Modell's vilification, including death threats, forced him into self-exile in his Florida condominium.
On Wednesday, N.F.L. owners are scheduled to vote on the move. But a postponement is likely because the Feb. 12 start of a city lawsuit that asks a court to force the team to stay in Cleveland until its lease ends after the 1998 season.
The Browns' move speaks loudest among all relocation questions.
Can the Chicago Bears seriously leave the Second City for Gary, Indiana? Will the Arizona Cardinals, who began life in Chicago, shifted to St. Louis, then left for Tempe, fill the N.F.L.'s void in Los Angeles? Or will it be the Seattle Seahawks or the Tampa Bay Buccaneers? And will the Cincinnati Bengals, whose founder, Paul Brown, created the Browns in his name, find financial solace in, of all places, Cleveland?
The map of the sports world, once reliably neat, begs near-daily revision. But the myriad routes described by all actual and possible moves lead to one place: a bank vault.
Still, this is about more than a mad dash for cash. If athletes' free agency has frayed bonds between stars and teams, as well as players and fans, then franchise free agency imperils the years of emotion, loyalty and money that fans invest, often to extremes, in their local teams.
Marc Ganis, president of Sportscorp Ltd., a Chicago-based sports consulting group that worked on the Oakland and St. Louis moves, said: "It's a free market. The Rams, Raiders and Oilers moves are all based on lack of fan support. The Browns move, which was based on the owner's financial distress, may be the anomaly that kills opportunities for other teams by getting Congress involved."
In Cleveland, Browns fans -- including the end-zone Dawgs -- turned out 70,000 a game in good times and bad. For their loyalty, they have been rewarded with the loss of their team.
"If this can happen in Cleveland," said Mayor Michael R. White, "there is no safe franchise in America."
 
It's N.F.L. That Has The Achilles' Heel
 The epidemic of franchise shifts is greatest in the N.F.L. but is felt elsewhere, especially in the National Hockey League. H. Wayne Huizenga has vowed to sell his deficit-riddled Florida Panthers if Broward County doesn't offer a new arena financing plan by Feb. 1. The Winnipeg Jets are going to Phoenix. The Nordiques left Quebec for Denver, and the former five-time Stanley Cup champion Oilers may flee Edmonton.
Shielded by its antitrust exemption, major league baseball has the power to block franchise moves and has not had one since since 1972.
Franchise stability characterizes the National Basketball Association where the sport's flush economy has made it wise for some owners to build their own arenas.
"Sports fans like stability," said Russell Granik, the N.B.A.'s deputy commissioner. "Fans of local teams like it, and fans of a league like to know where the teams are."
But it is the N.F.L. -- with owners saying they need more money for player salaries and bonuses and theleague itself unable to enforce its own relocation bylaws -- that has turned out to be the most susceptible to franchise moves. Without a great new influx of revenue from stadiums, teams feel they cannot compete.
"All teams in stadiums more than five or 10 years old are in play now," said Leigh Steinberg, the player agent who led a failed drive to keep the Rams from moving. "Plenty more smaller markets can get in. If Jacksonville, the No. 55 market, can have a team, so can Columbus," which ranks 34th.
Although many cities will keep their teams after finding the financing to build new stadiums, there could still be more moves. Rick Horrow, the N.F.L.'s facility development consultant, said that 18 of its 30 stadium situations are "unsettled" and 16 of the teams' leases will expire by 2006.
"Over a short period of time, this will be resolved," he said. "It's not as bleak as some would say."
But there is a grimmer view. Recently, Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, who has sponsored legislation that would keep the Browns in Cleveland, said of the N.F.L. situation: "It's chaos that is eroding the sport." And, in a reference to the N.F.L. commissioner, he added: "Paul Tagliabue doesn't control the league."
 
Who's in Charge? It's a Good Question
The legal question facing the league is how much control can it exert over where a team plays. At the moment, the answer is none, because of a Federal court's decision that backed the Oakland Raiders' right to move to Los Angeles in 1982, despite the league's opposition. "I realized then franchise relocation would be a big issue, but I didn't know how massive it would become," Rozelle said.
Modell may fall short of the 23 yes votes required to approve a move -- which may not matter -- but one voice in favor will be Wellington Mara's. The Giants' co-owner said he was dismayed over the league's refusal to face down an antitrust suit threatened by Missouri if the league had halted the Rams' move.
In the Rams' matter, a league veto of 21 votes against, 3 for and 6 abstentions turned to a 23-6-1 blessing one month later when the team increased its relocation fee to the league from $25 million to $46 million.
"We hurt our legal position by yielding," Mara said. "I voted against the Rams' move because I was voting to uphold our constitution. We had an absolute right to keep teams from moving. But we damaged ourselves."
Although Missouri's Attorney General never sued the league, the St. Louis Convention and Visitors Commission did. The commission filed suit for having to pay $20 million of the team's relocation fee.
The commission was unhappy that the Raiders returned to Oakland last summer without paying the league anything, while the Raiders were steamed that the N.F.L. wanted the team to share some of the new revenue it will get from returning to its ancestral home. The team built in the image of Al Davis, its managing partner, again challenged the legality of the league's relocation bylaws as it did more than a decade ago. Then, the Raiders' court victory cost the league $50 million. This time, the Raiders sued for $200 million.
Knowing that the relocation bylaws are meaningless, Tagliabue is pressing Congress to pass an exemption from the antitrust laws that would shield the league from lawsuits by teams, cities or states.
"If not for our antitrust exposure, the Rams' move would have been blocked," he told a Senate antitrust subcommittee in November.
But Mayor Bob Lanier of Houston, who is watching his city's Oilers leave for a munificent Nashville deal he could not match, distrusts an exemption unless it forces a quick expansion back into cities whose teams have already left.
"It's like the fox asking to guard the henhouse," Lanier said. "The fox tells the chicken, 'I'm good; I won't eat you,' and the chicken says, 'It makes me nervous with all those chicken feathers slurping out of your mouth.' "
When cities woo teams, they use all their financial wiles: lotteries, sales taxes, levies on parking, alcohol, car rentals and cigarettes. They will pass new taxes, extend old ones and reallocate money from one pocket to another. They will guarantee payment of the bonds if the forecasted revenue falls short.
Teams will contribute in their way, without really paying, by dedicating certain stadium revenue, like luxury suite rentals, to the cause. Actually, they are fan payments.
 
The Seat Is Yours, If You Buy a License
But the most intriguing form of financing is the permanent, or personal, seat license. P.S.L.'s are advance payments by fans for the right to buy season tickets. Essentially, they are money raised from thin air. But they make for powerful tools, having been part of the bounty used in the Raiders, Rams, Oilers, Browns and Panthers' packages. The total expected to be raised from P.S.L. sales in those cities: $450 million.
P.S.L. prices range from $250 each in St. Louis to $5,400 each in Charlotte. The charges are onetime, but Oakland's P.S.L.'s require annual fees of $50 to $75, and expire in 2006, six years before the Raiders' lease expires, to allow reselling them.
P.S.L.'s can be resold to whomever the holder desires. A 40-year, $1,000 Texas Stadium license -- sold to build the Cowboys' home in 1968 -- has sold for as much as $15,000.
Critics of the P.S.L. say it provides one more way for team owners to avoid having to pay for a stadium and is an onerous extra charge to fans. The Raiders' ownership will pocket $22 million, said Ezra Rapport, Oakland's deputy city manager.
"No matter how they dress it up, it's unseemly at its best, extortion at its worst," said Bob Costas, the NBC sportscaster, who lives in St. Louis and watched the marketing of Rams' P.S.L.'s, which paid off the team's debt in Anaheim and $20 million of the league-relocation fee.
Proponents say P.S.L.'s reduce public costs and, Tagliabue said in a recent league publication, "make the fans partners with their teams."
That logic has not been lost on buyers in the Carolinas and St. Louis who clamored to buy the P.S.L.'s. The Nashville P.S.L.'s went on sale last week.
 
Does a City Benefit? Some Have Doubts
Cities and states justify their ardent romancing of teams for the so-called economic impact they generate. Studies they commission testify to tens of millions in annual impact created from sales taxes and other activities at games, salaries paid to players and spending at hotels and restaurants.
A debate has developed over whether a team generates new spending or merely diverts money that would be spent on other leisure pursuits. "Lots of cities say they believe in economic impact because they can't take the chance there isn't one," said Robert Baade, an economist at Lake Forest College.
In Baltimore, a football stadium inhabited by the Browns would generate $123 million in new economic activity and $17 million in new local taxes, estimates the Maryland Stadium Authority, which built Oriole Park at Camden Yards.
"It is a legitimate government investment to put up these facilities," said John A. Moag Jr., chairman of the Maryland Stadium Authority, who personally wooed Modell. "Cities have spent money to entertain their citizens since the Greeks."
The cities admit that their sporting intentions, although with some basis in economics, are designed more to boost civic ego, expand the city's name recognition, encourage business relocation and get a big-league feel.
"We did an image study of how C.E.O.'s and relocation consultants view cities, and their perception of cities with pro sports was different," said Denny Bottorff, chairman of T.E.N.N.F.L., which is marketing the Nashville P.S.L.'s and luxury suites.
Al Kerth, a spokesman for Fans Inc., which wooed the Rams to St. Louis, said: "Economically, you're better off with a bank or a factory. The impact of a team is minimal, but buys a lot of emotional impact."
 Would the municipal executives luring teams with all manner of incentives work as feverishly to satisfy other types of businesses with tax abatements, low-interest loans and other sweeteners?
Of course, said Chris Warren, economic director for the city of Cleveland. He points to myriad projects that White's administration has moved rapidly to help, including one to bring a small biopharmaceutical firm from the Baltimore suburb of Gaithersburg to a new business park in Cleveland.
Coincidentally, the company, MedImmune, is being wooed to stay put with a package of incentives from Maryland. Would MedImmune make Cleveland its choice if the Browns stay? Mark Kauffman, a MedImmune executive, said: "No. A good health-care infrastructure is a lot more important."
In Houston, Lanier was unwilling to sacrifice much to keep the Oilers from moving and is not sorry. He opposed using taxpayer money or giving the Oilers tax abatements. "It's unjustifiable as economic development," he said.
The team accuses Lanier of presenting a viable stadium plan paid for without taxes only after the team owner, Bud Adams, signed his deal with Nashville. Apparently delighted to wave the Oilers goodbye, Lanier suggested that the Oilers be renamed the Nashville Welfare Mothers.
 
Keep an Eye On Cincinnati
 In today's market, the moving motive is easy: to make more money.
But free agency, accompanied by a steadily increasing salary cap that allows for huge signing bonuses, has made financial management precarious for teams that have chintzy leases or outmoded stadiums.
Although some observers believe there is a growing division between haves and have-nots in the league, N.F.L. officials play down the increasing anarchy.
They have called the relocation frenzy a result of the sport's growing popularity, the aggressiveness of cities that want teams and team owners' restless hunt for new revenue.
"I don't think greed is the issue at all," said Neil Austrian, the N.F.L.'s president. "If you can't sign players, if you don't have the capital available for signing bonuses, if you continually can't be a winner, nobody wants to stay in the league."
In Cincinnati, Mike Brown is not hollering that he will take his Bengals to Cleveland or any other city eager to satisfy his needs. But he might. His tale illustrates the situation of small market teams that need more money to compete in a league where wealthier owners are lavishing players with enormous bonuses.
"Our stadium seats 55,000; the league average is 66,000," Brown said. "We have 20 luxury boxes; the average is 108. We have no room for club seating. We don't get the revenues other teams do. We're the league's 31st largest market. The salary cap is going up faster than we can generate revenues."
A March 19 local referendum on a sales-tax increase to pay for stadiums for the Bengals and the Reds is crucial to Brown's decision to stay.
Brown says he had "the same opportunity" with Baltimore before the Browns did, which prompted a petition-signing drive for the March referendum.
He insisted that he is not seeking the best stadium deal in the league or meeting covertly with other cities. He wants to remain economically viable during the N.F.L.'s most volatile time ever. And if voters reject the tax?
"What we will say if the Doomsday scenario comes upon us we will save for Doomsday," Brown said. "If we lose, we know we cannot maintain ourselves under the current league structure. We wouldn't be profitable for long."

HEADLINE: City Is Safer, Rising Number Of People Say;
Attitudes Catching Up To 2-Year Fall in Crime

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
Two years ago, the McDonald's in Flatbush might as well have hoisted a white flag alongside the flags of Barbados, Grenada, Panama and Puerto Rico that wave from its roof. Drug dealers and their buyers gathered outside the restaurant at Parkside and Ocean Avenues and scared off the customers.
But now, said Ade McCullum, 22, the restaurant's manager, "we don't see the deadbeats and junkies anymore." As a result of increased police patrols, he said, "sales are up 10 to 15 percent in the last six months." 
 A mile and a half away, Carole DeBeer, the owner of Etc., a boutique on Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, said she had noticed that customers who once fretted to her about their safety have found other topics of conversation. "I hear less about burglaries, or even car thefts," Ms. DeBeer said. "And when I walk to work, I don't see the broken car-window glass on the sidewalks as often."
Mr. McCullum and Ms. DeBeer live and work in very different corners of Brooklyn, he in a neighborhood of immigrants whose tenements are splashed with graffiti and redolent of curry and ginger, and she in a neighborhood of young professionals and graceful brownstones accented by groomed gardens. But their shared view that life in New York is getting safer is apparently becoming more common, as public attitudes finally catch up with statistics that for the last two years have shown a sharp decrease in the rate of murders, muggings, car thefts and burglaries. Of course, attitudes about crime and safety develop in a variety of ways and often reflect whether the person has been a crime victim or knows someone who has.
Indeed, conversations with about 60 people over the last month in Flatbush and Park Slope elicited a wide range of responses, from the view of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as miracle worker to the opinion that the recent multiple slayings at a Harlem clothing store and a Bronx shoe store were evidence that crime remained out of control.
Crime and New Yorkers' fears about it have always been a central part of life in the city, often shaping its politics and the most basic daily decisions, like where to live, park or stand on a subway platform. People in Flatbush and Park Slope said they still worried about crime, but most of those interviewed said they had noticed a significant difference in the safety of their neighborhoods, and a few even said the difference had prompted them to change their lives in small but important ways.
A senior at Brooklyn College, who asked to remain unidentified, said that in the last few months she has begun to summon the courage to venture off campus to eat lunch in Flatbush. A day-care center operator said she was now willing to take the children she cares for out to play in Prospect Park because she no longer saw crack vials there.
Annie Williams, a 48-year-old unemployed woman living on Woodruff Avenue in Flatbush, said she had begun to leave her apartment door unlocked when she took a short walk.
"When you've seen as many children shot in these buildings since the 1980's as I have," Ms. Williams said, "you have to be grateful crime is down."
Mary Ann Albano, manager of the William B. May Real Estate brokerage firm office in Park Slope, said she thought changing perceptions had helped her business. "Two to three years ago, people were moving out to Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey because of crime," she said. Now, she added, many people who are selling their co-ops are staying in the neighborhood and buying larger apartments.
Public officials, like Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, and Richard A. Brown, the Queens District Attorney, have noted that the subject of crime has receded at town hall meetings, to be replaced by concerns like education and budget cuts.
"People are beginning to say what was unthinkable four years ago," said the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, "that things are beginning to look good for the safety of their neighborhoods."
Still, the slowly changing perceptions only partly reflect the degree to which the rate of reported crime has dropped in recent years -- to levels not seen in more than two decades. In the 70th Precinct, covering Flatbush and Kensington, there were 27 fewer murders in 1995 than in 1993, for a total of 19. The numbers of shooting victims, burglaries, car thefts and robberies decreased by 40 percent or more in each category.
In the adjacent 78th Precinct, which covers Park Slope and Prospect Park and where there is more property crime than violent crime, the changes were almost as large in the same period. Robbery was down by 36 percent, auto theft by 32 percent, first-degree rape by 50 percent, burglary by 27 percent and felony assault by 19 percent.
Nevertheless, recent polls continue to show a high level of fear in New York, while lengthy interviews indicate that people's feelings about crime are often complex and contradictory.
"I don't know if crime is down or not," said Joseph Shamie, 30, owner of the Dima department store on Flatbush Avenue, where 18 Polaroid pictures of shoplifters over the front door aid a security guard who checks packages of exiting customers. But, he added, "Since Giuliani came into office there is much more police presence, and that makes people feel better."
Israel Roman, a 54-year-old plumber who lives on Dorchester Avenue, said he knew crime was going down because he read about it in the newspapers. But he remembers when two police officers were shot two blocks from his apartment in 1993. And he said he still has not recovered from the trauma of being robbed at gunpoint of $300 on Flatbush Avenue last year.
Mr. Roman worries that crime will rise if the economy worsens. "I heard that in Westchester a man who was laid off shot his manager in an auto-parts store," he said. "People got to survive."
Mary Elmer-DeWitt, a 44-year-old Park Slope photographer, said her Sixth Avenue brownstone had been burglarized five years ago and again three years later. As a result, she worries. "It feels a little bit safer," she said. "There's more cops on the beat, that's for sure."
But speaking over tea while waiting for her groceries to be delivered, she added, "It could all change tomorrow." Now that her 10-year-old daughter, Lizzy, walks home from school by herself, she said, "I feel more vulnerable."
Margaret Nuzum, president of the board of School District 15, which includes Park Slope, said that, while people in the neighborhood "do feel a little bit safer," parents were concerned that increasing class size would worsen discipline problems in the public schools.
Perhaps because violent crime is more prevalent in Flatbush than in Park Slope, some Flatbush residents appear to feel the drop more. The gritty block of Woodruff Avenue between Church and Flatbush Avenues was a shooting gallery of drugs and bullets until late last year, but then an abandoned four-story building used as a crack house was taken over by a bank in a foreclosure.
Now night attendance at the Calvary Pentecostal Church across the street is up, shopkeepers say they feel safer and more children are attending the Happy Child Day Care Center.
"Over the last year, I haven't felt that feeling of apprehension," said Leolin Schleifer, 51, the director of the day-care center. An immigrant from the island of Saint Vincent, Ms. Schleifer said she was leaning toward voting for Mr. Giuliani in 1997 because of his record on crime after voting against him in 1993.
The mood was less upbeat at a recent community meeting on crime attended by 75 Park Slope residents at the United Methodist Church. While many people complimented the police for bringing down crime, others complained about graffiti, disrespectful police officers and homeless people who harassed passers-by.
Some suggested that these relatively minor complaints showed that the community was redefining its concerns about security and the quality of life. But others, particularly residents living between Third and Fifth Avenues, said they felt little or no change and complained that they did not see beat officers often enough.
"Where I live there is a very low amount of violence, but there are beginning to be outbreaks of prostitution," said Ben Meskin, a 35-year-old lawyer who lives on Third Avenue.
"The crimes that bother us are not down," said Carmelita Blake, a college teacher. "We're upset about noise and nervous about our cars."
Countering the complaints, Capt. Richard J. Rosa, the commander of the 78th Precinct, presented charts that showed that almost all categories of violent and property crime in the neighborhood were at levels not seen since the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay. "Utopia is a fairyland," he said, "but in 1996 we're going to try to get there."

SECTION: Section 8; Page 7; Column 4; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 1191 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Hmm . . . Salaries Are Unchanged

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
In trying to determine the direction salaries have taken this off season, consider the raise Al Leiter received in moving from the Toronto Blue Jays to the Florida Marlins, $795,000 for one year to $8.6 million for three years. On the other hand, consider the cut Jose Oquendo took in remaining with the St. Louis Cardinals, from a four-year, $8.5 million contract to a minor league contract that will pay him $250,000 in the majors.
Leiter and Oquendo are 2 of 138 players who became free agents in November and 2 of 99 who since have signed new contracts. The negotiating experience of that group shows that salaries are not plummeting, but then, they are not soaring either. 
 Those 99 players have new contracts whose signing bonuses and major league salaries total $367,580,000 for 160 years. Their contracts that expired at the end of last season earned them $407,321,153 over 169 years, including $12,946,153 in performance and award bonuses.
Subtracting the earned bonuses -- under the new contracts, many players have similar bonus provisions and can earn more than their salaries -- the annual average value of the old contracts per player was $2,333,580. The annual average of the new contracts per player is $2,297,375, only a 1.6 percent drop.
"On balance, it's come out about what I would have thought, maybe a little higher in some respects," Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said. "Nothing has really stunned me over all. There are some individual contracts that have startled me, but that's always the case."
Selig declined to single out any contracts, but the deals that have raised the most eyebrows include Leiter (the Marlins had stiff competition from the Baltimore Orioles, who were prepared to pay the same price), Kenny Rogers (the Yankees were bidding against themselves), Jose Canseco (ditto the Boston Red Sox) and Rick Aguilera (Minnesota gave him $9 million for three years to be a starting pitcher after six years of relieving).
The Yankees' five-year, $20 million contract for Tino Martinez also has raised serious questions, but he is not included in this group because he is not a free agent and can't be for two more years (exactly the point, cry critics of the contract).
Selig, who as the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers admits to having signed a questionable contract or two himself over the years, said that "quite a few" clubs probably spent more money than they might have last year because of the revenue they will receive from the new $1.7 billion television package.
But he rejected the idea that the clubs' spending has given players reason to be skeptical about the owners' demands for a payroll tax.
"Many have said that," he said. "However, I think this year it's absolutely not the case. I think that the spending habits of most clubs is pretty indicative of the economic situation they find themselves in."
He was suggesting that few teams have spent lots of money. One that has has been the Marlins, whose owner, Wayne Huizenga, was outspoken during the strike about the need for some kind of cap or tax system.
Asked about that seeming contradiction, Selig said, "Every club going in knows what they did last year, knows the anticipated revenue and makes their own decisions."
In dissecting the signings and comparing the players' new contracts with their old, one major factor is their circumstances at the time of signing. When Oquendo, for example, signed his $8.5 million contract in February 1991, he had been a regular infielder for three seasons, averaging 156 games. But now he is five years older, 32, and he averaged 51 games a season during the four-year contract.
Mike Stanley, for another example, had the opposite experience. When he signed a three-year contract with the Yankees in November 1992, he never had been a regular catcher. As a subsequent starter, he blossomed into one of the best hitting catchers in the majors. So the $2.3 million he is guaranteed for one year with the Red Sox exceeds the $2.2 million he earned the past three years with the Yankees.
Of the 99 free agents who have signed, if earned bonuses are excluded from their average annual pay, 46 have signed for increases, 44 for cuts and 9 for the same salary. Forty players have signed multiyear contracts (option years not included) this time compared with 37 the last time they signed contracts.
The most notable difference is in the number of players who have signed minor league contracts with provisions for major league salaries if they win major league jobs. Seven of the 97 signed such contracts the last time, but 25 have this off season.
 
 
 
Ordonez in the Doghouse?
 Word is circulating among front-office people from other clubs that the Mets are down on Rey Ordonez, supposedly their shortstop of the future, and are prepared to trade him. But General Manager Joe McIlvaine said neither element of the circulating report is true.
"I don't agree with the premise," McIlvaine said, meaning he didn't think Ordonez had become a problem player. Was he trying to trade him? "No," he replied, "absolutely not."
An official of another club, who thinks Ordonez is a good player, said the Mets are "raving" about him but added, "They're really trying to move him." The Mets, the official said, are good at selling their players when they want to create a market for them.
Ordonez, a Cuban defector, played for Norfolk in the International League last season and missed two weeks in August when he went home to Miami.
"There was a point where he went home for something and stayed longer than he was supposed to have stayed," McIlvaine acknowledged. "It was brought to his attention. I don't know if 'read the riot act' is right, but he was told about it and there weren't any reoccurrences."
Ordonez led Norfolk in games played with 125 and batted a disappointing .214. But in the recently concluded Puerto Rican winter league, he batted .351, squandering the league lead in the last few days and losing the batting title to Roberto Alomar, who batted .358.
 
 
 
La Russa's Reunions
 Earlier in the off season, the Oakland Athletics, Tony La Russa's old team, and the St. Louis Cardinals, his new team, were close to making a 9- or 10-player trade. The Cardinals were to get Dennis Eckersley, Todd Stottlemyre and Mike Bordick and send the Athletics six or seven players, mostly minor league prospects.
The deal did not come off, partly because the Cardinals were trying to sign Craig Biggio and Mark Grace as free agents and partly because they apparently had second thoughts about the players they would have to give up.
Instead, on Dec. 14, the Cardinals sent three players not in the "prospect" category to San Francisco for shortstop Royce Clayton, ending their interest in Bordick. Then, last Tuesday, they made a deal with the A's, acquiring Stottlemyre for an outfielder and three pitchers who were high draft choices within the last three years. All four players would have been in the big trade had it been made.
A trade for Eckersley could come later, if the Cardinals decide their young pitchers can't handle the closer's role.

HEADLINE: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE OVERVIEW;
Melting Snow in Northeast Has Nowhere to Go but Into Homes

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
After a week of savage storms that crippled government, commerce and travel across New York and the Northeast, golden sunshine and almost springlike warmth spread a watery new havoc across the region yesterday. Melting mountains of snow flooded wide areas, while homes and businesses suffered a plague of leaking roofs and collapses.
As temperatures climbed into the 40's and remnants of the Blizzard of '96 receded, life was limping back to normal for millions who had been snowbound, stranded or trapped in nightmarish commutes. Airports and roads were generally open, trains were nearly back on schedule and cleanup efforts were progressing on many fronts. 
 But from Maryland to Maine, the roofs of dozens of businesses, barns and other structures collapsed on Friday and yesterday under the weight of accumulated snow and freezing rain, and government agencies in New Jersey, Rhode Island and Massachusetts were warning that flat-roofed structures might still cave in.
In the New York area, a 40-foot section of wall at a National Guard armory in Teaneck, N.J., collapsed yesterday, apparently under the pressure of tons of snow and ice on the roof. At least 14 people were injured Friday evening when the roof of a Waldbaum's supermarket in Massapequa, L.I., fell in. They were the latest of a dozen collapsed roofs in the metropolitan area in recent days.
And yesterday, New Jersey joined New York on the list of states declared eligible for Federal disaster aid by President Clinton.
As sanitation crews in New York City planned to make their first garbage pickups today, after a week of grappling with snow instead, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said at a City Hall news conference that 14,000 miles of city streets had been plowed during the emergency.
The Mayor, who had estimated city costs for overtime, contracts and storm-fighting equipment at $30 million, raised the figure yesterday. "It'll take us a couple of weeks to really estimate the full cost to the city," he said, "but it'll range from $35 million to $40 million; it could go as high as $50 million."
Mr. Giuliani welcomed the announcement that New York had been declared a disaster area and thus was eligible for Federal reimbursement of some of the costs of clearing emergency routes. "It's really a recognition that a disaster is a disaster," the Mayor said.
Carl Golden, a spokesman for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, said of the similar announcement for New Jersey: "We're delighted that it's freeing up some money that was spent on the snow emergency. About $82 million was spent on snow removal by the state and municipalities."
Mr. Golden said state officials had no specific aid figure from the President. On Friday, Governor Whitman had sent a letter seeking $350 million for damage and cleanup efforts.
The overall cost of the storm in damage, cleanups and lost economic activity in 10 states has been estimated at more than $1 billion.
Meanwhile, plumbers, roofers and building contractors were swamped with calls for help from homeowners and businesses as melting snow and ice dripped -- often gushed -- into basements, attics and living rooms, some ceilings caved in, more roofs collapsed and damage began to mount into the millions.
"Anywhere water can come through it's coming through, even on brand-new roofs," Laurie Taylor, the owner of Four Seasons Roofing in East Farmingdale, L.I., said yesterday. She had a steady stream of S.O.S. calls from desperate people who told of water-damaged homes, furniture and other property.
Rudolph Damiani, owner of the Airtite Home Improvement Company in Fairfield, Conn., said his volume of calls for help had been the greatest in his 35 years in business. "People are hysterical," he said. "We're getting inundated with calls 24 hours a day."
Jim Coleman, a supervisor at J.J. Kenney Roofing in Garfield, N.J., which usually gets 20 calls a day, said, "We've gotten something like 600 calls over the last four days."
With the collapse at Waldbaum's and other sites in the news, many homeowners have been needlessly worried that something similar might happen to them, said Lauren Deribin, the owner of Capitol Roofing in Jersey City, N.J. She said the dangers of collapses are mostly in commercial buildings with flat roofs, where snow has piled up.
Roofers and contractors were not the only beneficiaries of the melting snows. Hardware stores reported a run on supplies for patching roof and foundation leaks, as well as on salt, sand, shovels, ice-melting materials and batteries.
Many fuel oil dealers and heating companies were also inundated with calls for deliveries and repairs to heating systems that had broken down in the storm. And plasterers were besieged as wet walls and ceilings sagged and in many cases fell.
While water damage was widespread, yesterday's sunshine and relatively warm temperatures were welcomed at New York City's huge snow-dumping operation on the Hudson River in Greenwich Village. Carl Fera, a sanitation foreman, smiled as he watched mammoth trucks full of snow line up and slide their loads into the river. Wet snow is easier to scoop up and cart away.
And there was more melting warmth on the way today. The National Weather Service predicted a mostly sunny day in the metropolitan area, with temperatures in the mid-40's, and no storms on the horizon. "As far as we go out, through Wednesday, I don't see anything happening," said Mike Wooldridge, a weather service meteorologist.
It was too late, however, for the Teaneck Armory and the Waldbaum's in Massapequa. Shortly after 10 A.M. yesterday, with tons of snow pressing down on the steel bow roof of the two-story, 36,000-square-foot armory on Teaneck Road, a 40-foot section of its brick wall separated from the roof and fell. No one was injured, but the armory, built in 1938, was off-limits for drill purposes.
In Massapequa, a huge section of the supermarket's flat roof, laden with tons of snow, collapsed Friday night. No one was killed, but 14 customers and employees suffered cuts and bruises, and one cashier was trapped briefly in the debris.
David Smithies, president of the Waldbaum chain, said that the snow from last week's blizzard had been shoveled from the roof, but that Friday's downpour had added considerable weight. "The drains were cleared," he said, "so we really don't know why it came down. Everything was built to code. It shouldn't have happened."
John Venditto, the Oyster Bay town attorney, said the supermarket had a clean record for adhering to the building codes, which call for commercial roofs to accommodate twice the weight they might be expected to bear. "In my opinion," he said, "last night was just a freakish accident."

HEADLINE: Top Target in Iowa Debate: Forbes, the No. 2 Candidate

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: JOHNSTON, Iowa, Jan. 13

 BODY:
In a telling display of how Steve Forbes has rattled the Republican Presidential field, the multimillionaire publisher emerged today as the central attraction and target in a nationally televised candidates' forum.
While all nine candidates shared the stage for the first time this year -- and for the last time before votes are cast in the Iowa caucuses in 30 days -- several passed up the chance to attack Senator Bob Dole, the front-runner. Instead, they turned their attention to Mr. Forbes, who has spent more than $10 million of his own money since his late entry in the race and is No. 2 behind Mr. Dole in many polls. 
 In the 90-minute forum, the candidates struggled to stand out from the group, even though they share many positions.
One after another, they attacked Government as too big and offered their own plans to simplify the tax system and improve education, and several reasserted their positions against abortion -- to the point that both Mr. Dole and Representative Robert K. Dornan of California sought to lay claim to Mother Teresa's political blessing on the issue. One after another, they jockeyed over who is the most conservative. Foreign policy hardly came up as the contenders were peppered with questions from readers of The Des Moines Register, which sponsored the forum in this suburb of Des Moines.
Less a debate than a series of sound bites, the forum represented the first chance this year for Iowans, and for a national audience, to see all nine Republican contenders on one stage. Although the candidates have been out on the road for months, spending millions on travel and television commercials, today's event was the opening of the race for the Iowa caucuses to be held Feb. 12, which will be the first nominating contest in which all the Republicans are entered. Much of the give-and-take at the forum, which was carried live by CNN, C-Span and Iowa Public Television, focused on Mr. Forbes. The questions were posed by The Register's editor, Dennis Ryerson.
Several candidates set out to tear apart Mr. Forbes's centerpiece proposal, for a 17 percent flat tax. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a former economics professor, was the first to question the proposal, saying Mr. Forbes was not committed to balancing the budget. Mr. Forbes interrupted the Senator, but Mr. Gramm insisted, "You've written it three or four times, Steve."
Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee, was even more forceful against Mr. Forbes, offering one one-liner after another about the flat tax, saying it was "a truly nutty idea" that would "cause a real estate crash" and was "going up there like the Great Pumpkin -- it's going to solve every problem that we have." Raising the subject again later, he said to Mr. Forbes, "The only thing you've ever run is a magazine you inherited and you raised the price of your magazine." The candidates broke up in laughter.
With all the talk about balancing the budget, even Mr. Dole made a crack that the Government could "borrow money from Steve Forbes."
The attacks on Mr. Forbes led Patrick J. Buchanan, the former conservative commentator, to say, "Since everyone's been piling on Steve Forbes here, I want to be fair and jump in on the piling on a little bit."
Mr. Forbes, clearly savoring the attention, said he was the subject of such sniping because his message was taking hold. "These lifetime politicians don't get it," he said, "and will never get it."
But while Mr. Dole enjoyed the unaccustomed position of escaping much of the attack, he was not completely overlooked by his rivals, who were in a quest to knock the Senator off stride and stand out with pithy remarks that they hoped would catch on with the voters here. Some candidates sharpened their attacks on Mr. Dole, saying he lacked the vision and leadership to defeat President Clinton.
At times the criticisms were personal, particularly from Mr. Dole's fellow Senator, Mr. Gramm, and from Mr. Alexander. But Mr. Dole was also portrayed by his rivals as a symbol of their more general attacks on Washington.
While his opponents said Mr. Dole's time had passed, the majority leader sought to turn his experience into a virtue and to behave as if he already were the nominee. Trying to stay clear of the intramural scrimmage, Mr. Dole devoted time to taking on Mr. Clinton on the negotiations on balancing the budget, and he emphasized his experience in Washington.
Turning to his opponents on the podium at the Iowa Public Television studio here, Mr. Dole, a Kansan who leads the field in Iowa by more than 30 percentage points, asserted: "There's one Senator here, one member of this family who has been making tough decisions every day for a long, long time. And I'm very proud of that."
But as the retorts grew more lively, Mr. Dole could not help but direct a few barbs at his opponents. At one point, he made fun of Mr. Gramm's failing three grades in school when he mentioned a student's question, saying, "She's passed every grade she's ever been in." Mr. Gramm often boasts about failing three grades as a child in school as evidence of the hard work it took for him to earn a doctorate in economics.
Mr. Alexander, who has campaigned in this state for at least two years but shown almost no movement in the polls, was most aggressive in suggesting that at age 72, Mr. Dole is too old to be President.
"We need to say, with respect, to Senator Dole that it may be your turn but it's not your revolution; it's not your time," Mr. Alexander said. "It's time we moved outside Washington. It's time we moved on."
With the arguing over the Federal budget dominating the news from Washington for weeks, the forum's moderator tried at the outset to pin down the candidates on what specific programs they considered sacred and would not touch in trying to balance the budget.
Some answered directly, like Senator Gramm, who cited Social Security and said he would look for waste in military spending. Others, like Mr. Buchanan, who gave himself honorary membership in the freshman class of the House, did not answer directly. Instead, Mr. Buchanan talked about what he would cut. He said he would begin phasing out foreign aid and would cancel the $50 billion bailout of Mexico. He also attacked the system of automatic and generous Congressional pensions, saying he would end this "looting of the American taxpayer." He said Representative Patricia Schroeder, the Colorado Democrat, was retiring with a pension worth a total of $4.2 million.
Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana said balancing the budget required raising revenue as well, and he said changes in the tax system were necessary.
Morry Taylor, a businessman from Michigan, said that he would take Medicare and Social Security off the table and that the Federal bureaucracy should be cut.
He also said that Congressional pensions were excessive and that as President, he would eliminate one-third of the Federal jobs that pay annual salaries between $50,000 and $143,000. "Look at where the real money is," he said. Among his rivals at the debate, he said, "I got a few million dollars in pensions here."
Mr. Dornan said the military and Social Security were off the table. Alan Keyes, a former State Department official who is a radio show host, said that nothing should escape examination and that he supported "the marriage-based, two-parent family."
Mr. Forbes said that Social Security for current recipients should be off the table but that a new system should be started for younger people.
Senator Dole said that except for Social Security, "everything else is on the table."
When the candidates were asked about race relations, Mr. Keyes, who is black, suggested that talk of racial separation was overblown.
"I'm tempted to say that the most important thing I could do to improve the climate of race relations in this country is to get elected President, and that's what I intend to do," he said with a smile.
In closing, most of the candidates sought to emphasize experience that connected them to viewers. Mr. Lugar talked about his 604-acre farm.
Mr. Dornan declared: "I have more progeny than all the rest put together. I have more military experience than anybody here."
Mr. Gramm suggested that Mr. Dole lacked firm principles, saying that on abortion he had been on "three sides of a two-sided issue."
Mr. Forbes took aim once again at Mr. Dole and the other Congressmen. "To change America, to get America moving again, we have to start clearly with the culture of Washington."
But Mr. Buchanan said his opponents were twisting the meaning of being a conservative by emphasizing free market economics. "What this campaign is going to decide is what conservatism means in America in the post-cold war era," he said.
Mr. Dole tried to present a neighborly, emphatic image. "I'm from Kansas, I'm a neighbor," he said. "In 1988, the Iowa people said Bob Dole is one of us, and I don't think anything's changed."
He stressed his humble beginnings, saying, "When my mother died, the net estate was worth $20,000." He added that he knew how it felt to have family members -- in his case, his grandparents -- receive public assistance. When they did so, he said, "I was the county attorney then and had to sign those checks."
In closing, he declared: "Bob Dole is not a polarizer. Bob Dole provides leadership, Bob Dole delivers. Bob Dole tries to get things done."

HEADLINE: Settle Now, Fight Later

 BODY:
President Clinton has proposed a constructive end to the budget impasse. He suggests splitting negotiations with Republican leaders in two.
In the first round, which could be completed quickly, the two parties would resolve their diminishing differences over spending and, perhaps, tax cuts that would balance the budget within seven years. In the second round, to be put off until voters decide in November whom they want to run Congress and the White House, the parties would decide how to restructure Federal entitlements like Medicare and Medicaid. 
 Mr. Clinton's proposal is admittedly self-serving. It would allow him to march into November as an effective leader who, despite an onslaught by extremist Republicans, kept Government offices open and forged a balanced budget agreement while preserving Medicaid and Medicare. But the proposal might also appeal to Republicans. They could say, with justification, that the G.O.P. forced Mr. Clinton to embrace their approach to a tax cut and balanced budget. They could also claim they wrenched from Mr. Clinton a pledge to knock about 30 percent off discretionary spending -- cutting the heart out of what he calls public investments in education, training and technological research but which the Republicans call Federal sloth.
Beyond political posturing, the budget two-step has a powerful rationale. The first-round issues are of modest dimensions. Whether Washington runs $200 billion deficits -- one of the smallest deficits, for the size of the economy, among industrialized countries -- does not affect the economy very much. Neither would a $200 billion tax cut over seven years. If those issues were resolved in the first round of negotiations, Democrats and Republicans could turn next fall to more fundamental issues.
Should Washington, as liberal Democrats insist, guarantee the poor, no matter where they live, cash assistance, food stamps and health insurance? Or, as the G.O.P. says, should states take care of the poor as they alone determine? Should Medicare -- which will drive the Federal deficit to dizzying levels in about 15 years -- be let alone, as Mr. Clinton proposes, or transformed, as the G.O.P. proposes, into a voucher system that gives the elderly the choice of traditional fee-for-service coverage or private managed care?
Mr. Clinton and the Republicans can complete the first round of negotiations quickly because they have drawn close on the raw numbers. The G.O.P.'s latest proposal would cut personal taxes by about $200 billion, almost half of what the Contract With America called for, and about $100 billion more than what the President proposes. Splitting the difference and spreading the cut over seven years would produce a budget that is less than $10 billion a year different from what either side now proposes -- a small difference compared with the $1 trillion the Government collects from taxpayers each year.
The spending gaps are also modest. The G.O.P. wants to cut Medicare by about $170 billion over seven years. The President says $100 billion. The Republicans want to cut Medicaid by $85 billion. The President says $50 billion. There is, as this page has argued, good reason to question whether either budget is wise. But there is little basis to claim that one budget is radically different from the other.
The political hot wires that the parties use to inflame voters -- balanced budgets and tax cuts -- are economic sideshows. The best way to get voters and politicians talking about policies that do matter is to put the sideshows to rest. Mr. Clinton and the Republican leadership can do voters a favor by putting their common spending and tax plans into law. Then get on with the debate about the type of Federal Government Americans want to have as they head into the 21st century.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:
The partial shutdown of the Government that ended last week delayed many reports on economic statistics. Those listed below are based on an amended schedule issued by the Commerce Department.
 
Monday
Because of the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the credit markets will be largely shut, and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange will end trading on most contracts at noon. All other exchanges plan normal hours.
Tuesday The Commerce Department reports on housing starts in November. In October, starts were down 3.7 percent.
 
Wednesday
The Commerce Department reports on the trade deficit in October. In September, the deficit was $8.4 billion, unchanged from August.
 
The Labor Department resumes weekly reports of first-time unemployment claims.
 
The Federal Reserve reports on industrial production and capacity utilization in December. In November, output rose two-tenths of 1 percent; utilization was at 83.1 percent.
 
The Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Federal agency, opens a conference in New York for business executives on financing international investments and mitigating risks.
 
Thursday
I.B.M., Microsoft, Sybase and Borland are expected to report earnings. Given the volatility in the technology sector, the results will be watched even more closely than usual.
 
Friday
The Commerce Department reports the second revision of gross domestic product growth for the third quarter of 1995. The first revision was to an annual rate of 4.2 percent, after an initial report of 3.4 percent.
 
The Commerce Department reports on sales of new homes. In October, sales fell 2.7 percent.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;
ELECTION WATCH: Council Contest on Tuesday

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Upper East Side voters will choose a new Council member in a special election Tuesday to fill the vacancy created when Charles Millard resigned to become president of the city's Economic Development Corp.
Although the law bars regular party designations, the race to fill the District 5 seat pits a Republican -- Judith G. Marcus, a top aide to Mr. Millard -- against a Democrat -- A. Gifford Miller, a top aide to United States Representative Carolyn B. Maloney. Their contest echoes a rivalry from last year when Mr. Millard lost his challenge to Ms. Maloney's Congressional re-election bid. 
 At stake are Republican hopes to retain the seat -- the G.O.P. holds just six others in the 51-member Council -- and Democratic hopes to reclaim it. The majority of the district's voters are Democrats, but Upper East Sider voters have traditionally shown an independent streak, often crossing party lines. And low turnout makes special elections hard to predict.
Democratic concerns of a party split were allayed when three challengers were removed from the ballot. Andrew Schiff quit and endorsed Mr. Miller. Two other Democrats, George Spitz and Samuel Morell, did not file enough signatures and lost a court challenge to get on the ballot.
The candidates will appear tomorrow in their second debate on New York 1.
Polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. Voters with questions can call the Board of Elections at (212) VOTE-NYC, or 868-3692. For hearing- impaired voters, the TTY number is (212) 487-5496. Absentee ballots must be postmarked by midnight tomorrow and received by the board in 10 days.
The winner will take office as soon as the results are certified. BRUCE LAMBERT
 
 JUDITH G. MARCUS, 51, Community First Party
Neighborhood ties Upper East Side resident for 25 years.
Political pedigree Republican-turned-Democrat-turned-Republican. First race. 14 years as constituent services director for District 5's last two Councilmen: Mr Millard and Robert Dryfoos, a Democrat.
Endorsements Mayor Giuliani, State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Mr. Millard, and other local G.O.P. legislators; Liberal Party leader Raymond B. Harding; some Democrats; Expects Mayor Giuliani's nod.
Platform District needs her experience in solving local problems.
Strengths Running in a district where Republicans are wealthy and politically active, and where female voters have a 3-to-2 edge. Paid campaign consultant, Joseph Mercurio. Contacts from years of helping local residents and community groups.
Weaknesses A Republican running on Democratic turf; possible Gingrich-Pataki backlash.
 
 A. GIFFORD MILLER, 26, East Side Neighbors Party
Political pedigree First race. Served as legislative aide to Ms. Maloney; now her district office chief.
Neighborhood ties Lifelong resident except during 18-month Washington stint.
Endorsements Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Representative Maloney, Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger.
Platform District needs a Democrat to fight conservative state and national social service policies.
Strengths Support (money and volunteers) from many Democratic clubs and party leaders. Potential for anti-G.O.P. backlash.
Weaknesses Relative newcomer.

HEADLINE: West Didn't Fail Russian Market Reform

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Michael M. Weinstein (Editorial Notebook, Jan. 10) says the West "squandered" an opportunity by denying $25 billion a year in aid to underwrite President Boris N. Yeltsin's "radical plan for moving to a market economy" in Russia. The program announced by acting Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar in 1992 contained no such opportunity. 
 The "shock therapy" target to slash the Russian budget deficit from 17 percent to 21 percent of gross domestic product in 1991 to zero in the first quarter of 1992 was a pipe dream rather than a realistic agenda. The huge reduction of subsidies to consumers and industry and of state-financed investments were Soviet-style fiats.
There was no strategy for dealing with the Supreme Soviet, which was divided into equal factions comprising, respectively, Communists, reformers and an unsteady group of legislators who could float in either direction. The shock therapists ruled out consensus-building.
The assertion that an immediate commitment of $25 billion from the West would have tilted the political scales in favor of the reformers overlooks that aid absorption by Russia could not have matched aid approvals.
For instance, the World Bank approved almost $3 billion in loans for Russia, but by June 1994 only $587 million had been used. And although the United State Congress appropriated $2 billion from 1992 to 1994, by December 1994 less than $500 million had been spent.
The West did not fail Russia. Mr. Gaidar's plan foundered because it was improbable.
 
PADMA DESAI
New York, Jan. 10, 1996
 
The writer is professor of comparative economics, Columbia U.

HEADLINE: JANUARY 7-13;
In Mr. Johnson's Neighborhood

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
Ask budding minority athletes what they intend to do if they strike it rich and the answer will be: do something for their "people." It is a promise few accomplish.
Magic Johnson is the exception. Six months ago the former basketball star opened a 12-screen movie complex in the economically depressed South-Central region of Los Angeles, which was especially hard hit by the 1992 riots following the acquittal of white policemen charged with beating Rodney G. King. 
 So far the theater has consistently ranked among the top five in gross revenues of 21,800 theaters surveyed nationwide, and was ranked second during the Christmas holiday weekend. In addition to providing employment for 75 people, mostly from the area, and entertainment, it has energized the immediate shopping area.
"Instead of just talking," Magic said, "I wanted to put my money where my mouth is." KENNETH B. NOBLE

HEADLINE: Utah Debates Firing Squads In Clash of Past and Present

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 12

 BODY:
When word got out that Utah was preparing to execute a child murderer by firing squad, Jack Ford's telephone started to ring off the hook.
"For two days, all I did was answer the phone," said Mr. Ford, the spokesman for the state corrections department. "Finally, I had a form letter printed up: We are not taking volunteers." 
 The unwanted flood of volunteer sharpshooters came with the first scheduled firing-squad execution in the United States in almost two decades. If Utah politicians have their way, the execution by firing squad scheduled for Jan. 26 may also be the nation's last.
In January 1977 it was a Utah firing squad that broke a 10-year hiatus in American executions by taking the life of Gary Gilmore, who became celebrated because he insisted on being executed for the killing of a motel clerk.
Now, a firing squad composed of state law-enforcement officers is set to take the life of John Albert Taylor, 36, who was convicted of sexually assaulting and strangling Charla Nicola King, 11, in 1989. Like Mr. Gilmore, Mr. Taylor chose a firing squad over lethal injection, Utah's other execution method.
The return of the firing squad, unique to Utah in modern times, offers a benchmark to measure the evolution in America's application of the death penalty.
Relatively rare through the early 1980's, executions nationwide jumped to 56 last year, nearly double the 31 recorded in 1994. Now running at levels of the 1950's, executions are largely restricted to the South and to the West. Utah has executed three people since 1977, all by lethal injection. There have been no executions in New York, New Jersey or New England since the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976.
"Our prediction is that we are going to climb to 100 executions this year," Steven W. Hawkins, executive director of the National Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty, said from Washington.
With executions already taking place at a rate of one a week, the news media and the public now only focus on executions with a twist, death-penalty opponents say.
"This is the month for the strange and the bizarre," Mr. Hawkins said, referring to executions scheduled for January. "There is the firing squad in Utah, a hanging in Delaware, and in Illinois, there is Guinevere Garcia, only the second woman to be executed" since 1976.
Fresh from an interview with a visiting network television crew, Carol L. Gnade agreed wholeheartedly. "The only reason that this execution is gaining attention across the country is the method," said Ms. Gnade, executive director of the Utah affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union. "The firing squad is no more barbaric than lethal injection or electrocution."
With a record 3,046 condemned men and women awaiting executions in 38 states, the public's increasingly hard line on crime pressures politicians to speed up executions. In Utah, polls indicate that 75 percent of voters support the death penalty.
"A lot of politicians have made their platforms to be tough on crime, to support the death penalty," said Richard C. Dieter, executive director of the Death Penalty Information Center, a Washington group opposed to the death penalty. "Clemency is becoming a thing of the past in death-penalty cases."
While state governors commuted 10 death sentences in 1991, that number fell to one in 1994 and to zero in 1995.
In a sign of the times, Congress voted this fall to cut out all Federal financing for a program designed to provide free legal aid for appeals by men and women sentenced to death. Known as Death Penalty Resource Centers, this nationwide network of offices had a budget of $19.6 million last year.
Although President Clinton has not signed the bill because of the budget impasse, he is expected to, and most of the centers are winding up operations. In Texas, where 92 men have been executed since 1977, the number of lawyers for the Death Penalty Center has dropped to 1 from 18 a year ago.
Next week, carpenters at the Uintah Prison Complex in Draper are to start customizing a firing squad execution chair for the 1990's.
"Blood-borne pathogens are a big issue now," Mr. Ford said when asked about changes since Mr. Gilmore was executed, in the pre-AIDS era. "There will be a pan underneath the chair to catch the blood."
To some in Utah, the grisly 19th century nature of a firing squad clashes with this state's modern image. With a booming economy revolving around computer software and ski tourism, Utah is to be the host of the 2002 Winter Olympics.
Utah's 19th century history helps explain why it is now the only state in the union to allow condemned prisoners to choose to die by the firing squad.
In an early radical phase, Utah's Mormon settlers believed that the sin of murder could only be atoned by shedding the murderer's blood.
"There are sins that the blood of a lamb, of a calf, or turtle doves cannot remit," Brigham Young, a Mormon prophet, told his pioneering flock here in 1856. "But they must be atoned by the blood of man."
For more than 30 years, this belief in blood atonement, and the practice of polygamy, blocked accommodation between Utah's Mormon "Kingdom" and Washington. In 1890, the church formally disavowed polygamy and blood atonement. In 1896, Utah joined the Union as a state.
But repeated pronouncements by the Mormons, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, have been unable to stamp out polygamy or a belief in blood atonement.
"Most Mormons in Utah would use blood atonement as their rationale for supporting capital punishment in general, and the firing squad in particular," said L. Kay Gillespie, a professor of criminal justice at Weber State University in Ogden. He said 39 of the state's executions since 1847 had been by firing squad.
Mr. Taylor, who is to be baptized a Roman Catholic next week, seems to have chosen the firing squad largely to embarrass the state.
"He said he didn't want to lay on the table and flip around like a fish out of water," Beverly DeVoy recalled of comments the condemned man made to her last month about lethal injection. Ms. DeVoy, the only reporter that Mr. Taylor talks to, added, "But I also think he wanted to cause more trouble for the state."
Mr. Taylor seems to have achieved his goal of embarrassing state officials. The state's largely Mormon political leaders seem determined to abolish the firing squad as an anachronistic holdover.
Next week, Sheryl L. Allen, a Republican State Representative, plans to submit a bill that would do away with firing squads. If passed by the State Legislature before the session ends late next month, two other Utah convicts who have chosen the firing squad would die by lethal injection.
"The law ought to updated," Representative Allen said. "It is my intention that no more inmates will have the choice between lethal injection and firing squad."
The State Legislature, which is dominated by Mormons, is expected to pass the measure easily.
Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, a Mormon and a Republican, said, "If it passes, it will have my signature."
 The article also misstated the circumstances of Gary Gilmore's execution in Utah in 1977. He chose death by firing squad over death by hanging, which was then the state's other method of execution.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 15, 1996, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the scheduled firing-squad execution of an inmate in Utah misstated, in some editions, the record of executions in Texas. The state has executed 92 criminals since the return of the death penalty in 1976, not in 1995 alone.
