HEADLINE: In Small-Town Texas, the Sewing Stops

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: GRANGER, Tex.

 BODY:
Pale green and beige sewing machines line the floor, seven neat rows of ghosts at the Ca-Ce-Len Manufacturing Company, a two-room garment factory in this small farm town in central Texas. The factory, set inside a whitewashed brick building on Granger's main street, closed last month, depriving 50 longtime workers of jobs that paid $5 to $8 an hour and marking one more small shift in how and where Americans' clothes are made.
"Now I know how the fellow who made buggy whips must have felt," said the company's owner, Douglas Benad, gesturing at the sewing machines, which used to stitch clothing as diverse as bathing suits and blazers but are now for sale and likely to wind up in factories in Mexico or Central America. "This place is kind of a dinosaur." 
 Little more than a decade ago, more than 500 rural towns in Texas, and hundreds of others in the South and Middle West, had contract garment factories like Ca-Ce-Len, which took its name from three local women (Carolyn, Cecilia and Lendy).
Such factories put together clothes for big American retailers and typically received a set amount for each piece -- as little as 46 cents for running shorts that might have sold in the stores for a few dollars, Mr. Benad's wife, Mary, said, and as much as $20 for blazers that retailed for $300.
But today in Texas, barely two dozen of the small-town factories hang on, the others squeezed out of the market by a range of things -- foreign competition, the removal of tariffs on apparel made overseas, a surge in illegal sweatshops and home-sewing operations in this country.
The economics behind the changes are not complex. "If you own a business and you could get a product made for a bowl of rice a day, or you could pay someone $6 an hour, what would you choose?" Mr. Benad said.
Indeed, the enigma is that a few places like Ca-Ce-Len managed to hold on at all into the 1990's, and the same is true for many of the towns themselves. Granger seems a place out of time, a hamlet off farm roads 45 miles northeast of Austin where many people still speak Czech, the language of many of the town's settlers. Granger, population 1,250, is home to the last Czech-language weekly paper in Texas.
But the number of garment industry survivors is clearly dwindling, said Joe Allen, a retired manufacturer in the Dallas area who used to do business with Ca-Ce-Len and dozens of other Texas factories. He is now a volunteer organizer of a union-backed program to get the Federal Government to enforce laws on wages and working conditions in the illegal factories and home-sewing operations in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
The Labor Department has conducted a handful of highly publicized raids on illegal garment factories, most notably a factory in Los Angeles where severely underpaid Thai immigrants were found last year to be turning out clothing stamped "Made in the U.S.A." under conditions reminiscent of slavery.
But Mr. Allen and other garment manufacturers said the problem was so widespread and the Labor Department so short of inspectors that most legitimate American apparel manufacturers, paying the minimum wage or more and subject to taxes and safety standards, were simply unable to compete.
Home-sewing operations, largely among immigrants in the Dallas area, amount to "a sweatshop in a living room," Mr. Allen said -- they are piecework businesses paying rates that cannot possibly result in minimum wage, and many of the workers are in the country illegally.
"A lot of us hung on too long thinking that the wage-an-hour people in the Department of Labor would come in and enforce the law," Mr. Allen said. "But instead there's been a little lip service and they've basically ignored it."
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich has said that enforcement of the laws is a major priority of the Labor Department. Last month Mr. Reich released the department's "Trendsetter List" of about three dozen national retailers and manufacturers that had made "meaningful efforts to eradicate sweatshops in the U.S." by dealing only with legitimate factories here and abroad.
But for many of the longtime workers at the Granger factory, most of them women, and for Mr. and Mrs. Benad, all such efforts come too late. And many concede that the factory may have been doomed anyway by changes in the global economy -- changes that are not at all welcome here.
"With Nafta, I thought the idea was that they would get some of the work, and we would get some of the work, and everybody would be able to buy everybody else's stuff," said Gladys W. Jones, a 59-year-old supervisor at Ca-Ce-Len who worked 18 years at the factory until its closing in December. "It sure hasn't happened that way, as far as I can tell."
She was referring to the North American Free Trade Agreement, which removed many tariff and trade barriers to Mexican products and which many here directly blame for the collapse of the region's garment manufacturing industry. Others say the problem can be traced to Dallas and Houston, where labor inspectors have found several illegal apparel operations in which Southeast Asian immigrants are paid less than the minimum wage.
In any event, not one of the 50 workers from Ca-Ce-Len has found a permanent job, Mr. Benad said. Ms. Jones said she had been seeking work at nursing homes, hoping to find a job caring for older people. "I can't think of too much of anything else I could do, really," she said.
Others seem daunted by the prospect of gaining a new set of skills but intend to try anyway. "I'm looking for some way to learn about word processing, Lotus, computers, something like that," said Linda McFarlin, a 41-year-old mother of two young girls who worked for 16 years at Ca-Ce-Len. "That's the wave of the future, I guess."
Mrs. McFarlin, whose husband, Tommy, is a maintenance worker in the local cemetery, said she had gone to the State Labor Department to see if she could qualify for some training money on the theory that her job had been eliminated because of Nafta. But officials there said that contention would be difficult to prove. She is now collecting $131 a week in unemployment, less than half her wage at the sewing factory.
A deep sense of bitterness lingers in Granger, though no one knows exactly whom to blame. And Patrick J. Buchanan, the one Presidential candidate who is focusing on the issue of reviving tariffs and eliminating the free-trade agreements that people here blame for their plight, does not seem to have any foothold.
"He's just too far out," Mr. Benad said of Mr. Buchanan. "I'm not any big fan of Ross Perot, but he sure was right about one thing -- that giant sucking sound. You hear it around here."
Mr. Benad, whose factory did work for big American retailers like J. C. Penney and Sears, said he could remember a time when most of the towns in the area, including nearby Taylor and Bartlett, had some kind of small clothing factory. Those factories were often vital parts of the local economy; most of their employees were women, and even part-time wages could provide an important piece of the family income.
"That was our middle class," he said. "The big thing now is high tech, but there's not a lot of it in a town like this. You see people working with high-tech scanners at the grocery store. That's about the only high tech you see around here."

HEADLINE: Betting on Rails in the Realm of Cars

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Robert Dziubla and his co-workers at his Los Angeles law firm may represent the best hope for the success of this county's $75 billion transportation program -- and the reason it could fail.
Although supporters of the huge transit project, one of the most expensive in history, say it will reduce stifling freeway congestion and clean the fouled air, skeptics argue that not enough commuters will abandon their beloved cars for the planned rail lines to justify the investment. 
 Mr. Dziubla, a lawyer who lives in Long Beach, said he is glad to make the 45-minute trip on the new Blue Line train a couple of times a week so he can read rather than joust with the jumpy road gladiators here.
But then, he said, he came from Chicago, where public transit is a way of life. All of the other lawyers at his firm drive to work. And the only employees who use trains or buses are some of the clerical staff.
"When I think about it," he said, "it's probably a class thing."
No major urban area in the country has been more influenced by or is more identified with the automobile than Los Angeles, and so the passionate debate over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's $75 billion, 20-year plan to break the dominance of the freeways has often been carried on with religious intensity rather than with a cool analysis of the transportation needs of the most populous county in the nation. It is not just a question of getting around, but of self-image, of one's place in the natural pecking order.
Ultimately, the transit fight is not just over the wisdom of tunneling through fault zones, tearing up neighborhoods or spending unprecedented sums -- nearly $500 million a mile for one section of the Red Line subway in downtown -- but about whether a government agency can modify the behavior of a region, and who that agency should be serving.
"It's simple," said Martin Wachs, director of the Institute of Transportation Studies at the University of California at Los Angeles. "The plan makes no sense in a region as widely dispersed as Los Angeles. It is an extremely expensive system that will move a tiny fraction of the people at extremely high cost."
Intensifying the battle is the fact that bus service, which some transit experts argue would be a more cost-efficient solution, has been declining here for a decade as it has deteriorated; total boardings have plummeted to 343 million in the fiscal year that ended last June 30, from 497 million in 1985. The M.T.A. has been sued by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Education Fund for spending vast sums on trains while allowing the bus system, used predominantly by blacks and Hispanics, to decay and become overcrowded.
On a recent afternoon, Martin Berrera, 26, a machine operator, stood on the packed No. 30 bus, straining to spy his stop through the graffiti-scarred windows, and told of how his half-hour commute that morning had taken about one-and-a-half hours after several jammed buses passed by before one stopped to pick him up.
Few doubt that people will ride the trains, but opponents argue that most of those people will be bus passengers like Mr. Berrera, not people like Mr. Dziubla who would be giving up their cars. Also, though transit officials deny it, the N.A.A.C.P. group and other critics have called the plan racist, saying the M.T.A. would be paying big subsidies to lure mostly white commuters from their autos rather than improving service for the mostly minority passengers on buses. As it is, many bus riders complain that the current fare, $1.35, is too high given the quality of service.
State Senator Tom Hayden, a onetime supporter of rail construction, now says the plan is little more than old-fashioned pork barrel. "I started out as a knee-jerk sympathizer with the concept of mass transit because it seemed like the way to clean up the air," Mr. Hayden said. "But it's become a fiscal tapeworm."
Los Angeles is not alone. Miami, Atlanta and Dallas, other sprawling urban areas, have also built expensive rail lines that have had only modest success. But none have approached the cost of Los Angeles's.
Some parts of the rail system, which when complete will include urban subways and suburban light rail, have already been constructed. The M.T.A. says that by the end of the current plan in 2015, the rail system would shuttle 440,000 people a day, only about a quarter of those riding public transit. At that time, public transit is expected to account for 9.2 percent of the total number of trips people here take every day, compared with 7.3 percent now.
Thomas E. Rubin, the authority's former controller and treasurer, said the price was too high for so little effect. "Every one of the rail lines can be described as the most expensive of its kind ever built in this country," he said.
The response of the transit authority is, although its plan may be costly, the alternatives are worse: paralysis and choking air pollution.
Joseph E. Drew, the authority's acting chief executive, said that without a rail system, in 20 years transportation tie-ups would cost the county $8 billion a year in lost economic activity.
"I think we're going to start seeing the payback from this system by the year 2000," Mr. Drew said. "By the year 2015 the payoff will be dramatic."
The counter-argument is that the economic losses and slowdowns would occur only if most workers here were fighting to commute to a central urban core, as in the New York City region.
Peter Gordon, a professor of urban and regional planning at the University of Southern California, said that in the Los Angeles area there are numerous cores, and these have been attracting a smaller and smaller percentage of the region's jobs, from 19 percent of all jobs in the area in 1970 to 12 percent in 1990.
"Most commuting now is suburb to suburb," Mr. Gordon said. "It's not from the suburbs to downtown."
The rail line, however, would bring commuters to and from a small number of cores including the current downtown.
Making the M.T.A.'s position even more tenuous has been a series of reversals over the past year. Some experts say at least some parts of the rail plan, like the Red Line subway, should be halted, which could have national implications. The Federal Government is paying half the construction costs, so dropping the rail lines could free up Federal money for other cities.
Among the problems the transit authority has had to contend with are a 70-foot sinkhole that swallowed up part of Hollywood Boulevard, lawsuits by landowners and shopkeepers angry about damage they say the construction caused, the guilty plea to bribery charges by an M.T.A. executive and numerous construction problems that led to the dismissal of the principal contractor, Shea-Kiewit-Kenney.
But the Clinton Administration has not wavered in its support. And, as many here point out, the construction has provided 10,000 jobs, so it is unlikely anyone in Washington is going to want to halt things in an election year.
"This is clearly being debated, but from a Federal perspective we think it works," said Mortimer Downey, the deputy secretary of transportation. "Aside from whether it has been executed well, the judgment here is that it's a cost effective system for the basin."
But the community has been left so deeply divided that even the M.T.A.'s board members have been able to do little more than fight bitterly among themselves. The plan includes some money for buses, car-pool and express lanes on the freeways and peak-demand charges for the use of the express lanes, but some board members favor less money for rail construction and more for those less-expensive alternatives.
Michael D. Antonovich, a county supervisor and the outgoing chairman of the M.T.A., ended his term last year by writing to Speaker Newt Gingrich and saying, "It is time for Congress to pull the plug on the Red Line subway construction in Los Angeles."
After being dismissed as chief executive last month because of the mounting problems, Franklin E. White, who served as New York State Transportation Commissioner under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, delivered a bitter parting speech in which he characterized the rail construction program as a crooked "money train" being run for the benefit of local politicians and businessmen.
The current chairman, Larry Zarian, who is also a city councilman in Glendale, agreed. "Whenever you have an abundance of money, you're going to have people who want it for their own use," Mr. Zarian said in an interview. "Some on the M.T.A. board are self-serving."
The M.T.A. has already scaled back its plans sharply; last year it abandoned a 30-year, $183 billion proposal that envisioned 296 miles of rail in favor of the 20-year plan with 95 miles of rail. Both plans included some upgrade of bus service.
But Zev Yaroslavsky, another board member, argued that the program is still too grandiose. "Frank White was a voice of relative financial reason," he said. "That's what got him into trouble."
The real problem, however, may not be the extent or quality of public transit, but Southern California's love affair with automobiles.
"Sometimes it's nice to ride the Metro," said Roberta West, a college student taking the Blue Line to her part-time job at a bank branch in Watts. "I can do my reading while I ride. But if I can get a car, I'd use it. I like the independence."
